Denote $\frac{\partial h}{\partial z_{\alpha}}, \frac{\partial h}{\partial \bar{z}_{\alpha}}, \frac{\partial^{2} h}{\partial \bar{z}_{\beta} \partial \bar{z}_{\alpha}}$ by $h_{\alpha}, h_{\bar{\alpha}}, h_{\alpha \bar{\beta}}$. A direct computation shows

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{1}= & h d w \wedge d \bar{w}+h^{-1} h_{\alpha} h_{\bar{\beta}} w \bar{w} d z_{\alpha} \wedge d \bar{z}_{\beta} \\
& +h_{\bar{\alpha}} \bar{w} d w \wedge d \bar{z}_{\alpha}+h_{\alpha} w d z_{\alpha} \wedge d \bar{w}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{2}= & 4 a^{2}(h w \bar{w})^{-2 a}\left\{(w \bar{w})^{-1} d w \wedge d \bar{w}+h^{-2} h_{\beta} h_{\bar{\alpha}} d z_{\beta} \wedge d \bar{z}_{\alpha}\right. \\
& \left.+h^{-1} h_{\bar{\alpha}} w^{-1} d w \wedge d \bar{z}_{\alpha}+h^{-1} h_{\alpha} \bar{w}^{-1} d z_{\alpha} \wedge d \bar{w}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Given a point $p_{0} \in \Sigma$, we can find coordinates $(z, w)$ (still distinguished in the sense of Proposition 2.1) with $(z, w)\left(p_{0}\right)=\left(z_{0}, w_{0}\right)$ such that

$$
h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=1 \text { and } d h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=0
$$

(cf. $[79$, p.80]).
Remark 3.2. In fact we only need to change $w$ to $j(z) w$ while the coordinate $z$ is fixed to achieve (3.13). So $h$ depends only on the choice of $w$-coordinate, denoted as $h^{w}$ below. If we make a change of $w: \bar{w}=c w$ for a constant $c \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ (with $z$-coordinate fixed), we then have $h^{\bar{w}}(z, \bar{z})=h^{w}(z, \bar{z})|c|^{-2}$.

Thus, at $p_{0}$ we simplify:

$$
G_{a}=\left(g_{M}\right)_{\alpha \beta}\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right) d z_{\alpha} d \bar{z}_{\beta}+\left(\varphi_{1}\left(w_{0} \bar{w}_{0}\right)+\varphi_{2}\left(w_{0} \bar{w}_{0}\right) 4 a^{2}\left(w_{0} \bar{w}_{0}\right)^{-2 a-1}\right) d w d \bar{w}
$$

where $d z_{\alpha} d \bar{z}_{\beta}$ and $d w d \bar{w}$ denote the symmetric product of 1-forms (this way of expression for a Hermitian metric follows the notation of [54, p.155 (4)]) and $\varphi_{2}:=$ $1-\varphi_{1}$.

So the metric $G_{a}$ of (3.14) has the property that "base" $z$-slice and "fibre" $w$ slice yield an orthogonal splitting at $p_{0}$ (here $z$-slice is noncanonical and depends on the choice of coordinates). Furthermore, the $w$-slice (which is always part of a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbit, cf. (2.16)) is totally geodesic (cf. Proposition 3.6 below).

Step 3. The normalized metric $G_{a, m}$ and its volume form $d v_{\Sigma, m}$ for $m \geq 0$.

Assume $m \geq 0$. Following Step 2, we have the intrinsic expression of the volume form $d v_{G_{a}}$ or $d v_{\Sigma}$ as follows:

$$
d v_{\Sigma}=\pi^{*} d v_{M} \wedge d v_{f}
$$

where $\pi^{*} d v_{M}(=d v(z)$ in coordinates $(z, w))\left(d v_{M}\right.$ denotes the volume form of $\left.M\right)$ is the volume form of $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ and the 2 -form $d v_{f}=d v_{f i b r e}$ on $\Sigma$ is basically the area form on the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbit extended to $\Sigma$ by using the embedding of (vertical, fibrewise) forms via the orthogonal splitting given by the metric (3.14).

Denote by $\mathbb{C}^{*} \circ p_{0}$ the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbit $\left\{\lambda \circ p_{0}: \lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}\right\}$ passing through $p_{0}$. Define $\tau_{p_{0}}: \mathbb{C}^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{*} \circ p_{0} \subset \Sigma$ by $\tau_{p_{0}}(\lambda)=\lambda \circ p_{0}$. Define for $l$ of (3.3)

$$
\lambda_{m}\left(p_{0}\right):=\int_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(\tau_{p_{0}}^{*} l\right)^{m}\left(\tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d v_{f}\right)
$$

This is an integral of the function $l^{m}$ along the orbit $\mathbb{C}^{*} \circ p_{0}$ (possibly with "multiplicities") and is easily seen to be independent of the choice of the point $p_{0}$ in the same orbit.

Let $p_{0} \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$, i.e. $p_{0}$ lies in the principal stratum. Choosing the coordinates $(z, w)$ such that $h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=1$ and $d h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=0$ at $p_{0}$ (3.13), we have (cf. (2.16) for $\delta=\pi$ in $C_{\delta}$ since $p_{0} \notin \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ )

$$
\tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d v_{f}(w)=d v(|w|) \wedge d v(\phi), w=|w| e^{i \phi} \in \mathbb{C}^{*}
$$

where $d v(\phi)\left(\right.$ or $\left.d v_{S^{1}}(\phi)\right):=d \phi$ and (cf. (3.14))

$$
d v(|w|)\left(\text { or } d v_{\mathbb{R}^{+}}(|w|)\right):=\left[\varphi_{1}\left(|w|^{2}\right)+\varphi_{2}\left(|w|^{2}\right) 4 a^{2}|w|^{-4 a-2}\right]|w| d|w|
$$

To compute $\lambda_{m}\left(p_{0}\right)$ of (3.16), by (3.17) and (3.4) that $l(q)=h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right) w \bar{w}=|w|^{2}$ we have (recalling $C_{\delta}=\mathbb{C}^{*}$ here)

$$
\lambda_{m}\left(p_{0}\right)=\int_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}|w|^{2 m} d v(|w|) \wedge d v(\phi)=2 \pi \int_{\mathbb{R}^{+}}|w|^{2 m} d v(|w|)
$$

It follows from (3.18) and (3.19) that the numbers $\lambda_{m}\left(p_{0}\right)$ are the same for all $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbits (by the obvious continuity of (3.16) when $p_{0}$ is across $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ ).
Notation 3.3. Let $\lambda_{m}$ denote the common number $\lambda_{m}\left(p_{0}\right)$ in (3.19). Let $d v_{m}(|w|)$ $:=2 \pi d v(|w|) / \lambda_{m}$ denote the normalized volume on $\mathbb{R}^{+}$, so that

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{+}}|w|^{2 m} d v_{m}(|w|)=1
$$

The normalized metric $G_{a, m}$ is given as

$$
G_{a, m}:=\pi^{*} g_{M}+\left(\varphi_{1} \circ l\right) \frac{g_{1}^{\#}}{\lambda_{m}}+\left(1-\varphi_{1} \circ l\right) \frac{g_{2}^{\#}}{\lambda_{m}}
$$

on $\Sigma$, where $g_{1}^{\#}, g_{2}^{\#}$ are as in Step 2 (cf. (3.9)). The associated volume form $d v_{\Sigma, m}$ has the following intrinsic expression (cf. (3.15))

$$
d v_{\Sigma, m}=\pi^{*} d v_{M} \wedge d v_{f, m}
$$

where $\pi^{*} d v_{M}(=d v(z)$ in coordinates $(z, w))$ is the volume form of $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ (recall that $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow M=\Sigma / \sigma$ is the natural projection) and

$$
d v_{f, m}=d v_{f} / \lambda_{m}, \tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d v_{f, m}(w)=d v_{m}(|w|) \wedge \frac{d v(\phi)}{2 \pi}
$$

Writing

$$
d v_{f, m}=l(q)^{-m} d \tilde{v}_{m}(q)
$$

one sees, with $l=h w \bar{w}$,

$$
\tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d \tilde{v}_{m}=(h w \bar{w})^{m}\left(\tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)=|w|^{2 m} d v_{m}(|w|) \wedge \frac{d v(\phi)}{2 \pi}
$$

In summary (for $h\left(p_{0}\right)=1$ and $d h\left(p_{0}\right)=0$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d \tilde{v}_{m}\right)(|w|) & = & |w|^{2 m} d v_{m}(|w|) \\
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{+}}\left(\tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d \tilde{v}_{m}\right)(|w|) & = & 1
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $l(q)$ is independent of the choice of $(z, w)$ coordinates ((3.3), (3.4)), intrinsically we have (cf. (3.25))

$$
\int_{\mathbb{C}^{*}} \tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d \tilde{v}_{m}=\frac{1}{\lambda_{m}} \int_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(\tau_{p_{0}}^{*} l\right)^{m} \tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d v_{f}=\int_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(\tau_{p_{0}}^{*} l\right)^{m} \tau_{p_{0}}^{*} d v_{f, m}=1
$$

We will often omit the pullback notation $\tau_{p_{0}}^{*}$ in later computations.
Remark that the 2 -form $d \tilde{v}_{m}$ above is used in the index formula (1.6) of Theorem 1.1 stated in the Introduction.

Remark 3.4. For $f \in C^{\infty}(\Sigma)$ with $f=O\left(|w|^{m}\right)$ in local coordinates $(z, w)$, it follows from (3.18) that $\int_{\Sigma}|f(x)|^{2} d v_{\Sigma, m}(x)<\infty$ for $a$ large, say, $a>\frac{m}{2} \geq 0$.

Lemma 3.5. For $a>\frac{m}{2} \geq 0$ the normalized metric $G_{a, m}$ (3.21) is uniformly equivalent to $G_{a}$ (3.9) in the sense that there exists a constant $C_{m}>0$ such that $C_{m}^{-1} G_{a, m} \leq G_{a} \leq C_{m} G_{a, m}$. As a consequence we have $L^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)=L^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a}\right)$.

Proof. At a point $p_{0}$ we can simultaneously "diagonalize" $G_{a}$ and $G_{a, m}$ in view of (3.14). Then $\left(C_{m}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} G_{a, m} \leq G_{a} \leq C_{m}^{\prime \prime} G_{a, m}$ where $C_{m}^{\prime}:=\max \left\{1, \lambda_{m}^{-1}\right\}$ and $C_{m}^{\prime \prime}:=$ $\max \left\{1, \lambda_{m}\right\}$. So $C_{m}:=C_{m}^{\prime} C_{m}^{\prime \prime}$ is a constant required in the lemma.

The following fact seems to be of independent interest although it is not strictly needed for our purpose. It serves as a piece of evidence for the fact that some geometric constructions (to be made later) on $\Sigma$ and on $M=\Sigma / \sigma$ respectively are mutually "compatible" in an appropriate context (cf. Proposition 3.12 and Corollary 3.19). It is mainly this compatibility that allows us to carry out our transversal heat kernel method for the proof of the asserted results in this paper.

Proposition 3.6. Let $p_{0} \in \Sigma$. Each $w$-slice in $\Sigma$, described by $\lambda \circ p_{0}=\sigma(\lambda) p_{0}, \lambda$ $\in C_{\bar{x}_{j}}$ in a local patch $D_{j}$, is totally geodesic with respect to $G_{a}$ or $G_{a, m}$. In other words, the Christoffel symbols have the following vanishing property:

$$
\Gamma_{A B}^{C}=0 \text { for } A, B \text { tangent and } C \text { normal to } w \text {-slices. }
$$

Proof. Let $g_{A B}$ denote the component of $G_{a}$ (resp. $G_{a, m}$ ) with respect to the directions $A, B$. In local holomorphic coordinates $z=\left(z_{1}, . ., z_{n-1}\right)$ and $w, A, B$ can be $\partial / \partial w$, or $\partial / \partial \bar{w}$ and $C$ can be $\partial / \partial z_{j}$ or $\partial / \partial \bar{z}_{j}$. By the formula of

$$
\Gamma_{A B}^{C}=\frac{1}{2} g^{C D}\left(\frac{\partial g_{A D}}{\partial x_{B}}+\frac{\partial g_{B D}}{\partial x_{A}}-\frac{\partial g_{A B}}{\partial x_{D}}\right)
$$

we can choose $w$ coordinate such that $h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=1, d h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=0$ at $p_{0}$ where $(z, w)\left(p_{0}\right)=\left(z_{0}, w_{0}\right)((3.13))$. The $w$-slice is described by $z=z_{0}$ in a local patch $D_{j}((2.6))$. For $C=\partial / \partial z_{j}$ or $\partial / \partial \bar{z}_{j}$ and $D=\partial / \partial w$ or $\partial / \partial \bar{w}$ one sees $g^{C D}=0$ at $z_{0}$ by (3.14), so $D$ in (3.29) can only be left in the $z$-direction. Since we take $A, B$ to be $\partial / \partial w$ or $\partial / \partial \bar{w}, \partial g_{A D} / \partial x_{B}$ and $\partial g_{B D} / \partial x_{A}$ can only involve $d h$ which vanishes at $z=z_{0}$ (cf. (3.11), (3.12)). Similarly $\partial g_{A B} / \partial x_{D}\left(z_{0}\right)$ can only contain the term $\partial\left(\varphi_{1} \circ l\right) / \partial x_{D}=\left(\partial h / \partial x_{D}\right) \varphi_{1}^{\prime} w \bar{w}$ (in (3.9)) which vanishes at $z=z_{0}$ since $d h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=0$. Altogether, in view of (3.29) we have shown (3.28).

The following definition of the formal adjoint is more or less standard.
Notation 3.7. Denote by $\vartheta_{\Sigma}, \vartheta_{U_{j}}$ the formal adjoint of $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma}: \Omega^{0, q}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, q+1}(\Sigma)$, $\bar{\partial}_{U_{j}}\left(=\bar{\partial}_{z}\right.$ in $\left.z\right): \Omega^{0, q}\left(U_{j}\right) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, q+1}\left(U_{j}\right)$ (see (2.6) for the notation $U_{j}$ ) with respect to $G_{a}, \pi^{*} g_{M}$ (see (3.9)) respectively (cf. [53, p.152], [17, p.62]). Namely $\vartheta_{\Sigma} u$ $\in \Omega^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ for $u \in \Omega^{0, q+1}(\Sigma)$ is defined to satisfy $\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} u, v\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(u, \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma} v\right)_{L^{2}}$ for any smooth $(0, q)$-form $v$ of compact support, where the $L^{2}$-inner product is with respect to $G_{a}$. Similarly $\vartheta_{U_{j}}$ is defined with $\Sigma$ (resp. $G_{a}$ ) replaced by $U_{j}$ (resp. $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ ).

For the $m$-space $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}$ the corresponding notion of formal adjoint is less straightforward in that the conventional use of compact support test functions $\phi$ is no longer available ( $\phi$ always involves $w^{m}$ along the $\mathbb{R}^{+}$-orbits). One way out is to insert cut-off functions into test functions, but for later use we find it most convenient if we simply allow the support to be noncompact. The $L^{2}$-inner product $(\cdot, \cdot)_{L^{2}}$ below is with respect to $G_{a, m}$. We define an operator $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}: \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}(\Sigma) \rightarrow$ $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ by $\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} u, v\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(u, \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} v\right)_{L^{2}}$ for all $v \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$, and $\vartheta_{D_{j}, m}: \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}\left(D_{j}\right)$ $\rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$ by $\left(\vartheta_{D_{j}, m} s, t\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(s, \bar{\partial}_{D_{j}, m} t\right)_{L^{2}}$ for $s=s(z, \bar{z}) w^{m} \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}\left(D_{j}\right), t$ $=t(z, \bar{z}) w^{m} \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$ with $t(z, \bar{z})$ being of compact support in $U_{j}$. For their existence we will deduce a (local) formula for $\vartheta_{D_{j}, m}$ in Proposition 3.12 and that for $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}$ in Definition 3.13 and Proposition 3.14. We can now make the following definition.

Definition 3.8. We call the above $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}$ (resp. $\vartheta_{D_{j}, m}$ ) the formal adjoint of $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}$ (resp. $\bar{\partial}_{D_{j}, m}$ ). (In the next section we need to extend their domains of definition from the smooth elements to the $L^{2}$-elements. See lines below Notation 4.1.)

Remark that $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}=\pi_{m} \circ \vartheta_{\Sigma}$ on $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$. See Proposition 6.6 for the orthogonal projection $\pi_{m}$ and for its integral representation. A key point here is that this formal adjoint $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}$ turns out to be a differential operator if one uses the metric $G_{a, m}$ (see Lemma 3.15, Remark 3.16 and Proposition 3.18). See also Corollary 3.19

below for the difference between the two Laplacians formed by the two operators $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}, \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma}$ with their respective adjoints (the $\bar{L}^{\prime}$ there is meant $\Sigma$ here).

In the remaining of this section, we will show that modulo certain zeroth order terms $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}$ equals $\left.\vartheta_{\Sigma}\right|_{\Omega_{m}^{0,5^{*} *}(\Sigma)}$. See Proposition 3.18. During the process, we find that our metric $G_{s, m}$ satisfies another important property (see Proposition 3.12), which is essential for an application in Proposition 5.3.

Note that $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} s=\left(\bar{\partial}_{s} s(z, \bar{z})\right) w^{m}$ where we express $s=s(z, \bar{z}) w^{m} \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ locally. Recall the line bundle $L_{\Sigma}$ in the beginning of this section. From (3.5) we learn that $e_{w}:=\partial / \partial w$ is a $\tilde{\sigma}$-invariant section of $L_{\Sigma}$ over $D_{j} \subset \Sigma$ (in fact, as a local section it is only local- $\mathbb{C}^{*}$ invariant). Let $L_{\Sigma}^{*}$ denote the dual holomorphic line bundle of $L_{\Sigma}$ and $e_{w}^{*}$ the local section of $L_{\Sigma}^{*}$, dual to $e_{w}$.

Notation 3.9. Denote by $\Omega_{0}^{0, q}\left(\Sigma,\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ the space of $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant elements $\varpi$ in $\Omega^{0, q}\left(\Sigma,\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$.

In a local patch $D_{j}$, write $\varpi=s\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ where $s \in \Omega^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$. We have the operator $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma,\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}: \Omega_{0}^{0, q}\left(\Sigma,\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \rightarrow \Omega_{0}^{0, q+1}\left(\Sigma,\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ given by $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma,\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}\left(s\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ $=\left(\bar{\partial}_{s} s(z, \bar{z})\right)\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$.

We may identify, for $D_{j} \subset \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$, say, $p_{1}=1$ and thus $\delta_{j}=\pi$ in (2.6) (cf. remarks after Definition 2.8) in

$$
\Omega_{0}^{0, q}\left(D_{j},\left(\left.L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right|_{D_{j}}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \simeq \Omega^{0, q}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right|_{U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}\right)=: \Omega^{0, q}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)
$$

where $\psi_{j}^{-1}: D_{j} \subset \Sigma \rightarrow U_{j} \times C_{\delta_{j}}$ is a local trivialization (see (3.6) for the definition of $C_{\delta_{j}}$ and (2.11) for $\psi_{j}$ ). Let $\bar{\partial}_{U_{j}, m}$ denote the $\bar{\partial}$ operator acting on the RHS of $(3.30)$.

Definition 3.10. Let $\Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ (resp. $\Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$ ) denote the space of elements $u \in \Omega^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ (resp. $\Omega^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$ ), having the form $w^{m} v(z, \bar{z})$ in local holomorphic coordinates $(z, w)$. Note that $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \subset \Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$, but they are not equal in general unless the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on $\Sigma$ is globally free. For later use we define the space $\bar{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ consisting of elements $u \in \Omega^{0, q}(\Sigma)$, having the form $w^{m} v(z, \bar{z}, w, \bar{w})$ in local holomorphic coordinates $(z, w)$, with bounded $C_{B}^{*}$-norms for each integer $s \geq$ 0 (see (6.7) for the definition of $C_{B}^{*}$-norm). We have $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \subset \bar{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$.

Let $\bar{\partial}_{D_{j}, m}$ denote the $\bar{\partial}$ operator acting on $\Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$. With the notation above, we generalize Proposition 2.9 as follows. Compare Remark 10.10.

Proposition 3.11. Recall the line bundle $L_{\Sigma}$ defined in the lines above (3.1), and also Notation 3.9. The map $\tilde{\Psi}_{q, m}: \Omega_{0}^{0, q}\left(\Sigma,\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ given by

$$
\tilde{\Psi}_{q, m}\left(s\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)=s(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}
$$

in any local patch $D_{j}$ (not necessarily in $\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ ) with holomorphic coordinates $(z, w)$, where $s \in \Omega_{0, l o c}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$, is globally defined and a vector space isomorphism. Moreover we have $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \circ \tilde{\Psi}_{q, m}=\tilde{\Psi}_{q+1, m} \circ \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma,\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}$. For $(z, w) \in U_{j} \times C_{\delta_{j}}$ we have $\bar{\partial}_{D_{j}, m} \circ \Psi_{q, m}=\Psi_{q+1, m} \circ \bar{\partial}_{U_{j}, m}$ on $\Omega^{0, q}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$, where $\Psi_{q, m}$ : $\Omega^{0, q}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \rightarrow \Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$ defined by

$$
\Psi_{q, m}\left(s(z, \bar{z})\left(\psi_{j}^{*} e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)=s(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}
$$

is a vector space isomorphism.

Proof. We focus on $\tilde{\Psi}_{q, m}$; the assertion for $\Psi_{q, m}$ in (3.32) can be proved similarly (compare Proposition 2.9). Observe that $\tilde{\Psi}_{q, m}$ is a linear isomorphism as long as it is well defined. Since the transformation law of $e_{w}^{*}$ is easily verified to be the same as that of $w$, one sees that $\tilde{\Psi}_{q, m}$ is well defined (with image in $\Omega^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ ). To see that the image of $\tilde{\Psi}_{q, m}$ is actually contained in $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$, we restrict ourselves to the principal stratum $\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ and then extend to $\Sigma$ by continuity. That is, the image of $\tilde{\Psi}_{q, m}$ lies in $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}\left(\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)$ (which is the same as $\Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}\left(\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)$ in this case) using (3.30) and (3.32) so it must be in $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ since it is already in $\Omega^{0, q}(\Sigma)$.

We are ready to formulate the first main result (Proposition 3.12) of this section.
The $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant Hermitian metric $\left\langle\cdot, \cdot\right\rangle$ on $L_{\Sigma}$ (see Step 1 at the beginning of this section) induces a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant Hermitian metric on $\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$, still denoted by the same notation if no confusion will occur. For $s=s(z, \bar{z}) \in \Omega^{0, q+1}\left(U_{j}\right)$, by abuse of notation, we denote

$$
\vartheta_{z, m} s:=\left.\frac{\vartheta_{U_{j}, m}\left(s\left(\psi_{j}^{*}\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)\right|_{U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)}{\left.\left(\psi_{j}^{*}\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)\right|_{U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}\right)^{\otimes m}}
$$

with respect to the metrics $\left.\pi^{*} g_{M}\right|_{U_{j}}$ (cf. (3.9)) and $\left\langle\cdot, \cdot\right\rangle$, where $e_{w}^{*}$ is dual to $e_{w}=\partial / \partial w$ as above and $\psi_{j}$ is as in (3.30). According to a standard formula (see $[53,(3.142)$ on p.160]) one has $\vartheta_{z, m} s=\vartheta_{z} s+$ (zeroth order terms in $s$ ), where we recall (Definition 3.8) that $\vartheta_{z}$ is the formal adjoint of $\bar{\partial}_{U_{j}}: \Omega^{0, q}\left(U_{j}\right) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, q+1}\left(U_{j}\right)$ (with respect to the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ ) in coordinates $z=\left(z_{1}, . ., z_{n-1}\right)$. By choosing $w$ coordinate such that $h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=1, d h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=0$ at a point $p_{0}=\left(z_{0}, w_{0}\right)$ (cf. (3.13)), the above implies

$$
\vartheta_{z, m} s=\vartheta_{z} s \text { at } p_{0}
$$

The formula (3.34) will be applied to (3.45) later on.
Remark that $\vartheta_{z, m}$ is not invariantly defined while $\vartheta_{U_{j}, m}$ is (cf. Definition 3.8).
It is worth mentioning that the special structure of our metric $G_{a, m}$ will yield that the two operators $\vartheta_{D_{j}, m} \circ \Psi_{q+1, m}$ and $\Psi_{q, m} \circ \vartheta_{U_{j}, m}$ are still comparable. More precisely, we have the following crucial fact. See Proposition 5.3 for an application.

Proposition 3.12. (The first main result of this section) Assume $m \geq 0$. Under the notations explained above, we have $\vartheta_{D_{j}, m}\left(s(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}\right)=\left(\vartheta_{z, m} s(z, \bar{z})\right) w^{m}$ and hence $\vartheta_{D_{j}, m}=\Psi_{q, m} \circ \vartheta_{U_{j}, m} \circ \Psi_{q+1, m}^{-1}$.
Proof. Let $t \in \Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right), s \in \Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q+1}\left(D_{j}\right)$. Write $t=t(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}, s=s(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}$ where $t(z, \bar{z}) \in \Omega^{0, q}\left(U_{j}\right), s(z, \bar{z}) \in \Omega^{0, q+1}\left(U_{j}\right)$. Here $U_{j}$ may be identified with $U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}(\subset \Sigma)$ via $\psi_{j}$. Take $t(z, \bar{z})$ as a test function/form so it is of compact support in $U_{j}$. Write $G$ for $G_{a, m}$ and $H$ for the metric on $\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ induced by $\|\cdot\|$ on $L_{\Sigma}$ (cf. Step 1 given earlier in this section). We compute, by using $<\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m},\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}>_{H}=\left(h^{-1}\right)^{m}($ see (3.4)), $l(q)=h w \bar{w},(3.5)$ and (3.22),

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{D_{j}}<\bar{\partial}_{D_{j}, m} t, s>_{G} d v_{\Sigma, m}=\int_{D_{j}}<\bar{\partial}_{z} t(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}, s(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}>_{G} d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
& =\int_{D_{j}}<\bar{\partial}_{z} t(z, \bar{z})\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}, s(z, \bar{z})\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}>_{G \otimes H} h^{m}|w|^{2 m} d v_{\Sigma, m}
\end{aligned}
$$

To proceed further, note first that all the integrands in (3.35) is invariantly defined. To integrate the above over $D_{j}$, by Fubini's theorem we may first integrate over (part of) every $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbit then over the directions orthogonal to the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbits. Note that the metric on the orthogonal/horizontal direction is given by $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ (see (3.14)). With the natural projection $D_{j}=U_{j} \times C_{\delta_{j}} \rightarrow U_{j}, U_{j}$ equipped with the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ can be regarded as a parameter space for horizontal directions. For the above reasoning, note however that $\left.G_{a, m}\right|_{T U_{j}} \neq \pi^{*} g_{M} \|_{T U_{j}}\left(U_{j} \cong U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right.$ $\subset \Sigma$ ) and that $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ is precisely the metric we use on $T U_{j}$; see the line after (3.33) above.

It turns out (see the last equality in (3.39) below and remarks after it) that (3.35) equals (where $\left\langle\cdot, \cdot>\right.$ below means $\left.<\cdot, \cdot>_{\pi^{*} g_{M} \otimes H}\right):$

$$
\int_{U_{j}}<\bar{\partial}_{U_{j}, m}\left(t(z, \bar{z})\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right), s(z, \bar{z})\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}>d v(z) \int_{C_{\delta_{j}}} l(q)^{m} d v_{f, m}
$$

Since the preceding expressions of the integrands are again invariantly defined, for any given $z_{0}$ in $U_{j}$ we choose $(z, w)$ with $h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=1$ and $d h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=0$ (cf. (3.13)), so that (see (3.20))

$$
\int_{C_{\delta_{j}}} l(q)^{m} d v_{f, m}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{+}}|w|^{2 m} d v_{m}(|w|) \int_{-\delta_{j}}^{\delta_{j}} d v(\phi)=\frac{\delta_{j}}{\pi}
$$

It is crucial that the integration (3.37) results in a constant independent of $z$ coordinates, so that for (3.36) we can now apply $\bar{\partial}_{U_{j}, m}^{*}$ effortlessly:

$$
(3.38)=\int_{U_{j}}<t(z, \bar{z})\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}, \vartheta_{U_{j}, m}\left(s(z, \bar{z})\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)>d v(z) \frac{\delta_{j}}{\pi}
$$

Let us continue with (3.38) and bring it back via (3.37) and (3.33) to the following (for the second equality recalling $l=h w \bar{w}$ ):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { RHS of (3.38) } \\
& =\int_{U_{j}}<t(z, \bar{z}), \vartheta_{z, m} s(z, \bar{z})>_{\pi^{*} g_{M}} h^{-m} d v(z) \int_{C_{\delta_{j}}} l(q)^{m} d v_{f, m} \\
& \stackrel{D_{j}=U_{j} \times C_{\delta_{j}}}{=} \int_{D_{j}}<t(z, \bar{z}) w^{m},\left(\vartheta_{z, m} s(z, \bar{z})\right) w^{m}>_{\pi^{*} g_{M}} d v(z) \wedge d v_{f, m} \\
& \stackrel{(3.21)}{=} \int_{D_{j}}<t(z, \bar{z}) w^{m},\left(\vartheta_{z, m} s(z, \bar{z})\right) w^{m}>_{G} d v_{\Sigma, m}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $\left(\vartheta_{z, m} s(z, \bar{z})\right) w^{m}=\left.\Psi_{q, m}\left(\vartheta_{U_{j}, m}\left(s\left(\psi_{j}^{*}\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)\right|_{U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\right)$ by (3.33) and (3.31) (with $\psi_{j}^{*}$ often omitted) is invariantly defined since $\Psi_{q, m}$ and $\vartheta_{U_{j}, m}$ are. So the above $\left\langle\cdots>_{\pi^{*} g_{M}}=\langle\cdots\rangle_{G}\right.$ holds as one checks that they coincide under a choice of special coordinates (at any given point, cf. (3.13), (3.14)).

In summary the LHS of (3.35) equals the RHS of (3.39): it follows the first part: $\vartheta_{D_{j}, m} s=\left(\vartheta_{z, m} s(z, \bar{z})\right) w^{m}$, also the second part by (3.33) and the definition of $\Psi_{q, m}$.

Definition 3.13. We define a differential operator $\tilde{\vartheta}_{\Sigma, m}: \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ by $\left.\left(\tilde{\vartheta}_{\Sigma, m} u\right)\right|_{D_{j}}:=\left.\vartheta_{D_{j}, m} u\right|_{D_{j}}=\left(\vartheta_{z, m} u_{j}(z, \bar{z})\right) w^{m}$ where $\left.u\right|_{D_{j}}=u_{j}(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}$. According to Proposition 3.12 that $\vartheta_{D_{j}, m}$ is a differential operator uniquely determined by $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}, \tilde{\vartheta}_{\Sigma, m}$ is well-defined.

In globalizing Proposition 3.12 the cut-off functions inevitably depend on the $\theta$-variable. Let us be specific about this point below. Let $(\cdot, \cdot)_{L^{2}}$ denote the inner product with respect to the metric $G_{a, m}$.

Proposition 3.14. For $u \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}(\Sigma), v \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ it holds that $\left(\tilde{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} u, v\right)_{L^{2}}=$ $\left(u, \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}\right)_{L^{2}}$. As a consequence $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}=\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}$ (Definition 3.8).
Proof. Write $u=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j} u=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j} u_{j}(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}\left(\varphi_{j}\left(=\varphi_{j}(z, \bar{z}, \theta)\right)\right.$ being cut-off functions introduced below Notation 6.1) and $\left.v\right|_{D_{j}}=v_{j}(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}$. Via Proposition 3.12 we are going to compute the following. Note that the $\theta$ in $\varphi_{j}$ is treated below as a parameter (on which $\vartheta_{z, m}$ has no action).

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} u, v\right)_{L^{2}} & =\sum_{j} \int_{D_{j}}<\vartheta_{z, m}\left(\varphi_{j} u_{j}\right) w^{m}, v_{j}(z, \bar{z}) w^{m}>_{G} d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
& =\sum_{j} \int_{D_{j}}<\varphi_{j} u_{j} w^{m},\left(\bar{\partial}_{z} v_{j}(z, \bar{z})\right) w^{m}>_{G} d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
& =\sum_{j} \int_{D_{j}}<\varphi_{j} u_{j} w^{m},\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} v\right)\left.\right|_{D_{j}}>_{G} d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
& =\int_{\Sigma}<u, \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} v>_{G} d v_{\Sigma, m}=\left(u, \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} v\right)_{L^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

To proceed further ${ }^{4}$, we need one more technical lemma.
Lemma 3.15. Assume $m \geq 0$. In local holomorphic coordinates $(z, w)$ we write $\tilde{\psi}=w^{m} \psi, \psi=\psi_{\bar{\beta}_{1} \ldots \bar{\beta}_{q+1}} d \bar{z}_{\beta_{1}} \wedge \ldots \wedge d \bar{z}_{\beta_{q+1}}$. Then we have

$$
\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}=\left(\vartheta_{z, m} \psi\right) w^{m}+\text { zeroth order terms in } \psi_{\bar{\beta}_{1} \ldots \bar{\beta}_{q+1}}
$$

Remark 3.16. The validity of the lemma relies on the specific metric $G_{a, m}$ on $\Sigma$. We do not see such compatibility result for general metric ( $\Sigma$ being of one dimension higher than the $z$-space).
Proof. (of Lemma 3.15) At a point $p_{0} \in \Sigma$, we find coordinates $(z, w)$ such that $z\left(p_{0}\right)=z_{0}=\left(z_{1}^{0}, . ., z_{n-1}^{0}\right), w\left(p_{0}\right)=w_{0}, h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=\left\|\frac{g}{g_{n}}\right\|_{\left(z_{0}, w_{0}\right)} \|^{2}=1$ and $d h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)$ $=0((3.13))$. By standard formulas for $\bar{\partial}^{*}$ (cf. [65, p.97] or [53, p.153]), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)^{\beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}} & =-\frac{1}{g} \partial_{\beta}\left(g \tilde{\psi}^{\beta \beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{g} \partial_{w}\left(g \tilde{\psi}^{w \beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}\right)-\frac{1}{g} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(g \tilde{\psi}^{z_{j} \beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$\left(\beta_{1}, \ldots, \beta_{q}\right.$ run for $z_{j}, w$ here) where $g:=\operatorname{det}\left(g_{\alpha \bar{\beta}}\right)$ and $g_{\alpha \bar{\beta}}$ are components of $G_{a}$ in coordinates $(z, w)$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{4}$ Although Corollary 3.19 below can be regarded as an objective of the remaining section, it serves as a motivation for the treatment of our Hodge theory in the coming section rather than an effective tool (cf. the introductory paragraph of Section 4). Despite this, (3.55) with an exact property in the complex two-dimensional case (3.56), seems a natural question that a reader may be led to inquire (see also Remarks 3.16 and 3.20); we decide to include the details here. For the proof below the first main result Proposition 3.12 will be needed (see proof of Proposition 3.18). See also Remark 3.20 for a comparison with related results.

Denote $\left(g_{\alpha \bar{\beta}}\right)^{-1}$ by $g^{\alpha \bar{\beta}}\left(\left[53, g^{\bar{\beta} \alpha}\right]\right)$, i.e., $g_{\alpha \bar{\beta}} g^{\gamma \bar{\beta}}=\delta_{\alpha}^{\gamma}$. Let $G^{\alpha \bar{\beta}}$ denote the cofactor of $\left(g_{\alpha \bar{\beta}}\right)$ at position $(\alpha, \beta)$, such that $g^{\alpha \bar{\beta}}=g^{-1} G^{\alpha \bar{\beta}}$.

First, we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
g \tilde{\psi}^{w \beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}} & =g g^{w \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \tilde{\psi}_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \\
& =G^{w \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \psi_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} w^{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

(note that $\bar{\gamma}_{1}, \ldots, \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}$ only run for $\bar{z}_{1}, \ldots, \bar{z}_{n-1}$ ). It can be checked that $G^{w \bar{\gamma}_{1}}$ and $\partial_{w} G^{w \bar{\gamma}_{1}}$ vanishes at $p_{0}$ using (3.11), (3.12) and (3.13). This vanishing and (3.42) yield

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{w}\left(g \tilde{\psi}^{w \beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}\right)= & \left(\partial_{w} G^{w \bar{\gamma}_{1}}\right) g^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \psi_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} w^{m} \\
& +G^{w \bar{\gamma}_{1}} \partial_{w}\left(g^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \psi_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} w^{m}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

at $p_{0}$. Finally, substituting (3.43) and $g \tilde{\psi}^{z_{j} \beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}=G^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \psi_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} w^{m}$ into (3.41) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)^{\beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}= & -\frac{1}{g} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(G^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}}\right) \psi_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} w^{m} \\
& -\frac{1}{g} G^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \partial_{z_{j}} \psi_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} w^{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand, denote $\operatorname{det}\left(g_{M \alpha \bar{\beta}}\right)$ by $g_{M}$ (in the same notation as the metric itself if no confusion occurs) and the cofactor of $\left(g_{M \alpha \bar{\beta}}\right)$ at position $(\alpha, \beta)$ by $H^{\alpha \bar{\beta}}$. Note that $g_{M}^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}=g_{M}^{\gamma-1} H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}$. At $p_{0}$ we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\vartheta_{z, m} \psi\right)^{\beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}=\left(\bar{\partial}_{z}^{*} \psi\right)^{\beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}(\text { by (3.34)) } \\
= & -\frac{1}{g_{M}} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(g_{M} \psi^{z_{j} \beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}\right)(\text { as in (3.41)) } \\
= & -\frac{1}{g_{M}} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g_{M}^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g_{M}^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \psi_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}}\right) \\
= & -\frac{1}{g_{M}} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g_{M}^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g_{M}^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}}\right) \psi_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \\
& -\frac{1}{g_{M}} H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g_{M}^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \ldots g_{M}^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \partial_{z_{j}} \psi_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

( $\beta_{1}, \ldots, \beta_{q}$ and $\gamma_{1}, \ldots, \gamma_{q+1}$ only run from $z_{1}$ to $z_{n-1}$ here).
To compare (3.44) and (3.45) as claimed by our main task (3.40), observe that at $p_{0}, g=g_{M} g_{w \bar{w}}, G^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}=H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g_{w \bar{w}}\left(g_{z_{j} \bar{w}}=g_{w \bar{z}_{j}}=0\right.$ by (3.11), (3.12)), and hence

$$
g^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}=\frac{1}{g} G^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}=\frac{1}{g_{M}} H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}=g_{M}^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}
$$

We also compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{g} \partial_{z_{j}} G^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} & =\frac{1}{g} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} g_{w \bar{w}}+\text { terms involving } h_{\alpha} h_{\bar{\beta}}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{g}\left(\partial_{z_{j}} H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}\right) g_{w \bar{w}}+\frac{1}{g} H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}\left(\partial_{z_{j}} g_{w \bar{w}}\right)=\frac{1}{g_{M}} \partial_{z_{j}} H^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

at $p_{0}$ where $d h=0$ and $(0=) \partial_{z_{j}} g_{w \bar{w}}=$ terms involving $\partial_{z_{j}} h$. Moreover from (3.46), (3.47) we have, at $p_{0}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \partial_{z_{j}} g^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}}=\partial_{z_{j}}\left(\frac{1}{g} G^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}}\right)=(-1) g^{-2}\left(\partial_{z_{j}} g\right) G^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}}+g^{-1} \partial_{z_{j}} G^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \\
= & (-1) g^{-2} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(g_{M} g_{w \bar{w}}+\text { terms involving } h_{\alpha} h_{\bar{\beta}}\right) G^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}}+\frac{1}{g_{M}} \partial_{z_{j}} H^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \\
= & (-1) \frac{1}{g_{M}}\left(\partial_{z_{j}} g_{M}\right) \frac{1}{g_{M}} H^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}}+\frac{1}{g_{M}} \partial_{z_{j}} H^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}} \\
= & \partial_{z_{j}}\left(\frac{1}{g_{M}} H^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}}\right)=\partial_{z_{j}} g_{M}^{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\beta_{1}$ runs from $z_{1}$ to $z_{n-1}$.
We are about to compare (3.44) and (3.45). We use (3.46), (3.47) and (3.48) to obtain

$$
\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)^{\beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}}=\left(\vartheta_{z, m} \psi\right)^{\beta_{1} \ldots \beta_{q}} w^{m}
$$

at $p_{0}$ for $\beta_{1}, \ldots, \beta_{q}$ running from $z_{1}$ to $z_{n-1}$. By (3.49) we lower the indices of (3.44):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q}} & =g_{\beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{1} \cdots} g_{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q}}\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)^{\beta_{1} \cdots \beta_{q}} \\
& =g_{M \beta_{1} \bar{\gamma}_{1} \cdots} g_{M \beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q}}\left(\vartheta_{z, m} \psi\right)^{\beta_{1} \cdots \beta_{q}} w^{m} \\
& =\left(\vartheta_{z, m} \psi\right)_{\bar{\gamma}_{1} \cdots \bar{\gamma}_{q}} w^{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

at $p_{0}$ for $\gamma_{1}, \ldots, \gamma_{q}$ running from $z_{1}$ to $z_{n-1}$. For these indices our claim (3.40) is now shown even without the correction of zeroth order terms.

The possible corrections by zeroth order terms occur when one (and thus the only one) of $\gamma_{1}, \ldots, \gamma_{q}$ equals $w$, say $\gamma_{1}=w$ (with $\gamma_{2}, \ldots, \gamma_{q}$ running from $z_{1}$ to $\left.z_{n-1}\right)$,

$$
\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)_{\tilde{\omega} \bar{\gamma}_{2} \cdots \bar{\gamma}_{q}}=g_{\beta_{1} \tilde{\omega}} g_{\beta_{2} \bar{\gamma}_{2} \cdots} g_{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q}}\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)^{\beta_{1} \cdots \beta_{q}}=g_{w \tilde{\omega}} g_{\beta_{2} \bar{\gamma}_{2} \cdots} g_{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q}}\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)^{w \beta_{2} \cdots \beta_{q}}
$$

at $p_{0}$ by $g_{z_{j}} \tilde{\omega}\left(p_{0}\right)=0$. We compute (as in (3.41)) using $\tilde{\psi}^{w w \beta_{2} \cdots \beta_{q}}=g^{w \bar{z}_{1}} g^{w \bar{z}_{2}} \ldots$ $\tilde{\psi}_{z_{1} z_{2} \cdots}=0$ at $p_{0}$ by $g^{w \bar{z}_{1}}\left(p_{0}\right)=g^{w \bar{z}_{2}}\left(p_{0}\right)=0$ and its $w$-derivatives $=0$ at $p_{0}$, for the second equality below

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)^{w \beta_{2} \cdots \beta_{q}} & =-\frac{1}{g} \partial_{w}\left(g \tilde{\psi}^{w w \beta_{2} \cdots \beta_{q}}\right)-\frac{1}{g} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(g \tilde{\psi}^{z_{j} w \beta_{2} \cdots \beta_{q}}\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{g} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(g \tilde{\psi}^{z_{j} w \beta_{2} \cdots \beta_{q}}\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{g} \partial_{z_{j}}\left(g^{z_{j} \bar{\gamma}_{1}} G^{w \bar{\gamma}_{2}} g^{\beta_{2} \bar{\gamma}_{3}} \ldots g^{\beta_{q} \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}} \tilde{\psi}_{\gamma_{1} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q+1}}\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{g}\left(\partial_{z_{j}} G^{w \bar{k}_{2}}\right) g^{z_{j} \bar{k}_{1}} g^{\beta_{2} \bar{k}_{3} \ldots} g^{\beta_{q} \bar{k}_{q+1}} \psi_{\bar{k}_{q} \ldots \bar{k}_{q+1}} w^{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

at $p_{0}$ by $G^{w \bar{\gamma}_{2}}\left(p_{0}\right)=0$. Finally, substituting (3.52) into (3.51), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)_{\tilde{\omega} \bar{\gamma}_{2} \cdots \bar{\gamma}_{q}}=-\frac{1}{g}\left(\partial_{z_{j}} G^{w \bar{k}_{2}}\right) g_{w \tilde{\omega}} g^{z_{j} \bar{k}_{1}} \delta_{\bar{\gamma}_{2}}^{k_{q}} \ldots \delta_{\gamma_{q}}^{k_{q+1}} \psi_{\bar{k}_{1} \ldots \bar{k}_{q+1}} w^{m} \\
= & -\frac{1}{g}\left(\partial_{z_{j}} G^{w \bar{k}_{2}}\right) g_{w \tilde{\omega}} g^{z_{j} \bar{k}_{1}} \psi_{\bar{k}_{1} \bar{k}_{2} \bar{\gamma}_{2} \cdots \bar{\gamma}_{q}} w^{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

at $p_{0}$. This term (3.53) is of zeroth order in $\psi_{\bar{k}_{1} \bar{k}_{2} \bar{\gamma}_{2} \ldots \bar{\gamma}_{q}}$. Our claim (3.40) in its complete form follows from (3.50) and (3.53).

Remark 3.17. In the case where $\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{C}} \Sigma=2$, observe that $\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}\right)_{\tilde{\psi} \tilde{\gamma}_{2} \ldots \tilde{\gamma}_{q}}=0$ because the RHS of (3.53) vanishes for dimension reason. In this case, $\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}=\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \tilde{\psi}$ exactly (by using (3.50) and Proposition 3.12).

We are almost ready to arrive at the second main result of this section. Let $L_{0, q+1}^{q}\left(\Sigma, G_{a}\right)$ denote the space of all square-integrable $(0, q+1)$ forms on $\Sigma$ with respect to $G_{a}$. For any given $m \geq 0$ and large positive $a$ (say, $a>\frac{m}{2}$ ), it is not difficult to see $\Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}(\Sigma) \subset L_{0, q+1}^{q}\left(\Sigma, G_{a}\right)$ (see Remark 3.4).

Proposition 3.18. (The second main result of this section) For $a>\frac{m}{2} \geq 0, \vartheta_{\Sigma, m}$ $: \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ is equal to the restriction $\left.\vartheta_{\Sigma}\right|_{\Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}(\Sigma)}$ modulo zeroth order terms, where $\vartheta_{\Sigma}: \Omega^{0, q+1}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, q}(\Sigma)$. That is, for $\tilde{\psi} \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}(\Sigma)$ we have

$$
\vartheta_{\Sigma} \tilde{\psi}=\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \tilde{\psi}+\text { zeroth order terms in } \tilde{\psi}
$$

Proof. The formal adjoints $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \tilde{\psi}=\left.\vartheta_{D_{j}, m} \tilde{\psi}\right|_{D_{j}}$ in $D_{j} \subset \Sigma$. So (3.54) follows from (3.40) of Lemma 3.15 and Proposition 3.12.

To streamline our ongoing presentation, let us indicate an application of the above results to $\bar{\partial}$-Laplacians. Back to the case $\Sigma=\bar{L} \backslash\{0$-section $\}=: \bar{L}^{\prime}$, in view of Proposition 2.9 we can convert $\bar{\partial}_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}: \Omega^{0, q}\left(M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, q+1}\left(M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ to $\bar{\partial}_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m}: \Omega_{m}^{0, q}\left(\bar{L}^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}\left(\bar{L}^{\prime}\right)$ given by $\bar{\partial}_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m}\left(\eta w^{m}\right)=\left(\bar{\partial}_{M} \eta\right) w^{m}$. That is, we have $\bar{\partial}_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m} \circ \psi_{q, m}=\psi_{q+1, m} \circ \bar{\partial}_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}$ (see Proposition 2.9 for $\psi_{q, m}$ ). Define $\bar{\partial}$-Laplacians $\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}}, \square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m}$ and $\square_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}$ by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}}:= & \vartheta_{\bar{L}^{\prime}} \circ \bar{\partial}_{\bar{L}^{\prime}}+\bar{\partial}_{\bar{L}^{\prime}} \circ \vartheta_{\bar{L}^{\prime}}, \square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m}:=\vartheta_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m} \circ \bar{\partial}_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m}+\bar{\partial}_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m} \circ \vartheta_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m} \\
\square_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}:= & \vartheta_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}} \circ \bar{\partial}_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}+\bar{\partial}_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}} \circ \vartheta_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}
\end{aligned}
$$

respectively. Now Proposition 2.9, Proposition 3.18 and Remark 3.17 yield immediately

Corollary 3.19. With the notation above,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}}+\text { first order operator }\right) \circ \psi_{q, m}=\psi_{q, m} \circ \square_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}} \\
& \left.\left(\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}}+\text { first order operator }\right)\right|_{\Omega_{m}^{0, q}\left(\bar{L}^{\prime}\right)}=\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m}
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{C}} \bar{L}^{\prime}=2$, then "first order operator" of (3.55) vanishes. That is to say,

$$
\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}} \circ \psi_{q, m}=\psi_{q, m} \circ \square_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}},\left.\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}}\right|_{\Omega_{m}^{0, q}\left(\bar{L}^{\prime}\right)}=\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m}
$$

Remark 3.20. This type of relation between the "upstair Laplacian $\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}}$ " and the "downstair Laplacian $\square_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}$ " is also seen in the work [18, Proposition 5.1] in the context of CR manifolds $X$ with $S^{1}$-action, where no "first order corrections" (such as the one in (3.55)) is needed, due to the use of an $S^{1}$-invariant metric on $X$.

# 4. A Hodge theory for $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ 

Let $\Sigma$ be as before. We are going to study a Hodge theory for the Laplacian $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ associated to $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}$ acting on $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$. For this purpose, certain a priori estimates such as elliptic estimates are useful. In view of Corollary 3.19 above for $\Sigma=\bar{L}^{\prime}$, it appears conceivable that the desired estimates for $\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}, m}$ could be available from those for $\square_{\bar{L}^{\prime}}$, and the latter is known classically (on compact manifolds). Strongly motivated by this though, in the present section we take an alternative approach. This approach basically aligns with Proposition 3.12, and part of the methodology will reappear in subsequent sections.

Our main result of this section is Theorem 4.22 with an application to the index in Corollary 4.24. See another application for the proof of (5.17) in Section 5. Fix a finite covering $\left\{D_{j}\right\}_{j \in J}$ of $\Sigma$ as in (2.6) and a partition of unity $\varphi_{j}\left(=\varphi_{j}(z, \theta)\right)$ subordinated to $D_{j}$ as in the item $i$ ) after Notation 6.1 with $U_{j}=V_{j}$ there. Write $\omega \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ as $\omega=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j} \omega$ with $\varphi_{j} \omega=w^{m} \varphi_{j} \mu_{j}(z, \bar{z})$ for $C^{\infty}$-smooth $(0, q)$-forms $\mu_{j}$ on $U_{j}$ by Definition $2.8 i i$.
Notation 4.1. Denote by $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ the space of $\|\cdot\|_{L^{2}}$-completion of $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ with respect to the metric $G_{a, m}$ (compare Remark 5.6 for similar notations $L_{m}^{2, s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right), L^{2, s}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ ). (Recall that any element in $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ is square-integrable if $a>\frac{m}{2}$; see Remark 3.4.)

It is convenient to define $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}\right)\left(\right.$ resp. $\left.\operatorname{Dom}\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}\right)\right)$ to be the space of all $\omega$ $\in L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ with $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \omega \in L_{0, q+1, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\left(\right.$ resp. $\left.\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \omega \in L_{0, q-1, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\right)$ in the distribution sense given as follows: $\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \omega, \varphi\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(\omega, \vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \varphi\right)_{L^{2}}$ (resp. $\left.\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \omega, \varphi\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(\omega, \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \varphi\right)_{L^{2}}\right)$ for all $\varphi \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}(\Sigma)\left(\right.$ resp. $\varphi \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q-1}(\Sigma)$ ) (note that $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}$, the formal adjoint of $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}$, as in Definition 3.8 acting on smooth elements is a differential operator via Proposition 3.12). In case $\omega$ is smooth the distributional $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \omega$ (resp. $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \omega$ ) coincides with the ordinary $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \omega$ (resp. $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \omega$ ) by Proposition 3.14. Here both $\left(\omega, \vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \varphi\right)_{L^{2}}$ and $\left(\omega, \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \varphi\right)_{L^{2}}$ are finite in view of Remark 3.4. The distribution sense above uses test functions necessarily of noncompact support; this is one of key features in our study. Write

$$
\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}:=\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \circ \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}+\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \circ \vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \text { on } \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right) \subset L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)
$$

Here $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)$ consists of elements $\omega \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}\right) \cap \operatorname{Dom}\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}\right) \subset L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a}\right)$ such that $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \omega \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}^{(q+1)}\right), \vartheta_{\Sigma, m} \omega \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}^{(q-1)}\right)$ (cf. [17, Definition 4.2.2 ] with their Hilbert space adjoint replaced by the formal adjoint $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}$ ). An alternative definition of $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)$ may be that $u \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)$ if $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u \in L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a}\right)$ in the distribution sense as above, i.e. $\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u, \varphi\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(u, \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} \varphi\right)_{L^{2}}$ for all $\varphi \in$ $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$. In this way, see Remark 4.7 for disadvantages.

Let $H_{0, q}^{s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ denote the usual Sobolev space of order $s$ for $(0, q)$-forms on $\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ with $\|\cdot\|_{s}$ its Sobolev norm. Let

$$
H_{0, q, m}^{s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right):=H_{0, q}^{s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \cap L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)
$$

which is the completion of $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ under $\|\cdot\|_{s}$ (here $\Omega_{m}^{0, q} \subset L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$, cf. Remark 3.4).

However the norm (4.2) is not going to be adopted here. Instead we have the following alternative approach, which we view as a novelty of this section:

Definition 4.2. With the notation above, by (3.32) $u \in L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ may be thought of as the form $u=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j} u$ with $\varphi_{j} u=\varphi_{j} v_{j}$ for some $\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$-valued $v_{j}=v_{j}(z, \bar{z})$, or $v_{j}(z)$ for short, $\in L_{0, q}^{2}\left(U_{j}, \psi_{j}^{*} G_{a, m} \otimes h^{-m}\right)$ (see (3.4) for $L_{\Sigma}$ and $h$, and (3.32) for this interpretation) with $\operatorname{supp} \varphi_{j} v_{j} \subset U_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right)\left(\times \mathbb{R}^{+}\right)$where $\varepsilon_{j}$ $=\varepsilon$ for all $j$ (note that $\varphi_{j}=\varphi_{j}(z, \theta)$ where $w=|w| e^{i \theta}$ or $w_{j}=\left|w_{j}\right| e^{i \theta_{j}}$ to indicate the dependence on $j$ ). This interpretation explains why the metric in $L_{0, q}^{2}$ above and in $i i$ ) below involves " $h^{-m}$ ". For most of the time we shall write $u=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j} u$ where $\varphi_{j} u$ is simply $w^{m} \varphi_{j} v_{j}, v_{j} \in L_{0, q}^{2}\left(U_{j}, \psi_{j}^{*} G_{a, m} \otimes h^{-m}\right)$ (in this way $v_{j}$ not $\left.\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right.$-valued). The two ways are used interchangeably. We define

$$
u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)
$$

if and only if the following $i$ ), $i i$ ) and $i i i$ ) hold

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { i) } u \in L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \\
& \text { ii) } \varphi_{j}\left(\cdot, \theta_{j}\right) v_{j}(\cdot) \in H_{0, q}^{s}\left(U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}, \psi_{j}^{*} \pi^{*} g_{M} \otimes h^{-m}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $j$ and $\theta_{j} \in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right)$, where the metric $\psi_{j}^{*} \pi^{*} g_{M}$ is part of $\psi_{j}^{*} G_{a, m}$ (see (3.21)), and

$$
\text { iii) }||u||_{s}^{\prime}<\infty
$$

where the $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$-norm is given by

$$
\|u\|_{s}^{\prime}:=\left(\sum_{j} \int_{-\varepsilon_{j}=-\varepsilon}^{\varepsilon_{j}=\varepsilon}\left\|\varphi_{j}\left(\cdot, \theta_{j}\right) v_{j}(\cdot)\right\|_{s, U_{j}}^{2} \frac{d \theta_{j}}{2 \pi}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

Here $\|\cdot\|_{s, U_{j}}$ denotes the usual Sobolev norm for $H_{0, q}^{s}\left(U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}, \psi_{j}^{*} \pi^{*} g_{M} \otimes\right.$ $\left.h^{-m}\right)$ using local coordinates $\left(z_{j}, w_{j}\right)(=(z, w)$ with " $j$ " often omitted) on $D_{j}$ for taking derivatives. We also write, if $v$ is of support in $U \subset U_{j}$

$$
\|v\|_{s, U \subset U_{j}}:=\|v\|_{s, U_{j}}
$$

i.e. the norm $\|\cdot\|_{s, U \subset U_{j}}$ uses the $U_{j}$-coordinates. It is not hard to see that $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ is a Hilbert space with the inner product $<\cdot, \cdot>_{H^{\prime s}}$ such that $\left.\left\langle u, u\right\rangle_{H^{\prime s}}=\left(\|u\|_{s}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right)$

Remark 4.3. From an intrinsic point of view, one may want to use covariant derivatives for $\|\cdot\|_{s, U_{j}}$ rather than ordinary derivatives in local coordinates. But since there are $\theta_{j}$-coordinates, the notion "family of $\theta_{j}$-parametrized sections" has no intrinsic meaning; that is, such a family of sections change as soon as the coordinates change. Even though $\|\cdot\|_{s, U_{j}}$ can be defined using covariant derivatives, there is no canonical choice of the family of sections in (4.3). We choose to work with ordinary derivatives in local coordinates for the $s$-norms.

Remark 4.4. It is a fact that $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 0}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ and $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ are the same space with different, yet equivalent norm if $a>\frac{m}{2}(\geq 0)$ (via Remark 3.4). The same can be said on $U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ with different metrics $\psi_{j}^{*} G_{a, m} \otimes h^{-m}$ and $\psi_{j}^{*} \pi^{*} g_{M} \otimes h^{-m}$ used in the statement of Definition 4.2. It is slightly tedious yet straightforward to check these statements; we omit the details. See applications in, for instance, the proofs of Lemma 4.17 and Proposition 4.21.

The notation $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$ with superscript "prime" distinguishes itself from the usual Sobolev norm. Different choice of coverings $\left\{D_{j}\right\}_{j}$ and $\varphi_{j}$ gives equivalent norms. Note the similarity and distinction between this norm and the $C_{B}^{*}$-norm to be defined in (6.7).

The particular setting above is going to be crucial for us to work through a number of technicalities and obtain a Hodge theory as just mentioned.

We may write $\left.\varphi_{k} u\right|_{D_{k} \cap D_{j}}=\varphi_{k} w_{j}^{m} v_{j}$ where $w_{j}\left(=\left|w_{j}\right| e^{i \theta_{j}}\right)$ denotes the $w$-coordinate in $D_{j}$. It is natural to define another $s$-norm by (see Remarks after (4.5))

$$
\|u\|_{s}^{\prime \prime}:=\left(\sum_{k, j} \int_{-\varepsilon}^{\varepsilon}\left\|\varphi_{k}\left(\cdot, \theta_{j}\right) v_{j}(\cdot)\right\|_{s, U_{s}}^{2} \frac{d \theta_{j}}{2 \pi}\right)^{1 / 2} ; \theta_{j} \text { rewritten as } \theta
$$

Here, on $D_{k} \cap D_{j}$ we write the same notation $\varphi_{k}$ expressed in terms of coordinates on $D_{j}$. As $\varphi_{k} \in C^{\infty}(\Sigma)$ we view $\varphi_{k} v_{j}$ as a function on $D_{j}$. With this understanding the subscript " $j$ " of $\theta_{j}$ in (4.5) may be dropped if no confusion occurs.

Lemma 4.5. With the notation above, we have the equivalence between $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$-norm (4.3) and $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$-norm (4.5).

Proof. One direction is clear: $\|u\|_{s}^{\prime} \leq\|u\|_{s}^{\prime \prime}$ by restriction to $k=j$ in the sum (4.5). For the other direction, suppose in $D_{k} \cap D_{j}, w_{k}=w_{j} l_{j k}$ for some holomorphic function $l_{j k}$ on $D_{j} \cap D_{k}$ in terms of $z_{j}$ or $z_{k}$ by (2.3). Then $w_{k}^{m} v_{k}=w_{j}^{m} v_{j}=u$ restricted on $D_{k} \cap D_{j}$ give that $v_{k} l_{j k}^{m}=v_{j}$, from which we compute (viewing " $\theta$ " $\left(=\theta_{j}, \theta_{k}\right)$ as a parameter; seeing also (4.4))

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\varphi_{k} v_{j}\right\|_{s, U_{j}} & =\left\|\varphi_{k} v_{k} l_{j k}^{m}\right\|_{s, U_{j} \cap U_{k} \subset U_{j}} \leq C_{1}\left\|\varphi_{k} v_{k} l_{j k}^{m}\right\|_{s, U_{j} \cap U_{k} \subset U_{k}} \\
& \leq C_{1} \max \left|l_{j k}^{m}\right|\left\|\varphi_{k} v_{k}\right\|_{s, U_{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C_{1}$, arising from the coordinate change from $U_{j}$ to $U_{k}$, depends on $j, k, m, s$ and not on $\theta\left(=\theta_{j}, \theta_{k}\right)$. It follows from integrating the square of (4.6) with respect to $\theta$ that $\|u\|_{s}^{\prime \prime} \leq(\#$ of $j)^{1 / 2} \cdot C\|u\|_{s}^{\prime}$.

Remark 4.6. Concerning the Sobolev norms $\|\cdot\|_{s}$ in (4.2) and $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$ in (4.3), although it is possible to study the relation between them especially when " $a$ " in $G_{a, m}$ is sufficiently large (depending on $m$ and $s$ ), we are not going to pursue this relation in the present paper.

We are going to compare local $\|\cdot\|_{s, D_{j}}^{\prime}$-norm (to be defined below) with global $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime \prime}$-norm. From Propositions 3.11 and 3.12 it follows

$$
\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)}=\Psi_{q, m} \circ \square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)} \circ \Psi_{q, m}^{-1}
$$

Here we recall the isomorphism $\Psi_{q, m}: \Omega^{0, q}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \rightarrow \Omega_{m, l o n}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$ in (3.32) and define $\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)}:=\vartheta_{D_{j}, m} \circ \bar{\partial}_{D_{j}, m}+\bar{\partial}_{D_{j}, m} \circ \vartheta_{D_{j}, m}$ and $\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}:=\vartheta_{U_{j}, m} \circ \bar{\partial}_{U_{j}, m}$ $+\bar{\partial}_{U_{j}, m} \circ \vartheta_{U_{j}, m}$ similarly as in (4.1) for $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$.

Remark 4.7. By the definition via test functions one sees that $i$ ) if $u \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)$ then $\left.u\right|_{D_{j}} \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)}\right)$ and $\left.\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u\right)\right|_{D_{j}}=\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\left.u\right|_{D_{j}}\right)$. The same is true of $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}, \vartheta_{D_{j}, m}$ in place of $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}, \square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)} \cdot i i)$ It is easily seen that if $u \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)}\right)$

(resp. $\left.\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}, \vartheta_{\Sigma, m}\right)$ and a cut-off function $\chi \in C_{c}^{\infty}\left(D_{j}\right)$ then $\chi u \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)}\right)$ (resp. $\left.\bar{\partial}_{D_{j}, m}, \vartheta_{D_{j}, m}\right)$ where the $w$-variable in $\chi$ is regarded as "parameter" without being acted on by these operators. The localization property ii) is not easily checked for the alternative choice of definition for $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)$ (see lines below (4.1)). Such a localization $i i$ ) is crucial for the proof of Proposition 4.15 below. Compare Remark 4.26 for rejustification of this localization.

Define the local $\|\cdot\|_{s, D_{j}}^{\prime}$-norm by

$$
\|\omega\|_{s, D_{j}}^{\prime}:=\left\|v_{j}\right\|_{s, U_{j}} \text { for } \omega=w_{j}^{m} v_{j} \in \Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)
$$

where $\|\cdot\|_{s, U_{j}}$ is the usual Sobolev $s$-norm on $U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ with respect to the metric $\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} g_{M}\right)$ together with the fibre metric $h^{-m}$ on $\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ in (3.4). Observe that no partition of unity is used for this local norm.

It is crucial to notice that $\Psi_{q, m}, \Psi_{q, m}^{-1}$ preserve respective Sobolev $s$-spaces. In fact, for $\omega \in \Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}\left(D_{j}\right)$

$$
\|\omega\|_{s, D_{j}}^{\prime}=\left\|\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} \omega\right\|_{s, U_{j}}
$$

by (3.32) and (4.8).
Suppose that $A$ and $B$ are functions on a set $S$. We use the notation $A \lesssim B$ to mean that there is some constant $C>0$ such that $A(u) \leq C B(u)$ for all $u \in S$. For instance, $\|\cdot\|_{1} \lesssim\|\cdot\|_{2}$ means that there exists a constant $C>0$ such that $\|\cdot\|_{1} \leq C\|\cdot\|_{2}$.
Lemma 4.8. (Localization of $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$-norm) With the notation above, it holds that

$$
\|\cdot\|_{s, D_{j}}^{\prime} \lesssim\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime \prime}
$$

on $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. That is $\|u\|_{s, D_{j}}^{\prime} \leq C\|u\|_{s}^{\prime \prime}$ for some $C>0$ and every $u \in$ $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$.
Proof. Write $\left.u\right|_{D_{j}}=w_{j}^{m} v_{j}$. From the definition it follows that ( $\theta$ as a parameter as above)

$$
\|u\|_{s, D_{j}}^{\prime}=\left\|v_{j}\right\|_{s, U_{j}} \leq \sum_{k:|\{k\}|<\infty}\left\|\varphi_{k}(\cdot, \theta) v_{j}(\cdot)\right\|_{s, U_{j}}
$$

Integrating the square of (4.11) over $\theta \in(-\varepsilon, \varepsilon)$ (cf. comments after (4.5)), we obtain (4.10) by (4.5).

Let $(\cdot, \cdot)_{L^{2}}$ denote the $L^{2}$-inner product for $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. For the notion of formally self-adjointness to be used below, compare [53, p.321]. We need the following.
Lemma 4.9. $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ is formally self-adjoint for $a>\frac{m}{2} \geq 0$, i.e. for $u, v \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ (being of noncompact support along the $\mathbb{R}^{+}$-direction) it holds that

$$
\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u, v\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(u, \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} v\right)_{L^{2}}
$$

For $u \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$

$$
\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u, u\right)_{L^{2}}=\left\|\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} u\right\|_{L^{2}}^{2}+\left\|\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} u\right\|_{L^{2}}^{2} \geq 0
$$

Here $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} \bullet$ is the differential operator action. As a consequence $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u$ coincides with the action in the distribution sense.

Proof. This immediately follows from Proposition 3.14 and the definition of $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$.

We adopt Definition 4.2 above (using $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$ ) throughout this section. The usual Hodge theory holds true when the underlying manifold is compact. In our case $\Sigma$ is noncompact, so special care should be taken. It turns out that with the special metric $G_{a, m}$, we can still build up a Hodge-type theory for $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$.

In the following we always assume that $m \geq 0$ and " $a$ " is large, say, $a>\frac{m}{2}(\geq 0)$.
Proposition 4.10. (Rellich-type compactness) With the notation above, the inclusion map $\iota: H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s+1}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \rightarrow H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right), s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$, is compact.
Proof. Recall that a partition of unity $\varphi_{j}$ (of noncompact support, with $j$ in a finite index set $J$, on $\Sigma$ satisfying the item $i$ ) after Notation 6.1 of Section 6) is taken. Suppose that $f_{k} \in H_{0, q, m}^{s+1}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ is a bounded sequence where $f_{k}=w^{m}\left(v_{k}\right)_{j}$ in $D_{j}$. We compute

$$
\|\left(v_{k}\right)_{j}\|_{s+1, U_{j}} \stackrel{(4.8)}{=}\left\|f_{k}\right\|_{s+1, D_{j}}^{\prime} \stackrel{(4.10)}{\lesssim}\left\|f_{k}\right\|_{s+1}^{\prime \prime} \stackrel{\text { Lemma } 4.5}{\lesssim}\left\|f_{k}\right\|_{s+1}^{\prime} \leq C
$$

Conditions on $\varphi_{j}$ give that $\hat{U}_{j}:=\overline{\cup_{\theta, \operatorname{supp}} \varphi_{j}\left(\cdot, \theta_{j}\right)} \subset U_{j}$ is a compact subset. Let $\chi_{j}$ be a cutoff function with supp $\chi_{j} \subset U_{j}$ and $\chi_{j}=1$ on $\hat{U}_{j}$. So by (4.14) $\left\|\chi_{j}\left(v_{k}\right)_{j}\right\|_{s+1, U_{j}}$ is bounded for all $k$. It follows from the usual Rellich's compactness lemma that there exists a subsequence $\{\mathrm{k}\} \subset\{k\}$ such that $\chi_{j}\left(v_{\mathrm{k}}\right)_{j}$ is a Cauchy sequence in $\|\cdot\|_{s, U_{j}}$-norm. Since $\left\|\left(v_{\mathrm{k}}\right)_{j}\right\|_{s, \hat{U}_{j}} \leq\left\|\chi_{j}\left(v_{\mathrm{k}}\right)_{j}\right\|_{s, U_{j}}$, more precisely $\left\|\left(v_{\mathrm{k}}\right)_{j}-\left(v_{\mathrm{k}^{\prime}}\right)_{j}\right\|_{s, \hat{U}_{j}} \leq\left\|\chi_{j}\left(v_{\mathrm{k}}\right)_{j}-\chi_{j}\left(v_{\mathrm{k}^{\prime}}\right)_{j}\right\|_{s, U_{j}},\left(v_{\mathrm{k}}\right)_{j}$ is Cauchy in $\|\cdot\|_{s, \hat{U}_{j}}$-norm. By similar arguments with $\left\|\varphi_{j}\left(\cdot, \theta_{j}\right)\left(v_{\mathrm{k}}\right)_{j}(\cdot)\right\|_{s, U_{j}} \lesssim\left\|\left(v_{\mathrm{k}}\right)_{j}\right\|_{s, \hat{U}_{j}}$ (using the definition of $\hat{U}_{j}$ above with the constant independent of $\left.\theta_{j}\right) \varphi_{j}\left(v_{\mathrm{k}}\right)_{j}$ is Cauchy in $\|\cdot\|_{s, U_{j}}$-norm uniformly in $\theta_{j}$ and hence by (4.3) a subsequence of $f_{\mathrm{k}}$ is Cauchy in $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$ due to $j$ $\in$ a finite index set.

Corollary 4.11. (Interpolation inequality) With the notation above and $s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$, we have the following interpolation inequality: given $\varepsilon>0$, there exists $C_{\varepsilon}>0$ such that for all $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s+2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ we have $\|u\|_{s+1}^{\prime} \leq \varepsilon\|u\|_{s+2}^{\prime}+C_{\varepsilon}\|u\|_{0}^{\prime}$.
Proof. By Lemma 4.10, both inclusions in $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s+2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \subset H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s+1}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \subset$ $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 0}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ for $s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$ are compact. The result follows from a general result in functional analysis [3, Theorem 3.77, p.99].

We have elliptic estimates for $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ as shown in the following theorem. Note that $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \subset L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ for $a>\frac{m}{2}$ (see Remark 3.4).
Theorem 4.12. (Transversally elliptic estimate) Fix $m \geq 0$ and $a>\frac{m}{2}$. For every $s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$, there are positive constants $C_{s}, C_{s}^{\prime}$ (depending on $s$ and $m$ with the $m$-dependence suppressed in notation) such that
i)

$$
\|u\|_{s+2}^{\prime} \leq C_{s}\left(\left\|\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u\right\|_{s}^{\prime}+\|u\|_{0}^{\prime}\right)
$$

for all $u \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \subset L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ and

ii) $\|u\|_{s+2}^{\prime} \leq C_{s}^{\prime}\left\|\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u\right\|_{s}^{\prime}$ for all $u \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \cap\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$.

Remark 4.13. It is easily seen that the similar statements and proofs work for $u$ $\in H_{0, q, m}^{s+2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ in place of $u \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$. See the proof of Proposition 4.21 for use of it.

Proof. (of Theorem 4.12) Recall that $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$ denotes the Sobolev $s$-norm on the whole space $\Sigma$ given by (4.3). For $u \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ and writing $\varphi_{j} u=w_{j}^{m} \varphi_{j} v_{j}$, we have

$$
\|u\|_{s+2}^{\prime} \stackrel{(4.3)}{=}\left(\sum_{j} \int_{-\varepsilon_{j}}^{\varepsilon_{j}}\left\|\varphi_{j}\left(\cdot, \theta_{j}\right) v_{j}(\cdot)\right\|_{s+2, U_{j}}^{2} \frac{d \theta_{j}}{2 \pi}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

From $\varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j}=\varphi_{j}\left(\cdot, \theta_{j}\right) v_{j}(\cdot)$ it follows that ( $\theta_{j}$ viewed as a parameter)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\varphi_{j}\left(\cdot, \theta_{j}\right) v_{j}(\cdot)\right\|_{s+2, U_{j}}=\left\|\varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j}\right\|_{s+2, U_{j}} \\
& \lesssim\left\|\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j}\right)\right\|_{s, U_{j}}+\left\|\varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j}\right\|_{0, U_{j}} \\
& \lesssim\left\|\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j}\right)\right\|_{s, U_{j}}+\left\|\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right\|_{D_{j}}\left\|_{s+1, U_{j}}+\right\| \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\left\|_{D_{j}}\right\|_{0, U_{j}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first inequality follows from classical elliptic estimates of $\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}$ for smooth sections with compact support in $U_{j}$. For the RHS of (4.17), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j}\right)\right\|_{s, U_{j}} \quad \lesssim\left\|\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)} u \mid D_{j}\right\|_{s, D_{j}}^{\prime} \\
& =\left\|\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u\right\|_{s, D_{j}}^{\prime} \stackrel{\text { Lem. } 4.8}{\lesssim}\left\|\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u\right\|_{s}^{\prime \prime} \stackrel{\text { Lem. } 4.5}{\lesssim}\left\|\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u\right\|_{s}^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

and similarly, for $l=s+1$ or 0

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right\|_{D_{j}}\left\|_{l, U_{j}} \quad=\quad\right\| v_{j}\left\|_{l, U_{j}}=\right\| u\left\|_{D_{j}}\right\|_{l, D_{j}}^{\prime} \\
& \stackrel{\text { Lem. } 4.8}{\lesssim} \quad\|u\|_{l}^{\prime \prime} \stackrel{\text { Lem. } 4.5}{\lesssim}\|u\|_{l}^{\prime} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting (4.18) and (4.19) into (4.17) and making use of the interpolation inequality (Corollary 4.11), we obtain (4.15) via (4.16).

For the second statement $i i$ ), the argument is similar to the classical one. Since we are in the transversal setting and using the modified norm $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$, we give details for the sake of clarity. Suppose otherwise. That is, for each large integer $k$ there exists $u_{k} \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \cap\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$ such that $\left\|u_{k}\right\|_{s+2}^{\prime}=1$ (by dividing $u_{k}$ by $\left.\left\|u_{k}\right\|_{s+2}^{\prime}\right)$,

$$
\left\|u_{k}\right\|_{s+2}^{\prime} \geq k\left\|\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{k}\right\|_{s}^{\prime}
$$

It follows from (4.20) that $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{k} \rightarrow 0$ in $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$ as $k \rightarrow \infty$. By using the basic weak convergence result with (4.15) there exists a subsequence (still denoted by) $u_{k}$ which weakly converges to $u_{\infty}$ in $\|\cdot\|_{s+2}^{\prime}$ and by Lemma 4.10 (the Rellichtype compactness), strongly converges in the $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$ norm. It follows that $u_{\infty} \in$ $H_{0, q, m}^{r s+2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \cap \operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ so that $<u_{k}, u_{\infty}>_{L^{2}}=0$ as $u_{k} \perp \operatorname{ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ by assumption. Taking $k \rightarrow \infty$ in $<u_{k}, u_{\infty}>=0$ implies $u_{\infty}=0$. On the other hand, by (4.15) we have

$$
1=\left\|u_{k}\right\|_{s+2}^{\prime} \leq C_{s}\left(\left\|\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{k}\right\|_{s}^{\prime}+\left\|u_{k}\right\|_{0}^{\prime}\right)
$$

Taking $k \rightarrow \infty$ in (4.21) and observing that $\left\|u_{k}\right\|_{0}^{\prime} \rightarrow\left\|u_{\infty}\right\|_{0}^{\prime}=0$ and $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{k} \rightarrow$ 0 in $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$ on the RHS of (4.21) by (4.20), we obtain $1 \leq 0$, a contradiction.

The following lemma will soon be used.
Lemma 4.14. (Transversal Gårding's inequality) Fix $m \geq 0$ and a $>\frac{m}{2}$. There exists a constant $C>0$ such that for all $u \in \Omega_{m: q}^{r_{i}(\Sigma)} \subset L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ it holds that

$$
\left(\|u\|_{1}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \leq C\left[\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u, u\right)_{L^{2}}+\left(\|u\|_{0}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

The term $\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u, u\right)_{L^{2}}$ can be replaced by $\left\|\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} u\right\|_{L^{2}}^{2}+\left\|\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} u\right\|_{L^{2}}^{2}$.
Proof. Write $u=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j} u=\sum_{j} w_{j}^{m} \varphi_{j} v_{j}$. To bound $\|u\|_{1}^{\prime}$ we look at $\left\|\varphi_{j}(\cdot, \theta) v_{j}(\cdot)\right\|_{1, U_{j}}^{2}$. By the classical Gårding's inequality e.g. [78, p.348] we have ( $\theta$ viewed as a parameter ranging over a compact interval),

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (4.23)\left\|\varphi_{j}(\cdot, \theta) v_{j}(\cdot)\right\|_{1, U_{j}}^{2}=\left\|\varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right\|_{D_{j}} \|_{1, U_{j}}^{2} \\
& \lesssim\left(\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}}\right), \varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1}\left.u\right|_{D_{j}}\right)_{L^{2}\left(U_{j}\right)}+\left\|\varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right\|_{D_{j}} \|_{0, U_{j}}^{2} \\
& \lesssim\left\|\bar{\partial}_{U_{j}, m}\left(\varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}}\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(U_{j}\right)}^{2}+\left\|\vartheta_{U_{j}, m}\left(\varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}}\right)\left\|_{L^{2}\left(U_{j}\right)}^{2}+\left\|\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right\|_{D_{j}}\right\|_{0, U_{j}}^{2} \\
& \lesssim\left\|\bar{\partial}_{U_{j}, m}\left(\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}}\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(U_{j}\right)}^{2}+\left\|\vartheta_{U_{j}, m}\left(\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}}\right)\left\|_{L^{2}\left(U_{j}\right)}^{2}+\left\|\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right\|_{D_{j}}\right\|_{0, U_{j}}^{2} \\
& \lesssim\left\|\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} u\right\|_{L^{2}(\Sigma)}^{2}+\left\|\vartheta_{\Sigma, m} u\right\|_{L^{2}(\Sigma)}^{2}+\left(\|u\|_{0}^{\prime}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we have used $\left\|\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right\|_{D_{j}} \|_{0, U_{j}}^{2} \lesssim\left(\|u\|_{0}^{\prime}\right)^{2}$ by Lemmas 4.8 and 4.5. Summing over $j$ (finitely many) and integrating over $\theta$ in (4.23) we obtain (4.22) in view of (4.13).

Proposition 4.15. (Transversally elliptic regularity) Fix $m \geq 0$ and $a>\frac{m}{2} \geq$ 0. Take $u \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right) \subset H_{0, q, m}^{s_{0}}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)=L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. Suppose $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u \in$ $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ for $s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$. Then $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s+2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$.
Proof. To simply the notation we use $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}(\Sigma)$ (resp. $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(D_{j}\right), H_{0, q, m}^{s}\left(U_{j}\right)$ ) to denote $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ (resp. $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(D_{j}, G_{a, m}\right), H_{0, q, m}^{s}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\mathrm{s}} L_{\Sigma}^{\mathrm{s}}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$. First we note that the statement

$$
u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s+1}(\Sigma) \text { and } \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}(\Sigma) \text { then } u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s+2}(\Sigma)
$$

implies " $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}(\Sigma)$ then $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s+2}(\Sigma)$ " as claimed in the proposition. This can be easily shown by induction on $s$ : for $s=0 \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u \in L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ and $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 0}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)=L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ gives $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 1}(\Sigma)$ by Gårding's inequality for $H^{\prime 1}$-norms (4.22) with the usual regularization process using the partition of unity as in (4.23) and Remark 4.7 for localization (see for instance [41, p.381]). So by (4.24) we get $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 0+2}(\Sigma)$. For $s=1$ we can make use of the $s=0$ case to get $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 2}(\Sigma)$ and then apply (4.24) for $s=1$ to conclude $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 1+2}(\Sigma)$. The similar reasoning works for $s=2,3, \cdots$.

In the following argument we will prove (4.24). First the assumption in (4.24) and Lemmas 4.8, 4.5 imply $\left.u\right|_{D_{j}} \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s+1}\left(D_{j}\right)$ and $\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left.u\right|_{D_{j}} \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime s}\left(D_{j}, G_{a, m}\right)$ with Remark 4.7. This yields, since $\Psi_{q, m}^{-1}$ induces equivalent Sobolev norms (4.9),

$\left.\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}} \in H_{0, q, m}^{s+1}\left(U_{j}\right), \square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}} \in H_{0, q, m}^{s}\left(U_{j}\right)$ by (4.7). Let $\chi_{j}$ be the cutoff function used in the proof of Proposition 4.10. Observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
(4.25) \square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\chi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}} & =\chi_{j} \square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}} \in+\left[\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}, \chi_{j}\right]\left(\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}} \\
{\left[\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}, \chi_{j}\right]\left(\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}} } & \in H_{0, q, m}^{s}\left(U_{j}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

since $\left[\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}, \chi_{j}\right]$ only takes one derivative and $\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j} \in H_{0, q, m}^{s+1}\left(U_{j}\right)$ as noted above. From (4.25) and the assumption $\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}} \in H_{0, q, m}^{s}\left(U_{j}\right)$, it follows that $\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}\left(\chi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}} \in H_{0, q, m}^{s}\left(U_{j}\right)$. Then the usual local elliptic regularity for $\square_{U_{j}, m}^{(q)}$ (see for instance [41, pp.379-382]) gives $\chi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j} \in H_{0, q, m}^{s+2}\left(U_{j}\right)$. Writing $\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j}=v_{j}$ we compute, for any $-\varepsilon_{j}<\theta_{j}<\varepsilon_{j}$

$$
\left\|\varphi_{j}\left(\cdot, \theta_{j}\right) v_{j}(\cdot)\right\|_{s+2, U_{j}}^{2} \lesssim\left\|v_{j}\right\|_{s+2, \hat{U}_{j}}^{2} \lesssim\left\|\chi_{j} v_{j}\right\|_{s+2, U_{j}}^{2}<\infty
$$

where the constants are independent of $\theta_{j}$, and $\hat{U}_{j}$ is defined after (4.14). It follows from (4.26) that (4.3) is finite and $i i$ ) holds in Definition 4.2 for $s$ replaced by $s+2$. We have shown $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{s+2}(\Sigma)$.

We have the following corollary.
Corollary 4.16. $\bigcap_{s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}} H_{0, q, m}^{s s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)=\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$.
Proof. It suffices to show that the LHS of the formula is contained in the RHS. Suppose $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{s s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. By (4.19) $\left.\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}}$ is in $H^{s}$ over $U_{j}$. So if $u$ is in the LHS of the formula, we obtain that over $U_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j}$ is in $H^{s}$ for all $s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$.
