By the usual Sobolev lemma $\left.\Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u\right|_{D_{j}}$ must be smooth in $U_{j}$. It follows that $u=$ $\sum_{j} \varphi_{j} \Psi_{q, m}^{-1} u \mid D_{j}$ is smooth and belongs to $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$.

Lemma 4.17. For $a>\frac{m}{2} \geq 0$, we have $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)=H_{0, q, m}^{s 2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$.
Proof. For the inclusion put $v=\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u \in F_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\left(=H_{0, q, m}^{s 0}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\right.$ by Remark 4.4). By Proposition 4.15 for $s=0$, we have $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{s 2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. The reverse inclusion can be checked via (4.7) and Definition 4.2.

Lemma 4.18. Let $\mu$ be an eigenvalue of $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$. Then $i)$ The eigenspace $\mathcal{E}_{m, \mu}^{q}(\Sigma):=$ $\left\{\omega \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right): \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} \omega=\mu \omega\right\}$ is finite-dimensional with $\mathcal{E}_{m, \mu}^{q}(\Sigma) \subset \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$. ii) In particular $\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}=\left\{v \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \mid \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} v=0\right\}$ and is finite-dimensional.

Proof. The finite-dimensionality of each eigenspace follows by a similar reasoning as in the classical case by the elliptic estimate (Theorem 4.12) and the Rellichcompactness (Proposition 4.10). The smoothness of eigenfunctions is from Proposition 4.15 and Corollary 4.16.

We are now in a position to carry out a Hodge theory (in a transversal sense) by strategically following the classical approach (nontransversal one) using the above tools formulated in terms of the (modified) Sobolev $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$-norm. However we avoid using the Lax-Milgram theorem in the proof of Lemma 4.19; see Remark 4.20. To define Green's operator we start by proving the following:

Lemma 4.19. Suppose $a>\frac{m}{2} \geq 0$. Denote by $\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$ the orthogonal complement of $\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ in $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. i) For $f \in\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$ there exists a unique solution $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \cap\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$ satisfying $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u=f$. ii) If $f \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \cap\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$ then $u \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \cap\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$.

Proof. $\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ is a closed subspace of $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ by Lemma 4.18 ii). On the other hand $\operatorname{Im} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\left(=\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\left(\operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)\right)\right)$ is perpendicular to $\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ using the definition of $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)$ and Lemma 4.18 ii). Moreover we claim that
(4.27) $\operatorname{Im} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ is a closed subspace of $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\left(i . e \cdot \operatorname{Im} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}=\operatorname{Im} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)$.

Assume $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{j}=f_{j} \rightarrow f$ in $L^{2}$ with $u_{j} \in\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$. We then have a Cauchy sequence $\left\{u_{j}\right\}$ in $\|\cdot\|_{2}^{\prime}$ by Theorem 4.12 ii), Remark 4.13 and Lemma 4.17. So $u_{j} \rightarrow u_{\infty}$ in the $\|\cdot\|_{2}^{\prime}$-norm, and in turn $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{j} \rightarrow \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{\infty}$ in the $\|\cdot\|_{0}^{\prime}$-norm. Since $H^{\prime 0}$ and $L^{2}$ are essentially the same by Remark 4.4, we obtain $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{\infty}=f$, proving $f \in \operatorname{Im} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ as claimed in (4.27).

We are going to show the following (orthogonal) decomposition:

$$
L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)=\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} \oplus \operatorname{Im} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}
$$

Suppose not. Then there exists $f \in L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ such that $f$ is perpendicular to $\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ and $\operatorname{Im} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$. From $f \in\left(\operatorname{Im} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$ one sees that $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} f=0$ in the distribution sense since $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \subset \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)$. Passing to localization $\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)} f\left\|_{D_{j}}\right.$ $=0$ in the distribution sense. By the standard regularity result using (4.7) $\left.f\right|_{D_{j}}$ is smooth (cf. [41, the lemma in p.379]). So $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} f=0$ strongly, giving $f \in \operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$. From that $f$ is perpendicular to $\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ by assumption, it follows $f=0$. We have shown (4.28). The assertion $i$ ) follows easily from (4.28) and Lemma 4.17. The assertion $i i$ ) follows from Proposition 4.15 and Corollary 4.16.

Remark 4.20. In [41, pp.94-95] the solution $u$ in $i$ ) of the above lemma is essentially obtained by the Lax-Milgram theorem (see [78, p. 205 Lemma 23.1]) with an intermediate operator $T$.

By Lemma 4.19 we can now define a linear operator $G_{m}^{(q)}: L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)=H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ ) such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
G_{m}^{(q)}(f) & =u\left(=\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{-1} f \quad \text { for } f \in \operatorname{Im} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\left(\subset L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\right)\right. \text { and } \\
& =0 \quad \text { for } f \in \operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We have the following results about $G_{m}^{(q)}$ and $\operatorname{Spec} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} \subset[0, \infty)$, the spectrum of $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$.

Proposition 4.21. i) $G_{m}^{(q)}$ is a compact, self-adjoint, bounded linear operator on $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. ii) Spec $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} \subset[0, \infty)$ consists only of discrete eigenvalues. iii) We have the orthogonal decomposition $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)=\hat{\oplus}_{\mu} \mathcal{E}_{m, \mu}^{q}(\Sigma)$, with $\mathcal{E}_{m, \mu}^{q}(\Sigma)$ given in Lemma 4.18.

Proof. The boundedness of $i$ ) follows from Theorem 4.12 ii) and the density of $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ in $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ (Notation 4.1). We are going to show that $G_{m}^{(q)}$ is selfadjoint on the space of smooth elements. For $f, g \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ write $f=H f+$ $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{f}$ ( $H$ being the $L^{2}$-projection onto $\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ ) where $u_{f}=G_{m}^{(q)}(f-H f)$. Similarly $g=H g+\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{g}, u_{g}=G_{m}^{(q)}(g-H g)$. Using $u_{f}, u_{g} \in\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(G_{m}^{(q)}(f), g\right)_{L^{2}} & =\left(u_{f}, H g+\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{g}\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(u_{f}, \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{g}\right)_{L^{2}} \\
\left(f, G_{m}^{(q)}(g)\right)_{L^{2}} & =\left(H f+\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{f}, u_{g}\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u_{f}, u_{g}\right)_{L^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

By Lemma 4.18 ii) and Lemma 4.19 ii) we learn that $u_{f}, u_{g} \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$. It follows from (4.12) $\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right.$ being formally self-adjoint) that the right-hand sides in (4.30) coincide, giving $\left(G_{m}^{(q)}(f), g\right)_{L^{2}}=\left(f, G_{m}^{(q)}(g)\right)_{L^{2}}$. As the space of smooth elements is dense in $L^{2}$ and $G_{m}^{(q)}$ is bounded linear, $G_{m}^{(q)}$ is self-adjoint on $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. Combining Theorem 4.12 ii) and Proposition 4.10 yields the compactness of $G_{m}^{(q)}$. To prove $i i$ ) we apply a general theorem [57, p.10] on a compact, self-adjoint, bounded linear operator on a Hilbert space to conclude that $\operatorname{Spec} G_{m}^{(q)}$ hence $\operatorname{Spec} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ consists only of discrete eigenvalues. The assertion iii) is now obvious.

Define the $m$-th Fourier-Dolbeault cohomology group or $m$-th $\mathbb{C}^{*} \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}$-cohomology group as follows:

$$
H_{m}^{q}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O}):=\frac{\operatorname{Ker} \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}: \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, q+1}(\Sigma)}{\operatorname{Im} \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}: \Omega_{m}^{0, q-1}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)}
$$

Denote $\left.\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}\right|_{\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)}$ by $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$. We call the complex $\left(\Omega_{m}^{0}, \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}^{(\cdot)}\right)$ the $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}$-complex and define its index by

$$
\operatorname{index}\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \text {-complex }\right):=\sum_{q=0}^{n}(-1)^{q} \operatorname{dim} H_{m}^{q}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})
$$

provided that each $H_{m}^{q}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})$ is finite-dimensional.
We have the following Hodge theorem for $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ on the noncompact $\Sigma$.
Theorem 4.22. For each $q \in\{0,1,2, \ldots, n\}, m \geq 0$ and $a>\frac{m}{2}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} G_{m}^{(q)}+P_{m, 0}^{(q)}=I \text { on } L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \\
& G_{m}^{(q)} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}+P_{m, 0}^{(q)}=I \text { on } \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)\left(=H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\right. \text { by Lemma 4.17) }
\end{aligned}
$$

where $G_{m}^{(q)}$ as defined in (4.29) is called the Green's operator, and $P_{m, 0}^{(q)}: L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ $\rightarrow \operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ is the orthogonal projection (denoted by $H$ previously). Moreover, we have $\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}=\mathcal{E}_{m, 0}^{q}(\Sigma) \cong H_{m}^{q}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})$. As a consequence $\operatorname{dim} H_{m}^{q}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})<\infty$ by Proposition 4.21.

Note that for the case of $m<0$ we refer to Remark 1.2.
Denote $\Omega_{m}^{0,+}(\Sigma)=\oplus_{\text {even } q} \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ and $\Omega_{m}^{0,-}(\Sigma)=\oplus_{\text {odd } q} \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$; similar notations are adopted for $L_{m}^{2,+}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ and $L_{m}^{2,-}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ out of $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$.

Let

$$
D_{m}^{+}:=\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}+\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}: \Omega_{m}^{0,+}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0,-}(\Sigma)
$$

with extension $D_{m}^{+}: \operatorname{Dom}\left(D_{m}^{+}\right)\left(\subset L_{m}^{2,+}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\right) \rightarrow L_{m}^{2,-}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ (by acting in the sense of distribution). Define the formal adjoint $\mathfrak{D}_{m}^{+}$of $D_{m}^{+}$in the way similar to $\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}$. By similar arguments as in the classical theory we have

Lemma 4.23. With the notation above we have

$$
\operatorname{Ker} D_{m}^{+}=\oplus_{\text {even } q} \operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} \subset \Omega_{m}^{0,+}(\Sigma) ; \operatorname{Ker} \mathfrak{D}_{m}^{+}=\oplus_{\text {odd } q} \operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} \subset \Omega_{m}^{0,-}(\Sigma)
$$

We have now that both $\operatorname{Ker} D_{m}^{+}$and $\operatorname{Ker} \mathfrak{D}_{m}^{+}$are finite-dimensional (Proposition 4.21 and Lemma 4.23). The index of $D_{m}^{+}$, denoted as $\operatorname{index}\left(D_{m}^{+}\right)$, is defined by

$$
\operatorname{index}\left(D_{m}^{+}\right):=\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} D_{m}^{+}-\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} \mathfrak{D}_{m}^{+}
$$

As usual Coker $D_{m}^{+}=\operatorname{Ker} \mathfrak{D}_{m}^{+}$. With Theorem 4.22 and Lemma 4.23 we have:
Corollary 4.24. index $\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}\right.$-complex $)=\operatorname{index}\left(D_{m}^{+}\right)=\sum_{q: \text { even }} \operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}-$ $\sum_{q: \text { odd }} \operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$.

Remark 4.25. It is possible to study the Hilbert space adjoint $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q) *}$ [17, pp.63-64] including its domain $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)^{*}}\right) \subset L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\left(\right.$ resp. $\left.\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}^{*}\right.$ and $\left.\operatorname{Dom}\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}^{*}\right)\right)$. One may show that $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ is (Hilbert space) self-adjoint, densely defined on a Hilbert space. In an abstract Hilbert space setting there are some basic material, for example, [62, Theorem C.2.1], [72, Theorem 13.30, p.348] and [29, Lemma 8.4.1] on the spectral analysis of a general self-adjoint operator, which might provide an alternative approach to Theorem 4.22. We leave the detail to the interested reader.

Remark 4.26. In connection with Remark 4.7 for localization, suppose $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} u=f$ in the distribution sense (see the 5 th line below (4.1)) where $u, f \in L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. Then one sees via definition that $f \perp \operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ so that $f=\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)} v$ for some $v \in$ $H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \cap\left(\operatorname{Ker} \square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}\right)^{\perp}$ using (4.28). It follows that $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}(v-u)=0$ in the distribution sense, which implies $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}(v-u)=0$ strongly (see lines below (4.28)), giving $u \in H_{0, q, m}^{\prime 2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ by Lemma 4.17. So the localization $\chi u \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\square_{D_{j}, m}^{(q)}\right)$ remains true. Remark that a localization result of similar nature is claimed in [41, p.380]; however, the detail is given only for their first-order operator $P$.

# 5. Transversally spin ${ }^{c}$ Dirac operators 

To compute $\sum_{q=0}^{n}(-1)^{q} h_{m}^{q}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})$ we are reduced to computing $\operatorname{index}\left(D_{m}^{+}\right)$by Corollary 4.24. To do it effectively we want to modify $D_{m}^{+}$so that the associated modified Laplacian has a manageable heat kernel. This modification becomes indispensable for us in dealing with the non-Kähler case. It will follow that index $\left(D_{m}^{+}\right)$ equals the index of a modified operator, to be denoted by $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}$. In fact the new operator $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}$ will be taken to be an $m$-th spin ${ }^{c}$ Dirac operator in the transversal sense closely related to the one described in [62] (yet in a different context).

The construction of $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}$ is first done locally; this local part is standard as in the classical sense. However, due to our transversal setting here some extra work will be needed to patch up those local constructions and form a global operator $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}$ on $\Sigma$. Then it turns out by computation that the chosen metrical structure in Section 3 makes it possible to compare the operator $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}$ constructed here with a natural $s p i n^{c}$ Dirac operator $D_{M_{0}, m}^{c+}$ at least on the principal stratum $M_{0}$ of the orbifold $M$

$=\Sigma / \sigma$; see Proposition 5.3, also Remarks 6.20, 10.9, 10.10 for issues of descent to the entire $M$. This part of computation is perhaps less geometrically illuminating than the preceding local-to-global construction.

Let us now start by choosing a local orthonormal frame $\left\{e_{2 j-1}, e_{2 j}\right\}_{1 \leq j \leq n}$ with respect to the metric $G_{a, m}$ (see (3.21) in Section 3) such that

$$
Z_{j}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(e_{2 j-1}-i e_{2 j}\right) ; Z_{j}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(e_{2 j-1}+i e_{2 j}\right) \quad 1 \leq j \leq n
$$

form a local unitary frame of $T^{1,0}(\Sigma)$ and $T^{0,1}(\Sigma)$ respectively. As is well known, one has the "Clifford multiplication" (or action) $c\left(e_{k}\right)$ on $\Lambda\left(T^{* 0,1} \Sigma\right):=\oplus_{q=0}^{n} T^{* 0, q} \Sigma$ and "Clifford connection" $\nabla_{e_{k}}^{C l}$ acting on $\Omega^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ (see [62, Chapter 1]). These are given only in the transversal parts (see (5.1)) and not in the standard Clifford setting. The spin ${ }^{c}$ Dirac operator $D^{c}$ on $\Sigma$ is defined by $D^{c}=1 / \sqrt{2} \sum_{k=1}^{2 n} c\left(e_{k}\right) \nabla_{e_{k}}^{C l}$ : $\Omega^{0, *}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ and is formally self-adjoint. Denote by $D^{c \pm}$the restriction $\left.D^{c}\right|_{\Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)}$. We have

$$
D^{c \pm}=\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma}+\vartheta_{\Sigma}+A^{c \pm}: \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, \mp}(\Sigma)
$$

where $A^{c \pm}: \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, \mp}(\Sigma)$ is a self-adjoint zeroth order operator and $A^{c \pm}=$ $\frac{1}{4}^{c}\left(T_{a s}\right)([62,(1.4 .17)])$.

The elements of the form (2.25) are not going to be preserved under the action of ${ }^{c}\left(T_{a s}\right)$ (cf. [62, (1.2.48) for $\left.T_{a s}\right]$ ). We would like to replace $A^{c \pm}$by another zeroth order operator which can preserve $\Omega_{m}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$. This is done as follows.

Let us first treat the globally free case $\Sigma=\hat{L} \backslash\{0$-section $\}=: \hat{L}^{\prime}$ (see Example 2.2 ii) for $\hat{L}$ ), and consider the standard spin ${ }^{c}$ Dirac operator on $M$ with $\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$-value: $D_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}^{c}=\bar{\partial}_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}+\vartheta_{M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}+A_{M, m}^{c}$ where $A_{M, m}^{c}$ maps $\Omega^{0, \pm}\left(M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ into $\Omega^{0, \mp}\left(M,\left(L^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ and is self-adjoint (on $\Omega^{0, *}=\Omega^{0,+} \oplus \Omega^{0,-}$ ). Here we adopt the metric $g_{M}$ for $M$ (cf. (3.9)); $\vartheta_{M}, \vartheta_{M, m}$ are as in Notation 3.7 and Definition 3.8. Proposition 2.9 yields a corresponding map on $\hat{L}^{\prime}$

$$
\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}:=\psi_{\mp, m} \circ A_{M, m}^{c} \circ \psi_{\pm, m}^{-1}: \Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}\left(\hat{L}^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, \mp}\left(\hat{L}^{\prime}\right)
$$

By abuse of notation, write

$$
C_{M, m}\left(h_{I_{q}}(z, \bar{z}) d \bar{z}^{I_{q}}\right):=\frac{A_{M, m}^{c}\left(h_{I_{q}}(z, \bar{z}) d \bar{z}^{I_{q}} \otimes\left(e^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)}{\left(e^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}}
$$

Note that this depends on the choice of the local section $e^{*}$ of $L^{*}$. In $(z, w), \tilde{A}_{m}^{c}$ acts on $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}\left(\hat{L}^{\prime}\right)$ by

$$
\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}\left(w^{m} h_{I_{q}}(z, \bar{z}) d \bar{z}^{I_{q}}\right)=w^{m} C_{M, m}\left(h_{I_{q}}(z, \bar{z}) d \bar{z}^{I_{q}}\right)
$$

Note that (5.4) here is invariantly defined by (5.3). The key observation that makes our construction of global transversal operators well defined, is based on the following:

Lemma 5.1. For general $\Sigma$ as before, the above (5.4) works unchangeably if $M$ is replaced by $U_{j}$ and $z, w$ are distinguished local holomorphic coordinates in (2.6). Thus if now define $\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}: \Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, \mp}(\Sigma)$ by using (5.4), $\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}$ is independent of the choice of local holomorphic coordinates and is self-adjoint on $\Omega_{m}^{0, *}(\Sigma)\left(=\right.$ $\left.\Omega_{m}^{0,+} \oplus \Omega_{m}^{0,-}\right)$.

Proof. We note that the local transformation law (2.3) of Proposition 2.1, together with (2.27), is similar to that of the case $\Sigma=\hat{L}^{\prime}$ in local expressions. Hence the first assertion of the lemma "almost" follows from the remark after (5.4). The point is that it is not quite automatic that the image of $\hat{A}_{m}^{c}$ so defined is contained in the $m$-space under consideration (the image lies in $\Omega^{0, \mp}(\Sigma)$ nevertheless), due to the local freeness of $\sigma$ (see case $i i$ ) after (6.82) in Section 6). But one can bypass this issue by first considering it on the principal stratum $\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ (similar to (5.3) for $\hat{L}^{\prime}$ ) then the assertion holds across $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ by argument of continuity (since $\hat{A}_{m}^{c}$ is global on $\Sigma$ as just mentioned). Compare the proof of Proposition 3.11. For the self-adjointness of $\hat{A}_{m}^{c}$, the treatment is similar to and simpler than Proposition 3.12 because $\hat{A}_{m}^{c}$ is of zeroth order.

Definition 5.2. (transversally spin ${ }^{c}$ Dirac operator) Define $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c \pm}$ (as a "transversally" spin ${ }^{c}$ Dirac operator) by, with $\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}$ in Lemma 5.1

$$
\tilde{D}_{m}^{c \pm}:=\tilde{D}_{m}^{c}=\tilde{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}+\vartheta_{\Sigma, m}+\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}: \Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, \mp}(\Sigma)
$$

$\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}$ is not directly linked to $A^{c}$ of (5.2); the "tilde" in $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c}$ is used to match that of $\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}$.

Let $\tilde{\vartheta}_{m}^{c}$ denote the formal adjoint of $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c}$ (cf. Notation 3.7). The self-adjointness $\tilde{\vartheta}_{m}^{c}=\tilde{D}_{m}^{c}$ follows from Lemma $5.1\left(\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}\right.$ is self-adjoint). Let $D_{U_{j}, m}^{c \pm}:=\bar{\partial}_{U_{j}, m}+\vartheta_{U_{j}, m}+$ $A_{U_{j}, m}^{c}: \Omega^{0,+}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \rightarrow \Omega^{0,-}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ be the spin ${ }^{c}$ Dirac operator on $U_{j}$ with bundle $\left.\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right|_{U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}$ (see (2.11) for $\left.\psi_{j}\right)$. Here the metric on $U_{j}$ is $\left.\pi^{*} g_{M}\right|_{T\left(U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right)}$ rather than $\left.G_{a, m}\right|_{T\left(U_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right)}$, and the metric on $L_{\Sigma}$ is $<\cdot, \cdot>$ (lines above (3.3)). We define the following spin ${ }^{c}$ Laplacians of Kodaira type by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { i) } \tilde{\square}_{m}^{c} & :=\tilde{\vartheta}_{m}^{c} \tilde{D}_{m}^{c}=\left(\tilde{D}_{m}^{c}\right)^{2}: \Omega_{m}^{0, *}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, *}(\Sigma) \\
\text { ii) } \tilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm} & :=\tilde{D}_{m}^{c \mp} \tilde{D}_{m}^{c \pm}: \Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \\
\text { iii) } \square_{U_{j}, m}^{c \pm} & :=D_{U_{j}, m}^{c \mp} D_{U_{j}, m}^{c \pm}: \Omega^{0, \pm}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, \pm}\left(U_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*} L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark that the notation $\square_{m}$ (or $\square_{\Sigma, m}$ ) is reserved for $\bar{\partial}_{m} \vartheta_{m}+\vartheta_{m} \bar{\partial}_{m}$ (4.1).
Our first main result Proposition 3.12 in Section 3 yields the following
Proposition 5.3. Restricted to $D_{j} \subset \Sigma$, we have $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c \pm}=\Psi_{\mp, m} \circ D_{U_{j}, m}^{c \pm} \circ \Psi_{\pm, m}^{-1}$ (see (3.32) for the definition of $\Psi_{\mp, m}$ ) and $\tilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm}=\Psi_{\mp, m} \circ \square_{U_{j}, m}^{c \pm} \circ \Psi_{\pm, m}^{-1}$.

Proof. Restricted to $D_{j} \subset \Sigma$, the assertions readily follow from Propositions 3.11, 3.12 and Lemma 5.1.

The above result is crucial for us to construct an approximation of transversal heat kernel (cf. (6.5)).

In the remaining of this section, we shall focus on the geometry of $\tilde{\square}_{m}^{c}$ (spectral aspects) and culminate in a McKean-Singer type formula (cf. Proposition 5.10 and Theorem 5.12).

We now extend $\tilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm}: \operatorname{Dom} \tilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm}\left(\subset L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\right) \rightarrow L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ (by acting in the sense of distribution). Here $L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ is as given in the line above (4.32).

Lemma 5.4. $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v}$ satisfies the transversally elliptic estimate as in the statements of Theorem 4.12 ( $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v}$ in place of $\square_{\Sigma, m}^{(q)}$ there).

Proof. The transversal ellipticity of $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v}$ follows from the ellipticity of $\square_{U_{j}, m}^{v \pm}$ via arguments similar to those in the proof of Theorem 4.12.

Denote by $H_{m}^{\prime s,+}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ (resp. $H_{m}^{\prime s,-}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ ) the even (resp. odd) part of Sobolev spaces $H_{0,*, m}^{\prime s}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. In the same vein as Lemmas 4.17 and 4.9, we have Dom $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v \pm}=H_{m}^{Q, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ and $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v \pm}$ are positive, formally self-adjoint.

Proposition 5.5. For $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v \pm}$, the corresponding statements in Proposition 4.21 and Lemma 4.18 hold true. Moreover, with obvious modifications of notation Spec $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v+} \cap$ $(0, \infty)=$ Spec $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v-} \cap(0, \infty)$, and $\operatorname{dim} \check{\mathcal{E}}_{m, \mu}^{+}(\Sigma)=\operatorname{dim} \check{\mathcal{E}}_{m, \mu}^{-}(\Sigma)$ for each $0 \neq \mu \in$ $\operatorname{Spec} \widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v+}$.

Remark 5.6. As an analogue of holomorphic tangents in the CR case via Example 2.2, we make the following definition. Let $\mathcal{E}_{M}$ denote the (orbifold) bundle of all $(0, q)$-forms on $M$. Let $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ be the pullback bundle over $\Sigma$, where $\pi: \Sigma$ $\rightarrow M:=\Sigma / \sigma$ is the natural projection. Since the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma$ is locally free, one sees that $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ embeds naturally as a subbundle of the bundle $\Lambda^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ of all $(0, q)$-forms on $\Sigma$. Consider the $L^{2}$-completion of smooth sections of $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ with compact support over $\Sigma$ with respect to the metric $G_{a, m}, a>\frac{m}{\rho} \geq 0$, denoted by $L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ or $L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ for short. Consider $L_{m}^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ to be the direct sum of $L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ for all $q$ (see Notation 4.1 for the definition of $\left.L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)\right)$. By the definition of $\Omega_{m}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ (cf. Definition $2.8 i i$ )) we have that $L_{m}^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \subset L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ (see Lemma 5.7). As an alternative choice of metric on $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ it is natural to use the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant Hermitian metric $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ (see Notation 3.1). It turns out that $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ on $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ is the same as $G_{a, m} \mid \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ (cf. Lemma 8.10 i)). Let

$$
\pi_{m}: L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right) \rightarrow L_{m}^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \subset L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)
$$

denote the orthogonal projection onto the $m$-space $L_{m}^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ or $L_{m}^{2, *}(\Sigma)$ for short with respect to the metric $G_{a, m}$ or $\pi^{*} g_{M}$. See Proposition 6.6 below for more about $\pi_{m}$.

Lemma 5.7. With the notation above, we have $L_{m}^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \subset L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$.
Proof. First we claim that $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma) \subset L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$. Write $u \in \Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ as $u=$ $\sum_{j} \varphi_{j} u$ with $\varphi_{j} u=w^{m} \varphi_{j} v_{j}(z, \bar{z})$ for $C^{\infty}$-smooth $(0, q)$-forms $v_{j}$ on $U_{j}$ (see the beginning of Section 4 for the notation). Let $\chi_{k}(|w|)$ be a cut-off function which equals 1 for $|w| \leq k$ and 0 for $|w|>k+1$. It is not difficult to see that $\chi_{k}(|w|) w^{m} \varphi_{j} v_{j}(z, \bar{z})$ (which is smooth and of compact support) tends to $w^{m} \varphi_{j} v_{j}(z, \bar{z})=\varphi_{j} u$ in $L^{2}$ in view of Remark 3.4. So $\varphi_{j} u$ (hence $u$ ) $\in L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ by definition. We have shown the claim. It follows that $L_{m}^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$, the $L^{2}$-closure of $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$, should also be included in $L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$.

For $\nu \in \operatorname{Spec} \widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v \pm}$ let $\check{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}: L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right) \rightarrow \check{\mathcal{E}}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}(\Sigma) \subset L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ denote the orthogonal projections. Denote the distribution kernels of $\check{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}$ by $\check{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}(x, y)\left(\in C^{\infty}\left(\Sigma \times \Sigma, T^{* 0, \pm} \Sigma \boxtimes\left(T^{* 0, \pm} \Sigma\right)^{*}\right)\right.$.

Proposition 5.8. Define the heat kernels of $\widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v+}$ and $\widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v-}$ to be

$$
e^{-t \widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v+}}(x, y):=\tilde{P}_{m, 0}^{ \pm}(x, y)+\sum_{\nu \in \operatorname{Spec} \widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v+}, \nu>0} e^{-\nu t} \tilde{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}(x, y)
$$

Then for a fixed $t>0 e^{-t \widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v+}}$ is a bounded linear operator on $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$, which maps $\Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ into $\Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \subset L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$. Moreover, $e^{-t \widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v+}}$ in (5.8) are (Hilbert space) self-adjoint and the kernel functions are infinitely smooth. They satisfy

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\frac{\partial}{\partial t}+\widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v \pm}\right)\left(e^{-t \widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v+}} u\right)=0, \forall t>0 \\
& e^{-t \widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v+}} u \rightarrow \pi_{m}^{ \pm} u \text { in } L^{2} \text { as } t \rightarrow 0 \quad \forall u \in \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\pi_{m}^{ \pm}: L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right) \rightarrow L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ is the orthogonal projection.
Remark 5.9. Although the uniqueness part can be done here, it is postponed until Theorem $6.18 i$ ) for the sake of convenience.

Proof. (of Proposition 5.8) We need to show that the kernel functions $e^{-t \widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v \pm}}(x, y)$ are infinitely smooth. The other statements are immediate (cf. the last paragraph of this proof with references, via the first half of Proposition 5.5 above). First we prove that the eigenvalues $0<\nu_{1} \leq \nu_{2} \leq \ldots \nu_{n} \leq \ldots$ of $\widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v \pm}$ (counting multiplicity) satisfy the growth rate as follows:

$$
\nu_{n} \geq C n^{\delta} \text { for a constant } C>0 \text { and an exponent } \delta>0
$$

if $n>n_{0}$ is large (see Lemmas 1.6.3 and 1.6.5 in [38]). The proof in [38] for elliptic operators on a compact manifold needs to be modified as shown below.

Let $\left\{\omega_{j}^{ \pm}\right\}$denote a complete orthonormal basis for $L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ such that $\widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v \pm} \omega_{j}^{ \pm}=\nu_{j} \omega_{j}^{ \pm}$by Proposition 5.5 above. For $f \in \Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$ we observe the following estimate:

$$
|f(x)| \leq C l(x)^{m / 2}\|f\|_{C_{D}^{n}}
$$

(see (6.7) for the definition of the norm $\|\cdot\|_{C_{D}^{n}}$ and (3.4) for $l(x)$ ). We have the following (recalling the notation $\lesssim$ meaning "the inequality $\leq$ holds modulo some multiplicative constant"), where for the first inequality we are applying the usual Sobolev embedding (after choosing $k$ such that $k \cdot 2>\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{R}}\left(\Sigma / \mathbb{C}^{*}\right) / 2=n-1$ ) together with using (4.9), Lemmas 4.8 and 4.5,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \|f\|_{C_{D}^{n}} \quad \underset{\text { Lemma } 5.4}{\lesssim} \quad\|f\|_{2 k}^{\prime} \underset{\text { Lemma } 5.4}{\lesssim} \| \widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v \pm} f\left\|_{2 k-2}^{\prime}+\right\| f \|_{0}^{\prime} \\
& \underset{\text { ( } 5.4}{\text { Lemma } 5.4} \quad\left\|\left(\widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v \pm}\right)^{k} f\right\|_{0}^{\prime}+\left\|\left(\widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v \pm}\right)^{k-1} f\right\|_{0}^{\prime}+\ldots+\|f\|_{0}^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

in the Sobolev $s$-norm $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{\prime}$ on $\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. Remark that the bundle $\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ implicitly involved in (5.12), (4.9) does not really matter with the preceding estimate.

The interpolation inequality (Corollary 4.11) brings (5.12) to

$$
\|f\|_{C_{D}^{n}} \lesssim\left\|\left(\widetilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m}^{v \pm}\right)^{k} f\right\|_{0}^{\prime}+\|f\|_{0}^{\prime}
$$

Taking $f=\sum_{j=1}^{n} c_{j} \omega_{j}^{ \pm}$in (5.13) and (5.11) gives (recalling that $\left\{\omega_{j}^{ \pm}\right\}$is orthonormal w.r.t. the $L^{2}$-norm $\|\cdot\|_{0}$ which is equivalent to $\|\cdot\|_{0}^{t}$ by Remark 4.4)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leq C_{1} l(x)^{m / 2}\left(\left\|\sum_{j=1}^{n} c_{j} \nu_{j}^{k} \omega_{j}^{ \pm}\right\|_{0}+\left\|\sum_{j=1}^{n} c_{j} \omega_{j}^{ \pm}\right\|_{0}\right) \\
& \leq C_{1} l(x)^{m / 2}\left(\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left|c_{j} \nu_{j}^{k}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}+\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left|c_{j}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}\right) \\
& \leq C_{1} l(x)^{m / 2}\left(\left|\nu_{n}\right|^{k}+1\right)\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left|c_{j}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Letting $c_{j}=\bar{\omega}_{j}^{ \pm}(x)$ in (5.14), squaring, cancelling off $\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left|c_{j}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}$ on both sides and integrating over $\Sigma$, we get

$$
n \leq C_{1}^{2}\left(\left|\nu_{n}\right|^{k}+1\right)^{2} \int_{\Sigma} l(x)^{m} d v_{\Sigma, m}
$$

By observing that

$$
\int_{\Sigma} l(x)^{m} d v_{\Sigma, m} \stackrel{(3.22)}{=} \int_{M \backslash M_{\text {sing }}} d v_{M} \int_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} l\right)^{m} \tau_{x}^{*}\left(d v_{f, m}\right) \stackrel{(3.27)}{=} \operatorname{Vol}(M) \cdot 1
$$

is finite, where $M_{\text {sing }}$ denotes the set of singular orbifold points in $M=\Sigma / \sigma$ (of measure zero), we reach (5.10) with $\delta=\frac{1}{2 k}$ from (5.15).

To show that the kernel functions $e^{-\imath \hat{\omega}_{m}^{v \pm}}(x, y)$ are infinitely smooth from the growth rate of $\nu_{n}$ in (5.10), we imitate the arguments in [38, pp.53-55] by using the norm $\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{*}}$ in place of the supreme $s$-norm in [38]. It is seen that the $C_{B}^{*}$-norms are suitable here, since the functions in our $m$-space are of the special form (6.4) of Section 6. Note that corresponding to [38, b) of Lemma 1.6.3, p.51] one can show similarly that $\left\|\omega_{j}^{ \pm}\right\|_{C_{B}^{*}} \lesssim 1+\left|\lambda_{j}\right|^{l(s)}$ from (5.10) and (5.12) (generalized from $C_{B}^{0}$ to $C_{B}^{l}$ ), and that (5.8) is the analogous expression in [38, Lemma 1.6.5, p.55]. These observations (together with the form of expressions (3.31), (3.30); see also (6.4) which reduces the study (transversal case) to that on $z$-spaces (elliptic case)) yield the desired smoothness of (5.8) as in [38]. The convergence of $e^{-\imath \hat{\omega}_{m}^{v \pm}} u$ is treated similarly. We leave the details to the reader.

For the remaining properties of $e^{-\imath \hat{\omega}_{m}^{v \pm}}$ claimed in the proposition, we observe that for $u \in \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$

$$
\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial t}+\hat{\psi}_{m}^{v \pm}\right)\left(e^{-\nu t} \hat{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm} u\right)=-\nu e^{-\nu t} \hat{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm} u+e^{-\nu t} \nu \hat{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm} u=0
$$

The first equation in (5.9) follows since one sees that taking differentiation in $t$ or $x$ commutes with the infinite sum of kernel functions of projectors (for a fixed $t>0$ ). For the second formula of (5.9) writing $u=\sum_{j} a_{j} \omega_{j}^{ \pm}$we have

$$
e^{-\imath \hat{\omega}_{m}^{v \pm}} u-\pi_{m} u=\sum_{\nu \in \operatorname{Spec} \hat{\omega}_{m}^{v \pm}}\left(e^{-\nu t}-1\right) \hat{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm} u=\sum_{\nu \in \operatorname{Spec} \hat{\omega}_{m}^{v \pm}}\left(e^{-\nu t}-1\right) a_{\nu} \omega_{\nu}^{ \pm}
$$

Note that $e^{-\nu t}-1$ in (5.16) is bounded by 1 since $\nu \geq 0 . \sum_{\nu} a_{\nu}^{2}$ is bounded, so for a large $N: \sum_{\nu \geq N} a_{\nu}^{2}$ is small. For a finite sum $\lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \sum_{\nu<N}\left(e^{-\nu t}-1\right) a_{\nu} \omega_{\nu}^{ \pm}=$ $\sum_{\nu<N} \lim _{t \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{-\nu t}-1\right) a_{\nu} \omega_{\nu}^{ \pm}=0$. Altogether $e^{-\imath \hat{\omega}_{m}^{v \pm}} u-\pi_{m} u \rightarrow 0$ in $L^{2}$ as $t \rightarrow 0$.

One sees that $\left\|e^{-t \tilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}} u\right\|_{L^{2}} \leq\left(\sum_{\nu \in \operatorname{Spec} \tilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}} e^{-\nu t}\right)\|u\|_{L^{2}}$, so $e^{-t \tilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}$ is bounded by (5.10). The self-adjointness of $e^{-t \tilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}$ follows from that each $\tilde{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}$is self-adjoint and the infinite sum of $\tilde{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm *}$ converges to $\left(e^{-t \tilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}\right)^{*}$.

For $\nu \in \operatorname{Spec} \tilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}$, let $\left\{f_{1}^{\nu}, \ldots, f_{d_{v}^{\pm}}^{\nu}\right\}$ be an orthonormal basis for $\tilde{\mathcal{C}}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}(\Sigma)$. Define the trace of $\tilde{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}(x, x)$ by $\operatorname{Tr} \tilde{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}(x, x):=\sum_{j=1}^{d_{v}^{\pm}}\left|f_{j}^{v}(x)\right|^{2} \in C^{\infty}(\Sigma)$ which equals $\sum_{j=1}^{d^{ \pm}}<\tilde{P}_{m, \nu}^{ \pm}(x, x) e_{j}(x) \mid e_{j}(x)>_{G_{a, m}}$ where $\left\{e_{j}(x)\right\}_{j=1, \ldots, d^{ \pm}}$is any orthonormal basis of $T_{x}^{* 0, \pm} \Sigma$. From Propositions $5.8,5.5$ and Lemma 4.23 (for $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c \pm}$ and $\tilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}$ ) it follows
Proposition 5.10. (Formula of McKean-Singer type for index $\left(\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}\right)$ ) For each $t>0$ we have

$$
\operatorname{index}\left(\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}\right)=\int_{\Sigma}\left[\operatorname{Tr} e^{-t \tilde{C}_{m}^{v+}}(x, x)-\operatorname{Tr} e^{-t \tilde{C}_{m}^{v-}}(x, x)\right] d v_{\Sigma, m}
$$

Recall $D_{m}^{+}$of (4.32). To compare index $\left(D_{m}^{+}\right)$with index $\left(\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}\right)$, we have the following homotopy invariance. Here our Hodge theory in Section 4 provides a useful tool in the proof below.
Lemma 5.11. (Homotopy invariance) index $\left(D_{m}^{+}\right)=\operatorname{index}\left(\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}\right)$.
Proof. Despite that our operators are of "transversal" type in the sense as constructed in this subsection, the arguments are essentially classical in spirit. The key point is to make sure that the noncompactness of $\Sigma$ endowed with our various geometric data does no essential harm to those arguments that are valid for compact manifolds. We sketch the idea of the proof; for more details and references, the reader is referred to the proof of [18, Theorem 4.7] in a similar vein.

From (4.32) and (5.5), we have $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}=D_{m}^{+}+\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}$ where $\tilde{A}_{m}^{c}: \Omega_{m}^{0,+}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0,-}(\Sigma)$ is a bounded linear operator of zeroth order. A homotopy between $L_{0}=D_{m}^{+}$and $L_{1}$ $=\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}$ can be realized by $L_{t}:=D_{m}^{+}+t \tilde{A}_{m}^{c}=\tilde{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}+\tilde{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}^{c}+t \tilde{A}_{m}^{c}: \Omega_{m}^{0,+}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega_{m}^{0,-}(\Sigma)$ for $t \in[0,1]$. Extending $L_{t}$ to $\operatorname{Dom}\left(L_{t}\right) \subset L_{0,+, m}^{2}:=\oplus_{q: \text { even }} L_{0, q, m}^{2}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$, one can show that $\operatorname{Dom}\left(L_{t}\right)=H_{0,+, m}^{\prime 1}:=L_{0,+, m}^{2} \cap H_{0,+}^{\prime 1}$ where $H_{0,+}^{\prime 1}:=\oplus_{q: \text { even }} H_{0, q}^{\prime 1}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ (cf. (4.3) for the notation).

Now consider $\mathcal{H}_{0}:=H_{0,+, m}^{\prime 1} \oplus \operatorname{Ker} L_{0}^{*}$ and $\mathcal{H}_{1}:=L_{0,-, m}^{2} \oplus \operatorname{Ker} L_{0}$. Let $A_{t}: \mathcal{H}_{0}$ $\rightarrow \mathcal{H}_{1}$ be the bounded linear map defined by $A_{t}(u, v)=\left(L_{t} u+v, P_{\text {Ker } L_{0}} u\right) \in \mathcal{H}_{1}$ for $(u, v) \in \mathcal{H}_{0}$, where $P_{\text {Ker } L_{0}}$ denotes the orthogonal projection onto $\operatorname{Ker} L_{0}$. We claim the following fact:

$$
\exists r_{0}>0 \text { such that } A_{t} \text { is invertible for every } 0 \leq t \leq r_{0}
$$

For $t=0$, the fact that $A_{0}$ is invertible follows from the Hodge theory for $L_{0}=D_{m}^{+}$ (cf. Theorem 4.22). For $t \neq 0$, write $A_{t}=A_{0}+R_{t}$ so that $\left\|R_{t} u\right\|_{\mathcal{H}_{t}} \leq C t\|u\|_{\mathcal{H}_{0}}$. We can then construct the inverse of $A_{t}$ by the Neuman series for small $t$, proving (5.17).

We claim another fact: (In the remaining of the proof, we use "ind" as abbreviation of "index".)

$$
\exists r>0 \text { such that ind } L_{t}=\text { ind } L_{0} \text { for every } 0 \leq t \leq r
$$

For $0 \leq t \leq r_{0}$ in (5.17) we define $B_{t}: \operatorname{Ker} L_{t}^{*} \oplus \operatorname{Ker} L_{0} \rightarrow \operatorname{Ker} L_{t} \oplus \operatorname{Ker} L_{0}^{*}$ by $B_{t}(a, b):=\left(P_{\text {Ker } L_{t}} u, v\right) \in \operatorname{Ker} L_{t} \oplus \operatorname{Ker} L_{0}^{*}$ where $(u, v)=A_{t}^{-1}(a, b)$. It is

not hard to see that $B_{t}$ is injective. It follows that $\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} L_{t}^{*}+\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} L_{0} \leq$ $\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} L_{t}+\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} L_{0}^{*}$. Hence ind $L_{0}:=\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} L_{0}-\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} L_{0}^{*} \leq \operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} L_{t}$ $-\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ker} L_{t}^{*}=$ ind $L_{t}$. By a similar argument, we have ind $L_{0}^{*} \leq$ ind $L_{t}^{*}$ for small t. Observe that ind $L_{t}^{*}=-$ ind $L_{t}$. So we also have ind $L_{0} \geq$ ind $L_{t}$. We have shown (5.18).

We shall now show that (ind $\left.\tilde{D}_{m}^{c+}=\right)$ ind $L_{1}=$ ind $L_{0}\left(=\right.$ ind $\left.D_{m}^{+}\right)$by the continuity method. Let $\Lambda=\left\{t \in[0,1]: \operatorname{ind} L_{t}=\right.$ ind $\left.L_{0}\right\}$. Clearly $0 \in \Lambda$, so $\Lambda$ is not empty. Suppose $t_{0} \in \Lambda$. By reasoning similar to the proof of (5.17) and (5.18) (replacing $L_{0}, A_{0}$ by $L_{t_{0}}, A_{t_{0}}$, respectively), we can show ind $L_{t}=$ ind $L_{t_{0}}$ for $t \in$ $\left(t_{0}-\varepsilon, t_{0}+\varepsilon\right)$ with some $\varepsilon>0$. This implies that $\Lambda$ is open. On the other hand, we apply the same reasoning as in (5.18) to a limit point $t_{\infty}$ of $\Lambda$ and show that ind $L_{t_{\infty}}=$ ind $L_{t_{n}}=$ ind $L_{0}$ where $t_{n} \in \Lambda$ is close enough to $t_{\infty}$. So $t_{\infty} \in \Lambda$. We have shown that $\Lambda$ is closed. Therefore $\Lambda=[0,1]$.

From Lemma 5.11, Corollary 4.24 and Proposition 5.10, there follows a formula of McKean-Singer type:

Theorem 5.12. (Formula of McKean-Singer type for index( $\left.\tilde{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \text {-complex }\right)$ ) For $m \geq 0$ and $a>\frac{m}{2}$ we have for each $t>0$

$$
\sum_{q=0}^{n}(-1)^{q} \operatorname{dim} H_{m}^{q}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})=\int_{\Sigma}\left[\operatorname{Tr} e^{-t \tilde{\tilde{C}}_{m}^{c+}}(x, x)-\operatorname{Tr} e^{-t \tilde{\tilde{C}}_{m}^{c-}}(x, x)\right] d v_{\Sigma, m}
$$

Remark 5.13. (Bundle case): Let $E$ be a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-equivariant holomorphic vector bundle over $\Sigma$, endowed with a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant Hermitian metric. We can extend $D_{m}^{ \pm}, \tilde{A}_{m}^{c}$, $\tilde{D}_{m}^{c \pm}$ and hence $\widetilde{\mathbb{C}}_{m}^{c \pm}$ to $E$-valued $m$-spaces $\Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma, E)$ in a standard manner. By similar arguments in deducing (5.19), we also have a McKean-Singer type formula for index $\left(\tilde{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}^{E}\right.$-complex). That is, with $H_{m}^{q}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})$ replaced by $H_{m}^{q}(\Sigma, E)$ and $\widetilde{\mathbb{C}}_{m}^{c \pm}$ in the RHS replaced by their counterparts for $E$, the resulting two sides are equal.

# 6. Approximation of the transversal heat kernel $e^{-t \tilde{\tilde{C}}_{m}^{c \pm}}$ 

In this section we are going to construct an (transversal) approximate heat kernel by patching up local heat kernels and taking its adjoint. We then carry out successive approximation to get a global (unique, transversal) heat kernel. Our main results are Theorems $6.13,6.18$ and 6.19 while the most technical lemma is Proposition 6.6 which brings the orthogonal projection $\pi_{m}$ as already seen in (5.7) to an integral representation.

The motivations for the whole setting are implicit in Propositions 3.12 and 5.3. Let us remark that the two cases stated between (6.82) and (6.83) yield some complication of the heat kernel evaluation as mentioned in the Introduction.

To start with, let us choose suitable charts on $\Sigma$ as follows. For $\Sigma$ satisfying (2.6), (2.7) and (2.8), with any point $q \in \Sigma$ write $\bar{q} \in \Sigma / \mathbb{R}^{+}$, the $\mathbb{R}^{+}$orbit of $q$. Choose a distance function on $\Sigma / \mathbb{R}^{+}$(say, obtained from a Riemannian metric on $\Sigma / \mathbb{R}^{+}$which is a smooth manifold as mentioned in the proof of Theorem 2.3). Given small $\varepsilon>0$, we have a coordinate neighborhood $V \times(-\varepsilon, \varepsilon) \subset \Sigma / \mathbb{R}^{+}$where $V \subset$ $\mathbb{C}^{n-1}$ is a bounded domain. Remark that we may always choose $\varepsilon=\pi$ if the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$ action on $\Sigma$ is globally free. Due to the compactness of $\Sigma / \mathbb{R}^{+}$, we can find finitely

many $V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right), V_{j} \subset \mathbb{C}^{n-1}$ so that (cf. (2.6))

$$
\Sigma / \mathbb{R}^{+}=\cup_{j}\left(V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j} / 4, \varepsilon_{j} / 4\right)\right), \Sigma=\cup_{j}\left(V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j} / 4, \varepsilon_{j} / 4\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}\right)
$$

It may be useful to assume that all $\varepsilon_{j}^{\prime} s$ are the same, but we keep the subscript $j$ for the time being. The following notations $W_{j}$ and $\hat{W}_{j}$ will be used later.

Notation 6.1. $W_{j}:=V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+} \subset \Sigma$ and $\hat{W}_{j}:=V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j} / 4, \varepsilon_{j} / 4\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$. See Remark 8.39 for explicit choices of $\varepsilon_{j}$.

Below are some cut-off functions $\varphi_{j}$ and $\tau_{j}$ with values in $[0,1]$.
i) $\varphi_{j} \in C_{c}^{\infty}\left(V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right)\right)$ with $\sum \varphi_{j}=1$ on $\Sigma / \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Extend the domain of definition of $\varphi_{j}$ to $W_{j}$ (still denoted as $\varphi_{j}$ ) by $\varphi_{j}(\bar{q}, r)=\varphi_{j}(\bar{q})$ for any $r \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$and $\bar{q} \in V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right)$. So we have $\sum \varphi_{j}=1$ on $\Sigma$ in view of (6.1). Note that supp $\varphi_{j} \subset \Sigma$ must be noncompact while if $\varphi_{j}$ is regarded as functions on $V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right)$, $\operatorname{supp} \varphi_{j}$ is compact.

Let $(z, \phi) \in V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right)$ denote the coordinates for $\bar{q} \in V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right)$. Put

$$
A_{j}=\left\{z \in V_{j}: \text { there is a } \phi \in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \text { such that } \varphi_{j}(z, \phi) \neq 0\right\} \subset \subset V_{j}
$$

ii) $\tau_{j}(z) \in C_{c}^{\infty}\left(V_{j}\right)$ with $\tau_{j} \equiv 1$ on some neighborhood of $A_{j}$ (and $\equiv 0$ outside $\left.V_{j}\right)$.
iii) $\sigma_{j} \in C_{c}^{\infty}\left(\left(-\frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{4}, \frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{4}\right)\right)$ with

$$
\int_{-\varepsilon_{j}}^{\varepsilon_{j}} \sigma_{j}(\phi) \frac{d v_{S^{1}}(\phi)}{2 \pi}=\int_{-\varepsilon_{j} / 4}^{\varepsilon_{j} / 4} \sigma_{j}(\phi) \frac{d v_{S^{1}}(\phi)}{2 \pi}=1
$$

It is possible to adapt the seemingly unusable formulas in [18, (5.39) on p.81] to the present situation. Let us first set up the following. For a (regular) domain $\Omega \subset \mathbb{C}^{n-1}$, we have the Dirichlet heat kernel for $\square_{\Omega, m}^{c}$ (see (5.6) iii), cf. (6.30), (6.31)), denoted by $K_{t}^{\Omega}(z, \zeta)$ for $z, \zeta \in \Omega$. See the preceding section for the definition of such spin ${ }^{c}$ Laplacians (cf. (5.6)), and [16] or [18] for the Dirichlet heat kernel construction (under suitable regularity conditions on $\partial V_{j}$ ). We set

$$
K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)=K_{t}^{\Omega}(z, \zeta) \text { with } \Omega=V_{j}
$$

Note that we have identified $V_{j} \subset \mathbb{C}^{n-1}$ with $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\} \subset V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$ as embedded in $\Sigma$ with the induced metric $\pi^{*} g_{M} \mid v_{j}$.

Remark that we should have considered the adjoint heat kernel in (6.3); but the operator here is self-adjoint the associated kernel functions are the same: $\left(K_{t}^{j}\right)^{*}(z, \zeta)$ $=K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)$ (acting to the left on an element in $\zeta$; compare (7.61)).

For $u \in L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ we have (see Notation 6.1 for $W_{j}$ )

$$
\pi_{m} u \mid W_{j}(\zeta, \eta)=\eta^{m} v_{j}(\zeta) ; \text { subscript " } j \text { " omitted in }(\zeta, \eta)
$$

for some $v_{j}(\zeta) \in L^{2, \pm}\left(V_{j}\right)$. This $L^{2}$ property of $v_{j}$ can be checked using (3.26). It is easily verified, with the metric $G_{a, m}$, that $L_{m}^{2, q}(\Sigma)$ is orthogonal to $L_{m^{\prime}}^{2, q}(\Sigma)$ if $m \neq m^{\prime}$. But these spaces $\left\{L_{m}^{2, q}(\Sigma)\right\}_{m \in \mathbb{Z}}$ do not constitute a complete decomposition of $L^{2, q}(\Sigma)$.

Let $\Psi_{S, m}$ (resp. $\Psi_{*, m}$ ) denote $\Psi_{q, m}$ in (3.32) for $q$ even/odd (resp. for all $q$ ) to identify bundle-valued elements on $V_{j}$ with $m$-space elements on $W_{j}$ (probably with an extra bundle $E ; U_{j}, \psi_{j}^{-1}\left(D_{j}\right)$ in (3.32) taken to be $V_{j}, W_{j}$ in Notation 6.1).

We schematically define the operator $H_{m, t}^{j}$ to be, with cut-off functions omitted, $\Psi_{*, m} \circ K_{t}^{j} \circ \Psi_{*, m}^{-1}$ (see (3.32) and (6.3)) and its adjoint to be $\Psi_{*, m} \circ K_{t}^{j *} \circ \Psi_{*, m}^{-1}$ where

$K_{t}^{j *}$ is the usual heat kernel adjoint (see Remark 6.2 below). More precisely one has the expression in terms of local coordinates (with the induced trivializations on bundles) and of those cut-off functions after Notation 6.1

$$
H_{m, t}^{j}(x, y) \stackrel{(6.3)}{:}=\varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) \eta^{-m} \tau_{j}(\zeta) \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) l(y)^{m}
$$

where $x=(z, w), y=(\zeta, \eta)\left(z, \zeta \in V_{j}, w, \eta \in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}\right.$with the subscript " $j$ " omitted in these coordinates), $\eta=|\eta| e^{i \vartheta}$. This slightly tedious expression (6.5) is basically motivated (modulo the cutoff functions) by Propositions 5.3 and 3.12 (see also $[18,(5.38)$ and (5.39) in p.81] and Remark 6.11 below for the differences) with a seemingly extra factor $l(y)^{m}$ in the end. This factor $l(y)^{m}$ plays a role similar to $\sigma_{j}$ (cf. (6.2)) due to its normalization/unity property (see (3.27), (3.16)). We note that the metric $G_{a, m}$ is used for $H_{m, t}^{j}$ while the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ is used for $K_{t}^{j}$, but they coincide on $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ (see Remark 5.6). See also Lemma 7.13 for the $L^{2}$-isometry property of $\Psi_{ \pm, m}$ that partly justifies the reason for why the expression (6.5) is formed in this way (cf. [18, top lines on p.74]). See more in Remark 6.2

Remark 6.2. Regarding the adjoint of $H_{m, t}^{j}$ as given before (6.5), it is shown in Lemma 7.13 that the above $\Psi_{ \pm, m}$ preserve $L^{2}$-norms (up to a multiplicative constant), giving isomorphisms between respective Hilbert spaces. So the adjoint of $H_{m, t}^{j}$ in the usual sense and the one as defined above coincide. The kernel function $\left(\Psi_{*, m} \circ K_{t}^{j} \circ \Psi_{*, m}^{-1}\right)(x, y)$ on $W_{j} \times W_{j}$ is $\frac{\pi}{\varepsilon_{j}} w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) \eta^{-m} l(y)^{m}$ because for $u(y)=\eta^{m} v(\zeta, \bar{\zeta}), \frac{\pi}{\varepsilon_{j}} \int_{W_{j}} w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) \eta^{-m} l(y)^{m} u(y) d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)$ equals

$$
w^{m} \int_{V_{j}} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) v(\zeta, \bar{\zeta}) \pi^{*} d v_{M}(\zeta)
$$

(see the proof of Lemma 7.13), and this is seen to be $\left(\Psi K_{t}^{j} \Psi^{-1}(u)\right)(x)$ (via definitions). This motivates (6.5). Denote by $L_{m, l o c}^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ (or $L_{m, l o c}^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, G_{a, m}\right)$ for short) the space of $L^{2}$-completion of $\Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, q}\left(W_{j}\right)$ (see Definition 3.10). Similarly denote by $L^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ (or $L^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, G_{a, m}\right)$ for short) the space of $L^{2}$ completion of square-integrable smooth sections of $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ over $W_{j}$ with respect to the metric $G_{a, m}$ (cf. Remark.5.6). In the similar spirit as in Lemma 5.7, we have $L_{m, l o c}^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, G_{a, m}\right) \subset L^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, G_{a, m}\right)$. Now if $\tilde{u} \in\left(L_{m, l o c}^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, G_{a, m}\right)\right)^{\perp}$ ( $\subset$ $\left.L^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, G_{a, m}\right)\right)$ then the similar argument as above implies that $\Psi K_{t}^{j} \Psi^{-1}(\tilde{u})=0$. Hence $\Psi_{*, m} \circ K_{t}^{j} \circ \Psi_{*, m}^{-1}$ extends to $L^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, G_{a, m}\right)$ with image in $L_{m, l o c}^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, G_{a, m}\right)$ $\subset L^{2, q}\left(W_{j}, G_{a, m}\right)$.

We are going to form an approximate heat kernel:

$$
P_{m, t}^{0}:=\sum_{j(\text { finite })} P_{m, t}^{0, j} \quad \text { where } P_{m, t}^{0, j}:=H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}
$$

where $H_{m, t}^{j}$ is the operator associated with the kernel function $H_{m, t}^{j}(x, y)$ of (6.5).
To formulate our next result, the following setup is needed. For any integer $s \geq$ 0 , we define the $C_{R}^{s}$-norm of an element $\omega$ in $\Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, s}(\Sigma)$ or $\Omega_{m, l o c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$ (see Definition 3.10) as follows.

Fix an integer $m \geq 0$ and a partition of unity $\varphi_{j}$ (see $i$ ) below Notation 6.1). Writing $\omega(x)=\Sigma_{j} \varphi_{j}(x) \omega(x)=\Sigma_{j} \varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} h_{I_{q}}(z, \bar{z}, w, \bar{w}) d \bar{z}^{I_{q}}$ where $z \in V_{j}$ and $w$

$\in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$are local coordinates of $x$, for an integer $s \geq 0$ we define ( $w=$ $\left.\left.\left|w\right| e^{i \phi}\right)\right.$

$$
\left\|\omega \|_{C_{B}^{s}}:=\sum_{j} \sum_{k=0}^{s} \sup _{w}\right\| \varphi_{j}(\cdot, \phi) h_{I_{k}}(\cdot, \bar{\cdot}, w, \bar{w}) d \bar{z}^{I_{q}} \|_{C^{k}\left(V_{j}\right)} \text { for } \omega \in \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma)
$$

which means the supremum over $x$ in the domain, of all partial derivatives in $z \in V_{j}$ up to order $s$. Compare the $\|\cdot\|_{s}^{*}$-norm given in (4.3). Similarly for an element of the form (cf. Proposition 6.9 or (6.27))

$$
K(x, y)=\sum_{j} w^{m} k^{j}(x, y) \bar{\eta}^{m}
$$

where $x=(z, w), y=(\zeta, \eta)$, assuming $k^{j}(x, y)$ are $C^{\infty}$-smooth we define the $C_{B}^{s}$ norm of $K$ as follows:

$$
\|K(\cdot, \cdot)\|_{C_{B}^{s}(\Sigma \times \Sigma)}:=\sum_{j} \sup _{w, \eta}\left\|k^{j}((\cdot, w),(\cdot, \eta))\right\|_{C^{s}\left(V_{j} \times V_{j}\right)}
$$

which means the supremum over all $x, y$ in the domain, of all partial derivatives of $k^{j}$ in $z, \zeta \in V_{j}$ up to order $s$. Note that the $C_{B}^{s}$-norm (6.9) depends on the choice of the expression (6.8) with " $m$ ", but we do not put on such dependence whenever no confusion occurs.

Lemma 6.3. With the notation above, $\lim _{t \rightarrow 0+} P_{m, t}^{0}(u)=\pi_{m} u$ (pointwise) for every $u \in \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$. Moreover, for every integer $s \geq 0$ it holds that $P_{m, t}^{0}(u) \rightarrow \pi_{m} u$ as $t \rightarrow 0$ in the norm $\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{s}}$ (hence in $L^{2}$ ) for $u \in$ $\Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$. In particular $P_{m, t}^{0}(u) \in \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$.

Remark 6.4. For $u_{t}, u_{0} \in \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$ assume $u_{t} \rightarrow u_{0}$ in $C_{B}^{0}$. Then it is easy to see that $u_{t} \rightarrow u_{0}$ pointwise on $\Sigma$ and in $L^{2, \pm}(\Sigma)$ (in view of Remark 3.4). In particular, if $u \in \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$ with $\|u\|_{C_{B}^{0}}=0$ then $u=0$.

Remark 6.5. The presence of the projection in Lemma 6.3 (rather than the identity operator in the usual case) reflects the transversal feature of $P_{m, t}^{0}$.

Proof. (of Lemma 6.3) For $u \in L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right), \pi_{m} u \in L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ and by (6.4) $\left.\pi_{m} u\right|_{W_{j}}=\eta^{m} v_{j}(\zeta)$ for some $v_{j}(\zeta) \in L^{2, \pm}\left(V_{j}\right)$, we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow 0+}\left(H_{m, t}^{j}\left(\pi_{m} u\right)\right)(x) \stackrel{(6.4)+(6.5)}{=} \lim _{t \rightarrow 0+} \int_{\Sigma}\left\{\varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)\right. \\
& \left.\eta^{-m} \tau_{j}(\zeta) \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) l(y)^{m} \eta^{m} v_{j}(\zeta)\right\} d v_{\tilde{V}_{j}}(\zeta) d v_{f, m}(\eta) \\
& =\lim _{t \rightarrow 0+} \int_{V_{j}}\left\{\varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) \tau_{j}(\zeta) v_{j}(\zeta)\right\} d v_{V_{j}}(\zeta) \int_{C_{\varepsilon_{j}}} l(y)^{m} \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) d v_{f, m}(\eta)
\end{aligned}
$$

By (6.2) and hence

$$
\int_{C_{\varepsilon_{j}}} l(y)^{m} \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) d v_{f, m}(\eta)=1
$$

(cf. (3.26) with $\tau_{p_{0}}^{*}$ dropped as remarked after (3.27)), the above simplifies to

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow 0+} \int_{V_{j}}\left\{\varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) \tau_{j}(\zeta) v_{j}(\zeta)\right\} d v_{V_{j}}(\zeta)
$$

then, since $K_{t}^{j} \rightarrow I$ in the distribution sense as $t \rightarrow 0$ (cf. [6, Definition 2.15 (4) on p.75 ]) it further simplifies to $\varphi_{j}(x) \tau_{j}(z)\left(\pi_{m} u\right)(z, w)$ by (6.4). From this, (6.6), $\tau_{j}(z)=1$ on $\operatorname{supp} \varphi_{j}$ and $\Sigma_{j} \varphi_{j}(x)=1$, the first assertion of the lemma follows. It also follows from the expression in the last paragraph of $[6$, p.85] that $P_{m, t}^{0}(u)=$ $\sum_{j} H_{m, t}^{j}\left(\pi_{m} u\right) \in \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$.

By the argument similar to (6.10)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P_{m, t}^{0}(u)(z, w)-\left(\pi_{m} u\right)(z, w) \\
= & \sum_{j} w^{m} \varphi_{j}(x)\left[\int_{V_{j}} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) \tau_{j}(\zeta) v_{j}(\zeta) d v_{V_{j}}(\zeta)-\tau_{j}(z) v_{j}(z)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence for some constant $C(s)>0$, as $t \rightarrow 0$

$$
\left\|P_{m, t}^{0}(u)-\left(\pi_{m} u\right)\right\|_{C_{D}^{s}} \leq C(s) \sum_{(j, k) \in I}\left\|K_{t}^{j}\left(\tau_{j} v_{j}\right)-\tau_{j} v_{j}\right\|_{C^{*}\left(V_{j}\right)} \rightarrow 0
$$

by directly applying [6, Theorem 2.20(2)]. This proves the second assertion (convergence in $L^{2}$ by Remark 6.4)..

The first task is aimed to express the kernel function $\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, y)$ (see the RHS of (6.6)) in a more manageable form. This is given in Proposition 6.9 below.

To start with, suppose that $(z, w)$ denotes local coordinates around $x \in \Sigma$. Let $\mathbb{C}^{*} \circ x$ denote the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbit of $x$. We define $\tau_{x}: \eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*} \rightarrow \eta \circ x \in \mathbb{C}^{*} \circ x$.

Recall the definition of $L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ (resp. $L_{m}^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right), \pi_{m}$ ) in Remark 5.6. We first express $\pi_{m}(u)(x)$ in the following proposition:

Proposition 6.6. For the orthogonal projection (recall that $a>\frac{\eta}{2} \geq 0$ )

$$
\pi_{m}: L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right) \equiv L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) \rightarrow L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)
$$

it holds that for $u \in L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$

$$
\pi_{m}(u)(x)=l(x)^{m} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \sigma(\xi)_{x}^{*} u(\xi \circ x)(\bar{\xi})^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi)
$$

where $\tau_{x}$ is defined precedingly. Moreover if $u$ is smooth, $\pi_{m}(u)$ remains smooth. Here $\sigma(\xi)_{x}^{*}:\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right)_{\xi \circ x} \rightarrow\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right)_{x}$ denotes the pullback of forms.

Remark 6.7. i) Note that since $u$ is $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$-valued and the action $\sigma$ leaves $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ invariant, we can trivialize $\sigma(\xi)_{x}^{*} u(\xi \circ x)$ and view it as coefficient function(s) with respect to a basis of global sections ( $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-equivariant) of $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ along the orbit $\mathbb{C}^{*} \circ x$. We then write $\sigma(\xi)_{x}^{*} u(\xi \circ x)$ as $u(\xi \circ x)$ by abuse of notation in the proof below. See Footnote ${ }^{6}$ (seated above (6.13)) for further details.
ii) The action $\sigma$ preserves the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ endowed on $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$. There is another metric $\left.G_{a, m}\right|_{\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}}$ on $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ induced from $G_{a, m}$ when $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ is viewed as a subbundle of $\Lambda^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ (see Remark 5.6). We have that $\pi^{*} g_{M}=\left.G_{a, m}\right|_{\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}}$ (cf. Lemma 8.10 i)) and thus $\sigma$ preserves the metric $\left.G_{a, m}\right|_{\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}}$ too.

Remark 6.8. i) $L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ is not trivial: Using a local bump function/section (cf. Remark 6.7) $u$ with value $u(\xi \circ x)$ close to $\xi^{m}$ and support near $x=(z, w=1)$ in coordinates such that $\pi_{m}(u)(x)>0$ as $l(x)$ and the measure $\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi)$ are positive, yields the desired result.

ii) There exists a fixed $u$ contained in $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a}\right)$ for any $a>0$ and $a>\frac{m}{2} \geq 0$ such that $\pi_{m}(u)=0$ in $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a}\right)$ (which by Lemma 3.5 equals $\left.L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)\right)$ : Let $u$ be a local function/section supported near $w=1 / 2$ in a chart $(z, w)$, depending only on $z, r=|w|$ such that for $m=0$ the integral (6.12) of $u(z, r)$ over $r$ equals 0 with respect to $G_{a}$ for any $a>0$; this is made possible because of (3.18) where the parameter " $a$ " has the impact on $G_{a}$ only outside a neighborhood of $\{w=1 / 2\}$. Since the angular integral of $u$ is seen to vanish for $m>0$ (cf. (6.12) and (7.24)), altogether we obtain the claim.

Proof. (of Proposition 6.6) Recall that $l(x)$ is defined in (3.3). Locally $l(x)$ $=h(z(x), \bar{z}(x)) w(x) \bar{w}(x)$ or $h w \bar{w}$ in short for $x \in\left(W_{j},(z, w)\right)$. The orthogonal projection $\pi_{m}$ is characterized by the following conditions:
i) $\pi_{m}$ is a bounded linear operator on $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$,
ii) $\pi_{m}(u) \in L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$ for $u \in L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$,
iii) $\pi_{m} \circ \pi_{m}=\pi_{m}$
iv) $\pi_{m}^{*}=\pi_{m}$, i.e., $\pi_{m}$ is self-adjoint.
v) $\pi_{m}(u)=u$ for $u \in L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$.

Now we claim that $\pi_{m}(u)$ defined by (6.12) satisfies the above conditions. For $x \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ (see (1.7) for the definition of $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ ), in local coordinates $(z, w)$ for $x$ and $(z, \eta)$ for $\xi \circ x$ where $\eta=\xi w$ (see Footnote ${ }^{5}$ ), we write (see Footnote ${ }^{6}$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{m}(u)(x) \stackrel{l=h w \bar{w}}{=} h^{m}|w|^{2 m} \int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} u(z, \eta)(\bar{\eta})^{m}(\bar{w})^{-m}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta) \\
& |w|^{2 m}(\bar{w})^{-m}=w^{m} \quad w^{m} h^{m}(z, \bar{z}) \int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} u(z, \eta)(\bar{\eta})^{m}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta)
\end{aligned}
$$

By Remark $6.7 i$ ) the norm of the coefficient (vector-valued) function $u(z, \eta)$ or $u(y)$ below should include the norms of $(0, q)$-forms; these norms of forms are nevertheless nonzero constants along $\mathbb{C}^{*} \circ x$ by the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariance of the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ (by Remark $6.7 \mathrm{ii})$ ). For simplicity we drop these constant norms henceforth (they can be uniformly bounded as $M=$ the space of $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbits is compact).

But since $x \notin \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$, we can assume that $\delta_{j}=\pi$ in (2.6) for suitable holomorphic coordinates $(z, w)$ at $x$.
