Write a global section $u$ of $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ along $\mathbb{C}^{*} \circ x$ as $u=u_{I_{q}} \tilde{\eta}^{I_{q}}$ (summing over $I_{q}$ and $q$ ). Compute

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
\sigma(\xi)_{*}^{*} u(\xi \circ x) & =\sigma(\xi)_{*}^{*} u_{I_{q}}(\xi \circ x) \sigma(\xi)_{*}^{*} \tilde{\eta}^{I_{q}}(\xi \circ x) \\
& =u_{I_{q}}(\xi \circ x) \tilde{\eta}^{I_{q}}(x)
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    by the $\sigma$-invariance of $\tilde{\eta}^{I_{q}}$. We can therefore identify $\sigma(\xi)_{*}^{*} u(\xi \circ x)$ with the coefficient functions $u_{I_{q}}(\xi \circ x)$ still denoted as $u(\xi \circ x)$ or $u(z, \xi w)=u(z, \eta)$ in coordinates. For later use note that $\sigma(\xi)_{*}^{*} u(\xi \circ x)=\left(\sigma(\xi)^{*} u\right)(x)$.

To prove $i$ ), upon applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality to the integral on the RHS of (6.13) we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} u(z, \eta)(\bar{\eta})^{m}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta)\right|^{2} \\
\leq & \int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}|u(z, \eta)|^{2}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta) \int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}|\eta|^{2 m}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta)
\end{aligned}
$$

We now estimate, by (6.13) and (6.14),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\pi_{m}(u)(x)\right|^{2} \leq & h^{m}|w|^{2 m} \int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}|u(z, \eta)|^{2}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta) \\
& \int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} h^{m}|\eta|^{2 m}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta) \\
= & h^{m}|w|^{2 m} \int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}|u(z, \eta)|^{2}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta)
\end{aligned}
$$

because

$$
\int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} h^{m}|\eta|^{2 m}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta)=1
$$

(cf. (3.27)) in (6.15).
Before proceeding further let us set up the following. Let $\bar{N}_{j}(j=1,2,3, \cdots)$ be an open neighborhood of $M_{\text {sing }}:=\pi\left(\Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right) \subset M$ by $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma / \sigma=M$. Write $N_{j}=\pi^{-1}\left(\bar{N}_{j}\right)$. We assume $\cap_{j} \bar{N}_{j}=M_{\text {sing }}$ and $\bar{N}_{1} \supset \bar{N}_{2} \supset \cdots$. By the compactness of $M$ we have that for $j^{\prime}$ in a finite index set $W_{j^{\prime}}, V_{j^{\prime}}$ (see Notation 6.1) can be formed to satisfy $\cup_{j^{\prime}} \pi\left(V_{j^{\prime}}\right)\left(=\pi\left(W_{j^{\prime}}\right)\right) \supset M \backslash \bar{N}_{j}$ with $\pi\left(V_{j^{\prime}}\right) \subset M \backslash M_{\text {sing }}$.

Assume from now on that the support of $u$ is contained in $\left(\Sigma \backslash N_{j} \subset\right) \tilde{W}_{j}:=$ $\cup_{j^{\prime}} W_{j^{\prime}}\left(\subset \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)$ with $\tilde{V}_{j}:=\cup_{j^{\prime}} V_{j^{\prime}}$, meaning that $u=0$ a.e. on a neighborhood of $\Sigma \backslash \tilde{W}_{j}$. We will come back to the general case later. Then (via Footnote ${ }^{5}$ as just mentioned)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.=\frac{1}{2} \int_{\tilde{W}_{j}}\left|\pi_{m}(u)(x)\right|^{2} d v_{\Sigma, m}(x) \stackrel{(6.15)+(3.22)}{\leq} \int_{z \in \tilde{V}_{j}}\left\{\int_{w \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} h^{m}|w|^{2 m} \tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}(w)\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.\int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}|u(z, \eta)|^{2}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta)\right\} d v(z) \stackrel{(6.16)}{\leq} \int_{\tilde{W}_{j}}|u(y)|^{2} d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $y=(z, \eta) \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ and the last term equals $\int_{\Sigma}|u|^{2} d v_{\Sigma, m}$ by the support condition, implies that

$$
\left\|\pi_{m}(u)\right\|_{L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)} \leq\|u\|_{L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)}
$$

since (6.17) holds for every $j, \cup_{j} \tilde{W}_{j}=\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ and $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ is of measure 0 . Condition i) follows.

For condition $i i$ ) observe that by $\lambda \circ(\xi \circ x)=(\lambda \xi) \circ x$, we have $\tau_{\xi \circ x}^{*} d v_{f, m}(\lambda)=$ $\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}(\lambda \xi)$ so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{m}(u)(\xi \circ x)=l(\xi \circ x)^{m} \int_{\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} u((\lambda \xi) \circ x) \bar{\lambda}^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\lambda \xi) \\
& \stackrel{\eta=\lambda \xi}{=} l(\xi \circ x)^{m}(\bar{\xi})^{-m} \int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} u(\eta \circ x) \bar{\eta}^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta)
\end{aligned}
$$

Condition $i i$ ) amounts to proving the equality

$$
\left(\sigma(\xi)^{*} \pi_{m}(u)\right)(x)=\pi_{m}(u)(\xi \circ x)=\xi^{m} \pi_{m}(u)(x) \text { a.e. }
$$

This immediately follows by applying $l(\xi \circ x)^{m}=|\xi|^{2 m} l(x)^{m}$ (see (7.20)) to (6.18) and using (6.13) (for $x \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ ).

Next we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{m}\left(\pi_{m}(u)\right)(x) \stackrel{(6.12)}{=} l(x)^{m} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \pi_{m}(u)(\xi \circ x) \bar{\xi}^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi) \\
& \stackrel{(6.18)}{=} l(x)^{m} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} l(\xi \circ x)^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi) \cdot \int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} u(\eta \circ x) \bar{\eta}^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta) \\
& \stackrel{(6.12)}{=} \pi_{m}(u)(x) \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} l(\xi \circ x)^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi) \stackrel{(3.27)}{=} \pi_{m}(u)(x),
\end{aligned}
$$

which gives condition $i i i$ ).
To show $i v$ ) let us compare $\left(\pi_{m}(u), v\right)$ and $\left(u, \pi_{m}(v)\right)$ for any $v \in L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. In local holomorphic coordinates $(z, w)$ for $x \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ and $(z, \eta)$ for $\xi \circ x \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ where $\eta=\xi w$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{m}(u)(x) \overline{v(x)} d v_{\Sigma, m}(x) \stackrel{(6.13)}{=}(3.22) w^{m} h^{m}(z, \bar{z})\left\{\int_{\eta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} u(z, \eta)(\bar{\eta})^{m}\right. \\
& \left.\quad\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta)\right\} \overline{v(z, w)} d v(z)\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(w) .
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand, we have, for $y=\xi \circ x \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ (in fact for $y \in \tilde{W}_{j}$ ),

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u(y) \overline{\pi_{m}(v)(y)}=u(y) l(y)^{m} \int_{\xi^{-1} \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \overline{v\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right)} \xi^{-m} \tau_{y}^{*} d v_{f, m}\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \\
= & u(z, \eta) h^{m}(z, \bar{z})|\eta|^{2 m} \int_{w \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \overline{v(z, w)} w^{m} \eta^{-m} \tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}(w) \\
= & u(z, \eta) h^{m}(z, \bar{z}) \bar{\eta}^{m} \int_{w \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \overline{v(z, w)} w^{m} \tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}(w)
\end{aligned}
$$

Inserting $d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)$ gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
u(y) \overline{\pi_{m}(v)(y)} d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)= & u(z, \eta) h^{m}(z, \bar{z}) \bar{\eta}^{m} \\
& \cdot\left\{\int_{w \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \overline{v(z, w)} w^{m} \tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}(w)\right\}\left(\tau_{(z, 1)}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta) d v(z)
\end{aligned}
$$

It is slightly tedious to write out both expressions $\int_{x=(z, w)}$ (RHS of (6.20)) and $\int_{y=(z, \eta)}(\mathrm{RHS}$ of $(6.21))$; once it is done, it is not difficult to see (without computing out any integration) that they are exactly the same. Hence $\pi_{m}^{*}=\pi_{m}$ proving condition $i v)$.

To show $v$ ), since supp $u \subset \tilde{W}_{j} \subset \Sigma \backslash N_{l}$ for $l \gg j$ by assumption, we have that $u(\xi \circ x)=\xi^{m} u(x)$ a.e. if $u$ is further assumed to be in $L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$; see the Footnote ${ }^{6}$ above for explanation of $u(\xi \circ x)$. For $x \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi_{m}(u)(x) & =l(x)^{m} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \xi^{m} u(x)(\bar{\xi})^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi) \\
& =u(x) \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} l\right)^{m}(\xi)\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi)=u(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (7.20) and $l^{m}(\xi \circ x)=\left(\tau_{x}^{*} l\right)^{m}(\xi)$ via definitions (resp. (3.27)) are used for the second (resp. third) equality. Condition $v$ ) follows.

For the general case let us first prove the following:
(6.22) For the sake of clarity let us denote by $\tilde{\pi}_{m}(u)$ the RHS of (6.12).

Let $u_{j} \rightarrow u$ in $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. Then $\tilde{\pi}_{m}\left(u_{j}\right) \rightarrow \tilde{\pi}_{m}(u)$ in $L^{2}$.
Proof of (6.22): The $L^{2}$-difference $\left\|\tilde{\pi}_{m}\left(u_{j}\right)-\tilde{\pi}_{m}(u)\right\|_{L^{2}}^{2}$ is bounded by

$$
I_{j}:=\int_{\Sigma} l(x)^{2 m}\left\{\int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \mid u_{j}(\xi \circ x)-u(\xi \circ x)\left\|\xi\left|{ }^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi)\right.\right\}^{2} d v_{\Sigma, m}(x)\right.
$$

Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality to the integral over $\xi$ gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{j} \leq \int_{\Sigma}\left\{l(x)^{m} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \mid u_{j}(\xi \circ x)-u(\xi \circ x)\right\}^{2}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi) \\
& \cdot \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} l(x)^{m}|\xi|^{2 m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi)\} d v_{\Sigma, m}(x) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that $l(x)^{m}|\xi|^{2 m}=l(\xi \circ x)^{m}$ by (7.20) and hence $\int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} l(x)^{m}|\xi|^{2 m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi)$ $=1$ by (3.27). It is possible to simplify (6.23) further: Substituting this into (6.23) and making a change of variables $y=\xi \circ x$ over $\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ (to ensure bijectivity), we can write the RHS of (6.23) as ( $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ being of measure 0 )

$$
\int_{y \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}}\left\{\left|u_{j}(y)-u(y)\right|^{2} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} l\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right)^{m}\left(\tau_{y}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}\right)\right\} d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)
$$

because $\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi) d v_{\Sigma, m}(x)$ in (6.23) equals $\left(\tilde{\sigma}^{*}\left[\left(\tau_{y}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}\right) d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)\right]\right)(\xi, x)$ (where $\tilde{\sigma}:(\xi, x) \rightarrow\left(\xi^{-1}, y=\xi \circ x\right)$ ) as proved in Lemma 7.6 iii). Again $\int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} l\left(\xi^{-1} \circ\right.$ $y)^{m}\left(\tau_{y}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}\right)=1$ for any $y$ by (3.27) reduces (6.24) to $\int_{\Sigma}\left|u_{j}(y)-u(y)\right|^{2} d v_{\Sigma, m}$ which tends to zero as $j \rightarrow \infty$ by assumption. We have shown (6.22).

We can now finish the proof for the general $\tilde{u}$. Let $\bar{\chi}_{j}$ be cut-off functions with support in $M \backslash M_{\text {sing }}$ (cf. [13, p.37]), which are $\equiv 1$ on $\pi\left(\tilde{W}_{j}\right)\left(=\pi\left(\tilde{V}_{j}\right)\right) \supset M \backslash \tilde{N}_{j}$ and $\bar{\chi}_{j} \rightarrow 1$ on $M \backslash M_{\text {sing }}$ via $\cap_{j} \tilde{N}_{j}=M_{\text {sing }}$ as already assumed. Write $\chi_{j}=\pi^{*} \bar{\chi}_{j}$ and consider $\chi_{j} \tilde{u}$. Then one has the following: $a) \chi_{j} \tilde{u} \rightarrow \tilde{u}$ in $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right) ; b$ ) if $\tilde{u} \in$ $L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$, since $\chi_{j}$ is $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant by construction $\chi_{j} \tilde{u}(\xi \circ x)=\xi^{m}\left(\chi_{j} \tilde{u}\right)(x)$, i.e. $\chi_{j} \tilde{u} \in L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, G_{a, m}\right)$. Using $a$ ), $b$ ) and applying (6.22) with the previously proved special case $u \equiv \chi_{j} \tilde{u}$ one checks that $\tilde{\pi}_{m}$ easily satisfies the above conditions $i$ ) to $v$ ) as the original orthogonal projection $\pi_{m}$ does, giving that $\tilde{\pi}_{m}=\pi_{m}$ as desired.

For the last statement of the lemma, the continuity property of $\pi_{m}$ in $C_{B}^{*}$-norm (see (6.7)) is postponed to Lemma 6.14.

Define $d \mu_{y, m}(\xi)$, a 2 -form in $\xi$ for $(\xi, y) \in \mathbb{C}^{*} \times \Sigma$ (i.e., it is of the form $f(y, \bar{y}, \xi, \bar{\xi}) d \xi \wedge$ $d \bar{\xi})$ by

$$
d \mu_{y, m}(\xi):=l\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right)^{m} d v_{\Sigma, m}\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right) \wedge d v_{f, m}(y) / d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)
$$

where $d v_{\Sigma, m}\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right)$ denotes the pullback on $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times \Sigma$ of $d v_{\Sigma, m}$ (see (3.22)) by the map $(\xi, y) \rightarrow \xi^{-1} \circ y$. Notice that $d v_{\Sigma, m}\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right)$ in (6.25) contains a 2 -form in $\xi$ wedging a "horizontal" $2 n-2$ form in $y$, and one sees that it is this 2 -form that survives in the RHS of (6.25).

To express $\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, y)$ as mentioned earlier, via Proposition 6.6 above we view $\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, y)$ and $H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} \circ y\right) \circ \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} \circ y}^{*}$ as linear transformations from $\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right)_{y}$ to $\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right)_{x}$, where $\sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} \circ y}^{*}:\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right)_{y} \rightarrow\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right)_{\xi^{-1} \circ y}$ denotes the pullback of forms.

Proposition 6.9. Let the notation $\sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} \circ y}^{*}$ be as above.
i) The kernel function for $P_{m, t}^{0, j} \equiv H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}$ is given by
$(6.26)$
$\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, y)=\int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} \circ y\right) \circ \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} \circ y}^{*}\right)(\bar{\xi})^{m} d \mu_{y, m}(\xi), \forall(x, y) \in \Sigma \times \Sigma$.
ii) $\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, y)$ is of the form, with $x=(z, w), y=(\zeta, \eta)$ as in (6.5),

$$
\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, y)=w^{m} p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y) \bar{\eta}^{m}
$$

for some smooth and $C_{B}^{*}$-bounded ( $t$-dependent) linear transformation $p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y)$ from $\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right)_{y}$ to $\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right)_{x}$ (see (6.9) for the definition of $C_{B}^{*}$-norm).
iii) $\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, y)$ is $L^{2}$ in two variables $(x, y) \in \Sigma \times \Sigma$ with respect to the metric $G_{a, m} \times G_{a, m}$. Compare Lemma 6.12 and its proof for similar consequences.

Proof. Compute $\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right) u$ as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right) u\right](x)=H_{m, t}^{j}\left(\pi_{m}(u)\right)(x)} \\
= & \int_{p \in \Sigma} H_{m, t}^{j}(x, p) \pi_{m}(u)(p) d v_{\Sigma, m}(p) \\
= & \int_{p \in \Sigma} H_{m, t}^{j}(x, p) \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \sigma(\xi)_{p}^{*} u(\xi \circ p)(\bar{\xi})^{m}\left(\tau_{p}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi) l(p)^{m} d v_{\Sigma, m}(p)
\end{aligned}
$$

We now make a change of variables: $(p, \xi) \rightarrow(y, \xi)$ by $y=\xi \circ p$ (on $\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ ). After a careful examination, (6.28) equals ( $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ being of measure zero)

$$
\int_{y \in \Sigma} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} H_{m, t}^{j}(x, p) \circ\left(\sigma(\xi)_{p}^{*} u(y)\right)(\bar{\xi})^{m} d v_{f, m}(y) l\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right)^{m} \wedge d v_{\Sigma, m}\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right)\}
$$

By rearranging terms, the above becomes (by (6.25)) (noting that $p=\xi^{-1} \circ y$ and $\left.H_{m, t}^{j}(x, p) \circ \sigma(\xi)_{p}^{*} \text { acts on } u(y)\right)$

$$
\int_{y \in \Sigma}\left[\int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} \circ y\right) \circ \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} \circ y}^{*}\right)(\bar{\xi})^{m} d \mu_{y, m}(\xi)\right] u(y) d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)
$$

Now (6.26) follows from the integrand $[\ldots]$ in (6.29).
The proof of (6.27) will be postponed to Section 7 after studying the properties of $d \mu_{y, m}(\xi)$. See the paragraph prior to Remark 7.9 (containing (7.40) through (7.49)). The assertion iii) follows from the $C_{B}^{*}$-bound ( $C_{B}^{0}$ enough) and Remark 3.4 .

Next we want to compute $\left(\partial_{t} P_{m, t}^{0}\right) u+P_{m, t}^{0} \widetilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm} \pi_{m} u$ (see (5.6) for $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm}$, (6.6) for $\left.P_{m, t}^{0}\right)$. For use in the following lemma, as similar to $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm}$ we let the local operator (which is a notation used interchangeably with $\square_{U, m}^{c \pm}$ in (5.6))

$$
\square_{z, m}^{c \pm}:=D_{z, m}^{c \mp} D_{z, m}^{c \pm}
$$

denote the Laplacian of (the standard $m$-th) spin ${ }^{c}$ Dirac operator

$$
D_{z, m}^{c}=D_{z, m}+A_{z, m}^{c}=\bar{\partial}_{z, m}+\bar{\partial}_{z, m}^{*}+A_{z, m}^{c}
$$

on $V_{j} \subset \mathbb{C}^{n-1}$ (recall (3.33) for $\bar{\partial}_{z, m}^{*}$ ). $P_{m, t}^{0}$ satisfies the following adjoint type heat equation asymptotically; compare [18, Lemma 5.12] and see Remark 6.11 for a significant difference.

Lemma 6.10. It holds that
(6.32) $\left(\partial_{t} P_{m, t}^{0}\right) u+P_{m, t}^{0}\left(\bigcirc_{m}^{c \pm} \circ \pi_{m}\right) u=R_{t} u$ for $u \in \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$
where $R_{t}: \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$ is an operator with distribution kernel $R_{t}(x, y)$ (= $R(t, x, y) \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{+} \times \Sigma \times \Sigma, T^{* 0,+} \Sigma \otimes\left(T^{* 0,+} \Sigma\right)^{*}\right)$ ) of the form (6.8) satisfying that for every $s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$, there exist $\varepsilon_{0}>0, C_{s}>0$ independent of $t$ such that

$$
\|R(t, x, y)\|_{C_{\infty}^{\infty}(\Sigma \times \Sigma)} \leq C_{s} e^{-\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{t}} \text { for } t \in \mathbb{R}^{+}
$$

Proof. Write $\left.\pi_{m} u\right|_{W_{j}}(\zeta, \eta)=\eta^{m} v_{j}(\zeta)$ (see (6.4); we drop subscripts " $j$ " on the coordinates). Recalling that $\bigcirc_{m, y}^{c \pm}$ acts on $y(=(\zeta, \eta))$ while $\square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm}$ acts on $\zeta$ via Proposition 5.3, we compute $\left(P_{m, t}^{0}\right.$ is the sum of $\left.H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right.$ over $\left.j(6.5)\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \partial_{t} H_{m, t}^{j}\left(\pi_{m} u\right)+H_{m, t}^{j} \bigcirc_{m, y}^{c \pm}\left(\pi_{m} u\right) \\
= & \int_{W_{j}}\left\{\varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} \partial_{t} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) v_{j}(\zeta) \tau_{j}(\zeta)\right. \\
& \left.+\varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)\left(\square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm} v_{j}(\zeta)\right) \tau_{j}(\zeta)\right\} \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) l(y)^{m} d v_{\Sigma, m}(y) \\
= & \int_{V_{j}} \varphi_{j}(x) w^{m}\left\{\partial_{t} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) v_{j}(\zeta)+K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)\left(\square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm} v_{j}(\zeta)\right)\right\} \tau_{j}(\zeta) d v(\zeta)
\end{aligned}
$$

in which we have used $\int_{C_{s_{j}}} \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) l(y)^{m} d v_{f, m}(\eta)=1$ by (6.11). Noting that

$$
\int_{V_{j}}\left\{\partial_{t} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)+K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) \square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm}\right\}\left(v_{j}(\zeta) \tau_{j}(\zeta)\right) d v(\zeta)=0
$$

since $K_{t}^{j}$ is the Dirichlet heat kernel (6.3), we reduce the RHS of (6.34) to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{V_{j}} \varphi_{j}(x) S_{j}(t, x, \zeta) \bar{\eta}^{-m} v_{j}(\zeta) d v(\zeta) \\
& \stackrel{(6.11)}{=} \int_{W_{j}} \varphi_{j}(x) S_{j}(t, x, \zeta) \bar{\eta}^{-m} \eta^{-m}\left(\pi_{m} u\right)(y) \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) l(y)^{m} d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
S_{j}(t, x, \zeta)\left(\eta^{-m}\left(\pi_{m} u\right)(y)\right)=w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) \bar{\eta}^{m}\left[\tau_{j}(\zeta), \square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm}\right]\left(v_{j}(\zeta)\right)
$$

Note that $\tau_{j}(\zeta)=1$ for $\zeta$ in some small neighborhood of the $z$-part of $\operatorname{supp} \varphi_{j}$. It follows that $\varphi_{j}(x) S_{j}(t, x, \zeta)=0$ if $(z(x), \zeta)$ is in some small neighborhood of $(z, z)$ (due to $[\tau, \square]=0$ there). The idea is that the singular part of $\varphi_{j} S_{j}$ originally caused by $K_{t}^{j}$ along the diagonal $\left(\sim \frac{1}{t^{n-1}}\right)$ is now dismissed.

Note that $S_{j}(t, x, \zeta)$ in (6.35) is a differential operator acting on $v_{j}(\zeta)$. We can convert it into a kernel function via an integration by parts as follows: by

(6.36), the self-adjointness of $\square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm}$ with $\tau_{j}(\zeta)$ being of compact support, and $\int_{C_{z_{j}}} \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) l(y)^{m} d v_{f, m}(\eta)=1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { LHS of }(6.35)=\int_{V_{j}} \varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)\left|\tau_{j}(\zeta), \square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm}\right|\left(v_{j}(\zeta)\right) d v(\zeta) \\
& =\int_{V_{j}} \varphi_{j}(x) w^{m}\left\{\square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm}\left(K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) \tau_{j}(\zeta)\right)-\left(\square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm} K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)\right) \tau_{j}(\zeta)\right\} v_{j}(\zeta) d v(\zeta) \\
& =\int_{V_{j}} \varphi_{j}(x) \hat{S}_{j}(t, x, y) \bar{\eta}^{-m} v_{j}(\zeta) d v(\zeta) \\
& =\int_{W_{j}} \varphi_{j}(x) \hat{S}_{j}(t, x, y) \bar{\eta}^{-m} \eta^{-m}\left(\pi_{m} u\right)(y) \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) l(y)^{m} d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (the $\left[\square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm}, \tau_{j}(\zeta)\right]$ below as a first order differential operator acts on the $\zeta$-variable of $\left.K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)\right)$

$$
\hat{S}_{j}(t, x, y):=w^{m}\left[\square_{\zeta, m}^{c \pm}, \tau_{j}(\zeta)\right]\left(K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)\right) \bar{\eta}^{m}
$$

Therefore using an analogous argument of $[18,(5.47)]$ for (6.37) (it is essential that the Gaussian factor $\exp \left(-\frac{\partial_{t}^{2} \tau_{j}(\zeta)}{\mathrm{d} t}\right)$ encoded in $K_{t}^{j}$, see (6.84), absorbs the singular part $\frac{1}{t^{\varepsilon-1}}$ if $(z, \zeta)$ is off the diagonal where $[\tau, \square]=0$ as mentioned above), we conclude that for every $s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$, there exist $\varepsilon>0, C_{s}>0$ independent of $t$ such that (noting that $\bar{\eta}^{-m} \eta^{-m} l(y)^{m}=h^{m}(\zeta, \bar{\zeta})$ by (6.43) below)

$$
\left\|\varphi_{j}(x) \hat{S}_{j}(t, x, y) h^{m}(\zeta, \bar{\zeta}) \sigma_{j}(\vartheta)\right\|_{C_{R}^{s}(\Sigma \times \Sigma)} \leq C_{s} e^{-\frac{s}{\tau}} \text { for } t \in \mathbb{R}^{+}
$$

From (6.34) and (6.37) it follows that

$$
\left(\partial_{t} P_{m, t}^{0}\right) u+P_{m, t}^{0}\left(\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm} \circ \pi_{m}\right) u=\hat{R}_{t}\left(\pi_{m} u\right)
$$

where

$$
\hat{R}_{t}(x, y):=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j}(x) \hat{S}_{j}(t, x, y) \bar{\eta}^{-m} \eta^{-m} \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) l(y)^{m}
$$

So (6.32) holds for $R_{t}:=\hat{R}_{t} \circ \pi_{m}$ in view of (6.40) and (an analogue of (6.26))

$$
R(t, x, y)\left(=R_{t}(x, y)\right)=\int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(\hat{R}_{t}\left(x, \xi^{-1} \circ y\right) \circ \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} \circ y}^{*}\right)(\bar{\xi})^{m} d \mu_{y, m}(\xi)
$$

Now that

$$
\bar{\eta}^{-m} \eta^{-m} l(y)^{m}=h^{m}(\zeta, \bar{\zeta})
$$

from (6.41) is bounded in $\zeta \in M=\Sigma / \mathbb{C}^{*}$ by Lemma $7.6 i v$ ), which is compact, $\bar{\eta}^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right) \bar{\xi}^{m}$ (from (6.38) and (6.42)) is also bounded for $\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ (using (2.7) for $\rho=|\xi|$ ) and $\int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} d \mu_{y, m}(\xi)=1$ by Corollary 7.7, we conclude (6.33) for $s=0$ by (6.39) via (6.41), (6.42). For $s>0$ note the definition of $C_{R}^{s}$-norms that concern mainly the $z$ or $\zeta$-variables (i.e. the horizontal ones). Observe that

$$
\bar{\eta}^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right) \bar{\xi}^{m}=\chi(y) \bar{\eta}^{m}(y)
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\chi(y) & =\frac{\bar{\eta}^{m}\left(e^{-i \gamma} \circ y\right)}{\bar{\eta}^{m}(y)}|\xi|^{-m} \bar{\xi}^{m}\left(\xi=|\xi| e^{i \gamma}\right) \\
& =e^{i m \theta\left(e^{-i \gamma} \circ y\right)} e^{-i m \gamma} e^{-i m \theta(y)}\left(\eta(y)=|\eta(y)| e^{-i \theta(y)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $C_{B}^{s}$-norms involve no $\bar{\eta}^{m}(y)$ (see (6.7)), for the $C_{B}^{s}$-norms of $R(t, x, y)$ it suffices to prove, with (6.39), the smoothness of $h^{m}$ and $\chi(y)$ by using the compactness of their $\zeta$-domains. We discuss this smoothness issue as follows. For the smoothness of $\theta\left(e^{-i \gamma} \circ y\right)$ (in $\chi(y)$ ) see a similar claim on $C_{B}^{s}$-norm in (6.27) (as it involves the similar expression $\left(\xi^{-1} \circ y\right)$ by (6.26)), whose proof is placed after (7.35). In this proof $\theta\left(e^{-i \gamma} \circ y\right)$ actually lies in (7.45), whose smoothness is proved in the last paragraph after (7.49) involving the smoothness of $\alpha_{k}$. The point is that the "large" angle action (see Case ii) after (6.82)) due to the local freeness of the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action makes the treatment less direct and leads to the consideration of $\alpha_{k}$. Lastly, to deal with $C_{B}^{s}$-norms for $y$ in $d \mu_{y, m}(\xi)$, simply notice the expression (7.23), (7.24) with $x$ replaced by $y$, which can be simplified further by the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariance of $d v_{M}$ (Lemma 7.6 ii)) . Our proof is now completed.

Remark 6.11. The difference between the $S_{j}$ of (6.36) and the corresponding term in the same notation $S_{j}$ in $[18,(5.46)$ and p.84] arises from that between $H_{m, t}^{j}(x, y)$ of (6.5) and $H_{j}(t, x, y)$ of $[18,(5.38)]$. This difference is partly due to the fact in Lemma 7.13 that holds only at the Hilbert space level, while some similar identifications in the proof of [18, Proposition 5.1, p.73] hold at the pointwise level. That these identifications, adapted to their own contexts, are only similar in nature leads to the different results. Compare Remark 3.20 for different effects caused by the metrics here and [18]. Note that the $S_{j}(t, x, w)$ of [18, p.84] is actually a (first-order) differential operator, so the presentation in [18, p.84], especially the derivation of $[18,(5.47)]$, need be fixed in a similar way as the part from $S_{j}$ of (6.36) to $\bar{S}_{j}$ of (6.38).

If one tries to directly show that $P_{m, t}^{0}$ is an approximate heat kernel one may encounter a difficulty which we refer to [18, the paragraph after (1.81), p.36] for a similar situation and explanation. Suffice it to say that it becomes easier to show that its adjoint $P_{m, t}^{0 *}$ is an approximate heat kernel. To express $P_{m, t}^{0 *}$ in terms of $H_{m, t}^{j *}$ we need the following lemma that $H_{m, t}^{j}$ (hence $H_{m, t}^{j *}$ ) is a bounded linear operator on $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$, defined through the kernel function $H_{m, t}^{j}(x, y)$ (see (6.5)).

Lemma 6.12. The kernel function $H_{m, t}^{j}(x, y)$ as in (6.5) defines a bounded linear operator on $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$. In fact $H_{m, t}^{j}(x, y)$ is $L^{2}$ in two variables $(x, y)$ $\in \Sigma \times \Sigma$ with respect to the metric $G_{a, m} \times G_{a, m}$. The kernel function $H_{m, t}^{j *}(x, y)$ defined by $H_{m, t}^{j *}(x, y):=\overline{H_{m, t}^{j}(y, x)}$ represents the Hilbert space adjoint operator $H_{m, t}^{j *}$ (A superscript " $t$ " meant as transpose may be placed on $\overline{H_{m, t}^{j}(y, x)}$, but we omit it.)

Proof. A "local version" of this (with cut-off functions in (6.5) removed) is seen in Remark 6.2. Now in (6.5) observe that $\eta^{-m} l(y)^{m}=h(\zeta, \bar{\zeta})^{m} \bar{\eta}^{m}$. From this and Remark 3.4 the assertion on the $L^{2}$-condition follows. This yields the first and third assertions (see [57, Theorem 2, p.13 ]).

Using Lemma 6.12 we have now

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P_{m, t}^{0 *}=\sum_{j}\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)^{*}=\sum_{j} \pi_{m}^{*} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *} \\
= & \sum_{j} \pi_{m} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *}: L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right) \rightarrow L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It is worth noting that while the action of $P_{m, t}^{0}$ may not preserve the space $\Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$ (cf. Lemma 6.3), the image of $P_{m, t}^{0 *}$ on $\Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ is nonetheless seated in $\Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$ because of $\pi_{m}$. By taking the adjoints $P_{m, t}^{0 *}, R_{t}^{*}$ of $P_{m, t}^{0}, R_{t}$ respectively, we are going to prove the following. Denote by $\Omega_{c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \subset$ $\Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$ the set of those elements (smooth sections of $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ ) of compact support in $\Sigma$. Note that $\Omega_{c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$ is dense in $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ (see Remark 5.6).

Theorem 6.13. In the preceding notation, we have
i)

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}} P_{m, t}^{0 *} u=\pi_{m} u \text { in }\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{*}} \quad \text { for } u \in \Omega_{c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)
$$

ii)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial P_{m, t}^{0 *}}{\partial t} u+\widehat{\bigcirc}_{m}^{c \pm} P_{m, t}^{0 *} u=R_{t}^{*} u \text { for } u \in L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right) \cap \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \\
& \text { (not necessarily in } \Omega_{c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)) \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

iii) The distribution kernel $R^{*}(t, x, y)$ of $R_{t}^{*}$ is given by $\overline{R(t, y, x)}$ (cf. (6.33)); it satisfies a similar estimate as $R_{t}$ in Lemma 6.10.

Although $\lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}} P_{m, t}^{0} u=\pi_{m} u$ in $\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{*}}$ for $u \in \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ holds by Lemma 6.3, it is a bit surprising that the corresponding statement for $P_{m, t}^{0 *}$ is not obviously true as it might appear to be at first sight, unless $u$ is further restricted. This difference is essentially due to the noncompactness of $\Sigma$. Compared to the compact CR case [18, Theorem 5.13, p.84] the following proof is less trivial in that certain elements " $\alpha_{l} \in S^{1}$ " related to the local orbifold group will be introduced (and also used in some later parts of the paper).

For the proof of Theorem 6.13 we start by proving the following lemma. Writing $\tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma):=\oplus_{q} \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, q}(\Sigma)$ (see Definition 3.10) we want the boundedness of $\pi_{m}$ : $\tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma) \rightarrow \tilde{\Omega}_{m}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ with respect to $C_{B}^{*}$-norm. In the CR case [18] these $C_{B}^{*}$-norms were neither needed nor were they pursued because the compactness of the total space there simplifies the picture. The technicalities here lie in the local freeness of the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action.
Lemma 6.14. With the notation above, $\left\|\pi_{m}(u)\right\|_{C_{B}^{*}} \leq C_{1}\|u\|_{C_{B}^{*}}$ for every $u \in$ $\tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma), s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$.
Proof. Write $u(x)=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j}(x) u(x)=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} v_{j}(x)$ where $(z, w)$ are local coordinates (with $j$-dependence suppressed), $v_{j}$ is a $(0, q)$-form and $\varphi_{j}$ is as in item i) after Notation 6.1. Substituting it into (6.12), we obtain (omitting " $\circ$ " in $\xi \circ x$ )

$$
\pi_{m}(u)(x)=l(x)^{m} \sum_{j} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \sigma(\xi)_{x}^{*}\left(\varphi_{j}(\xi x) w(\xi x)^{m} v_{j}(\xi x)\right) \bar{\xi}^{m} \tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}(\xi)
$$

We first want to extract $w(x)^{m}$ out of $w(\xi x)^{m}$ in (6.48). Given a local chart $W_{j}:=$ $V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$as in Notation 6.1 and suppose $x \in W_{j}$, there exist at most

finitely many $\alpha_{l}$ 's $\in S^{1}\left(\subset \mathbb{C}^{*}\right)$ dependent on $x$ such that $\alpha_{l} x \in W_{j}$ with $\phi\left(\alpha_{l} x\right)=$ 0 (recall $w=r e^{i \phi}$ ) because if $\alpha_{l}$ is such an element then any $\alpha_{l}^{\prime} \in S^{1}$ near $\alpha_{l}$ will give $\phi\left(\alpha_{l}^{\prime} x\right) \neq 0$ by small angle action (see Case $i$ ) after (6.82)). Let $\alpha_{0}=e^{-i \phi(x)}$ so that $w\left(\alpha_{0} x\right)=\alpha_{0} w(x)(=r(x))$. Denote $J_{l}:=\left\{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}:-\varepsilon_{j}<\arg \left(\xi \alpha_{l}^{-1}\right)<\right.$ $\left.\varepsilon_{j}\right\}$. It follows that for $\xi \in J_{l},-\varepsilon_{j}<\phi(\xi x)=\arg \left(\xi \alpha_{l}^{-1}\right)+\phi\left(\alpha_{l} x\right)=\arg \left(\xi \alpha_{l}^{-1}\right)<\varepsilon_{j}$ hence that $w(\xi x)=\xi \alpha_{l}^{-1} w\left(\alpha_{l} x\right)$ since $\xi \alpha_{l}^{-1}$ is of small angle (Case $i$ ) after (6.82)). Using $\phi\left(\alpha_{l} x\right)=\phi\left(\alpha_{0} x\right)=0$ together with Lemma $7.6 i$ ) gives $w\left(\alpha_{l} x\right)=w\left(\alpha_{0} x\right)=$ $\alpha_{0} w(x)$. In sum, for $\xi \in J_{l}$ we have

$$
w(\xi x)=\xi \alpha_{l}^{-1} \alpha_{0} w(x)
$$

extracting $w(x)$ from $w(\xi x)$, as mentioned earlier. Remark that $\alpha_{l}^{-1} \alpha_{0}$ is independent of $x$ and $\left\{\alpha_{l}^{-1} \alpha_{0}\right\}_{l}$ forms a group (see Proposition 8.7), but we need not use this fact here.

Write $z_{l}=z(\xi x)$ for $\xi \in J_{l}$. Note that $z_{l}$ is independent of $\xi$ in $J_{l}$ (similarly implied by the small angle condition as above). For any fixed $j$ in (6.48), by the cut-off $\varphi_{j}$ we can now reduce the integral in (6.48) to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{l} \int_{\xi \in J_{l}} \xi^{m} \alpha_{l}^{-m} \alpha_{0}^{m} w(x)^{m} \varphi_{j}\left(z_{l}, \phi(\xi x)\right) \sigma(\xi)_{x}^{*} v_{j}\left(z_{l}, w(\xi x)\right) \bar{\xi}^{m} \tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}(\xi) \\
& =\sum_{l} \alpha_{l}^{-m} \alpha_{0}^{m} w(x)^{m} \sigma\left(\alpha_{l}\right)_{x}^{*} \int_{\xi \in J_{l}} \varphi_{j}\left(z_{l}, \phi(\xi x)\right) v_{j}\left(z_{l}, w(\xi x)\right)|\xi|^{2 m} \tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}(\xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that

$$
l(x)^{m} \int_{\xi \in J_{l}}|\xi|^{2 m} \tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}(\xi) \stackrel{(7.20)}{=} \int_{\xi \in J_{l}} l(\xi x)^{m} \tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}(\xi) \stackrel{(3.37)}{=} \frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{\pi}
$$

The fact that $\alpha_{l}$ smoothly depends on $x$ is proved in remarks after (7.49). This leads, via $u=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j} w^{m} v_{j}$ and the definition of $C_{B}^{*}$-norm, to (noting that $\left|\alpha_{l}\right|=1$, $w=|w| e^{i \phi}$ and $\varphi_{j}$ is bounded)

$$
\left\|\pi_{m}(u)\right\|_{C_{B}^{*}} \leq C_{0} \sum_{l} \sum_{j} \sum_{k=0}^{s} \sup _{w}\left\|\varphi_{j}(\cdot, \phi) v_{j}(\cdot, w)\right\|_{C^{k}\left(V_{j}\right)}=C_{0} \cdot(\# \text { of } l)\|u\|_{C_{B}^{*}}
$$

Using the above lemma we continue with the proof of Theorem 6.13.
Proof. (of Theorem 6.13) Let us first prove that $P_{m, t}^{0 *} u=\pi_{m}\left(H_{m, t}^{j *} u\right)$ converges in the $\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{*}}$-norm as $t \rightarrow 0$. The kernel function of $H_{m, t}^{j *}$ reads as (see (6.5) with $x=(z, w), w=|w| e^{i \phi}, y=(\zeta, \eta), \eta=|\eta| e^{i \vartheta}$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
H_{m, t}^{j *}(x, y) & =\overline{w^{-m}(x) \tau_{j}(z(x)) \sigma_{j}(\phi(x)) l(x)^{m}} K_{t}^{j *}(z(x), \zeta) \overline{\varphi_{j}(y) \eta^{m}(y)} \\
& =w^{m} \tau_{j}(z) \sigma_{j}(\phi) h^{m}(z, \bar{z}) K_{t}^{j *}(z, \zeta) \varphi_{j}(y) \overline{\eta^{m}(y)}
\end{aligned}
$$

For given $t$ it is easy to verify that $H_{m, t}^{j *} u \in \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l m}^{0 *}(\Sigma)$. The convergence of $H_{m, t}^{j *} u$ in the $\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{*}}$-norm as $t \rightarrow 0$ follows simply because $K_{t}^{j *}=K_{t}^{j}$ involved in the above expression of $H_{m, t}^{j *}$ has the property that $K_{t}^{j}(u) \rightarrow u$ in $C^{*}$-norm (with respect to $z)$ uniformly in "parameter" $\eta$ since $u$ is assumed to be of compact support (see the bottom paragraph for the variable change to absorb the singular part $\frac{1}{C^{*}}$ (of $\left.K_{t}^{j}\right)$ in $\left[6\right.$, p.85]). This together with Lemma 6.14 yields $P_{m, t}^{0 *} u \rightarrow$ (say) $P_{m, 0}^{0 *} u \in$

$\tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ in the $\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{c}}$-norm as $t \rightarrow 0$. To prove that $P_{m, 0}^{0 *} u=\pi_{m}(u)$ consider for $v \in \Omega_{c}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(P_{m, t}^{0 *} u-\pi_{m} u, v\right)_{L^{2}} & =\left(P_{m, t}^{0 *} u-P_{m, 0}^{0 *} u+P_{m, 0}^{0 *} u-\pi_{m} u, v\right)_{L^{2}} \\
& =\left(P_{m, t}^{0 *} u-P_{m, 0}^{0 *} u, v\right)_{L^{2}}+\left(P_{m, 0}^{0 *} u-\pi_{m} u, v\right)_{L^{2}} \\
& \rightarrow 0+\left(P_{m, 0}^{0 *} u-\pi_{m} u, v\right)_{L^{2}} \text { as } t \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\left(P_{m, t}^{0 *}-\pi_{m}\right) u, v\right)_{L^{2}} & =\left(u,\left(P_{m, t}^{0}-\pi_{m}^{*} v\right)_{L^{2}}\right. \\
& =\left(u,\left(P_{m, t}^{0}-\pi_{m}\right) v\right)_{L^{2}} \rightarrow 0 \text { as } t \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

by Lemma 6.3. It follows from (6.54) and (6.55) that the limit $P_{m, 0}^{0 *} u=\pi_{m} u$. We have shown (6.46).

To show (6.47) we take the adjoint of (6.32) in Lemma 6.10 to get

$$
\partial_{t} P_{m, t}^{0 *}+\left[P_{m, t}^{0}\left(\tilde{\bigcirc}_{m}^{c \pm} \circ \pi_{m}\right)\right]^{*}=R_{t}^{*} \text { on } \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)
$$

where $\left(\tilde{\bigcirc}_{m}^{c \pm}\right.$ is formally self-adjoint on $\left.\Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \supset P_{m, t}^{0 *}\left(\Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}(\Sigma)\right)\right)$; see Lemma 4.9)

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[P_{m, t}^{0}\left(\tilde{\bigcirc}_{m}^{c \pm} \circ \pi_{m}\right)\right]^{*} } & =\pi_{m}^{*} \circ\left(\tilde{\bigcirc}_{m}^{c \pm}\right)^{*} \circ P_{m, t}^{0 *} \\
& =\pi_{m} \circ \tilde{\bigcirc}_{m}^{c \pm} \circ P_{m, t}^{0 *}=\tilde{\bigcirc}_{m}^{c \pm} \circ P_{m, t}^{0 *}
\end{aligned}
$$

giving (6.47). The last claim of the theorem for $R^{*}(t, x, y)$ follows from a similar estimate for $R(t, x, y)$ of (6.33), so that $R^{*}(t, x, y)$ is in $L^{2}(\Sigma \times \Sigma)$ and represents the kernel function of the adjoint operator $R_{t}^{*}$ (compare Lemma 6.12).

Before solving our heat equation let us show that $P_{m, t}^{0 *}$ is a bounded linear operator on $\tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ in the $\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{c}}$-norm uniformly for $t$ near 0 . Recall the notation $\tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ in Definition 3.10. For $u \in \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ recall the definition of $\|u\|_{C_{B}^{c}}$ in (6.7).

Proposition 6.15. Given $\delta>0$ and $s \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$, there exists a constant $C_{s}$ independent of $\delta$ and $t$ (but may depend on $s$ ) such that (see (6.7) for $\left.\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{c}}\right)$

$$
\left\|P_{m, t}^{0 *}(u)\right\|_{C_{B}^{c}} \leq C_{s}\|u\|_{C_{B}^{c}}
$$

for $0 \leq t \leq \delta$ and $u \in \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma) \subset L^{2, *}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$.
Proof. By (6.6) $P_{m, t}^{0 *}=\sum_{j} \pi_{m}^{*} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *}=\sum_{j} \pi_{m} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *}$. We claim that $H_{m, t}^{j *}$ satisfies the following estimate: there exist $\delta_{0}>0$ and $C_{s}^{\prime}>0$ (independent of $\delta_{0}$ and $t$ ) such that for $0<t<\delta_{0}$

$$
\left\|H_{m, t}^{j *} u\right\|_{C_{B}^{c}} \leq C_{s}^{\prime}\|u\|_{C_{B}^{c}}
$$

for $u \in \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l o c}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$. Writing $x=(z, w)(w=|w| e^{i \phi}), y=(\zeta, \eta)$ in local coordinates and $u(y)=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j}(y) u(y)=\sum_{j} \varphi_{j}(y) \eta^{m} v_{j}(y)$, we have by (6.53)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(H_{m, t}^{j *} u\right)(x)=\int_{\Sigma} H_{m, t}^{j *}(x, y) u(y) d v_{\Sigma, m}(y) \\
= & w^{m} h^{m}(z, \bar{z}) \sum_{j} \tau_{j}(z) \sigma_{j}(\phi) \int_{\Sigma} K_{t}^{j *}(z, \zeta) \varphi_{j}(y) \bar{\eta}^{m} \eta^{m} v_{j}(y) d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that for each $t>0 \operatorname{Im} H_{m, t}^{j *}\left|_{\tilde{\Omega}_{m, t \omega}^{0, *}}(\Sigma)\right| \subset \tilde{\Omega}_{m, l \omega}^{0, *}(\Sigma)$ (Definition 3.10). To estimate (uniformly in $t$ ) the $C_{B}^{*}$-norm of the RHS of (6.58) is reduced to estimating the usual $C^{*}$-norm in $z$ and the supremum norm in $w$ of

$$
h^{m}(z, \bar{z}) \tau_{j}(z) \sigma_{j}(\phi) \int_{\Sigma}|\eta|^{2 m} K_{t}^{j *}(z, \zeta) \varphi_{j}(y) v_{j}(y) d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)
$$

The following inequality follows from [6, Theorem 2.20 or 2.29] (cf. comments below (6.53) in the proof of Theorem 6.13): there exists $\delta_{0}>0$ and $C_{s}^{\prime \prime}>0$ (independent of $\delta_{0}$ and $t$ ) such that for $0<t<\delta_{0}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\int K_{t}^{j *}(z, \zeta) \overline{\varphi_{j}(\zeta, \eta) v_{j}(\zeta, \eta)} d v(\zeta)\right\|_{C^{*}(z)} \\
\leq & C_{s}^{\prime \prime} \mid \overline{\varphi_{j}(\cdot, \eta) v_{j}(\cdot, \eta)}\left\|_{C^{*}(\zeta)} \leq C_{s}^{\prime \prime} \sup _{\eta}\right\| \varphi_{j}(\cdot, \eta) v_{j}(\cdot, \eta) \|_{C^{*}(\zeta)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that $|\eta|^{2 m}$ in the integrand of (6.59) is independent of $z$ and its integral with respect to the fibre measure $d v_{f, m}(y)$ is bounded. This together with (6.60) gives

$$
\sup _{w}\| \text { the term (6.59) }\|_{C^{*}(z)} \leq(\text { constant }) \cdot\|u\|_{C_{\tilde{\Omega}}}
$$

Now (6.57) follows. This together with Lemma 6.14 implies (6.56).

One way to solve our heat equation, based on Theorem 6.13 and Proposition 6.15, resorts to the method of successive approximation (cf. [6], [18]). The convolution of two operators $A, B$ is defined through its distribution kernel as usual:

$$
(A \sharp B)_{t}(x, y):=\int_{0}^{t} \int_{\Sigma} A(t-s, x, p) B(s, p, y) d v_{\Sigma, m}(p) d s
$$

The method of successive approximation results in a solution to our heat equation; see Proposition 6.17 below. But since $\Sigma$ is noncompact, to have convergence requires a special class of operators. Fortunately the operators $P_{m}^{0 *}$ and $R^{*}$ belong to this class $\left(P_{m}^{0 *}, R^{*}\right.$ denote the operators with distribution kernels $P_{m, t}^{0 *}(x, y), R_{t}^{*}(x, y)$ respectively). The point is basically that although $\Sigma$ is noncompact, we have only one direction which is noncompact, and the integration along this noncompact direction can be controlled by the choice of our metric $G_{a, m}$ (see Remark 3.4). Another ingredient to be used here is (6.49) in the proof of Lemma 6.14 above; see the proof of Lemma 6.16 below. These features give more complexities than the previous work [18, Proposition 5.14].

Lemma 6.16. The kernel functions associated to $R_{t}^{*}, \cdots,\left(R^{* k}\right)_{t}\left(=\left(R^{*} \sharp R^{*} \cdots\right.\right.$ $\left.\sharp R^{*}\right)_{t}, k$ copies) and $P_{m, t}^{0 *},\left(P_{m}^{0 *} \sharp R^{*}\right)_{t},\left(P_{m}^{0 *} \sharp R^{*} \sharp R^{*}\right)_{t}, \cdots$ are of the form (6.8). Moreover, given $s \in \mathbb{N}$, there are $1>\delta_{0}, \delta_{1}>0$ and $C_{s}>0$ (independent of $\delta_{0}, \delta_{1}$ and $t$ ) such that for all $t \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|R_{t}^{*}\right\|_{C_{\tilde{\Omega}}} \leq \frac{1}{2} e^{-\frac{\delta_{1}}{\tau}}, \cdots,\left\|\left(R^{* k}\right)_{t}\right\|_{C_{\tilde{\Omega}}} \leq \frac{1}{2^{k}} e^{-\frac{\delta_{1}}{\tau}} \\
\left\|P_{m}^{0 *} \sharp R^{*}\right\|_{C_{\tilde{\Omega}}} \leq \frac{C_{s}}{2} e^{-\frac{\delta_{1}}{\tau}}, \cdots,\left\|P_{m}^{0 *} \sharp R^{* k}\right\|_{C_{\tilde{\Omega}}} \leq \frac{C_{s}}{2^{k}} e^{-\frac{\delta_{1}}{\tau}}
\end{gathered}
$$

Here $\left\|R_{t}^{*}\right\|_{C_{\tilde{\Omega}}}$ means $\left\|R_{t}^{*}(x, y)\right\|_{C_{\tilde{\Omega}}(\Sigma \times \Sigma)}$ (as given in (6.9)), etc.

Proof. By (6.12) we easily obtain

$$
\left(\pi_{m} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *}\right)(x, y)=l(x)^{m} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \sigma(\xi)_{x}^{*} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *}(\xi x, y) \bar{\xi}^{m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi)
$$

and by (6.53) we have $\left(w=|w| e^{i \phi}\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (6.65) \sigma(\xi)_{x}^{*} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *}(\xi x, y) \\
& \quad=\sigma(\xi)_{x}^{*} \circ w^{m}(\xi x) h^{m}(z(\xi x), \bar{z}(\xi x)) \tau_{j}(z(\xi x)) \sigma_{j}(\phi(\xi x)) K_{t}^{j *}(z(\xi x), \zeta) \varphi_{j}(y) \bar{\eta}^{m}(y)
\end{aligned}
$$

Next we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
& w^{m}(\xi x) h^{m}(z(\xi x), \bar{z}(\xi x)) \\
& \stackrel{(6.49)}{=} h^{m}(z(\xi x), \bar{z}(\xi x))\left(\xi \alpha_{k}^{-1} \alpha_{0}\right)^{m} w^{m}(x) \text { for } \xi \in J_{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting (6.66) into (6.65) we see that $\pi_{m} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *}(x, y)$ is of the form (6.8) (containing factors $w^{m}(x)$ and $\bar{\eta}^{m}(y)$ ) after the parameter $\xi$ is integrated out in (6.64). Hence $P_{m, t}^{0 *}(x, y)=\sum_{j}\left(\pi_{m} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *}\right)(x, y)$ is of the form (6.8). Alternatively we can take the adjoint of $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, y)=\sum_{j} w^{m} p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y) \bar{\eta}^{m}$ (see (7.49) for the explicit form of $p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y))$ to obtain $P_{m, t}^{0 *}(x, y)=\sum_{j} w(x)^{m} p_{m, t}^{0, j *}(x, y) \overline{\eta(y)}^{m}$ where we have, via (7.49) using $K_{t}^{j *}=K_{t}^{j},\left(\alpha_{k} \alpha_{0}^{-1}\right)=\alpha_{k}^{-1} \alpha_{0}$ and $z_{k}=z\left(\alpha_{k} x\right)$

$$
p_{m, t}^{0, j *}(x, y)=h^{m}(z(x), \bar{z}(x)) \sum_{k=0}^{\Lambda}\left(\alpha_{k}^{-1} \alpha_{0}\right)^{m} \sigma\left(\alpha_{k}\right)_{x}^{*}\left\{\tau_{j}\left(z_{k}\right) K_{t}^{j}\left(z_{k}, \zeta(y)\right)\right\} \varphi_{j}(y)
$$

For $R_{t}^{*}=\pi_{m} \circ \hat{R}_{t}^{*}$ we can also get its kernel function through a direct computation using the formulas for $\pi_{m}(6.12)$ and $\hat{R}_{t}(6.41)$ in a way parallel to (6.64) and (6.67) (with $\xi$ integrated out using (3.27) and (6.2)). Putting $R_{t}^{*}(x, y)=$ $\sum_{j} w^{m} r_{t}^{j *}(x, y) \bar{\eta}^{m}$ we have

$$
r_{t}^{j *}(x, y)=h^{m}(z(x), \bar{z}(x)) \sum_{k=0}^{\Lambda}\left(\alpha_{k}^{-1} \alpha_{0}\right)^{m} \sigma\left(\alpha_{k}\right)_{x}^{*}\left(\left[\square_{z_{k}, m}^{c \pm}, \tau_{j}\left(z_{k}\right)\right] K_{t}^{j}\left(z_{k}, \zeta(y)\right)\right) \varphi_{j}(y)
$$

By $\left\|R(t, x, y)\right\|_{\left(C_{R}^{*}(\Sigma \times \Sigma)\right.} \leq C_{s} e^{-\frac{\tau_{0}}{t}}$ for $t>0$ (6.33) and Theorem 6.13 iii) we conclude

$$
\left\|R_{t}^{*}\right\|_{C_{R}^{*}} \leq \frac{1}{2} e^{-\frac{\tau_{1}}{t}}
$$

in (6.62).
Next we compute the convolution

$$
\left(P_{m}^{0 *} \sharp R^{*}\right)_{t}(x, y)=\sum_{j, j^{\prime}}\left(P_{m}^{0, j *} \sharp R^{j^{\prime} *}\right)_{t}(x, y)=\sum_{j, j^{\prime}} w^{m}(x)\left(p_{m}^{0, j *} \sharp r^{j^{\prime} *}\right)_{t}(x, y) \bar{\eta}^{\prime m}(y)
$$

where, with $y=\left(\zeta^{\prime}, \eta^{\prime}\right), q=\left(\beta^{\prime}, \gamma^{\prime}\right)$ in the $j^{\prime}$-chart and $q=(\beta, \gamma)$ in the $j$-chart

$$
\left(p_{m}^{0, j *} \sharp r^{j^{\prime} *}\right)_{t}(x, y):=\int_{0}^{t} \int_{\Sigma} p_{m, t-s}^{0, j *}(x, q) \bar{\gamma}(q)^{m} \gamma^{\prime}(q)^{m} r_{s}^{j^{\prime} *}(q, y) d v_{\Sigma, m}(q) d s
$$

The integrand $p_{m, t-s}^{0, j *}(x, q) \bar{\gamma}(q)^{m} \gamma^{\prime}(q)^{m} r_{s}^{j^{\prime} *}(q, y)$ in (6.71) has the following explicit expression: (denoting by $\alpha_{l}^{\prime}$ the corresponding $\alpha_{k}$ in the $j^{\prime}$-chart where $\beta_{l}^{\prime}:=$

$\beta^{\prime}\left(\alpha_{l}^{\prime} q\right)\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { (6.72) } h^{m}(z(x), \bar{z}(x)) \sum_{k=0}^{\Lambda}\left(\alpha_{k}^{-1} \alpha_{0}\right)^{m} \sigma\left(\alpha_{k}\right)_{x}^{*}\left\{\tau_{j}\left(z_{k}\right) K_{l-s}^{j}\left(z_{k}, \beta(q)\right)\right\} \varphi_{j}(q) \bar{\gamma}(q)^{m} \\
& \cdot \gamma^{\prime}(q)^{m} h^{\prime m}\left(\beta^{\prime}(q), \bar{\beta}^{\prime}(q)\right) \sum_{l=0}^{\Lambda^{\prime}}\left(\alpha_{l}^{\prime-1} \alpha_{0}^{\prime}\right)^{m} \sigma\left(\alpha_{l}^{\prime}\right)_{q}^{*}\left(\left\|\square_{\beta_{l}^{\prime}, m}^{c \pm}, \tau_{j^{\prime}}\left(\beta_{l}^{\prime}\right)\right\| K_{s}^{j^{\prime}}\left(\beta_{l}^{\prime}, \zeta^{\prime}(y)\right)\right\} \varphi_{j^{\prime}}(y)
\end{aligned}
$$

To bound $\left\|P_{m}^{0 *} \sharp R^{*}\right\|_{C_{B}^{*}}$ by $e^{-\frac{\gamma}{\alpha}}$ note first that for the singular term $\frac{1}{(t-s)^{n-1}}$ along the diagonal of $K_{l-s}^{j}$ in (6.72) we can get rid of it using the change of variable on $t-s$ as in the proof of Theorem 6.13 above. This and $\left\|r_{s}^{j^{\prime *}}\right\|_{C^{t}} \leq \frac{1}{2} e^{-\frac{\gamma}{\alpha}}$ (6.69) (note that $e^{-c / s} \leq e^{-c / t}$ for $0<s \leq t$ ) give that $K_{l-s}^{j}$ hence $p_{m, t-s}^{0, j *}$ and $r_{s}^{j^{\prime} *}$ in (6.71) are jointly controlled by the factor $e^{-c / t}$ after integrating out " $q$ ", i.e. the $z$-part $\beta(q)$ of $q$. Using this one sees that, as $\gamma^{\prime}$ and $\gamma$ differ by a bounded holomorphic transition function and $|\gamma(q)|^{2 m}$ is integrable by Remark 3.4, the convolution (6.72) in (6.71) is integrable since $\left|\alpha_{k}\right|=\left|\alpha_{l}^{\prime}\right|=1$ and $h^{m}, h^{\prime m}$ are bounded. Altogether the first inequality in (6.63) for the $C_{B}^{0}$-norm follows. For the $C_{B}^{*}$-norm, $s>0$, we note that the derivatives of (6.72) in $z(x)$ and $\zeta(y)$ do not change the above basic structure. So we also have (6.63) for the $C_{B}^{*}$-norm. From the structure of $P_{m, t}^{0 *}$ and $R_{t}^{*}$ we see without difficulty that the similar conclusions hold with all the other convolutions mentioned in the lemma.

We can now adapt [18, Proposition 5.14] here and reach the following result of similar nature, with the difference that we are adopting $C_{B}^{*}$-norms here.

Proposition 6.17. i) (Existence) Given $s \in \mathbb{N}$, there exists $\varepsilon>0$ such that for every fixed $t \in(0, \varepsilon)$ the kernel function $\Lambda_{t}(x, y)$ given by

$$
\Lambda_{t}(x, y):=P_{m, t}^{0 *}(x, y)-\left(P_{m}^{0 *} \sharp R^{*}\right)_{t}(x, y)+\left(P_{m}^{0 *} \sharp R^{*} \sharp R^{*}\right)_{t}(x, y)-\cdots
$$

exists, and converges in $C_{B}^{*}(\Sigma \times \Sigma)$ (including its $t$-derivatives up to any given order). ii) Let $\left(R^{* k}\right)_{t}$ be as in Lemma 6.16, $k \geq 0$. Suppose $u \in L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$. Then $\left(P_{m}^{0 *} \sharp R^{* k}\right)_{t} u \in L_{m}^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$. In particular the image of $\Lambda_{t}$ lies in the $m$-space. Moreover for $u \in \Omega_{c}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial \Lambda_{t}}{\partial t} u+\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm} \Lambda_{t} u & =0 \\
\lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}} \Lambda_{t} u & =\pi_{m} u \text { in }\|\cdot\|_{C_{B}^{*}}
\end{aligned}
$$

iii) (Approximation) Given $s \in \mathbb{N}$, there exists $\varepsilon_{0}>0$ independent of $t$ such that

$$
\left\|\Lambda_{t}(\cdot, \cdot)-P_{m, t}^{0 *}(\cdot, \cdot)\right\|_{C_{B}^{*}(\Sigma \times \Sigma)} \leq e^{-\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{t}} \text { for all } t \in\left(0, \varepsilon_{0}\right)
$$

Proof. It follows from (6.63) that the sequence (6.73) converges in the $C_{B}^{*}$-norm and (6.75) holds. By the definition of the $C_{B}^{*}$-norm associated with a fixed $m$ (6.9), the function $\Lambda_{t}(x, y)$ of (6.73) exists on $\Sigma \times \Sigma$.

For $i i$ ) we observe that the image of the convolution lies in the image of its first operator. In our case the first operator is $P_{m, t}^{0 *}$ so the image is in the $m$-space. To verify (6.74) takes slightly more work. Let $q_{t}^{k}$ denote the $(k+1)$-th term in (6.73).

A direct computation shows that

$$
\frac{\partial q_{t}^{k}}{\partial t}(x, y)+\widetilde{C}_{m, x}^{v \pm} q_{t}^{k}(x, y)=\left(R^{* k}\right)_{t}(x, y)+\left(R^{*(k+1)}\right)_{t}(x, y)
$$

(cf. $[6,(2)$ of Lemma 2.22]). Noting that $\Lambda_{t}$ is the alternating sum of these $q_{t}^{k}$, one interchanges the order of the action of $\partial_{t}+\widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}$ on $\Lambda_{t}$ with the summation in view of (6.63) and similar estimates on their $t$-derivatives. The first equation of (6.74) follows from telescoping with (6.76) (cf. [6, Theorem 2.23]). The second equality of (6.74) follows from (6.46) (cf. (6.56)) and (6.62).

We are now back to discuss the properties of $P_{m, t}^{0, \pm}$. Recall that $e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}(x, y)$ is the heat kernel that we obtain in Proposition 5.8. Similarly let $\Lambda_{t}^{ \pm}$denote $\Lambda_{t}$ acting on the even/odd elements. Suppose $B_{t}^{ \pm}, t>0$, is any bounded linear operator on $L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right)$ such that $i$ ) for $\psi \in \Omega^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) \cap L^{2, \pm}\left(\Sigma, \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, G_{a, m}\right), B_{t}^{ \pm} \psi \in$ $\Omega_{m}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma) ;$ ii) $B_{t}^{ \pm} \psi$ satisfies the heat equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\partial_{t}+\widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}\right) B_{t}^{ \pm} \psi & =0 \quad \text { (differentiability in } t \text { is assumed) } \\
B_{t}^{ \pm} \psi & \rightarrow \pi_{m} \psi \text { in } L^{2} \text { as } t \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

iii) $B_{t}^{ \pm} \psi \rightarrow B_{t_{0}}^{ \pm} \psi$ in $L^{2}$ as $t \rightarrow t_{0}$ for any fixed $t_{0}>0$. The uniqueness part is the following.

Theorem 6.18. i) (Uniqueness) It holds that

$$
B_{t}^{ \pm}=e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}, \text { in particular }
$$

$$
\Lambda_{t}^{ \pm}(x, y)=e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}(x, y)
$$

and as a consequence $\Lambda_{t}^{ \pm}$are self-adjoint (Proposition 5.8).
ii) (Approximation) For every $s \in \mathbb{N}$ there exist $\varepsilon_{0}>0$ and $\varepsilon>0$ such that

$$
\left\|e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}(\cdot, \cdot)-P_{m, t}^{0, \pm}(\cdot, \cdot)\right\|_{C_{B}^{s}(\Sigma \times \Sigma)} \leq e^{-\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{t}} \text { for all } t \in(0, \varepsilon)
$$

As a consequence $e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}(x, y)$ and $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, y)$ are the same in the sense of asymptotic expansion (as defined in [18, Definition 5.5] with $C^{l}$-norms replaced by $C_{B}^{l}$-norms). Along the diagonal it holds that

$$
\left|e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}(x, x)-P_{m, t}^{0, \pm}(x, x)\right|=O\left(l(x)^{m} e^{-\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{t}}\right)
$$

( $l(x)$ being unbounded on $\Sigma$ ).
Proof. The idea of the proof can now follow that in [6]. We compute for $\psi, \varphi \in$ $\Omega_{v}^{0, \pm}(\Sigma), \partial_{\tau}<B_{t-\tau}^{ \pm} \psi, e^{-\tau \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}} \varphi>=0(0<\tau<t)$ by using heat equations (6.77) and (5.9). By the initial condition in (6.77) and (5.9), and the images of $e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}}$ and $B_{t}^{ \pm}$belonging to the $m$-space (Proposition 5.8 and the property $i$ ) of $B_{t}^{ \pm}$), we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =\int_{0}^{t} \partial_{\tau}<B_{t-\tau}^{ \pm} \psi, e^{-\tau \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}} \varphi>d \tau=< \pi_{m}^{ \pm} \psi, e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}} \varphi>-<B_{t}^{ \pm} \psi, \pi_{m} \varphi> \\
& =<\psi, e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}} \varphi>-<B_{t}^{ \pm} \psi, \varphi>=<e^{-t \widetilde{C}_{m}^{v \pm}} \psi, \varphi>-<B_{t}^{ \pm} \psi, \varphi>
\end{aligned}
$$

Here the property iii) of $B_{t}^{ \pm}$has been used for the second equality above. So (6.78) hence (6.79) follows. From (6.75), (6.79) and $e^{-t \hat{\omega}_{m}^{0} \dot{\alpha}}$ being self-adjoint (cf. Proposition 5.8), (6.80) follows.

As for the factor $l(x)^{m}$ in (6.81) we first observe that $P_{m, t}^{0 *}=\sum_{j} \pi_{m} \circ H_{m, t}^{j *}$ contains the factor $l(x)^{m}$ in view of (6.64). Therefore $P_{m, t}^{0 *}(x, x)$, hence $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)$, contains the factor $l(x)^{m}$ so do $\Lambda_{t}^{ \pm}(x, x)$ and $e^{-t \hat{\omega}_{m}^{0} \dot{\alpha}}(x, x)$ in view of (6.73) (the convolution led by $P_{m, t}^{0 *}$ always has the factor $l(x)^{m}$ ) and (6.79). This together with (6.80) gives (6.81).

In the remaining of this section, we shall treat $P_{m, t}^{0}$ more closely as will be needed in the next section via (6.79) above. The main result is Theorem 6.19 below. Writing $\xi^{-1} y$ for $\xi^{-1} \circ y$, we have ${ }^{7}$ (see (6.5) with $x=(z, w), y=(\zeta, \eta)$ )

$$
\begin{gathered}
H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} y\right) \circ \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} \circ y}^{*}=\varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} K_{t}^{j}\left(z, \zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \eta^{-m}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right) \\
\tau_{j}\left(\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \sigma_{j}\left(\vartheta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) l\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)^{m} \circ \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} y}^{*}
\end{gathered}
$$

Due to $\xi^{-1} y$ in the arguments above, we note the following two cases (cf. (2.6), $(2.7))$ :

Case $i$ ) : If $\xi$ is close to 1 such that $\xi^{-1} y$ is still in the same chart as $y$ (where $\zeta(y)=\zeta$ ), then $\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)=\zeta, \eta^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)=\bar{\xi}^{-m} \eta^{m}$ and $\vartheta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)=\vartheta(y)-\gamma$ where we write $\xi=|\xi| e^{\imath \gamma}$

Case $i i$ ) : For $\xi$ general, $\xi^{-1} y$ and $y$ do not necessarily lie in the same chart. Even if $\xi^{-1} y$ and $y$ lie in the same chart, unlike case $i$ ) the $\zeta$-values of $\xi^{-1} y$ and $y$ may not be the same. Indeed $\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right) \neq \zeta(y)$ for $y$ near the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-strata $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ of $\Sigma$. See (7.14) for the detail. This fact will be rather crucial for us in the subsequent sections.

Remark that if the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma$ on $\Sigma$ is globally free then only Case $i$ ) will occur (and in this case it is valid to take all $\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ rather than $\xi \sim 1$ ).

Substituting (6.82) into the RHS of (6.26) gives, recalling $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, y)=\sum_{j}\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ\right.$ $\left.\pi_{m}\right)(x, y)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, y)=\varphi_{j}(x) \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}\left\{w^{m} K_{t}^{j}\left(z, \zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \eta^{-m}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right. \\
& \left.\tau_{j}\left(\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \sigma_{j}\left(\vartheta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) l\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)^{m} \bar{\xi}^{m}\right\} \circ \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} y}^{*} d \mu_{y, m}(\xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

It is well known that the (ordinary, local) heat kernel $K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta)$ has the asymptotic expansion (see for instance $[18,(5.19)$ on p.76])

$$
\begin{aligned}
K_{t}^{j}(z, \zeta) & =e^{-\frac{d \bar{\xi}_{j}(z, \zeta)}{4 t}} K^{j}(t, z, \zeta) \\
K^{j}(t, z, \zeta) & \sim t^{-n+1} b_{n-1}(z, \zeta)+t^{-n+2} b_{n-2}(z, \zeta)+\ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

as $t \rightarrow 0^{+}$for $z, \zeta$ in $V_{j}$, where $\tilde{d}_{M}$ denotes the distance function associated with the metric $\pi^{\star} g_{M} \mid V_{j}$ (cf. (3.9) with lines above). Note that $\tilde{d}_{M}$ may depend on the

choice of charts $V_{j}$ a priori. Recalling that $V_{j}$ is endowed with the metric induced by $\pi^{*} g_{M}$, we can assume $V_{j}$ (as a Riemannian manifold) to be convex for every $j$ (possibly after shrinking).
