Via (6.84) we then get an asymptotic expansion of (6.83) for $\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, y)$ hence for $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, y)$ without difficulty (the fact that $l\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)^{m} \dot{\xi}^{m}=l(y)^{m} \xi^{-m}$ by (7.20) has been used here).

Theorem 6.19. (Asymptotic expansion) With the notation above, we have that $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, y)$ is of the form (6.8) and, via (6.80)
(6.85) $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, y), e^{-t \widetilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm}}(x, y) \sim t^{-(n-1)} a_{n-1}(t, x, y)+t^{-(n-2)} a_{n-2}(t, x, y)+\cdots$
(for the meaning of the above " $\sim$ " we refer to [18, Definition 5.5, p.75] with $C^{l}$ norms replaced by $C_{B}^{l}$-norms) where for $s=n-1, n-2, \cdots$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{s}(t, x, y)=l(y)^{m} \sum_{j} \varphi_{j}(x) w^{m} & \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}\left\{e^{-\frac{\tilde{d}_{M}^{2}(x, \xi)}{2 t}} b_{s}(z, \zeta)\right. \\
& \left.\eta^{-m} \tau_{j}(\zeta) \sigma_{j}(\vartheta) \xi^{-m}\right\} d \mu_{y, m}(\xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

where to simplify notations, we use $\zeta, \eta^{-m}$ and $\vartheta$ to denote $\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right), \eta^{-m}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)$ and $\vartheta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)$ respectively.

Remark 6.20. Even for $x=y, a_{s}(t, x, x)$ still depends on $t$. See [18, Remark 1.6] for details. Further $a_{s}(t, x, y)$ are not uniquely determined; indeed they depend on the various data in, e.g. (6.5), (6.1) and (6.2). In contrast $b_{s}(z, \zeta)$ in (6.86) is intrinsic (cf. remarks after (7.9)). Note that $P_{m, t}^{0}$ may not preserve the $m$-space. However if we consider $\tilde{P}_{m, t}^{0}(x, y):=\left(\pi_{m} \circ P_{m, t}^{0}\right)(x, y)$ it is not difficult to see that the associated $\tilde{a}_{s}(t, x, y)$ (resp. $\left.\tilde{P}_{m, t}^{0}(x, y)\right)$ descends to $\underline{\tilde{a}}_{s}(t, \pi(x), \pi(y))$ (resp. $\left.\tilde{\mathrm{P}}_{m, t}^{0}(\pi(x), \pi(y))\right)$ on the compact complex orbifold $M=\Sigma / \sigma$ (as one can show $\left.\left(\sigma_{\alpha, \beta}^{*} \tilde{a}_{s}(t, \cdot, \cdot)\right)(x, y)=\right.$ $\left.\alpha^{m}(\bar{\beta})^{m} \tilde{a}_{s}(t, x, y)\right.$ where $\left.\sigma_{\alpha, \beta}(x, y):=(\alpha x, \beta y)\right.$ and similar formulas for $\tilde{P}_{m, t}^{0}(x, y)$ ). It can be shown that both $\underline{\tilde{a}}_{s}(t, \pi(x), \pi(y))$ and $\widetilde{\mathrm{P}}_{m, t}^{0}(\pi(x), \pi(y))$ are associated with $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{c \pm}$, as the extension of $\square_{V_{j}, m}^{c \pm}$ to $M$ in (5.6) (acting on sections of the $m$-th power of orbifold line bundle $L_{\Sigma}^{+} / \sigma$, cf. Remarks 10.9 and 10.10).

# 7. Asymptotic expansion of the transversal heat kernel 

The goal of this section is to prove Theorem 1.3. Our notation follows that of the introductory paragraph of the last section. Recall that (see (6.6))

$$
P_{m, t}^{0}=\sum_{j} H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}
$$

$\hat{W}_{j} \subset W_{j}\left(=V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}\right)$and $\varepsilon_{j}(=\varepsilon, \forall j)$ small, such that

$$
\hat{W}_{j}=V_{j} \times\left(-\frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{4}, \frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{4}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}
$$

and $\Sigma$ is still a union of finitely many $\hat{W}_{j}$.

Assume that $x \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ is in the chart $\dot{W}_{j}$ and $x$ has coordinates $(z, w)$ with $z$ $\in V_{j}, w=|w| e^{i \phi}$. We write $\xi^{-1} x$ (resp. $\left.\left(\sigma_{\xi^{-1}}^{*}\right)_{x}\right)$ for $\xi^{-1} \circ x$ (resp. $\left.\sigma\left(\xi^{-1}\right)_{\bar{x}}^{*}\right)$. From (6.83) for $x=y$ we write ${ }^{8}$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left.\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, x)=\varphi_{j}(x) \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}\left\{w^{m}(x) K_{t}^{j}(z(x), z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right))\bar{w}^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right.\right. \\
\left.\left.h^{m}\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right), \bar{z}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \tau_{j}\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \sigma_{j}\left(\phi\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \bar{\xi}^{m}\right\} \circ\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x} d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)
\end{gathered}
$$

Let $\frac{2 \pi}{p}$ be the largest period of the action $\left.\sigma\right|_{S^{1}}$. By assumption $x$ has the period $\frac{2 \pi}{p}$ since $x \in \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$. To facilitate the computation of (7.3), we divide $\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ into two parts:

Part I: $\xi \in C:=\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$;
Part II: $\xi \in C^{\prime}:=\left(\varepsilon_{j}, \frac{2 \pi}{p}-\varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$.
Part I of the RHS of (7.3): Let us first compute the RHS of (7.3) for $\xi$ in Part I. The net result will be given in (7.11) and (7.12). For $\xi$ in Part I, by case $i$ ) after (6.82) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Part I of }\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, x)=\varphi_{j}(x) \int_{\xi \in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}}\left\{w^{m} K_{t}^{j}(z, z)\right. \\
& \xi^{m} w^{-m} l\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)^{m} \tau_{j}(z) \sigma_{j}\left(\phi\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \bar{\xi}^{m}\} d \mu_{x, m}(\xi) \\
& \stackrel{(7.20)}{=} \varphi_{j}(x) l^{m}(x) K_{t}^{j}(z, z) \tau_{j}(z) \int_{\xi \in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}} \sigma_{j}\left(\phi\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

Plugging in $d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)$ for $\xi \in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$(see (6.25)), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)=\frac{l\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)^{m} d v_{\Sigma, m}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right) \wedge d v_{f, m}(x)}{d v_{\Sigma, m}(x)} \\
& \stackrel{(\text { 3.22) }}{=} \frac{h^{m}(z, \bar{z})\left|\xi^{-1} w\right|^{2 m} d v\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \wedge\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \wedge d v_{f, m}(x)}{d v(z(x)) \wedge d v_{f, m}(x)} \\
& =l^{m}(x)|\xi|^{-2 m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \frac{d v\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right)}{d v(z(x))}
\end{aligned}
$$

See also (7.23) for $d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)$.
Write $d v\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) / d v(z(x))=: f\left(\xi^{-1}\right)$ (which equals 1 since $z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)=z(x)$ for the Part I case but we keep the notation). In (7.4) the following term simplifies (via (2.7) for the $\mathbb{R}^{+}$-action)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\xi \in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}} \sigma_{j}\left(\phi\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) d \mu_{x, m}(\xi) \\
= & l^{m}(x) \int_{\xi \in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}} \sigma_{j}\left(\phi\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right)|\xi|^{-2 m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}\right) f\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \\
& \stackrel{\eta=\xi^{-1}}{=} \quad l^{m}(x) \int_{\eta \in\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}} \sigma_{j}(\phi(\eta x))|\eta|^{2 m}\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\eta) f(\eta) \\
& \eta=|\eta| e^{i \tau} \stackrel{(3.23)}{=} \int_{|\eta| \in \mathbb{R}^{+}} \int_{I} \sigma_{j}(\gamma+\phi(x)) f(\eta) \frac{d v_{\mathbb{R}^{+}}(\gamma)}{2 \pi} l^{m}(x)|\eta|^{2 m} d v_{m}(|\eta||w|) .
\end{aligned}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{8}$ See the footnote attached to (6.82) of Section 6.

where $I \supset\left[-\frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{2}, \frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{2}\right]$ since $\phi(x) \in\left(-\frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{4}, \frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{4}\right)$ by (7.2). Now by (6.2) for $\int_{I} \sigma_{j}=1$ and choosing coordinates with $h(z(x), \bar{z}(x))=1$ at this $x$ so that $l^{m}(x)=h^{m}|w|^{2 m}=$ $|w|^{2 m}$ and using $f(\eta)=1$ (cf. Lemma 7.6 ii) below), the RHS of (7.6) equals:

$$
\int_{|\eta| \in \mathbb{R}^{+}}|w|^{2 m}|\eta|^{2 m} d v_{m}(|\eta||w|)^{\tilde{\eta} \overline{=} w \eta} \int_{|\tilde{\eta}| \in \mathbb{R}^{+}}|\tilde{\eta}|^{2 m} d v_{m}(|\tilde{\eta}|) \stackrel{(3.20)}{=} 1
$$

Remark that the resulting constant 1 in (7.7) hence in (7.6) plays an implicit yet crucial role in many places of our computation (cf. (7.11), (8.30), (8.32) and (8.33); also (3.37), (3.39)). We are not going to elaborate on the question whether it would still be possible to obtain the existence of a local index density of Theorem 1.1 if the metric $G_{a, m}$ used here did not possess this unity-property.

Substituting (7.6) and (7.7) into (7.4), we obtain
(7.8) Part I of $\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, x)=\varphi_{j}(x) l^{m}(x) K_{t}^{j}(z, z)\left(\tau_{j}(z)=1\right.$ on $\left.\operatorname{supp} \varphi_{j}\right)$.

Recall the asymptotic expansion of the (ordinary, local) heat kernel $K_{t}^{j}\left(z, z^{\prime}\right)$ (see (6.84) or $[18,(5.19)$ on p.76]):

$$
\begin{aligned}
K_{t}^{j}\left(z, z^{\prime}\right) & =e^{-\frac{d_{M}^{2}\left|z, z^{\prime}\right|}{4 t}} K^{j}\left(t, z, z^{\prime}\right) \\
K^{j}\left(t, z, z^{\prime}\right) & \sim t^{-n+1} b_{n-1}\left(z, z^{\prime}\right)+t^{-n+2} b_{n-2}\left(z, z^{\prime}\right)+\ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

as $t \rightarrow 0^{+}$for $z, z^{\prime}$ in $V_{j}$, where $\tilde{d}_{M}$ denotes the distance function associated with the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M} \|_{V_{j}}$ (cf. (3.9) with lines above).

It is not difficult to see via Theorem 2.3 (with its proof) that $\tilde{d}_{M}$ is the distance function on orbifold charts, associated with the metric $g_{M}$ on $M=\Sigma / \sigma$ (via the projection $\Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma / \sigma$ ). The reader is warned that $\tilde{d}_{M}$ is in general not the distance function on $M$ (unless the globally free case).

Further, the coefficients $b_{s}\left(z, z^{\prime}\right)(s=n-1, n-2, \cdots)$ in (7.9) depend only on $(x, y)$ (with $z(x)=z, z(y)=z^{\prime}$ ) and are independent of the choice of charts $D_{j} \ni x, y$. For, it is well known ([6, Chapter 2]) that the coefficients depend only on the local geometry; since the local geometry we use consists of $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ and the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant metric on $L_{\Sigma}^{*}$ (see (6.3), (5.6) and Step 1 of Section 3), these can be regarded as local geometry data on the orbifold $M=\Sigma / \sigma$ (with $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow M$ ) thus intrinsic in nature.

For every compact set $K \subset V_{j}$, there is a constant $C_{K}>1$ such that

$$
\frac{1}{C_{K}}\left|z-z^{\prime}\right| \leq \tilde{d}_{M}\left(z, z^{\prime}\right) \leq C_{K}\left|z-z^{\prime}\right|
$$

Set $b_{s}(z):=b_{s}(z, z), s \leq n-1$. Note that $b_{s}(z)$ (dependent on $z=z(x))$ are independent of $j$ as just mentioned. Plugging (7.9) into (7.8) and noting $\tilde{d}_{M}^{2}(z, z)$ $=0$ yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Part I of } \sum_{j}\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, x) \\
& \sim t^{-n+1} \alpha_{n-1}(x)+t^{-n+2} \alpha_{n-2}(x)+\cdots \text { as } t \rightarrow 0^{+}
\end{aligned}
$$

where, for $s \leq n-1$,

$$
\alpha_{s}(x)=b_{s}(z(x)) l^{m}(x)
$$

This finishes the computation of (7.3) for $\xi$ in Part I.

Part II of the RHS of (7.3): The computation for $\xi$ in Part II of (7.3) takes some extra work for which we start with the following set-up. First recall that $\frac{2 \pi}{p_{j}}, p=p_{1}<p_{2}<\ldots<p_{k}$, denote all possible periods of the locally free action $\left.\sigma\right|_{S^{1}}$. Define $\Sigma_{p_{j}}:=\left\{x \in \Sigma\right.$ : the period of $x$ is $\left.\frac{2 \pi}{p_{j}}\right\}$ and recall $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}:=\cup_{j=2}^{k} \Sigma_{p_{j}}$ (cf. (1.7)). Let $d(\cdot, \cdot)$ denote the distance function on $\Sigma$ with respect to the metric $G_{a, m}$.

Recall that we have the case $i i$ ) stated after (6.82). We are going to be more precise about it in (7.14) below. Let us start with

Definition 7.1. (cf. Remark 7.2 for geometrical aspects) $S:=\left\{l e^{-i \tilde{\gamma}}: 0<\frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{2} \leq\right.$ $\left.\tilde{\gamma} \leq \frac{2 \pi}{p}-\frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{2}, l \in \mathbb{R}^{+}\right\}$

$$
\hat{d}\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right):=\inf \{d(s \circ x, x): s \in S\} \geq 0
$$

We claim the existence of a constant $\hat{\varepsilon}_{0}>0$ satisfying the following. Let $x \in$ $\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ and $x=(z, w) \in \hat{W}_{j}($ see $(7.2))$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Suppose } e^{-i \gamma} \circ x & =(\tilde{z}, \tilde{w}) \in \hat{W}_{j} \text { for some } \gamma \in\left[\varepsilon_{j}, \frac{2 \pi}{p}-\varepsilon_{j}\right] \\
\text { Then }|\tilde{z}-z| & \geq \hat{\varepsilon}_{0} \hat{d}\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)>0
\end{aligned}
$$

The Case $i i$ ) after (6.82) has mentioned that the above $z, \tilde{z}$ could be different. Here (7.14) confirms a positive lower bound for $|\tilde{z}-z|$ (see $[18,(6.5)]$ for a statement similar to (7.14)).

Proof. (of (7.14)) First it can be verified that there is an $\hat{\varepsilon}_{0}>0$ independent of $w$ such that $|\tilde{z}-z| \geq \hat{\varepsilon}_{0} d((\tilde{z}, w),(z, w))$. For this verification, we content ourselves with referring to (3.21) and (3.14) where $G_{a, m}$ is seen to be uniformly bounded along the $w$-direction. For instance, choosing the curve $((1-t) z+t \tilde{z}, w)$ with estimation of its length implies this inequality. With $\hat{w}$ in (7.14) writing $\xi_{1}=w / \hat{w}=\left|\xi_{1}\right| e^{i \phi}$ with $-\varepsilon_{j} / 2<\phi<\varepsilon_{j} / 2$ (by the $\hat{W}_{j}$-condition), we note that $\xi_{1} \circ(\tilde{z}, \tilde{w})=\left(\hat{z}, \xi_{1} \hat{w}\right)$ $=(\tilde{z}, w) \in W_{j} \supset \hat{W}_{j}$ (see cases $i$ ) and $i i$ ) after (6.82)). Then we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (7.15)|\tilde{z}-z| \geq \hat{\varepsilon}_{0} d((\hat{z}, w),(z, w))=\hat{\varepsilon}_{0} d\left(\xi_{1} \circ(\hat{z}, \tilde{w}),(z, w)\right) \\
& =\hat{\varepsilon}_{0} d\left(\left(\xi_{1} e^{-i \gamma}\right) \circ x, x\right) \geq \hat{\varepsilon}_{0} \hat{d}\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)(\text { using }(7.13),(7.14))
\end{aligned}
$$

To see $\hat{d}\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)>0$, since $S$ in Definition 7.1 is clearly disjoint from the isotropy group at $x$, i.e. $x \notin S \circ x$ and further, the orbit $S \circ x$ is closed (cf. (2.6), (2.7)), by the definition of $\hat{d}$ in (7.13) the desired strict positivity follows.

Remark 7.2. One expects that the function $\hat{d}\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)$ is comparable to the genuine distance function $d\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)$. See [18, Theorem 6.7] in the CR context.

To proceed further, we need the following fact:
Lemma 7.3. It holds that (see (3.3) for $l(x)$ )

$$
l\left(e^{i \gamma} \circ x\right)=l(x) \text { provided that } e^{i \gamma} \circ x\left(e^{i \gamma} \in S^{1} \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}\right) \text { and } x \text { lie in }
$$

the same chart $W_{j}$ with coordinates $(z, w)$ (cf. Notation 6.1).
Proof. Let $D_{0}=W_{j}, D_{1}, \ldots, D_{L}, D_{L+1}$ be a sequence of patches with coordinates $\left(z_{k}, w_{k}\right)$ on each $D_{k}$, and $x_{0}, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{L}, x_{L+1}$ be a sequence of points. Assume the

following: $D_{L+1} \equiv D_{0},\left(z_{0}, w_{0}\right) \equiv\left(z_{L+1}, w_{L+1}\right) \equiv(z, w)$ and $x_{0}:=x \in D_{0}, x_{k} \in$ $D_{k} \cap D_{k-1}, 1 \leq k \leq L, x_{L+1} \in D_{0} \cap D_{L}$ such that

$$
x_{k+1}=e^{i \gamma_{k}} \circ x_{k}, 0 \leq k \leq L
$$

We further assume: for every $0 \leq k \leq L$, if $\theta \in\left[0, \gamma_{k}\right]$ then $e^{i \theta} \circ x_{k} \in D_{k}$. This gives

$$
w_{k}\left(e^{i \theta} \circ x_{k}\right)=e^{i \theta} w_{k}\left(x_{k}\right)
$$

by (2.7). Since $l(q)=h(z(q), \bar{z}(q)) w(q) \bar{w}(q)$ in (3.3), (3.4) is independent of the choice of coordinates, from (7.17) and the fact that $h$ is invariant under rotation (by $\gamma_{k}$ ) by using (7.18) and (3.4), it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
l\left(x_{k+1}\right) & =h\left(z_{k}\left(x_{k+1}\right), \bar{z}_{k}\left(x_{k+1}\right)\right) w_{k}\left(x_{k+1}\right) \bar{w}_{k}\left(x_{k+1}\right) \\
& =h\left(z_{k}\left(x_{k}\right), \bar{z}_{k}\left(x_{k}\right)\right) w_{k}\left(x_{k}\right) \bar{w}_{k}\left(x_{k}\right) \\
& =l\left(x_{k}\right), 0 \leq k \leq L
\end{aligned}
$$

Clearly (7.16) follows from (7.19).

Remark 7.4. The above proof actually shows that (7.16) holds unconditionally. As an important application, one sees that the metric $G_{a, m}$ on $\Sigma$ (in Section 3) is $S^{1}$-invariant via (3.8), (3.9), (3.7) and Lemma 7.6 iv).

Corollary 7.5. It holds that for all $\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ and for all $x \in \Sigma$,

$$
l^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} \circ x\right)=|\xi|^{-2 m} l^{m}(x)
$$

Proof. By Lemma 7.3 and writing $\xi=|\xi| e^{i \gamma}$, we see that (via Remark 7.4)

$$
l\left(\xi^{-1} \circ x\right)=l\left(|\xi|^{-1} \circ\left(e^{-i \gamma} \circ x\right)\right)=|\xi|^{-2} l\left(e^{-i \gamma} \circ x\right)=|\xi|^{-2} l(x)
$$

and hence the lemma.

In the remaining part of this section, we will omit " $\circ$ " in the notation of $\mathbb{C}^{*}$ action.

Let us now continue with Part II of (7.3). Recall $H_{m, t}^{j}$ in (6.5) (with the footnote as in (6.82)):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} x\right) \circ\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x}\right) \bar{\xi}^{m}=\varphi_{j}(x) w^{m}(x) K_{t}^{j}\left(z(x), z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \circ\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x} \\
& \quad w^{-m}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right) l^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right) \tau_{j}\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \sigma_{j}\left(\phi\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \bar{\xi}^{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

To integrate (7.21) over $I=\left[\varepsilon_{j}, \frac{2 \pi}{p}-\varepsilon_{j}\right]$ for Part II, we shall now divide $I=J \cup J^{\prime}$ where $J$ is the subset of those $\gamma \in\left[\varepsilon_{j}, \frac{2 \pi}{p}-\varepsilon_{j}\right]$ such that $e^{-i \gamma} x \in \tilde{W}_{j}$ (Notation 6.1) and $J^{\prime}$ is the complement of $J$ in $\left[\varepsilon_{j}, \frac{2 \pi}{p}-\varepsilon_{j}\right]$. If we denote by $(\tilde{z}, \tilde{w})$ the coordinates of $e^{-i \gamma} x$ with $\gamma \in J$, then $\tilde{z} \neq z$ by (7.14) (noting that $\frac{2 \pi}{p}$ is the period of $x$ ). We suppress the dependence of $J$ on $x$ since $x$ is fixed throughout.

From (6.26) of Proposition 6.9 and the notation there, it follows that with $\xi=$ $|\xi| e^{i \gamma}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Part II of }\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, x) \\
& :=\int_{\varepsilon_{j}}^{\frac{2 \pi}{\pi}-\varepsilon_{j}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{+}}\left(H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} x\right) \circ\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x}\right) \bar{\xi}^{m} d \mu_{x, m}(\xi) \\
& =\left(\int_{J}+\int_{J^{\prime}}\right) \int_{\mathbb{R}^{+}}\left(H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} x\right) \circ\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x}\right) \bar{\xi}^{m} d \mu_{x, m}(\xi) \\
& =\int_{J} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{+}}\left(H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} x\right) \circ\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x}\right) \bar{\xi}^{m} d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the integral over $J^{\prime}$ vanishes since in $H_{m, t}^{j}$ (6.5) the term $\tau_{j}\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \sigma_{j}\left(\phi\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right)$ $=0$ for $e^{-i \gamma} x \notin \dot{W}_{j}$ where $\gamma \in J^{\prime}$ (see (6.5) and items ii), iii) after Notation 6.1).

Next for the integral over $J$ in the RHS of (7.22) we need some preparations, which go from (7.23) until Corollary 7.7.

Recall from (6.25) and remarks below it that $d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)$ equals $\left(\tau_{x}: \mathbb{C}^{*} \rightarrow \Sigma\right.$ defined by $\tau_{x}(\lambda)=\lambda \circ x$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
& d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)=\frac{l^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right) d v_{\Sigma, m}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right) \wedge d v_{f, m}(x)}{d v_{\Sigma, m}(x)} \\
& \stackrel{(7.20)(3.22)}{=} \frac{1}{2} l^{m}(x)\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \frac{d v_{M}\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right)}{d v_{M}(z(x))}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note also (cf. (3.23) and $i$ ) of Lemma 7.6):

$$
\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}\right)=d v_{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1}|w|\right) \wedge d v(-\gamma) / 2 \pi, \xi=|\xi| e^{i \gamma}
$$

and the invariantly defined integral:

$$
\int_{|\xi| \in \mathbb{R}^{+}} l^{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1} x\right) d v_{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1} x\right)=1
$$

(cf. (3.26) where we chose $h\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right)=1$ and the notation $d v_{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1} x\right)$ is for $\left.d v_{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1}|w|\right)\right)$. By our choice of the holomorphic coordinate $w$, we have (see (2.7) for $\left.\lambda \in \mathbb{R}^{+}\right):$

$$
|w|^{-m}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)|\xi|^{-m}=\frac{1}{|w|^{m}\left(e^{-i \gamma} x\right)}, e^{-i \gamma}=\xi^{-1}|\xi| \in S^{1} \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}
$$

For one more preparation, a technical lemma is in order. Items iii), iv) below have been used in $(6.24),(6.43)$ respectively.

Lemma 7.6. It holds that
i) $\frac{|w(x)|}{|w\left(e^{-i \gamma} x\right)|}=1$ for $e^{-i \gamma} \in S^{1}$ such that $e^{-i \gamma} x \in W_{j}$ of Notation 6.1.
ii) $\frac{d v_{M}\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right)}{d v_{M}(z(x))}=1$ for $\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ such that $\xi^{-1} x \in W_{j}$.
iii) In the product space $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times \Sigma$, under the transformation $\tilde{\sigma}:(\xi, x) \rightarrow\left(\xi^{-1}, y\right.$ $=\xi \circ x)$ we have

$$
\left(\tau_{x}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi) d v_{\Sigma, m}(x)=\left\{\tilde{\sigma}^{*}\left[\left(\tau_{y}^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}\right) d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)\right]\right\}(\xi, x)
$$

iv) For $h$ of (3.4) and notations there, $h\left(z^{\prime}, \overline{z^{\prime}}\right)=h(z, \bar{z})$ if $\left\{p, e^{-i \gamma} \circ p\right\} \subset D_{j}$ and $z^{\prime}=z\left(e^{-i \gamma} \circ p\right)$. Moreover the global 2-form $\partial \bar{\partial} \log h$ on $\Sigma\left(=\partial_{z} \bar{\partial}_{z} \log h\right.$, see (3.7)) is $S^{1}$-invariant.

Proof. For $i$ ), if $\gamma$ is small this is automatic.(cf. Case $i$ ) after (6.82)). In general, by (7.20) and for $\xi^{-1} x \in W_{j}$ with $|\arg \xi|$ small

$$
l\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)=h\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right), \bar{z}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right)|w|^{2}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)
$$

(cf. (3.4)) we obtain

$$
\frac{|w|(x)}{|w|\left(e^{-i \gamma} x\right)}=\frac{h^{1 / 2}\left(z\left(e^{-i \gamma} x\right), \bar{z}\left(e^{-i \gamma} x\right)\right)}{h^{1 / 2}(z(x), \bar{z}(x))}
$$

Resorting to the fact that $h$ is invariant under local rotations as remarked in the proof of Lemma 7.3, in a similar way we use the local rotations step by step as in (7.19). This, together with (7.29), leads to the first equality.

For the second equality, since $d v_{M}=$ the volume form on $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\} \subset \Sigma$ induced by $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ (cf. (3.22)) which is trivially $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant (see the beginning of step 2 in Section 3), the conclusion follows.

For iii), first observe that (recalling $\sigma: \mathbb{C}^{*} \times \Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma$ defined by $\sigma(\lambda, p):=\lambda \circ p$ )

$$
L H S \text { of }(7.27)=\left(\sigma^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi, x) \wedge d v_{\Sigma, m}(x)
$$

$$
R H S \text { of }(7.27)=\left\{\tilde{\sigma}^{*}\left[\left(\sigma^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}, y\right) \wedge d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)\right]\right\}(\xi, x)
$$

It then follows from (3.22) that

$$
R H S \text { of }(7.30)=\left(\sigma^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi, x) \wedge \pi^{*} d v_{M}(x) \wedge d v_{f, m}(x)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
R H S \text { of (7.31) } & =\left\{\tilde{\sigma}^{*}\left[\left(\sigma^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)\left(\xi^{-1}, y\right)\right] \wedge \tilde{\sigma}^{*}\left(d v_{\Sigma, m}(y)\right)\right\}(\xi, x) \\
& =d v_{f, m}(x) \wedge\left(\sigma^{*} \pi^{*} d v_{M}\right)(\xi, x) \wedge\left(\sigma^{*} d v_{f, m}\right)(\xi, x)
\end{aligned}
$$

Comparing (7.32) with (7.33) and noting that $\left(\sigma^{*} \pi^{*} d v_{M}\right)(\xi, x)=\pi^{*} d v_{M}(x)$ since $\pi^{*} d v_{M}$ is $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant (alternatively, computing it using $(z, w)$ coordinates is recommended), we conclude that $R H S$ of (7.32) equals $R H S$ of (7.33). Hence (7.27) follows from (7.30) and (7.31).

For $i v$ ) the first assertion follows from $i$ ) of this lemma, (3.4) and (7.16). It is clear that $e^{\pm i c}$ preserves the global form $\partial \bar{\partial} \log h$ for $|\varepsilon|<<1$ so does $e^{i c q}$ for any $q \in \mathbb{Z}$, giving the second assertion.

Corollary 7.7. It holds that

$$
\int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)=1
$$

Proof. (7.34) follows from (7.23), ii) of Lemma 7.6, (7.24) and (7.25).

We can now estimate Part II of $\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, x)$ as follows.
Proposition 7.8. For any $N_{0} \geq n+1$ there exists $\delta=\delta\left(N_{0}\right)>0$ and $C_{N_{0}}>0$ such that for $0<t<\delta$ it holds that

$$
\left|\text { Part II of }\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, x)\right| \leq C_{N_{0}} l^{m}(x) t^{-(n-1)} e^{-\frac{\xi_{0}^{\prime} d\left(x, \Sigma_{s i n g}\right)^{2}}{t}}
$$

for $x \in\left(\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right) \cap \dot{W}_{j}$, where $C_{N_{0}}$ and $\bar{\varepsilon}_{0}^{\prime}$ are independent of $x$.

Proof. In view of (7.22) we need to estimate a certain integral of $\left(H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} x\right) \circ\right.$ $\left.\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x}\right) \bar{\xi}^{m} d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)$. First we deal with $H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} x\right)$. Let both $x$ and $\xi^{-1} x$ be in $\left(\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right) \cap \hat{W}_{j}$ as required by the reduction of (7.35) to the $J$-part integral in (7.22). By Lemma $7.6 i$ ) and (7.20) we obtain the modulus of the RHS of $H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} x\right)$ (6.5) for terms except $K_{t}^{j}$ and cutoff functions: (noting that $(\zeta, \eta)=(z, w)$ as $\xi^{-1} x$ lies in $\hat{W}_{j}$ by assumption)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|w^{m}(x)\right|\left|w\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)^{-m}\right| l\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)^{m} \\
= & \left|w^{m}(x)\right||\xi|^{m}\left|w(x)^{-m}\right||\xi|^{-2 m} l(x)^{m}=l(x)^{m}|\xi|^{-m}
\end{aligned}
$$

By (6.5) and (7.36) we can then estimate the integrand (7.21) of (7.22): noting that $\sigma_{\xi}^{*}$ leaves $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ invariant (with respect to the basis $\tilde{\eta}^{I_{\eta}}$ in Footnote ${ }^{6} \sigma_{\xi}^{*}$ is the identity matrix)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\left(H_{m, t}^{j}\left(x, \xi^{-1} x\right) \circ\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x}\right) \bar{\xi}^{m} d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)\right| \\
\leq & C_{1} l(x)^{m}\left|K_{t}^{j}\left(z(x), z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right)\right| d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C_{1}$ is a constant independent of $x$ and $\xi$. Now from the asymptotic expansion (7.9) of $K_{t}^{j}$ it follows that for $N_{0}>n=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{R}} V_{j}+1$ (cf. [6, Theorem 2.23, p.81]) there exists $\delta=\delta\left(N_{0}\right)>0$ and $C_{N_{0}}^{\prime}>0$ such that for $0<t<\delta$ and $x, \xi^{-1} x \in$ $\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }} \cap \hat{W}_{j}$

$$
\left|K_{t}^{j}\left(z(x), z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right)\right| \leq C_{N_{0}}^{\prime} e^{-\frac{d_{M}^{2}\left(z, z^{\prime}\right)}{4 t}} t^{-(n-1)}
$$

where we have written $z=z(x), z^{\prime}=z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)$ and $C_{N_{0}}^{\prime}$ is independent of $x$ and $\xi$ (such that $\xi^{-1} x \in \hat{W}_{j}$ ). By (7.10) and (7.14) we obtain

$$
e^{-\frac{d_{M}^{2}\left(z, z^{\prime}\right)}{4 t}} \leq e^{-\frac{\rho_{0}^{2} d\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)^{2}}{t}}
$$

with $\bar{\varepsilon}_{0}^{\prime}=\bar{\varepsilon}_{0}^{2} / C_{K^{\prime}}^{2}$. Using (7.22), (7.35) follows from (7.37), (7.38), (7.39) and (7.34) with $C_{N_{0}}=C_{1} C_{N_{0}}^{\prime}$.

Having just worked out (7.3), we can now prove Theorem 1.3 stated in the Introduction. Before going on, we pause to give a proof of (6.27) as an interlude since we have now learned many properties about $d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)$. The following proof uses $\alpha_{k}$ constructed in the proof of Lemma 6.14 in an essential way, but the reader may skip this proof and come back to it in due course.

Proof. (of (6.27) in Proposition 6.9) Substituting (7.23) (with $x$ replaced by $y$ ) into (6.26) and using (7.24), (6.82) one is able to obtain $p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y)$ in (6.27) as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y) \stackrel{(7.20)}{=} \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}\left\{\varphi_{j}(x) K_{t}^{j}\left(z(x), \zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right)\right. \\
& \frac{\bar{\eta}^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)}{\bar{\eta}^{m}(y)} \bar{\xi}^{m} h^{m}\left(\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right), \bar{\zeta}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \tau_{j}\left(\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \sigma_{j}\left(\vartheta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \\
& \left.l^{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1} y\right)\right\}\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} y} d v_{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1}|\eta(y)|\right) \wedge \frac{d v(-\gamma)}{2 \pi} \frac{d v_{M}\left(\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right)}{d v_{M}(\zeta(y))}
\end{aligned}
$$

for the above noting that one replaces $l^{m}(x)$ in (7.23) by

$$
l^{m}(y)=h^{m}\left(\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right), \bar{\zeta}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \eta^{m}(y) \bar{\eta}^{m}(y)
$$

using Lemma $7.6 i v$ ). Observe that in (7.40)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{\eta}^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right) h^{m}\left(\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right), \bar{\zeta}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) / \bar{\eta}^{m}(y) \stackrel{l=h \eta \bar{\eta}}{=} \frac{l^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)}{\eta^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} y\right) \bar{\eta}^{m}(y)} \\
& \stackrel{(7.20)}{=} \frac{|\xi|^{-2 m} l^{m}(y)}{|\xi|^{-m} \eta^{m}\left(e^{-i \gamma} y\right) \bar{\eta}^{m}(y)}=\frac{1}{\eta^{m}\left(e^{-i \gamma} y\right) \bar{\eta}^{m}(y)}|\xi|^{-m} l^{m}(y) \\
& =\quad\left(\frac{\eta^{m}(y)}{\eta^{m}\left(e^{-i \gamma} y\right)} \frac{h^{m}(\zeta, \bar{\zeta})}{l^{m}(y)}\right)|\xi|^{-m} l^{m}(y)=h^{m}(\zeta, \bar{\zeta})|\xi|^{-m} \frac{\eta^{m}(y)}{\eta^{m}\left(e^{-i \gamma} y\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $y$ is omitted in $\zeta=\zeta(y)$. By (7.41), Lemma $7.6 i i$ ) we reduce (7.40) to (recalling $\xi=|\xi| e^{i \gamma}, \eta(y)=|\eta|(y) e^{i \vartheta(y)}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y)=\varphi_{j}(x) h^{m}(\zeta(y), \bar{\zeta}(y)) \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}\left\{K_{t}^{j}\left(z(x), \zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \mid \xi\right\}^{-m} \tilde{\xi}^{m} \\
& \frac{\eta^{m}(y)}{\eta^{m}\left(e^{-i \gamma} y\right)} \tau_{j}\left(\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) \sigma_{j}\left(\vartheta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)\right) l^{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1} y\right)\left\{\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} y} d v_{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1}|\eta(y)|\right) \frac{d v(-\gamma)}{2 \pi}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Here one trouble is $\eta\left(e^{-i \gamma} y\right)$ because for $\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ its angle $\gamma$ may be "large"; one runs into the large angle action. To figure out $\eta\left(e^{-i \gamma} y\right)$ we apply the construction of $\alpha_{k}$ in the proof of Lemma 6.14 for coordinates $(\zeta, \eta)$ of $y$ (replacing coordinates $(z, w)$ of $x$ there) so that $\vartheta\left(\alpha_{k} y\right)=0, \alpha_{0}=e^{-i \vartheta(y)}$,

$$
\zeta_{k}:=\zeta\left(\alpha_{k} y\right)
$$

$J_{k}:=\left\{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}:-\varepsilon_{j}<\arg \left(\xi \alpha_{k}^{-1}\right)<\varepsilon_{j}\right\}\left(\varepsilon_{j}\right.$ as in the local chart $D_{j}:=V_{j} \times$ $\left.\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}\right)$. Similar to (6.49) we now have

$$
\eta(\xi y)=\xi \alpha_{k}^{-1} \alpha_{0} \eta(y) \text { for } \xi \in J_{k}
$$

where $k=0,1, \cdots, \Lambda$ (some nonnegative integer). Using the above formula gives

$$
\frac{\eta^{m}(y)}{\eta^{m}\left(e^{-i \gamma} y\right)}=e^{i m \gamma}\left(\alpha_{k} \alpha_{0}^{-1}\right)^{m} \text { for } e^{-i \gamma} \in J_{k}
$$

Two more formulas for use: For $\xi^{-1} \in J_{k}$ we have in the notation above (with Case $i)$ after (6.82) applied to $J_{k}$ )

$$
\zeta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right)=\zeta\left(\left(\xi^{-1} \alpha_{k}^{-1}\right) \alpha_{k} y\right)=\zeta\left(\alpha_{k} y\right)=\zeta_{k}
$$

Writing $\alpha_{k}=e^{-i \gamma_{k}}$ and $\xi=|\xi| e^{i \gamma}$ we have, for $\xi^{-1} \in J_{k}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\vartheta\left(\xi^{-1} y\right) & =\vartheta\left(\left(\xi^{-1} \alpha_{k}^{-1}\right) \alpha_{k} y\right)=\vartheta\left(\xi^{-1} \alpha_{k}^{-1}\right)+\vartheta\left(\alpha_{k} y\right) \\
& =\vartheta\left(\xi^{-1} \alpha_{k}^{-1}\right)=-\gamma+\gamma_{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $-\varepsilon_{j}<-\gamma+\gamma_{k}<\varepsilon_{j}$ since $\xi^{-1} \in J_{k}$. Namely (7.46) and (7.47) are part of the coordinates of $\xi^{-1} y$.

We are ready to substitute (7.46), $|\xi|^{-m} \tilde{\xi}^{m}=e^{-i m \gamma}$, (7.45) and (7.47) into (7.42), giving (via the cut-off functions reducing it to a summation over smaller regions of integration)

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y) & =\varphi_{j}(x) h^{m}(\zeta(y), \bar{\zeta}(y)) \sum_{k=0}^{\Lambda}\left\{K_{t}^{j}\left(z(x), \zeta_{k}\right) \tau_{j}\left(\zeta_{k}\right)\left(\alpha_{k} \alpha_{0}^{-1}\right)^{m}\right\} \\
{ }^{\circ}\left(\sigma_{\alpha_{k}^{-1}}^{*}\right)_{\alpha_{k} y} & \cdot \int_{\gamma=\gamma_{k}+\bar{\epsilon}_{j}}^{\gamma=\gamma_{k}-\bar{\epsilon}_{j}} \sigma_{j}\left(\gamma_{k}-\gamma\right) \frac{d v(-\gamma)}{2 \pi} \int_{|\xi| \in \mathbb{R}^{+}} l^{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1} y\right) d v_{m}\left(|\xi|^{-1} y\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\left(\sigma_{\alpha_{k}^{-1}}^{*}\right)_{\alpha_{k} y}$ is from the fact that $\left(\sigma_{\xi}^{*}\right)_{\xi^{-1} y}$ is the map $\xi^{-1} y \rightarrow y$ that pulls back a section at $y$ to one at $\xi^{-1} y$ so that the resulting section over $\left\{\xi^{-1} y\right\}_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}}$ behaves as a "constant section" (in a piecewise sense due to the large angle action). By $\bar{\gamma}=\gamma_{k}-\gamma$, the angular integral above gives $\int_{-\bar{\epsilon}_{j}}^{\gamma_{j}} \sigma_{j}(\bar{\gamma}) \frac{d v(\bar{\gamma})}{2 \pi}=1$ by (6.2), while by (7.25) the last integral in (7.48) equals $1^{9}$. Thus (7.48) is reduced to (7.49)

$$
p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y)=\varphi_{j}(x) h^{m}(\zeta(y), \bar{\zeta}(y)) \sum_{k=0}^{\Lambda}\left\{K_{t}^{j}\left(z(x), \zeta_{k}\right) \tau_{j}\left(\zeta_{k}\right)\left(\alpha_{k} \alpha_{0}^{-1}\right)^{m}\right\} \circ\left(\sigma_{\alpha_{k}^{-1}}^{*}\right)_{\alpha_{k} y}
$$

Note that $\zeta_{k}$ and $\alpha_{k}$ in (7.49) depend on $y$ and that for the $x$-part $p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y)$ is independent of $|w|(x)$. Moreover, differentiating $\vartheta(\alpha y)$ in $\alpha \in S^{1}\left(\subset \mathbb{C}^{*}\right)$ is not zero by the locally freeness. From this it follows that $\alpha_{k}$ defined by $\vartheta\left(\alpha_{k} y\right)=0$ is smooth in $y$ by the implicit function theorem. Therefore $\zeta_{k}=\zeta\left(\alpha_{k} y\right)$ is also smooth in $y$. Clearly $\alpha_{k}$ does not depend on the variable $|\eta|$ (the radial part of $y$ ), neither does $\zeta_{k}$ since by (7.46) $\zeta_{k}(\lambda y)=\zeta\left(\alpha_{k}(\lambda y) \lambda y\right)=\zeta\left(\alpha_{k}(y) \lambda y\right)=\zeta\left(\alpha_{k}(y) y\right)=\zeta_{k}(y)$ for any $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Since $\mathbb{R}^{+}$is the only noncompact direction, it follows from the above independence that $\zeta_{k}$ and $\alpha_{k}$ are $C_{B}^{*}$-bounded. We conclude that $p_{m, t}^{0, j}$ is smooth in $x, y$ in view that $\zeta_{k}$ and $\alpha_{k}$ are smooth in $y$, and $C_{B}^{*}$-bounded since $\zeta_{k}$ and $\alpha_{k}$ are $C_{B}^{*}$-bounded (cf. (6.9)).

Remark 7.9. In the above proof suppose that the action $\sigma$ is globally free everywhere on the local chart $D_{j}$. Then $\Lambda=0, \zeta_{0}=\zeta\left(\alpha_{0} y\right)=\zeta(y)$ and we have $p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, y)=\varphi_{j}(x) h^{m}(\zeta(y), \bar{\zeta}(y)) K_{t}^{j}(z(x), \zeta(y)) \tau_{j}(\zeta(y))$ which depends only on $z(x)$ and $\zeta(y)$ (except the cutoff function $\varphi_{j}(x)$ ).

Proof. (of Theorem 1.3) The assertion $i$ ) of the theorem follows from Proposition 6.17 and $i$ ) of Theorem 6.18. To prove the formula (1.8) for $i i$ ) of the theorem, we reduce the estimate to that of $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)$ by (6.81). Let us estimate $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)$ which is essentially (7.3). First suppose the simplest situation $p\left(=p_{1}\right)=1$. By (7.35) and (7.11), (7.12) (using the meaning of " $\sim$ ") for every $N_{0} \geq N_{0}(n)$ ([6, p.81]) there exist constants $C_{N_{0}}, \delta=\delta\left(N_{0}\right)>0$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)-\sum_{j=0}^{N_{0}} t^{-(n-1)+j} b_{n-1-j}(z(x)) t^{m}(x)\right| \\
\leq & C_{N_{0}} l^{m}(x)\left(t^{-(n-1)+N_{0}+1}+t^{-(n-1)} e^{-\frac{\delta_{0} \delta\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {ring }}\right)^{2}}{t}}\right), 0<t<\delta
\end{aligned}
$$

for some constant $\hat{\varepsilon}_{0}>0$ (independent of $N_{0}$ and $x$ ). Remark 7.10. To generalize the $C^{0}$ estimate here to the $C^{l}\left(C_{B}^{l}\right.$ more precisely) estimate presents no serious problem. We skip the details, and content ourselves with referring to [18, Corollary 6.3] for a closely related treatment.

One sees that the RHS of (7.50) (for general $p$ ) blows up as $t \rightarrow 0$ and $x \rightarrow \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ at various speeds (due to $t^{-(n-1)}$ in the second term). Let $b_{s}^{ \pm}(z, \zeta)$ be coefficients in the asymptotic expansion of $K_{t}^{j, \pm}(z, \zeta)( \pm$ means acting on even/odd degree of elements as usual) (cf. (7.9)):

$$
\begin{aligned}
K_{t}^{j, \pm}(z, \zeta) & =e^{-\frac{\tilde{\delta}_{2 s}^{2}(z, \zeta)}{4 t}} K^{j, \pm}(t, z, \zeta) \\
K^{j, \pm}(t, z, \zeta) & \sim t^{-n+1} b_{n-1}^{ \pm}(z, \zeta)+t^{-n+2} b_{n-2}^{ \pm}(z, \zeta)+\cdots
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 7.11. Note that the notion of the above asymptotic expansion (7.52) (see $[18,(5.19)$ on p.76]) is different from the one in [6, p.87] in which the meaning of $\sim$ is given in such a way that it includes the Gaussian term $e^{-\frac{\tilde{\delta}_{2 s}^{2}(z, \zeta)}{4 t}}$; our above meaning of $\sim$, excluding the Gaussian term, is basically equivalent to the one in Chavel's book $[16,(45)$ on p.154].

Let $\psi_{j}^{-1}: D_{j} \subset \Sigma \rightarrow W_{j}=V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$denote a local trivialization (cf. the line below (3.30)).
Notation 7.12. i) Let $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}^{m}:=\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M} \otimes E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ and $\mathcal{E}^{m}:=\left.\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\tilde{\mathcal{E}}^{m}\right)\right|_{V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}$ $=\left.\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M} \otimes E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\right|_{V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}$ be a complex vector bundle over $V_{j}$, where $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow M=\Sigma / \sigma$ denotes the natural projection, $\mathcal{E}_{M}$ denotes the (orbifold) bundle of all $(0, q)$-forms on $M, E$ denotes a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-equivariant holomorphic vector bundle over $\Sigma$, equipped with a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant Hermitian metric $h_{E}$ (constructed similarly as for $L_{\Sigma}$ in Step 1 of Section 3), and $L_{\Sigma}$ is defined before (3.1). Let $e^{E}$ denote a locally $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant section of $E$ over $D_{j} \subset \Sigma$ (meaning that it is invariant under $\mathbb{R}^{+}$and small-angle action). Similarly let $\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}$ denote the even/odd part

$\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}^{ \pm} \otimes E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ of $\mathcal{E}^{m}$. Although $\mathcal{E}_{M}$ is only an orbifold bundle, the "pullback $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ " having local sections of the form $f_{I_{q}}(z, \bar{z}) d \bar{z}^{I_{q}}$ can be identified as a vector bundle. Recall that the metrics for $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ and $L_{\Sigma}$ are $\pi^{*} g_{M}\left(=G_{a, m} \mid \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right.$, see Lemma $8.10 i))$ and $<\cdot, \cdot>_{L_{\Sigma}}$ (see lines above (3.3)) respectively.
ii) Let $\Psi_{ \pm, m}$ denote $\Psi_{q, m}$ in (3.32) for $q$ even/odd that identify bundle elements with $m$-space elements (with an extra bundle $\left.\psi_{j}^{*} E\right|_{V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}} ; U_{j}, \psi_{j}^{-1}\left(D_{j}\right)$ there taken to be $V_{j}, W_{j}$ in Notation 6.1). Namely

$$
\left.\Psi_{ \pm, m}: \Omega^{0, \pm}\left(V_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{*}\left(E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\right|_{V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}\right) \rightarrow \Omega_{m, l o e}^{0, \pm}\left(D_{j}, E\right)\right.
$$

is defined by

$$
\left.\Psi_{ \pm, m}\left(s(z, \bar{z}) \psi_{j}^{*}\left(e^{E} \otimes\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\right|_{V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}\right)\right)=s\left(z, \bar{z}\right) w^{m} e^{E}
$$

Let us now be specific about the various metrics: We define the metric $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ (hence $\left.<\cdot, \cdot>_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\right)$ at $\left.\mathcal{E}^{m}\right|_{(z, 0,1)}$ by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \eta^{I_{q}} \otimes e^{E} \otimes\left(e_{w}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\right\|_{\left.\gamma_{, 0,1}\right\rangle} \|_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}^{2} \\
:= & \left\|\eta^{I_{q}}\right\|_{g_{M}}^{2}\left\|e^{E}\right\|_{h_{E}}^{2} h(z, \bar{z})^{-m}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the notation $\eta^{I_{q}}$ is as in Footnote ${ }^{6}$ (the line above (6.13)) and $e_{w}$ is $\partial / \partial w$ in local coordinates $(z, w) \in W_{j}$ with $\left\|e_{w}\right\|^{2}=h(z, \bar{z})$ (see (3.4)). For the $m$-space bundle $\Lambda_{m, l o e}^{0, *}\left(D_{j}\right)$ whose sections are just $\Omega_{m, l o e}^{0, *}\left(D_{j}\right)$ (Definition 3.10) we define the metric $\|\cdot\|_{\Lambda_{m}^{0, *}}$ (hence $\left.<\cdot, \cdot>_{\Lambda_{m}^{0, *}}\right)$ at $\left.q=\psi_{j}((z, w)) \in D_{j}\right\}$ by

$$
\left\|\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \eta^{I_{q}} \otimes e^{E}\right) w^{m}\right\|_{\Lambda_{m}^{0, *}}^{2}:=\left\|\eta^{I_{q}}\right\|_{g_{M}}^{2}\left\|e^{E}\right\|_{h_{E}}^{2}\left|w\right|^{2 m}
$$

We define the $L^{2}$-inner product $(\cdot, \cdot)_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ (resp. $(\cdot, \cdot)_{\Lambda_{m}^{0, *}}$ ) on sections of $\mathcal{E}^{m}$ (resp. $\left.\Lambda_{m, l o e}^{0, *}\left(D_{j}\right)\right)$ by integrating the fibrewise inner product $<\cdot, \cdot>_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\left(\right.$ resp. $\left.<\cdot, \cdot>_{\Lambda_{m}^{0, *}}\right)$ over $V_{j}$ (resp. $W_{j}$ ).
Lemma 7.13. With the notation above, it holds that $\Psi_{ \pm, m}$ preserves $L^{2}$-inner product up to a constant, i.e.

$$
\left(\Psi_{ \pm, m}(s), \Psi_{ \pm, m}(t)\right)_{\Lambda_{m}^{0, *}}=\frac{\varepsilon_{j}}{\pi}(s, t)_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}
$$

for sections $s, t$ of $\mathcal{E}^{m}$.
Proof. We observe that $h(z, \bar{z})^{-m}$ in (7.55) and $|w|^{2 m}$ in (7.56) are related in the following fibre integration: (writing $d v_{f, m}=l(q)^{-m} d \hat{v}_{m}(q)(3.24)$; omitting the pullback $\tau_{p_{0}}^{*}$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}}|w|^{2 m} d v_{f, m}= & \int_{\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}}|w|^{2 m} l(q)^{-m} d \hat{v}_{m}(q) \\
& \stackrel{(3.4)}{=} h(z, \bar{z})^{-m} \int_{\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}} d \hat{v}_{m}(q) \\
& \stackrel{(3.25)}{=} h(z, \bar{z})^{-m} \frac{2 \varepsilon_{j}}{2 \pi}
\end{aligned}
$$

In view of (7.56), (7.55) and $\left\|e^{E}\right\|_{h_{E}}^{2}$ being invariant under the action of $\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times$ $\mathbb{R}^{+}$, (7.57) follows easily from (7.58) and the relation of the measures as given in (3.15).

To proceed further, let us set up some more notation. In (7.49) the expression given by $K_{t}^{j, \pm}\left(z(x), z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right)$ "composed" with $\sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} x}^{*}$ can be interpreted as (see the line above $(6.5)$ )

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(\Psi_{ \pm, m} \circ K_{t}^{j, \pm} \circ \Psi_{ \pm, m}^{-1}\right) \circ \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} x}^{*} \\
=\Psi_{ \pm, m} \circ\left(K_{t}^{j, \pm} \circ \gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}\right) \circ \Psi_{ \pm, m}^{-1}
\end{gathered}
$$

where we have written (see Notation 7.12 for $\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}$ )

$$
\gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}:=\Psi_{ \pm, m}^{-1} \circ \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} x}^{*} \circ \Psi_{ \pm, m}:\left.\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}\right|_{(z(x), 0,1)} \rightarrow\left.\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}\right|_{\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right), 0,1\right)}
$$

in order to be consistent with the notation used in [6] and Section 8. In later use of (7.60) (cf. lines below (8.23)) we take $\xi=\alpha_{k} \in S^{1}$ such that $\alpha_{k}^{-1} x \in V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ for $x \in V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ (compare (6.49) and (7.43) for a similar notation). For $e^{E} \in$ $\psi_{j}^{*} E$ in Notation $7.12 i$ ), $\sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} x}^{*}$ hence $\gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}$ sends it to $\sigma^{E}\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \circ e_{x}^{E} \in\left.\psi_{j}^{*} E\right|_{\xi^{-1} x}$ where $\sigma^{E}$ is a lifted action on the bundle $\psi_{j}^{*} E$. Note that $\sigma^{E}\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \circ e_{x}^{E}$ may not be $e_{\xi^{-1} x}^{E}$ for $\xi^{-1} x \in D_{j}$, especially when $x \in \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ and $\xi$ gives a large angle action as in Case $i i$ ) after (6.82), but $\left\|\sigma^{E}\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \circ e_{x}^{E}\right\|_{h_{E}}=\left\|e_{x}^{E}\right\|_{h_{E}}$ remains true. Writing $z=z(x), \zeta=z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)$ and using " $\dagger$ " to denote the adjoint (to distinguish it from the pullback notation), for $|\xi|=1$ we have, by $\gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}=\left(\gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}\right)^{\dagger}$ (see Lemma 7.14 below)

$$
\begin{aligned}
K_{t}^{j, \pm}\left(z(x), z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \circ \gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}} & =\left(\gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}} \circ K_{t}^{j, \pm}(z, \zeta)^{\dagger}\right)^{\dagger} \\
& =\left(\gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}} \circ K_{t}^{j, \pm}(\zeta, z)\right)^{\dagger}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $K_{t}^{j, \pm}(z, \zeta)^{\dagger}=\left(K_{t}^{j, \pm}\right)^{\dagger}(\zeta, z)=K_{t}^{j, \pm}(\zeta, z)$ and the associated kernel function is always acting to the left on an element in $z$ by our convention: $K_{t}^{j, \pm}(\zeta, z)$ : $\left.\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}\right|_{(z, 0,1)} \rightarrow\left.\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}\right|_{(\zeta, 0,1)}$ satisfies $K_{t}^{j, \pm}(z, \zeta)^{\dagger}=K_{t}^{j, \pm}(\zeta, z)$. (7.61) will be used in (8.21) and more importantly, in (8.35).

It is important to remark that for $x \in \Sigma_{p}\left(=\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)$ so that $z(x)=z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)$ in the above $K_{t}^{j, \pm}$ for every $\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}, \gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}$ is just the identity endomorphism (at $z(x))$; however for $x \in \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ and $\xi \in G_{x}:=\left\{\xi \in S^{1} \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}: \sigma(\xi) x=x\right\}$ the (finite) isotropy group at $x, \gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}$ may not be the identity. This feature is crucial to our supertrace evaluation later on.

Lemma 7.14. With the notation above, it holds that for $x \in D_{j},|\xi|=1$ and $\xi^{-1} x \in D_{j}, \gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}$ is an isometry on the bundle part; see also Corollary 8.5). It holds that

$$
\gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}=\left(\gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}\right)^{\dagger}
$$

Proof. Since the action may involve the large angle one, let us be specific about the proof. Observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} x}^{*}\left(\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \eta^{I_{q}} \otimes e^{E}\right) w^{m}\right)_{x} \\
= & \psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \eta^{I_{q}}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x} \otimes \psi_{j}^{*}\left(\sigma^{E}\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \circ e_{x}^{E}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x} \xi^{m} w^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

by the $\sigma$-invariance of the sections $\pi^{*} \eta^{I_{q}}$. Note that $\left(\sigma^{E}\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \circ e_{x}^{E}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x}$ may not be $e_{\xi^{-1} x}^{E}$ unless $\sigma(\xi)$ is a small-angle action. However it remains true that

$$
\left\|\left(\sigma^{E}\left(\xi^{-1}\right) \circ e_{x}^{E}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x}\right\|_{h_{E}}=\left\|e_{\xi^{-1} x}^{E}\right\|_{h_{E}}
$$

by the $\sigma^{E}$-invariance of the metric $h_{E}$ and the choice of local invariant section $e^{E}$. Also by the $\sigma$-invariance of the metrics $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ for $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ and (7.64), we conclude from (7.63) that
(7.65) $\left\|\sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} x}^{*}\left(\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \eta^{I_{\xi}} \otimes e^{E}\right) w^{m}\right)_{x}\right\|_{\Lambda_{m}^{0, *}}=\left\|\left(\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \eta^{I_{\xi}} \otimes e^{E}\right) w^{m}\right)_{\xi^{-1} x}\right\|_{\Lambda_{m}^{0, *}}|\xi|^{m}$.

Hence for $|\xi|=1$ we learn that $\sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} x}^{*}$ is an isometry with respect to the metric $\|\cdot\|_{\Lambda_{m}^{0, *}}$. Together with (7.53)/(7.54) it follows that for $|\xi|=1 \gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}=\Psi_{ \pm, m}^{-1} \circ$ $\sigma(\xi)_{\xi^{-1} x}^{*} \circ \Psi_{ \pm, m}$ is an isometry with respect to the metric $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ (hence $\left\langle\cdot, \cdot>_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\right.$ ). So taking $u \in \mathcal{E}^{m \pm}\left.\right|_{x}, v \in \mathcal{E}^{m \pm}\left.\right|_{\xi x}$ we have

$$
\left\langle\gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}} u, v\right\rangle_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}=\left\langle\gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}}\left(\gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}} u\right), \gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}} v\right\rangle_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}=<u, \gamma_{\xi^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m \pm}} v>_{\mathcal{E}^{m}}
$$

which gives $(7.62)$.

# 8. LOCAL $m$-INDEX FORMULA 

In this long section we want to get an explicit expression of the local index density, to which the first three subsections are devoted. The remaining two subsections compare our index formula with the one - which we view as a pure orbifold result, of Duistermaat.

Before proceeding to Subsection 8.1 let us discuss a number of auxiliary results, which may be regarded as background material for the subsequent subsections. First, we have the following "supertrace" integral equality by the McKean-Singer formula (Theorem 5.12) together with (6.81) of Theorem 6.18 using the approximate heat kernel $P_{m, t}^{0, \pm}$(noting that the integral of $l(x)^{m} d v_{\Sigma, m}$ over $\Sigma$ is finite as in Remark 3.4):

Theorem 8.1. For $m \geq 0, a>\frac{m}{2}$ (on which the metric $G_{a, m}$ depends), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\Sigma}\left[\operatorname{Tr} e^{-t \mathcal{C}_{m}^{0, *}}(x, x)-\operatorname{Tr} e^{-t \mathcal{C}_{m}^{0, *}}(x, x)\right] d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
= & \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma}\left[\operatorname{Tr} P_{m, t}^{0,+}(x, x)-\operatorname{Tr} P_{m, t}^{0,-}(x, x)\right] d v_{\Sigma, m}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we are reduced to computing the supertrace of $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)$, which is done in the first two subsections (cf. (8.29) and (8.56) below). We prove Theorem 1.1 in the third subsection.

Our actual computation starts with (8.20). But before doing it we need some preparatory work. From Section 2 we learn that the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma$ on $\Sigma$ gives rise to a complex orbifold structure on $\Sigma / \sigma$ (see Theorem 2.3). Write $W_{j}=V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times$ $\mathbb{R}^{+}$for a chart of $\Sigma$ (see Notation 6.1) where $V_{j}$ is chosen to be a complex orbifold chart of $\Sigma / \sigma$ (see the proof of Theorem 2.3). Moreover the finite group associated to the orbifold chart $V_{j}$ is a cyclic subgroup of $S^{1} \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}$, denoted by $G_{j} ; W_{j}$ is suitably shrinked so that $G_{j}$ is the largest isotropy group at some point $x \in W_{j}$, containing isotropy groups at any $y \in W_{j}$ as subgroups, cf. Corollary 8.6. Let $g_{0} \in G_{j}$ be a generator of order $N_{j}+1$

$$
g_{0}^{N_{j}+1}=1 \text { and } g_{k}:=g_{0}^{k}, \quad k \geq 1 \quad\left(\text { note } g_{1}=g_{0}\right)
$$

Each $g_{k}$ depends on $j$ but for the simplicity of notation we omit " $j$ " in the expression of the symbol $g_{k}$. Define (possibly after shrinking $V_{j}$ )

$$
\gamma_{k}^{-1}\left(\in \sigma\left(S^{1}\right)\right):=\pi_{V_{j}} \circ \sigma\left(g_{k}^{-1}\right): V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\} \rightarrow V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}
$$

for all $k=1, \cdots, N_{j}$, where $\pi_{V_{j}}$ is the natural projection from $W_{j}$ onto $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$; note that
(8.4) $\quad \gamma_{k}$ is denoted by $\tau\left(g_{k}\right) \in \sigma\left(S^{1}\right)$ in the proof of Theorem 2.3.

Lemma 8.2. With notations in the proof of Lemma 7.3 suppose $x, x^{\prime} \in W_{j}$ with $w(x)=w\left(x^{\prime}\right)$. Assume that $e^{i \beta} \circ x$ and $e^{i \beta} \circ x^{\prime}$ lie in $W_{j}$ for some $e^{i \beta} \in S^{1}$. Then $w\left(e^{i \beta} \circ x\right)=w\left(e^{i \beta} \circ x^{\prime}\right)$
Proof. First assume that $x^{\prime}$ is close to $x$. As in the proof of Lemma 7.3, we take a sequence of points $x_{l} \in D_{l} \cap D_{l-1}$ (resp. $x_{l}^{\prime} \in D_{l} \cap D_{l-1}$ ), $l=0,1, \cdots, L$ such that $x_{0}=x, \cdots, x_{L+1}=e^{i \beta} \circ x \in D_{0} \cap D_{L}$ (resp. $x_{0}^{\prime}=x^{\prime}, \cdots, x_{L+1}^{\prime}=e^{i \beta} \circ x^{\prime} \in D_{0} \cap D_{L}$ ). Let $\left(z_{l}, w_{l}\right)$ denote the coordinates of the patch $D_{l}$ with $D_{0}=D_{L+1}=W_{j}$. Note that $w_{0}=w_{L+1}=w$. By (2.3) in Proposition 2.1 we have

$$
w_{l}\left(x_{l}\right)=w_{l-1}\left(x_{l}\right) f_{l}\left(z_{l}\left(x_{l}\right)\right), l=1, \cdots, L+1
$$

where $f_{l}$ is holomorphic in $z_{l}$. From (7.17) and (7.18) (replacing $\gamma_{l}$ by $\beta_{l}$ ) it follows that $w_{l}\left(x_{l+1}\right)=w_{l}\left(e^{i \beta_{l}} x_{l}\right)=e^{i \beta_{l}} w_{l}\left(x_{l}\right)$. Together with (8.5) and $\beta:=\sum_{l=0}^{L} \beta_{l}$ we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
w\left(e^{i \beta} \circ x\right) & =w_{L+1}\left(x_{L+1}\right) \\
& =e^{i \beta} w(x) f_{1}\left(z_{1}\left(x_{1}\right)\right) \cdots f_{L+1}\left(z_{L+1}\left(x_{L+1}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly we have

$$
w\left(e^{i \beta} \circ x^{\prime}\right)=e^{i \beta} w\left(x^{\prime}\right) f_{1}\left(z_{1}\left(x_{1}^{\prime}\right)\right) \cdots f_{L+1}\left(z_{L+1}\left(x_{L+1}^{\prime}\right)\right)
$$

By Lemma $7.6 i$ ) we have $\left|w\left(e^{i \beta} \circ x\right)\right|=|w(x)|$ (resp. $\left|w\left(e^{i \beta} \circ x^{\prime}\right)\right|=\left|w\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right|$ ) and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|f_{1}\left(z_{1}\left(x_{1}\right)\right) \cdots f_{L+1}\left(z_{L+1}\left(x_{L+1}\right)\right)\right| & =1 \\
\left(\text { resp. }\left|f_{1}\left(z_{1}\left(x_{1}^{\prime}\right)\right) \cdots f_{L+1}\left(z_{L+1}\left(x_{L+1}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right| & =1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

in view of (8.6) (resp. (8.7)). The actions $e^{i \beta_{l}}$ are holomorphic and hence, in terms of $x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f_{1}\left(z_{1}\left(x_{1}\right)\right) \cdots f_{L+1}\left(z_{L+1}\left(x_{L+1}\right)\right) \\
= & f_{1}\left(z_{1}\left(e^{i \beta_{0}} \circ x\right)\right) f_{2}\left(z_{2}\left(e^{i\left(\beta_{1}+\beta_{0}\right)} \circ x\right)\right) \cdots f_{L+1}\left(z_{L+1}\left(e^{i \beta} \circ x\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is holomorphic in $x$. This together with (8.8) implies that $f_{1}\left(z_{1}\left(x_{1}\right)\right) \cdots f_{L+1}\left(z_{L+1}\left(x_{L+1}\right)\right)$ is independent of $x$ so that it is the same as $f_{1}\left(z_{1}\left(x_{1}^{\prime}\right)\right) \cdots f_{L+1}\left(z_{L+1}\left(x_{L+1}^{\prime}\right)\right)$ (here $x \sim x^{\prime}$ so $\beta_{l}, \beta_{l}^{\prime}$ can be chosen to be the same). In view of (8.6) and (8.7) we conclude that $w\left(e^{i \beta} \circ x\right)=w\left(e^{i \beta} \circ x^{\prime}\right)$. For the general case where $x$ and $x^{\prime}$ are not necessarily close, one connects $x$ and $x^{\prime}$ by a path $\alpha(t) \subset W_{j}$ with the same $w(\alpha(t))$ values. The proof follows by the usual continuity argument.

For the fixed point set $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}\left(\subset V_{j}\right)$ of $\gamma_{k}$ or $\gamma_{k}^{-1}(k \geq 1)$ in (8.3) we write

$$
\Sigma_{j, k}:=\mathbb{C}^{*} \circ\left(V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right), \quad k \geq 1
$$

for the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbit of $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ in $\Sigma$. The local trivialization $\psi_{j}$ is often omitted.
Remark 8.3. i) We can choose the above chart $W_{j}\left(=V_{j} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}\right)$such that $a) \cup_{k} \Sigma_{j, k}$ from (8.9) is connected and $b) \gamma_{k}$ acts on $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ itself for all $k$ as in (8.3). ii) Note that the slice $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\} \subset \Sigma$ depends on the choice of local coordinates of $\Sigma$.

Define $V_{j}^{g_{k}}:=\left\{z^{\prime} \in V_{j} \mid \sigma\left(g_{k}\right)\left(z^{\prime}, 0,1\right)=\left(z^{\prime}, 0,1\right)\right\}$ and $\Sigma^{g_{k}} \subset \Sigma$, the fixed point set of $\sigma\left(g_{k}\right)$, so $V_{j}^{g_{k}}=\Sigma^{g_{k}} \cap V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$. Let $V_{j}^{F}:=\cup_{k=1}^{N_{j}} V_{j}^{g_{k}}$. Note that for $1 \leq k \leq N_{j}$

$$
V_{j}^{g_{k}} \neq V_{j}
$$

Otherwise $\sigma\left(g_{k}\right)$ will fix all points in $V_{j}$ and hence one sees that $W_{j} \subset \Sigma^{g_{k}}$. Since $W_{j}$ is open in $\Sigma$, it follows by holomorphicity that $g_{k}=\{1\}$, a contradiction to $1 \leq k \leq N_{j}$.

We have from (8.3) and Lemma $7.6 i$ ) that

$$
\gamma_{k}^{-1} x=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
\sigma\left(e^{i \eta_{k}(x)}\right) x & x \in\left(V_{j} \backslash V_{j}^{F}\right) \times\{0\} \times\{1\} \\
x & x \in V_{j}^{g_{k}} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $\eta_{k}$ is a real valued, continuous function (at least locally defined at a given $x)$. Based on Lemma 8.2 we have

Proposition 8.4. With the chart $W_{j}$ chosen in Remark 8.3 and the notations above, we have $i$ ) $e^{i \eta_{k}}$ is a constant, independent of the choice of $x \in\left(V_{j} \backslash V_{j}^{F}\right) \times$ $\{0\} \times\{1\} ;$ ii) $\gamma_{k}^{-1}=\sigma\left(e^{i \eta_{k}}\right)$ acting on $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ itself is an isometry with respect to the metric induced from $G_{a, m} ;$ iii) $e^{i \eta_{k}}=g_{k}^{-1}$. In particular $\gamma_{k}^{-1}$ equals $\sigma\left(e^{i \eta_{k}}\right)=\sigma\left(g_{k}^{-1}\right)$ on $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$; namely $\pi_{V_{j}}$ in the definition (8.3) of $\gamma_{k}^{-1}$ can be dropped.

Proof. We will simply write $e^{i \eta_{k}(x)} x$ for $\sigma\left(e^{i \eta_{k}(x)}\right) x$. For $x, x^{\prime} \in\left(V_{j} \backslash V_{j}^{F}\right) \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$, $w(x)=w\left(x^{\prime}\right)=1$ which by Lemma 8.2 gives that $w\left(e^{i \eta_{k}(x)} x\right)=w\left(e^{i \eta_{k}(x)} x^{\prime}\right)$ (for $x^{\prime}$ close to $x$ so that $e^{i \eta_{k}(x)} x^{\prime}$ falls in $W_{j}$ and is close to $e^{i \eta_{k}(x)} x$ ). By the definition of $\eta_{k}$ $w\left(e^{i \eta_{k}(x)} x\right)=1=w\left(e^{i \eta_{k}\left(x^{\prime}\right)} x^{\prime}\right)$ and we get $w\left(e^{i \eta_{k}\left(x^{\prime}\right)} x^{\prime}\right)=w\left(e^{i \eta_{k}(x)} x^{\prime}\right)$. By Lemma 8.2 again, applying $e^{-i \eta_{k}(x)}$ to the arguments of $w$ we conclude $w\left(e^{i\left(\eta_{k}\left(x^{\prime}\right)-\eta_{k}(x)\right)} x^{\prime}\right)=$ $w\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ which is 1 . In view of the action by a small angle (by the continuity of $\eta_{k}$ and $x^{\prime} \sim x$ ) it follows that for $x^{\prime}$ near $x, e^{i\left(\eta_{k}\left(x^{\prime}\right)-\eta_{k}(x)\right)} x^{\prime}=x^{\prime}$ so that $e^{i \eta_{k}\left(x^{\prime}\right)}=$ $e^{i \eta_{k}(x)}$ since $x^{\prime} \notin V_{j}^{F}$. Therefore $e^{i \eta_{k}}$ is constant in each connected component of $\left(V_{j} \backslash V_{j}^{F}\right) \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ by continuity. Now $V_{j} \backslash V_{j}^{F}$ is connected since $V_{j}^{g_{k}}$ is of real codimension $\geq 2$ in $V_{j}$ by the holomorphicity of $g_{k}$. We have shown $i$ ).

From $i$ ) and (8.11) we have now that $\gamma_{k}^{-1}=\sigma\left(e^{i \eta_{k}}\right)$ on $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ (including $\left.V_{j}^{g_{k}} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right)$ by continuity from $V_{j} \backslash V_{j}^{F}$ to its closure $V_{j}$. That $\gamma_{k}^{-1}$ is an isometry follows from the fact that the $\sigma\left(S^{1}\right)$-action is an isometry (see Remark 7.4). We have shown $i i$ ).

To show iii), we fix an $x_{0}=\left(z^{\prime}, 0,1\right)$ with $z^{\prime} \in V_{j}^{g_{k}}$. Then $\sigma\left(e^{i \eta_{k}}\right) x_{0}=\gamma_{k}^{-1} x_{0}$ by $i i$ ) and $\gamma_{k}^{-1} x_{0}=\left(\pi_{V_{j}} \circ \sigma\left(g_{k}^{-1}\right)\right) x_{0}=\sigma\left(g_{k}^{-1}\right) x_{0}=x_{0}$ since $\pi_{V_{j}}$ is trivially the identity on $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ from its definition. It follows that we can put

$$
e^{i \eta_{k}}=h_{x_{0}} g_{k}^{-1}
$$

for some $h_{x_{0}} \in G_{j} \subset S^{1}$. Next, we apply the action

$$
\sigma\left(e^{i \eta_{k}}\right) \stackrel{i i}{=} \gamma_{k}^{-1} \stackrel{(8.3)}{=} \pi_{V_{j}} \circ \sigma\left(g_{k}^{-1}\right)
$$

to any $x$ near $x_{0}$. We have $\sigma\left(e^{i \eta_{k}}\right)(x)=\sigma\left(e^{i \epsilon_{k}} g_{k}^{-1}\right)(x)$ for a small angle $\epsilon_{k}$ (depending on $x$ a priori) obtained by $\pi_{V_{j}}$; compare (2.12) and the lines below it. From

the global freeness of the $\sigma\left(S^{1}\right)$-action at $x \in\left(V_{j} \backslash V_{j}^{F}\right) \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ it follows that $e^{i \eta_{k}}=e^{i \epsilon_{k}} g_{k}^{-1}$ for such $x$. Comparing this with (8.12) gives

$$
h_{x_{0}}=e^{i \epsilon_{k}}
$$

The contradiction is arising: The number of $h_{x_{0}}$ is at most $\left|G_{j}\right|$, while by choosing $x$ sufficiently near $x_{0}$ and applying the continuity argument at $x_{0}$ as just mentioned one can make the angle $\epsilon_{k}(x)$ arbitrarily small. This would violate (8.13) unless $\epsilon_{k}$ $=0$ thus $h_{x_{0}}=1$, giving $e^{i \eta_{k}}=g_{k}^{-1}$ by (8.12). The claim iii) of the proposition is now proved.

The following two corollaries are needed for later use.
Corollary 8.5. $\gamma_{k}^{-1}: V_{j} \rightarrow V_{j}$ is also an isometry with respect to the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M} \mid V_{j}$.
Proof. Let $i: V_{j} \rightarrow \Sigma$ be the natural embedding. By Proposition 8.4 one has $\gamma_{k}=$ $\left.\sigma\left(g_{k}\right)\right|_{V_{j}}$, giving that $\gamma_{k}^{*} i^{*} \pi^{*} g_{M}=i^{*} \sigma\left(g_{k}\right)^{*} \pi^{*} g_{M}=i^{*} \pi^{*} g_{M}$ using $\pi \circ \sigma\left(g_{k}\right)=\pi$.

Corollary 8.6. The map $\tau: G_{j} \rightarrow \tau\left(G_{j}\right)$ used in Theorem 2.3 is a group isomorphism.

Proof. By Proposition 8.4 iii) and (8.4) we learn that $\tau\left(g_{k}\right)=\sigma\left(g_{k}\right)$. If $\tau\left(g_{k}\right)$ is the identity on $V_{j}$, this contradicts (8.10). So $\operatorname{ker} \tau=\{1\}$ hence $\tau$ is a group isomorphism since in Theorem 2.3 we have shown that $\tau$ is a group homomorphism.

Recall (in the proof of Lemma 6.14) that $\alpha_{k}(x) \in S^{1} \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}$ is chosen to satisfy the property that for $x \in W_{j}, \alpha_{k}(x) x\left(=\alpha_{k}(x) \circ x\right) \in W_{j}$ and $\phi\left(\alpha_{k}(x) x\right)=0$. For $k=0$ set

$$
\alpha_{0}(x)=e^{-i \phi(x)} \text { for } x=(z, \phi, r)
$$

Clearly $\phi\left(\alpha_{0}(x) x\right)=0$. We describe the properties of $\alpha_{k}(x)$ below.
Proposition 8.7. (group property of $\alpha_{k}$ in the proof of Lemma 6.14) With the chart $W_{j}$ chosen as in Remark 8.3 and the notation above, it holds that $\alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x)$ is independent of $x \in W_{j}$ and

$$
\left\{\alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x): k=0,1, \cdot, \Lambda\right\}=G_{j}
$$

(see (7.44) for $\Lambda$ and (8.2) for $G_{j}$ ). So $\Lambda=N_{j}$. Moreover we can arrange $1 \leq k$ $\leq N_{j}$ such that

$$
\alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x)=g_{k}^{-1}
$$

In particular, the set $\left\{\alpha_{k}(x)\right\}_{k=0,1, \cdots, \Lambda}$ is independent of those $x \in W_{j}$ with $\phi(x)=0$ and this set forms a group equal to the local orbifold group $G_{j}$.
Proof. Let $x_{1}=(z, 0,1) \in V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$. It follows from the definition of $\alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right)$ and Lemma $7.6 i$ ) that $\sigma\left(\alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right)\right) x_{1}=\left(z_{k}, 0,1\right) \in V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$. Since $V_{j}$ is an orbifold chart, there is $g_{l}\left(=g_{0}^{l}\right) \in G_{j}$ such that $\tau\left(g_{l}\right) z=z_{k}$ (see the proof of Theorem 2.3). By Proposition 8.4 iii) (noting $\gamma_{l}=\tau\left(g_{l}\right)$, cf. (8.4)) $\sigma\left(g_{l}\right) x_{1}=\sigma\left(\alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right)\right) x_{1}$. So $g_{l}^{-1} \alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right)$ lies in the isotropy group of $x_{1}$, which is a subgroup of $G_{j}$. It follows that $\alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right) \in G_{j}$. Denote the set $\left\{\alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x): k=0,1, \cdot, \Lambda\right\}$ by $\Gamma_{x}$. Observing $\alpha_{0}\left(x_{1}\right)=1$ by (8.14), we have shown

$$
\Gamma_{x_{1}} \subset G_{j}
$$

Conversely by Proposition 8.4 iii) again any element of $G_{j}$ acts on $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ itself via $\sigma$, so from the definition of $\alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right)$, it follows that $G_{j} \subset \Gamma_{x_{1}}$. Together with (8.17) we conclude

$$
\Gamma_{x_{1}}=G_{j}
$$

For $x=(z, \phi, r) \in W_{j}$ we compute ( $\sigma$ omitted for simplicity of notation)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha_{0}(x) \alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right) x & =e^{-i \phi(x)} \alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right)\left(r e^{i \phi(x)} x_{1}\right) \\
& =r \alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right) x_{1}=\left(z_{k}, 0, r\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

so $\phi\left(\alpha_{0}(x) \alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right) x\right)=0$. It follows that as sets $\left\{\alpha_{0}(x) \alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right)\right\}_{k} \subset\left\{\alpha_{k}(x)\right\}_{k}$ from the definition of $\alpha_{k}(x)$, so up to multiplication by $\alpha_{0}^{-1}(x)$ on both sets $\left\{\alpha_{k}\left(x_{1}\right)\right\}_{k}=$ $\Gamma_{x_{1}}\left(\alpha_{0}\left(x_{1}\right)=1\right) \subset\left\{\alpha_{0}^{-1}(x) \alpha_{k}(x)\right\}_{k}=\Gamma_{x}$. Similarly one proves $\phi\left(\alpha_{0}^{-1}(x) \alpha_{k}(x) x_{1}\right)$ $=0$, giving $\Gamma_{x} \subset \Gamma_{x_{1}}$ so $\Gamma_{x_{1}}=\Gamma_{x}$. This, together with (8.18), gives (8.15). By the continuity of $\alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x)$ in $x$ and the discreteness of $G_{j}, \alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x)$ for each $k$ must be independent of $x \in W_{j}$.

An immediate corollary to Propositions 8.4 and 8.7 is the following lemma.
Lemma 8.8. It holds that for $1 \leq k \leq N_{j}$

$$
\sigma\left(\alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x)\right)=\sigma\left(g_{k}^{-1}\right)=\gamma_{k}^{-1} \text { maps } V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\} \quad(\subset \Sigma) \text { to itself. }
$$

We can now compute the supertrace of the approximate heat kernel $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)$ in $(6.6)$

$$
P_{m, t}^{0}:=\sum_{j(\text { finite })} H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}
$$

where by $(7.3),(7.59),(7.61)$ and the notation " $\mid$ " (see the lines before and after $(7.61))$

$$
\begin{gathered}
(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m})(x, x)=\varphi_{j}(x) w^{m}(x) \int_{\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}} \Psi_{*, m}\left\{\left(\gamma_{\xi}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}} \circ K_{t}^{j}(\zeta, z)\right)^{\dagger} \Psi_{*, m}^{-1}\right. \\
\left.\bar{w}^{m}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right) h^{m}\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right), \bar{z}\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \tau_{j}\left(z\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \sigma_{j}\left(\phi\left(\xi^{-1} x\right)\right) \bar{\xi}^{m}\right\} d \mu_{x, m}(\xi)
\end{gathered}
$$

Remark 8.9. We equip $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ with the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M}$, cf. the first term of the RHS in (8.50) in local coordinates. Associated to the metric $h_{E}$ on $E$, we consider the Chern connection $\nabla^{h_{E}}$ (see [62]) for later use. For the heat kernel $K_{t}^{j}$ below in (8.23) we use the metric $\left.\pi^{*} g_{M}\right|_{V_{j}}$ (see the note below (6.3)).

Note that $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ is not a Clifford module over $\Sigma$ although $\mathcal{E}_{M}$ is a Clifford module over $M$. Recall that in (7.49) (in Section 7) for $y=x,\left(\sigma_{\alpha_{k}}^{*}\right)_{y}=\sigma\left(\alpha_{k}(x)\right)_{x}^{*} \cdot \check{\mathcal{E}}_{\alpha_{k}(x) x}^{m}$ $\left(=\mathcal{E}_{\alpha_{k}(x) x}^{m}\right) \rightarrow \check{\mathcal{E}}_{x}^{m}$ where $\check{\mathcal{E}}^{m}=\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M} \otimes E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ (Notation 7.12). Since $\alpha_{k}(x) x$ $\in V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}, \check{\mathcal{E}}_{\alpha_{k}(x) x}^{m}=\mathcal{E}_{\alpha_{k}(x) x}^{m}$. For the integral in (8.21), using (6.27) and (7.49) we can write

$$
\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, x)=p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, x)|w|^{2 m}
$$

where we recall: (8.3) for the definition of $\gamma_{k},(7.60)$ for $\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ with $\xi^{-1}=g_{k}$ and $z_{k}=z\left(\alpha_{k}(x) x\right)$,
$p_{m, t}^{0, j}(x, x)=\varphi_{j}(x) h^{m}(z, \bar{z}) \sum_{k=0}^{N_{j}} \Psi_{*, m}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}} \circ K_{t}^{j}\left(z_{k}, z\right)\right)^{\dagger} \Psi_{*, m}^{-1} \tau_{j}\left(z_{k}\right)\left(\alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x)\right)^{m}$

by a slightly tedious verification using (8.21), (7.49) and (8.19): For this verification we are contented with pointing out that in (8.19) $\alpha_{0}^{-1}$ is involved and noting that $\sigma_{\alpha_{0}^{-1}}^{*}$ acts on $\check{\mathcal{E}}^{m}$ "trivially" ${ }^{10}$ so using $\sigma_{\alpha_{k}^{-1} \alpha_{0}}^{*}=\sigma_{\alpha_{k}^{-1}}^{*}$ and $\gamma_{k}=\sigma_{g_{k}}=\sigma_{\alpha_{k}^{-1} \alpha_{0}}$ it follows from $\sigma_{\alpha_{k}^{-1}}^{*}$ in (7.49), (7.61) the expression $\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ in (8.23). With $z=z(x)$ and $z_{k}=z\left(\alpha_{k}(x) x\right)$ we have an endomorphism

$$
\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}=\gamma_{\alpha_{k}^{-1}}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}: \mathcal{E}_{\left(z_{k}, 0,1\right)}^{m} \rightarrow \mathcal{E}_{\left(z, 0,1\right)}^{m}
$$

(with $\xi=\alpha_{k}$ in (7.60)) of $\mathcal{E}^{m}=\left.\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M} \otimes E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\right|_{V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}}$, induced by the pullback of $\sigma\left(\alpha_{k}\right)=\gamma_{k}^{-1}:(z, 0,1) \rightarrow\left(z_{k}, 0,1\right)$ for $k=1, \cdots, N_{j}$; note that a local equivariant section of $\check{\mathcal{E}}^{m}$ formed from those of $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}, E$ and $\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ has been used to lift $\gamma_{k}$ to $\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$. For $k=0$ we define $\sigma\left(\alpha_{0}(x)\right)=: \gamma_{0}^{-1}$ at $x$ (see Footnote ${ }^{10}$ at general $x$ ) and then for $x=(z, 0,1)$ (thus $\alpha_{0}(x)=1$ ) we have

$$
\gamma_{0}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}: \mathcal{E}_{\left(z, 0,1\right)}^{m} \rightarrow \mathcal{E}_{\left(z, 0,1\right)}^{m} \text { is the identity }
$$

8.1. Part I of the local index formula ( $k=0$ in (8.23)). When $k=0$ thus $z_{0}=z$ and $\gamma_{0}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}=$ identity endomorphism (8.25), the $k=0$ term in (8.23) equals

$$
\varphi_{j}(x) h^{m}(z, \bar{z}) K_{t}^{j}(z, z) \tau_{j}(z)
$$

and the corresponding supertrace (denoted as Part I of $\operatorname{Str} P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)$ ) of $P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)$ in (8.20), (8.22) reads (by noting that $\tau_{j}(z)=1$ on $\operatorname{supp} \varphi_{j}$ and $\left.h^{m}(z, \bar{z})|w|^{2 m}=\right.$ $\left.l^{m}(x)\right)$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Part I of } \operatorname{Str} P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x) \\
& \text { (8.22) } \underset{\sim}{=}(8.26) \\
& \sum_{j} \varphi_{j}(x) l^{m}(x) \operatorname{Str}\left(K_{t}^{j}(z, z)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which gives the major contribution for the index of $\partial_{\Sigma, m}^{E}$-complex in Theorem 1.1 (see Theorem 8.11 below). With (8.27) we are almost ready to derive "Part I" of the local index density of Theorem 1.1 as stated in the Introduction. To fix the notation let $E$ be a holomorphic vector bundle on $\Sigma$ with a connection $\nabla$. Let $c h(\nabla, E)$ and $T d(\nabla, E)$ be the $\nabla$-induced Chern character form and the Todd form respectively. For the Chern connection $\nabla^{h_{E}}$ of $E$ (see Remark 8.9) we write $T d\left(E, h_{E}\right):=T d\left(\nabla^{h_{E}}, E\right) ; c h\left(E, h_{E}\right):=c h\left(\nabla^{h_{E}}, E\right)$. Recall that the metric $G_{a}$ or $G_{a, m}$ on $\Sigma$ has the property that "base" $z$-slices and "fibre" $w$-slices are orthogonally splitting (see (3.14) for a precise discussion). We summarize the results as follows.

Lemma 8.10. With notations above and those in the Introduction, we have $i$ ) the quotient (Hermitian) metric $g_{\text {quot }}$ on $T^{1,0}(\Sigma) / L_{\Sigma}$ defined by the restriction of $G_{a, m}$ on the orthogonal complement of the tangent space to the "fibre" (the orbit of the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action) is isometric to $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ and is $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant; ii) for $E$ being $\mathbb{C}^{*}$ equivariant with a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant Hermitian metric $h_{E}, T d\left(E, h_{E}\right)$ and $c h\left(E, h_{E}\right)$ are $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant, denoted by $T d_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(E, h_{E}\right)$ and $c h_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(E, h_{E}\right)$ respectively.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{10}$ Note that $\alpha_{0}(x)$ (cf. (8.14)) acts as a small-angle rotation $e^{-i \phi(x)}$ whose action on any $y=(z, \phi, r)$ keeps $z$-coordinates unchanged so that the (induced) action of $\sigma_{\alpha_{0}(x)}$ on the bundle $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ (as well as the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-equivariant $E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ ) is regarded as "trivial" under the natural trivialization using the pullback sections (see also Footnote ${ }^{6}$ associated with (6.13)).

Recall that $\|\cdot\|$ denotes the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant Hermitian metric on $L_{\Sigma}$ (Step 1 in Section 3), which induces $\|\cdot\|^{*}$ and $\|\cdot\|_{m}^{*}$ on $L_{\Sigma}^{*}$ and $\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{m}$ respectively. As above we write the first Chern form $c_{1}\left(L_{\Sigma},\|\cdot\|\right)$.

We are going to establish "Part I" of our transversal local index density in Theorem 8.11 via the local adaptation of classical local index density arguments (non-transversal ones) with (8.27).

Theorem 8.11. With notations and assumptions as in Theorem 1.1, we have

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \operatorname{Part} I \text { of } \operatorname{Str} P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x) d v_{\Sigma, m}
$$

$$
=p \delta_{p \mid m}\left[T d_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(T^{1,0} \Sigma / L_{\Sigma}, g_{\text {quot }}\right) \wedge c h_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(E, h_{E}\right) \wedge e^{-m c_{1}\left(L_{\Sigma},\|\cdot\|\right)} \wedge d \tilde{v}_{m}\right]_{2 n}(x)
$$

(in a pointwise, non-uniform manner) for $x \in \Sigma_{p}\left(=\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)$. Moreover

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma} \operatorname{Part} I \text { of } \operatorname{Str} P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x) d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
& =p \delta_{p \mid m} \int_{\Sigma} T d_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(T^{1,0} \Sigma / L_{\Sigma}, g_{\text {quot }}\right) \wedge c h_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(E, h_{E}\right) \wedge e^{-m c_{1}\left(L_{\Sigma},\|\cdot\|\right)} \wedge d \tilde{v}_{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Let $N_{0}(n)$ be as in $i i$ ) of Theorem 1.3. We first claim that for every positive integer $N_{0} \geq N_{0}(n)(=n+1)$, there exist $\delta>0$ and $C_{N_{0}}>0$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\operatorname{Part} \mathrm{I} \text { of }\left(\operatorname{Tr} P_{m, t}^{0,+}(x, x)-\operatorname{Tr} P_{m, t}^{0,-}(x, x)\right)\right. \\
& \left.-p \delta_{p \mid m} l^{m}(x) \sum_{j=0}^{N_{0}} t^{-(n-1)+j}\left(\operatorname{Tr} b_{n-1-j}^{+}(z)-\operatorname{Tr} b_{n-1-j}^{-}(z)\right)\right| \\
& \leq C_{N_{0}} l^{m}(x) t^{-(n-1)+N_{0}+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

for any $t, 0<t<\delta$ and any $x \in \Sigma_{p}\left(=\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)$. For $p=1$ the proof of (8.30) follows from (7.52) (with $\zeta=z$ ) and (8.27). Since $l^{m}(x)$ in (8.30) blows up as $|w(x)| \rightarrow \infty$, no uniform convergence follows from (8.30). In fact the convergence cannot be uniform; this follows from an inspection of the factor $l^{m}(x)$ in (7.52) and (8.27) used for deriving (8.30). For $p>1$ there is an extra factor $p \delta_{p \mid m}$ as shown before (see (7.51) and the paragraph after it). Hence the claim. It is known by using rescaling techniques that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{j=0}^{N_{0}} t^{-(n-1)+j}\left(\operatorname{Tr} b_{n-1-j}^{+}(z)-\operatorname{Tr} b_{n-1-j}^{-}(z)\right) \\
= & \sum_{j=n-1}^{N_{0}} t^{-(n-1)+j}\left(\operatorname{Tr} b_{n-1-j}^{+}(z)-\operatorname{Tr} b_{n-1-j}^{-}(z)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as is from [6, Proposition 3.21 and Theorem 4.1 (1)] (about the vanishing of the supertrace for degrees strictly less than $\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{R}} M=2(n-1)$ ). Note that only the $t^{0}$-term $\operatorname{Tr} b_{0}^{+}(z)-\operatorname{Tr} b_{0}^{-}(z)(j=n-1)$ in (8.31) would survive as $t \rightarrow 0$. We obtain via (8.30) and (8.31)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \operatorname{Part} \mathrm{I} \text { of } \operatorname{Str} P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x) d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
& =\sum_{i} \varphi_{i}(x) p \delta_{p \mid m} l^{m}(x)\left(\operatorname{Tr} b_{0}^{+}(z)-\operatorname{Tr} b_{0}^{-}(z)\right) d v_{V_{i}}(z) d v_{m}(|w|) d v(\phi) / 2 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

The RHS of (8.32) is seen to be related to the classical local index density. For, in view of the heat kernel $K_{t}^{i}(z, \zeta)$ for $\square_{\mathbb{V}_{i, m}}^{\zeta}$ (see (6.3) and (5.6)) the well-known local

index density computation (in connection with Hirzebruch-Riemann-Roch theorem, cf. [6]) can be adapted and applied on $V_{i}$ (with the extra bundle $E$ ), and then, since the background metric $g_{M}$ on $V_{i}$ for $\square_{V_{i}, m}^{\mathrm{c}}$ (cf. Step 3 of Section 3 and Definition 3.8) has been identified with the above-mentioned metric $g_{\text {quot }}$ on $T^{1,0}(\Sigma) / L_{\Sigma}$ (Lemma 8.10), we arrive at the following equalities:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\operatorname{Tr} b_{0}^{+}(z)-\operatorname{Tr} b_{0}^{-}(z)\right) d v_{V_{i}}(z) \\
= & {\left[\left.T d\left(T^{1,0} V_{i}, \pi^{*} g_{M}\right) c h\left(\psi_{i}^{*}\left(E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{m}\right)\right|_{V_{i}}, h_{E} \otimes\| \cdot \|_{m}^{s}\right)\right]_{2(n-1)}(z) } \\
= & {\left[\left.T d\left(T^{1,0}(\Sigma) / L_{\Sigma}, g_{\text {quot }}\right) c h\left(E, h_{E}\right) c h\left(\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{m},\| \cdot \|_{m}^{s}\right)\right]_{2(n-1)}(z, w) } \\
