= & {\left[\left.T d_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(T^{1,0}(\Sigma) / L_{\Sigma}, g_{\text {quot }}\right) c h_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(E, h_{E}\right) e^{-m c_{1}\left(L_{\Sigma},\| \| \|}\right)\right]_{2(n-1)}(z, w) }
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\psi_{i}:(z, w) \in V_{i} \times C_{\varepsilon_{i}} \rightarrow \Sigma$ is the local trivialization (see (3.6) and (2.11)) and $V_{i}$ may be identified with $V_{i} \times\{0\} \times\{1\} \subset \Sigma$. By (3.23) we write (8.32) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{i} \varphi_{i}(x) p \delta_{p \mid m} l^{m}(x)\left(\operatorname{Tr} b_{0}^{+}(z)-\operatorname{Tr} b_{0}^{-}(z)\right) d v_{V_{i}}(z) d v_{f, m} \\
& \stackrel{(8.33)}{=} p \delta_{p \mid m}\left[T d_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(T^{1,0}(\Sigma) / L_{\Sigma}, g_{\text {quot }}\right) c h_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(E, h_{E}\right)\right. \\
& \left.e^{-m c_{1}\left(L_{\Sigma},\| \| \|}\right]_{2(n-1)}(z, w) \wedge l^{m}(x) d v_{f, m}(\text { also by } \sum_{i} \varphi_{i}(x)=1)\right. \\
& \stackrel{(3.24)}{=} p \delta_{p \mid m}\left[T d_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(T^{1,0} \Sigma / L_{\Sigma}, g_{\text {quot }}\right) \wedge c h_{\mathbb{C}^{*}}\left(E, h_{E}\right) \wedge e^{-m c_{1}\left(L_{\Sigma},\| \| \|}\right) \wedge d \bar{v}_{m}\right]_{2 n}(x) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The claim (8.28) follows from (8.32) and (8.34). To exchange the limit $t \rightarrow 0$ and the integral sign we note that $l^{m}(x)$ in the RHS of (8.30) is an $L^{1}$ function in view of Remark 3.4, implying the second claim (8.29).
8.2. Part II of the local $m$-index formula ( $k \geq 1$ in (8.23)) via Lefschetz type formulas. In contrast to the $k=0$ case, $\gamma_{k}^{p m}$ is not necessarily the identity endomorphism if $k \geq 1$ in (8.23). In view of local equivariant index theorems, the fixed points set $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$ (in $V_{j}$, identified with $\left.\left(V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right)^{\gamma_{k}} \subset V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right)$ of $\gamma_{k}$ and hence the singular stratum $\Sigma_{j, k}$ (see (8.9)) (which may cover $\left|\Sigma_{j, k}\right|$ - the support of $\Sigma_{j, k}$, several times) are expected to play a role in the final index formula. See the remark below for the support $\left|\Sigma_{j, k}\right|$ of $\Sigma_{j, k}$.

Remark 8.12. Let $O:=\mathbb{C}^{*} \circ S$ be the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbit of a set $S$. We write $|O|$ for the "support of $O$ ", that is, the set-theoretical image of the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on $S$. This counts the points in the orbit only once.

Notation 8.13. In the remaining of this section $\sigma_{\bullet}$ denotes the symbol map as in [6, Definition 3.4 and Proposition 3.6] and for $\sigma_{\bullet}$ (endomorphisms) see [6, Lemma 6.10 and the top two lines on p.193] which is basically the symbol of the Clifford algebra part of endomorphisms.

To proceed with (8.23), let us first write the asymptotic expansion of $\left(\gamma_{k}^{p m} \circ\right.$ $\left.K_{t}^{j}\left(z_{k}, z\right)\right)^{t}$ which appears in (8.23) and (8.24), as follows (without " $\mid$ " below): as $t \rightarrow 0$ (cf. (7.9) for $k=0$ )

$$
\gamma_{k}^{p m} \circ K_{t}^{j}\left(z_{k}, z\right) \sim(4 \pi t)^{-\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{E}} V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}} / 2} \sum_{i=0}^{\infty} t^{i} \Phi_{i}^{\gamma_{k}^{p m}}(z, z), \quad z \in V_{j}
$$

(cf. [6, Theorem 6.11] with notations parallelly used yet slightly modified here; $\gamma_{k}^{p m}$ acts at $\left.z_{k}\right)$. Notice that (8.35) holds true for an open domain $V_{j}$ although

[6, Theorem 6.11] is applicable for a compact manifold. See [20] for some detailed explanation.

In the spirit of deducing Lefschetz fixed point theorem we compute the following limit via (8.35) (in the space of generalized sections, see [6, Theorem 6.16] for details by noting that $\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ on $\left(V_{j}, \mathcal{E}^{m}\right)$ is an isometry by Corollary 8.5 and Lemma 7.14)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \operatorname{Str}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}} \circ K_{t}^{j}\left(z_{k}, z\right)\right) \\
= & c_{j, k} T_{V_{j}}\left\{\operatorname{Str}_{\mathcal{E}^{m} / S}\left[\sigma_{2 \operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{C}} V_{j}}\left(\Phi_{\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{S}} V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}} / 2}^{\gamma_{k}}(z, z)\right)\right]\right\} \\
= & c_{j, k} T_{V_{j}}\left\{I_{j}\left(\gamma_{k}\right) S t r_{\mathcal{E}^{m}} / S\left[\sigma_{2 \operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{C}} V_{j}-\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{S}} V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\right) \exp \left(-F_{0}^{\mathcal{E}^{m} / S}\right)\right]\right\} \delta_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the Berezin integral denoted by $T_{V_{j}}\left\{I_{j}\left(\gamma_{k}\right) \cdots\right\}$ gives a smooth function on $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}[6$, p. 196 and p.54], $F_{0}^{\mathcal{E}^{m} / S}$ denotes the restriction to $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$ of the twisting curvature [6, p. 195 and p.120] $\left(V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}\right.$ endowed with the metric induced from $\left.\pi^{*} g_{M} \mid V_{j}\right), \sigma_{\bullet}$ is the symbol map (not to be confused with the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma$, see also (8.87)), $c_{j, k}$ $:=(4 \pi)^{-\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{S}} V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}} / 2}(-2 i)^{\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{C}} V_{j}}$ with $(4 \pi)^{-\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{S}} V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}} / 2}$ from (8.35) and $(-2 i)^{\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{C}} V_{j}}$ from the formula in [6, Proposition 3.21] and finally

$$
I_{j}\left(\gamma_{k}\right):=\frac{\hat{A}_{B G V}\left(V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}\right)}{\operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}\right) \operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1} \exp \left(-R^{1}\right)\right)}
$$

(see [6, Theorem 6.11] and Notation 8.15 below). Note that the use of $\hat{A}_{B G V}$ here according to [6] is different from the usual $\hat{A}$-genus form (8.75) by a constant factor involving $2 \pi$. About these expressions, see related discussions prior to (and in the proof of) Proposition 8.33.

Note also that following [6, the line above Theorem 6.16] we use the notation $T_{V_{j}}$ in (8.36) although it is applied to a delta-function like object supported on $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$. For the insertion of $\delta_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}$ in (8.36) in the end, see [6, Theorem 6.11]. With the notation above, set

$$
\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}(z, \bar{z}):=c_{j, k} T_{V_{j}}\left\{I_{j}\left(\gamma_{k}\right) S t r_{\mathcal{E}^{m}} / S\left[\sigma_{2 \operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{C}} V_{j}-\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{S}} V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\right) \exp \left(-F_{0}^{\mathcal{E}^{m} / S}\right)\right]\right\}
$$

for $z \in V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$. Rewrite (8.36) as

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \operatorname{Str}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}} \circ K_{t}^{j}\left(z_{k}, z\right)\right)=\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}(z, \bar{z}) \delta_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}
$$

It follows from (8.39), (8.23) and $l(x)=h(z, \bar{z})|w|^{2}$ that (by $\operatorname{Str}\left(\bullet^{\dagger}\right)=\overline{\operatorname{Str}(\bullet)}$ for the first equality then separating the $k=0$ term where $\gamma_{0}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ is the identity (8.25), from $k \geq 1$ terms in the second equality below)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \operatorname{Str}\left(H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}\right)(x, x) \\
= & \varphi_{j}(x) l^{m}(x) \sum_{k=0}^{N_{j}} \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \overline{S t r\left(\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}} \circ K_{t}^{j}\left(z_{k}, z\right)\right)} \tau_{j}\left(z_{k}\right)\left(\alpha_{k} \alpha_{0}^{-1}\right)^{m} \\
= & \varphi_{j}(x) l^{m}(x) \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \operatorname{Str}\left(K_{t}^{j}(z, z)\right) \tau_{j}(z) \\
& +\varphi_{j}(x) l^{m}(x) \sum_{k=1}^{N_{j}} \overline{\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}(z, \bar{z})} \tau_{j}\left(z_{k}\right)\left(\alpha_{k} \alpha_{0}^{-1}\right)^{m} \delta_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here notice that $\alpha_{k} \alpha_{0}^{-1}\left(=\alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x)=g_{k}^{-1}\right.$ by (8.16)) are independent of $x$ and that $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}=V_{j}^{g_{k}}$ by iii) of Proposition 8.4. We now compute the integral of the supertrace:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma} \operatorname{Str} P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x) d v_{\Sigma, m} \stackrel{(7.1)}{=} \sum_{j} \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma} \operatorname{Str} H_{m, t}^{j} \circ \pi_{m}(x, x) d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
& \stackrel{(8.40)}{=} \sum_{j} \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma} \varphi_{j}(x) l^{m}(x) \operatorname{Str}\left(K_{t}^{j}(z, z)\right) \tau_{j}(z) d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
& +\sum_{j} \sum_{k=1}^{N_{j}}\left(g_{k}^{-1}\right)^{m} \int_{W_{j}} \varphi_{j}(x) l^{m}(x) \overline{\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}(z, \bar{z})} \tau_{j}\left(z_{k}\right) \delta_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}} d v_{\Sigma, m}
\end{aligned}
$$

the last term of which can be computed by (8.52) below to become

$$
\sum_{j} \sum_{k=1}^{N_{j}}\left(g_{k}^{-1}\right)^{m} \int_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}} \varphi_{j}(z, \phi) \overline{\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}(z, \bar{z})} d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}(z) \wedge d \tilde{v}_{m}(z, \phi,|w|)
$$

by $l^{m}(x) d v_{\Sigma, m}=d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}(z) \wedge d \tilde{v}_{m}(z, \phi,|w|)$ in $W_{j}$ with $\sigma(\tilde{g})=\gamma_{k}$ in $V_{j}$ (8.19) and $\tau_{j}=1$ on $\left\{\varphi_{j}(z, \phi) \neq 0\right\}$, see (8.52) and Remark 8.22 for $d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}$ here.

We are going to look for an integrand defined on $\Sigma$ such that its integral over singular strata $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ (see (1.7)) equals (8.42), cf. Theorem 1.1 and (8.48). To this aim (see Proposition 8.23 below) first recall (8.2) for the definition of $g_{k}$ and $G_{j}$ $\left(\subset S^{1} \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}\right)$ and let

$$
\mathcal{G}:=\bigcup_{j(\text { finite })} G_{j}
$$

Note that the finite index set $\mathcal{G}$ may not be a group and $g_{k}$ in (8.2) depends on $j$.
We use $g_{k}$ or $g_{k}^{(j)}$ interchangeably below. For $\tilde{g} \in \mathcal{G}$ let $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ denote the set of points fixed by $\tilde{g}$ (via $\sigma$ ) in $\Sigma$. By (8.9) for $\Sigma_{j, k}$ we then have

$$
\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}=\bigcup_{(j, k): g_{k}^{(j)}=\tilde{g}}\left|\Sigma_{j, k}\right|
$$

Observe that $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ is a (complex) submanifold of $\Sigma$. The following basically follows from definitions.

Lemma 8.14. With the notation above, it holds that ( $\mathcal{G}$ being a finite set)

$$
\Sigma_{\text {sing }}=\bigcup_{\tilde{g} \in \mathcal{G}, \tilde{g} \neq 1} \Sigma^{\tilde{g}}
$$

Proof. Recall that $\Sigma_{p_{j}}$ denotes the set of points having period $2 \pi / p_{j}$ and that $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ is by definition the union of $\Sigma_{p_{j}}, j \geq 2$. If a point has the period less than $2 \pi / p_{1}$, then its isotropy group $\subset S^{1}$ is nontrivial so that it is a fixed point of some element $\tilde{g}$ of $S^{1}$. Conversely, any point in $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ for $\tilde{g} \neq 1$ has a nontrivial isotropy group rendering its period less than $2 \pi / p_{1}$.

Notation 8.15. i) Let $\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{R}}$ denote the real normal bundle of $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$, but for notational convenience we drop the subscript $\mathbb{R}$. We equip it with the metric induced from $G_{a, m}$ or $\pi^{*} g_{M}$; see Remark 8.17 for the equivalence in this case. ii) We follow the notation adopted by [6]: Let $R^{1}$ denote the curvature of $\mathcal{N}$ and by $\tilde{g}_{1}$ the naturally induced action of $\tilde{g}$ on $\mathcal{N}$.

In view of (8.37) we set ( $T \Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ and $L_{\Sigma \delta}$ below viewed as real tangent bundle and subbundle respectively with Lemma $8.10 i$ ) for the metric $g_{\text {quot }}$ )

$$
I(\tilde{g}):=\frac{\tilde{A}_{B G V}\left(T \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} / L_{\Sigma \delta}, g_{q u o t}\right)}{\operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\tilde{g}_{1}\right) \operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\tilde{g}_{1} \exp \left(-R^{1}\right)\right)}
$$

on $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$. Note that for $\tilde{g}=g_{k}^{(j)}=g_{k}$ locally in $W_{j}$ as in (8.44)

$$
\tilde{g}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}=\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}} \text { on } V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}
$$

by (8.19) for $\sigma\left(g_{k}\right)=\gamma_{k}$ on $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$. We prefer the use of two separate notations $\tilde{g}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ and $\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ because the former is meant to be global and intrinsic while the latter is for the restriction of the former on $V_{j}$ (which depends on the trivialization $\psi_{j}$ ). In view of (8.38) and (8.47) we define a complex-valued function $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$ on $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \subset \Sigma$ via "projections" $\pi_{V_{j}}:\left(z_{j}, w_{j}\right) \in W_{j} \rightarrow\left(z_{j}, 1\right) \in V_{j}\left(T_{V_{j}}\right.$ below as in (8.36)): for $q \in \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap D_{j}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}\right|_{\Sigma \delta \cap D_{j}}(q) \\
:= & \left.c_{j, k} T_{V_{j}}\left\{I(\tilde{g}) S t r_{\mathcal{E} / S}\left[\sigma_{2 n-\left(l_{j, k}+2\right)}\left(\tilde{g}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\right) \exp \left(-F_{0}^{\mathcal{E}^{m} / S}\right)\right]\right\}\right|_{\pi_{V_{j}}\left(\psi_{j}^{-1}(q)\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $l_{j, k}=\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{S}} V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$. In Lemma 8.19 below we show that (8.48) is independent of the choice of $D_{j}$ that contains $q$.

It follows (cf. (8.38) for $\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}$ ) that for $q \in \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap D_{j}$

$$
\left.\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}\right|_{\Sigma \delta \cap D_{j}}(q)=\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}\left(z\left(\psi_{j}^{-1}(q)\right), \bar{z}\left(\psi_{j}^{-1}(q)\right)\right)
$$

Here we think of $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$ as a global function and $\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}$ as its local expression.
Lemma 8.16. With the notation above $\tilde{A}_{B G V}\left(T \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} / L_{\Sigma \delta}, g_{\text {quot }}\right), R^{1}$ and $\tilde{g}_{1}$ are locally $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant (meaning that it is invariant under the action of $\rho e^{i \phi}$ with $\rho \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{+}$and $|\phi|$ small). Moreover $\operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\tilde{g}_{1}\right)$ and $\operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\tilde{g}_{1} \exp \left(-R^{1}\right)\right)$ in (8.46) are also locally $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant.

Proof. By (3.21) and (3.14) we write the metric $G_{a, m}$ in special local coordinates $(z, w)$ for (3.13) at $\sigma(c) q_{0}=\left(z_{0}, c w_{0}\right)$ with $q_{0}=\left(z_{0}, w_{0}\right) \in \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap D_{j}$ and $c=|c| e^{i \varphi} \in$ $\mathbb{C}^{*}$ for $|c| \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$arbitrary, $\varphi$ sufficiently near 0 such that $\sigma(c) q_{0}$ still lies in $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap D_{j}$, as follows (with the same coordinates (3.13) holds at $\sigma(c) q_{0}$ when $c$ varies)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& G_{a, m} \mid \sigma(c) q_{0}=\left(g_{M}\right)_{\alpha \bar{\beta}}\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right) d z_{\alpha} d \bar{z}_{\beta}+ \\
& \left(\varphi_{1}\left(|c|^{2} w_{0} \bar{w}_{0}\right)+\varphi_{2}\left(|c|^{2} w_{0} \bar{w}_{0}\right) 4 a^{2}|c|^{-4 a-2}\left(w_{0} \bar{w}_{0}\right)^{-2 a-1}\right) \frac{d w d \bar{w}}{\lambda_{m}}
\end{aligned}
$$

It is not difficult to see from (8.50) that the normal space $\mathcal{N}_{\sigma(c) q_{0}}$, which is perpendicular to $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ at $\sigma(c) q_{0}$, consists of vectors depending only on $z$-coordinate as $c$ varies. It follows that $\sigma(c)_{*}: \mathcal{N}_{q_{0}} \rightarrow \mathcal{N}_{\sigma(c) q_{0}}$ is an isometry with respect to $\pi^{*} g_{M}=$ $\left(g_{M}\right)_{\alpha \bar{\beta}}\left(z_{0}, \bar{z}_{0}\right) d z_{\alpha} d \bar{z}_{\beta}$ in $W_{j}=\psi_{j}^{-1}\left(D_{j}\right)$, and hence the curvature $R^{1}$ of $\mathcal{N}$ is locally $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant. For $\tilde{A}_{B G V}$ on $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ we observe that $g_{q u o t}$ is identified with the metric $\left.\pi^{*} g_{M}\right|_{\Sigma \bar{\delta} \cap D_{j}}$ on the $W_{j}$-chart (see Lemma $8.10 i$ )) so that $\tilde{A}_{B G V}\left(T \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} / L_{\Sigma \delta}, g_{q u o t}\right)$ is also locally $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant. That $\tilde{g}_{1}$ is locally $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant follows from that the action of $\tilde{g}$ commutes with the (local) $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action. The last statement easily follows via the isometry $\sigma(c)_{*}$ just mentioned.

Remark 8.17. By (8.50) the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M}$ and the metric $G_{a, m}$ coincide on the normal bundle $\mathcal{N}$, cf. Remark 8.22.

Corollary 8.18. With the notation above, $\left.\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}\right|_{\Sigma \tilde{s} \cap D_{j}}\left(=\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{I}(z, \bar{z})\right.$ by (8.49)) viewed as a function of $(z, w) \in\left(\psi_{j}^{-1}\right) \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap D_{j}$ is a function of $z$ (and $\bar{z}$ ) only, $z \in$ $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$. In particular $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m} \mid \Sigma \tilde{s} \cap D_{j}$ is locally $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant.

Proof. From Lemma 8.16 $I(\tilde{g})$ in (8.46) is independent of the local $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action. The curvature $F_{0}^{\gamma_{m} ; \bar{z}}$ (8.36) and the symbol $\sigma_{2 n-\left(l_{j, k}+2\right)}\left(\tilde{g}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\right)$ work on $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$ and so involve the $z$-coordinate(s) only. Altogether in view of (8.48) $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m} \mid \Sigma \tilde{s} \cap D_{j}$ is a function of $z$ in $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$.

Using Lemma 8.16 we prove
Lemma 8.19. For $q \in \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap D_{j} \cap D_{j^{\prime}}$ we have

$$
\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}\left\lvert\, \Sigma \tilde{s} \cap D_{j}(q)=\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}\right.$ $\left.\left|\Sigma \tilde{s} \cap D_{j^{\prime}}(q)\right.\right.
$$

Namely $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$ is a globally defined smooth function on $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$.
Proof. Suppose that $g_{k}^{(j)}=g_{k^{\prime}}^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}=\tilde{g}$ thus $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}=V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}=\Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap\left(V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right)$ (resp. $\left.V_{j^{\prime}}^{\gamma_{k^{\prime}}}=V_{j^{\prime}}^{\tilde{g}}=\Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap\left(V_{j^{\prime}} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right)\right)$. We leave the reader to check the equality of the constants $l_{j, k}=l_{j^{\prime}, k^{\prime}}, c_{j, k}=c_{j^{\prime}, k^{\prime}}$. To compare the two sides of (8.51) we notice that by (2.7) and Theorem 2.3 one finds $\zeta_{j} \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ with $\zeta_{j}=\left|\zeta_{j}\right| e^{i \phi_{j}},\left|\phi_{j}\right|<$ $\varepsilon_{j}\left(\right.$ resp. $\zeta_{j^{\prime}} \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ with $\zeta_{j^{\prime}}=\left|\zeta_{j^{\prime}}\right| e^{i \phi_{j^{\prime}}},\left|\phi_{j^{\prime}}\right|<\varepsilon_{j^{\prime}}$ ) such that

$$
\psi_{j} \pi_{V_{j}}\left(\psi_{j}^{-1}(q)\right) \xrightarrow{\sigma\left(\zeta_{j}\right)} q\left(\text { resp. } q \xrightarrow{\sigma\left(\zeta_{j^{\prime}}\right)} \psi_{j^{\prime}} \pi_{V_{j^{\prime}}}\left(\psi_{j^{\prime}}^{-1}(q)\right)\right)
$$

so that $\sigma\left(\zeta_{j^{\prime}} \zeta_{j}\right)$ sends $\psi_{j} \pi_{V_{j}}\left(\psi_{j}^{-1}(q)\right)$ to $\psi_{j^{\prime}} \pi_{V_{j^{\prime}}}\left(\psi_{j^{\prime}}^{-1}(q)\right)$. Since $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$ in both sides of (8.51) arise from the quantity $I(\tilde{g}) \operatorname{Str}_{\mathcal{E} / \bar{S}}\left[\sigma_{2 n-\left(l_{j, k}+2\right)}\left(\tilde{g}^{\tilde{\mathcal{E}}^{m}}\right) \exp \left(-F_{0}^{\mathcal{E}^{m} / \bar{s}}\right)\right]$ on $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ (see Notation $7.12 i$ ) for $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}^{m}, \mathcal{E}^{m}$ and (8.48) with no "tilde" on $\mathcal{E}^{m}$ ), we see from (8.48) that the values in (8.51) differ by the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma\left(\zeta_{j^{\prime}} \zeta_{j}\right)$ and then the local $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariance (Corollary 8.18) gives the same value, proving (8.51).

In the above discussion we refer to the local $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariance of $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$. In fact $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$ is (globally) $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant: (This fact is not strictly needed until (8.116); see remarks after (8.116).)

Corollary 8.20. For all $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ and $q$, (hence) $\sigma(\lambda) q \in \Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ it holds that $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}(\sigma(\lambda) q)$ $=\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}(q)$. In particular, the function $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$ takes the same value if both $q$ and $\sigma(\lambda) q$ lie in the same local chart $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap D_{j}$.
Proof. Since $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$ is well defined on the whole $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ by Lemma 8.19 and is locally $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant by Corollary 8.18 , the global $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariance follows from a composition of finite number of local $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-actions (cf. proof of Lemma 8.2).

Note that $G_{a, m}$ is not $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant in general but it is $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant after restricting to some subbundles such as the above-mentioned normal bundles (Remark 8.17). In $M=\Sigma / \sigma$ let $\tilde{F}$ (resp. $\tilde{F}_{j}$ ) denote a fixed point orbifold (resp. the $j$-chart part of $\tilde{F})$; see (8.113) and the paragraph there for the precise meaning of $\tilde{F}$. Let $d v_{\tilde{F}_{j}}, d v_{\tilde{F}}$ denote the (induced) volume forms on $\tilde{F}_{j} \subset M, \tilde{F} \subset M$ respectively with respect to the metric $g_{M}$ (Notation 3.1). Let $d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}}$ be the pullback of $d v_{\tilde{F}_{j}}$ by $V_{j}^{\tilde{g}} \rightarrow \tilde{F}_{j}$

(the $j$-part orbifold chart for some $\tilde{g} \in \mathcal{G}$ in (8.43) under the restriction of $\pi: \Sigma$ $\rightarrow \Sigma / \sigma$ to $V_{j}^{\tilde{g}} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$. Let $d v_{\Sigma \bar{\partial}, m}$ denote the volume form of $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ with respect to the metric induced from $G_{a, m}$. With respect to the metrics $g_{M}$ and $G_{a, m}$, the relation between these volume forms is given by

Lemma 8.21. With the notation above and in Section 3, we have i)

$$
\begin{aligned}
d v_{\Sigma \bar{\partial}, m} & =\left.\pi^{*} d v_{\tilde{F}} \wedge d v_{f, m}\right|_{\Sigma \bar{\partial}} \\
& =d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}} \wedge\left.\left(l^{-m} d \tilde{v}_{m}\right)\right|_{\left.\Sigma_{\Sigma_{j}, k}\right|} \quad\left(\widetilde{g}=g_{k}^{(j)} \text { in }(8.44)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

ii) for $m=0$, given $p_{0}=\{z\} \times\{0\} \times\{1\} \in W_{j}$, choose new coordinate $w=|w| e^{i \phi}$ with $z$-coordinate fixed so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left.d v_{\Sigma \bar{\partial}, 0}\right|_{\{z\} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}} & =\left.\pi^{*} d v_{\tilde{F}_{j}}(z) \wedge d \tilde{v}_{0}\right|_{\Sigma \bar{\partial}}(w) \\
& =d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}}(z) \wedge d v_{0}(|w|) \wedge \frac{d v(\phi)}{2 \pi}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here note that $V_{j}$ is determined by the "old" coordinate $w(=1)$.
Proof. For $i$ ) the first equality of (8.52) follows from (3.22) (see also (8.50)). In view of (8.44), (8.9) the second equality of (8.52) follows from the definition of $d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}}$ and (3.24). For $i i$ ) with the metric on $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ induced from the metric $G_{a, m}(m=0)$ on $\Sigma$, the volume form $\left.d v_{\Sigma \bar{\partial}, 0}\right|_{\{z\} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}}$along a local $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbit of $p_{0}$ reads as (8.53) by (3.22), (3.23) with the reasoning there for $m=0$ : given $p_{0}=\{z\} \times\{0\} \times$ $\{1\}$, choose new $w=|w| e^{i \phi}$ such that $h(z, \bar{z})=1, d h(z, \bar{z})=0$ at $p_{0}$. Hence (8.53) holds.

The notation $d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}}$ is the volume form on $V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}$ with respect to the metric $\pi^{*} g_{M}$; this metric is to be distinguished from the metric $G_{a, m}$. It is worthwhile noting the following.

Remark 8.22. Let $d v_{V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}}$ denote the volume form induced by $G_{a, m}$. Then $d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}}$ may not equal $d v_{V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}}$ in general in view of (3.11), (3.12) and (3.21). Compare Remark 8.17 .

With reference to (8.42), the integrand to be desired (cf. the paragraph after (8.42)) is now seen by the following.

Proposition 8.23. With the notation above, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\tilde{g}^{-m} \int_{\Sigma \bar{\partial}} \overline{\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}(x)} l^{m}(x) d v_{\Sigma \bar{\partial}, m} \\
=\sum_{(j, k): g_{k}^{(j)}=\tilde{g}}\left(g_{k}^{-1}\right)^{m} \int_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}} \times\left(-\varepsilon_{j}, \varepsilon_{j}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+}} \varphi_{j}(z, \phi) \overline{\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}(z, \bar{z})} \\
d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}(z) \wedge d \tilde{v}_{m}(z, \phi,|w|)
\end{gathered}
$$

Proof. Observe that by (8.52) $l^{m}(x) d v_{\Sigma \bar{\partial}, m}=d \tilde{v}_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}(z) \wedge d \tilde{v}_{m}$ on $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}} \cap D_{j}$. From this, $\Sigma_{j} \varphi_{j}=1$ and Corollary $8.18,(8.54)$ follows.

Recall that the largest period is $\frac{2 \pi}{p}$ (see the paragraph after (1.5)). We can now prove the main result Theorem 1.1.

# 8.3. The local index formula completed. 

Proof. (of Theorem 1.1) To show $i$ ) of the theorem, observe that the formula (8.28) gives the $H R R_{m}$ term in the RHS of (1.5). To compute the singular part of $\operatorname{Str} P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)$ we sum up over $j$ the second term in the RHS of (8.40) in view of (8.20). This results in getting the term $\overline{\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}}$ (the complex conjugate of $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$ in (8.48)) by noting that $\alpha_{k} \alpha_{0}^{-1}=\alpha_{k}(x) \alpha_{0}^{-1}(x)=g_{k}^{-1}$ by (8.16) and $\tau_{j}=1$ on supp $\varphi_{j}$. We have shown (1.5) for $\operatorname{Str} P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x)$ as $t \rightarrow 0$.

To show ii) for the index formula, from the McKean-Singer type formula (5.19) for $\widetilde{\square}_{m}^{v \cdot x}$ (with $E$ added by Remark 5.13) together with Theorem 8.1, it follows that

$$
\operatorname{index}(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}^{E} \text {-complex })=\lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma}\left[\operatorname{Tr} P_{m, t}^{0,+}(x, x)-\operatorname{Tr} P_{m, t}^{0,-}(x, x)\right] d v_{\Sigma, m}
$$

By (8.41), (8.42) and (8.54), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
R H S \text { of (8.55) }= & \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma} \operatorname{Part} \mathrm{I} \text { of } \operatorname{Str} P_{m, t}^{0}(x, x) d v_{\Sigma, m} \\
& +\sum_{\tilde{g} \in \tilde{\mathcal{G}}, \tilde{g} \neq 1} \tilde{g}^{-m} \int_{\Sigma \tilde{g}} \overline{\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}(x)} l^{m}(x) d v_{\Sigma \tilde{g}, m}
\end{aligned}
$$

The first term in the RHS of (8.56) is reduced to the RHS of (8.29) by Theorem 8.11. The second term in the RHS of (8.56) is real-valued since the other terms in (8.56) are real-valued. Thus (1.6) follows from (8.55) and taking the complex conjugate of the second term in the RHS of (8.56).

Remark 8.24. In comparison with [32, (14.3) and (14.4)] a sum over $\tilde{g}$ or $k$ in our formula (8.56) is anticipated; see also Remark 8.41. A detailed comparison is made in the next subsection.

In these subsections devoted to the local $m$-index density, we have given an expression based on the language of [6], which are written in the setting of Riemannian geometry. For complex manifolds here, it is desirable to express $\mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m}$ in (8.48) in terms of Todd form $\operatorname{Td}\left(T \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} / L_{\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}}, g_{\text {quot }}\right)$, twisted Chern character form $c h\left(\gamma_{k}^{E}, E\right)$ (it is the usual Chern character form twisted by $\gamma_{k}^{E}$ in the sense of (8.77)) where $E$ is a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-equivariant holomorphic vector bundle and the (usual/untwisted) Chern character form $c h\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$. The expression that we will end up with is the following: for $(j, k)$ such that $g_{k}^{(j)}=\tilde{g}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{F}_{\tilde{g}, m} \mid \Sigma \tilde{g} \cap D_{j} \stackrel{(8.49)}{=} \mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}(z, \bar{z})= \\
& T_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}} \frac{T d\left(T \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} / L_{\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}}, g_{\text {quot }}\right) c h\left(\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*} E \mid V_{j}}, \psi_{j}^{*} E \mid V_{j}\right) c h\left(\left.\psi_{j}^{*}\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right|_{V_{j}}\right)}{\operatorname{det}\left(1-\left(\tilde{g}^{-1}\right)_{i}^{v} \exp \left(-\frac{i}{2 \pi} R_{c}^{1}\right)\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

(see the paragraph before Notation 8.30 below for notations involving the superscript/subscript " $c$ " in $\left(\tilde{g}^{-1}\right)_{i}^{v}$ and $R_{c}^{1}$ above). Some details for deducing (8.57) is given in Subsection 8.4 below. Formula (8.57) allows us to compare our result with [32, p.184, (14.4)] which corresponds to the $m=0$ case of (8.57).

An application of the $m$-index on some two-dimensional $\Sigma$ yields algebraic identities that are perhaps interesting and nontrivial (see (8.65)).
Example 8.25. Consider $\tilde{M}=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ also viewed as $S^{2}$, the unit sphere in $\mathbb{R}^{3}$. Let $l$ be an integer larger than or equal to 2 . Let $g=e^{\mathbb{Z}_{l}} \in G=\mathbb{Z}_{l} \subset S^{1} \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}$ act on

$S^{2}$ by a rotation of $\frac{2 \pi}{l}$ degree around the $z$-axis. So the north pole $N=(0,0,1)$ and the south pole $S=(0,0,-1)$ are the only fixed points of $g, g^{2}, \cdots, g^{l-1}$. Let $K_{\tilde{M}}$ denote the canonical line bundle over $\tilde{M}$. The $G$-action on $\tilde{M}$ induces an action on $K_{\tilde{M}}$ by pulling back the forms. Observe that

$$
\Sigma:=\left(K_{\tilde{M}} \backslash\{0 \text {-section }\}\right) / G
$$

is a complex surface with a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action induced by the natural $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on $K_{\tilde{M}} \backslash\{0$ section $\}$, which becomes a locally free action denoted as $\sigma_{s}$ on $\Sigma$ in the sense of Theorem 1.1. It follows that

$$
\Sigma / \mathbb{C}^{*}\left(\text { or } \Sigma / \sigma_{s}\right) \cong \tilde{M} / G=\mathbb{C P}^{1} / \mathbb{Z}_{l}
$$

is a (1-dimensional) compact complex orbifold with the two orbifold points $N$ and $S$.

Take $m=0$ in (1.6). We first compute index $\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m}$ for $m=0$. Using (10.30) with $P=\Sigma, M=\Sigma / \sigma_{s}=\Sigma / \mathbb{C}^{*}$ by Remark 10.10 we get $h_{m=0}^{0}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})=h^{0}\left(\Sigma / \mathbb{C}^{*}, \mathcal{O}_{\Sigma / \mathbb{C}^{*}}\right)$ $=1$ and $h_{m=0}^{1}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})=h^{1}\left(\Sigma / \mathbb{C}^{*}, \mathcal{O}_{\Sigma / \mathbb{C}^{*}}\right)=h^{1}\left(\mathbb{C P}^{1} / \mathbb{Z}_{l}, \mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C P}^{1} / \mathbb{Z}_{l}}\right)$. The fact that $H^{1}\left(\mathbb{C P}^{1} / \mathbb{Z}_{l}, \mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C P}^{1} / \mathbb{Z}_{l}}\right)$ is easily seen to be a $\mathbb{Z}_{l}$-invariant subspace of $H^{1}\left(\mathbb{C P}^{1}, \mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C P}^{1}}\right)$ which equals 0 , gives the LHS of (1.6):

$$
\operatorname{index}\left(\bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m=0}\right)=h_{m=0}^{0}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})-h_{m=0}^{1}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})=1
$$

By $h^{0}\left(\mathbb{C P}^{1}, \mathcal{O}\right)-h^{1}\left(\mathbb{C P}^{1}, \mathcal{O}\right)=1$ given by the similar index formula, it is seen that the first term on the RHS of (1.6) equals $1 / l$. For the remaining terms of (1.6) with $\tilde{g}=g, g^{2}, \cdots, g^{l-1} \in G, \Sigma^{\tilde{g}}(\subset \Sigma)$ consists of two fibres of $\Sigma$ at $N$ and $S$ each with area $\frac{1}{l}$ with respect to the measure $d v_{0}(|w|) \frac{d v(\tilde{g})}{2 \pi}$ (see (8.44) and (8.53)). It is not difficult to see that the contribution from $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ associated with $(N, g),\left(N, g^{2}\right), \cdots$, $\left(N, g^{l-1}\right), \tilde{g}=g^{k}, 1 \leq k \leq l-1$ in the RHS of (1.6) using (8.57) without $E$ gives, where $1-g^{-k}$ below is from the denominator of (8.57) and found to be $\left(\tilde{g}^{-1}\right)_{1}^{c}=$ $g^{-k}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{l} \sum_{k=1}^{l-1} \frac{1}{1-g^{-k}} & =\frac{1}{l} \sum_{k=1}^{l-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}-i \frac{\sin \frac{2 \pi k}{l}}{2\left(1-\cos \frac{2 \pi k}{l}\right)}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{l} \sum_{k=1}^{l-1} \frac{1}{2}=\frac{l-1}{2 l}
\end{aligned}
$$

in view of $\Sigma_{k=1}^{l-1} \sin \frac{2 \pi k}{l} /\left(1-\cos \frac{2 \pi k}{l}\right)=0$ since the complex conjugate of $\sum_{k=1}^{l-1} \frac{1}{1-g^{-k}}$ equals itself $\left(\tilde{g}^{-k}=g^{-l+k}\right)$. Similarly the contribution from $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ associated with $(S, g),\left(S, g^{2}\right), \cdots,\left(S, g^{l-1}\right)$ also gives $\frac{l-1}{2 l}$. Altogether we get $\frac{1}{l}+\frac{l-1}{2 l}+\frac{l-1}{2 l}=1$ for the RHS of (1.6) and hence have verified (1.6) for $m=0$.

We turn now to $m>0$. Write $G=\mathbb{Z}_{l}$. The situation is now equivalent to adding an orbifold line bundle $\left(K_{\tilde{M} / G}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$; this follows from Remark 10.10 using (10.30) with $P=\Sigma, M=\Sigma / \sigma_{s}=\tilde{M} / G$ and (10.29) and (8.58) with $L_{M}=\Sigma \times_{\sigma_{s}} \mathbb{C}=$ $K_{\tilde{M}} / G=K_{\tilde{M} / G}$ as a holomorphic orbifold line bundle over $M=\tilde{M} / G$. Denote the holomorphic line bundle of degree $d$ over $\tilde{M}=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ by $\mathcal{O}(d)$. By $K_{\tilde{M}}=\mathcal{O}(-2)$

$$
H^{1}\left(\tilde{M},\left(K_{\tilde{M}}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)=H^{0}(\tilde{M}, \mathcal{O}(-2 m-2))=0
$$

for $m \geq 0$. It follows from (10.30) (which holds for orbifolds via Remark 10.10) that $H_{m}^{1}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O}) \simeq H^{1}\left(\tilde{M} / G,\left(K_{\tilde{M} / G}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$, a $G$-invariant subspace of $H^{1}\left(\tilde{M},\left(K_{\tilde{M}}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ as

in the $m=0$ case since $G$ is a finite group, vanishes via (8.60). Now we are going to compute the dimension of $H_{m}^{0}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O}) \simeq H^{0}\left(\tilde{M} / G,\left(K_{\tilde{M} / G}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \simeq G$-invariant elements of $H^{0}\left(\tilde{M},\left(K_{\tilde{M}}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$. Let $[z: w]$ denote the homogeneous coordinates of $\tilde{M}=\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ with $G=\mathbb{Z}_{l}$ action by $[z: w] \rightarrow\left[e^{2 \pi i / l} z: w\right]$. Write a holomorphic section of $T \tilde{M}^{\otimes m}=\left(K_{\tilde{M}}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ in $[z: 1]$ as $f(z)\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\right)^{m}$ for a polynomial $f(z)$ of degree $\leq$ $2 m$. Its $G$-invariance implies that

$$
f\left(e^{2 \pi i / l} z\right)=e^{2 \pi m i / l} f(z)
$$

Writing $f(z)=\sum_{k=0}^{2 m} c_{k} z^{k}$ and $m \equiv r \bmod l$ for some $0 \leq r<l$., we obtain by (8.61) that for $c_{k} \neq 0, e^{2 \pi i k / l}$ must be $e^{2 \pi i r / l}$. Write
(8.62) $\kappa(l, m):=$ the number of nonnegative integers $n$ satisfying $r+l \cdot n \leq 2 m$.

So $h_{m}^{0}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})=h^{0}\left(\tilde{M} / G,\left(K_{\tilde{M} / G}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ equals $\kappa(l, m)$. Thus

$$
\text { index } \bar{\partial}_{\Sigma, m} \equiv h_{m}^{0}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})-h_{m}^{1}(\Sigma, \mathcal{O})=\kappa(l, m)
$$

as the LHS of (1.6). For instance, if $l \mid m$ then $r=0$ and $\kappa(l, m)=\frac{2 m}{l}+1$.
We now compute the RHS of (1.6) for $m \geq 0$, the first term of which being the integral of $\mathrm{HRR}_{m}$ equals $\frac{2 m+1}{l}$ by similar arguments as in the $m=0$ case above. The contribution from $\Sigma^{\bar{g}}$ associated with $(N, g),\left(N, g^{2}\right), \cdots,\left(N, g^{l-1}\right)$ (resp. $(S, g)$, $\left.\left(S, g^{2}\right), \cdots,\left(S, g^{l-1}\right)\right)$ in the RHS of (1.6) using (8.57) without $E$ gives, where the numerator $g^{k m}$ below is from $\bar{g}^{m}$ of (1.6),

$$
\frac{1}{l} \sum_{k=1}^{l-1} \frac{g^{k m}}{1-g^{-k}}=: \mu_{N}(l, m)\left(\text { resp. } \mu_{S}(l, m)\right), \quad g=e^{\frac{2 \pi i}{l}}
$$

Clearly $\mu_{N}(l, m)=\mu_{S}(l, m)$ denoted by $\mu(l, m)$. To verify (1.6) for any integers $l \geq 2, m \geq 0$, is the same as to show the following identity

$$
\kappa(l, m)=\frac{2 m+1}{l}+2 \mu(l, m)
$$

Write $x_{k}=g^{k}$. So $\frac{g^{k m}}{1-g^{-k}}$ in (8.64) equals $\frac{x_{k}^{m+1}}{x_{k}-1}$. It follows from (8.64) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
l \cdot \mu(l, m) & =\sum_{k=1}^{l-1} \frac{x_{k}^{m+1}}{x_{k}-1} \\
& =\sum_{k=1}^{l-1} \frac{x_{k}^{m+1}-1}{x_{k}-1}+\sum_{k=1}^{l-1} \frac{1}{x_{k}-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

The first term of the RHS in (8.66) equals

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{k=1}^{l-1}\left(x_{k}^{m}+x_{k}^{m-1}+\cdots+x_{k}+1\right) \\
= & \sum_{a=0}^{m} \sum_{k=1}^{l-1} x_{k}^{a}=\sum_{a=0}^{m} \sum_{k=1}^{l-1}\left(g^{a}\right)^{k} \\
= & \sum_{0 \leq a \leq m, g^{a}=1} \sum_{k=1}^{l-1} 1+\sum_{0 \leq a \leq m, g^{a} \neq 1} \frac{g^{a}-\left(g^{a}\right)^{l}}{1-g^{a}}\left(\text { note that } g^{l}=1\right) \\
= & (l-1) \cdot \#\left\{a \mid 0 \leq a \leq m, g^{a}=1\right\}+(-1) \cdot \#\left\{a \mid 0 \leq a \leq m, g^{a} \neq 1\right\} \\
= & (l-1)(1+q)+(-1)(m-q)=-m+l-1+l \cdot q
\end{aligned}
$$

where $q$ is the nonnegative integer such that $m=q \cdot l+r, 0 \leq r<l$. In the RHS of (8.66) the second term via (8.59) reads

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{l-1} \frac{1}{x_{k}-1}=-\frac{l-1}{2}
$$

Substituting (8.67) and (8.68) into (8.66) we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu(l, m) & =\frac{1}{l}\left[\left(-m+l-1+l \cdot q\right)-\frac{l-1}{2}\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{l}\left(-m+\frac{l-1}{2}+l \cdot q\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By (8.69) the RHS of (8.65) reads as

$$
\frac{2 m+1}{l}+2 \mu(l, m)=1+2 q
$$

From $r=m-q \cdot l$ and $r+l \cdot n \leq 2 m$ it follows that $n \leq 2 q+\frac{r}{l}$ hence $n=0,1, \cdots$, $2 q$. So $\kappa(l, m)$-the number of the nonnegative integers $n$ satisfying $r+l \cdot n \leq 2 m$, is exactly $1+2 q$. By this and (8.70) we have proved (8.65).

Finally let us indicate the following fact which is of topological nature.
Proposition 8.26. The first integral of (1.6) in Theorem 1.1 is independent of the choice of $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant connections on $T^{1,0}(\Sigma) / L_{\Sigma}, E$ and $L_{\Sigma}$ respectively, used for computing the associated Todd form and Chern character forms in (1.6). Furthermore the similar conclusion holds for those integrals over $\Sigma^{2}$ of (1.6).
Proof. We follow the notation in the preceding proof. From [62, Appendix B.5] we see that the "d-exact" objects, resulting from the difference between the characteristic forms associated with different $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant connections, can be chosen to be " $\mathrm{d}\left(\mathbb{C}^{*}\right.$-invariant forms)". We are then reduced to checking the following vanishing on the noncompact space $\Sigma$ (for the first integral of (1.6))

$$
\int_{\Sigma} d Q \wedge d \bar{v}_{m}=0
$$

where $Q$ is a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant $(2 n-3)$-form. That the integrand in (8.71) is $L^{1}$ integrable is easily checked (cf. Remark 3.4).

Some preparations are in order. Take a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant distance function $\rho\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)$, i.e. $\rho\left(\sigma(\lambda)(x), \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right)=\rho\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right), \lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, which can be constructed from a distance function on $M:=\Sigma / \sigma$ using $g_{M}$ (thus degenerate along the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-orbits). Let

$0 \leq \chi_{\varepsilon} \leq 1$ on $\Sigma$ be a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant $C^{\infty}$ cut-off function: $\chi_{\varepsilon}(x)=1$ if $\rho\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right) \geq$ $2 \varepsilon, \chi_{\varepsilon}(x)=0$ if $\rho\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right) \leq \varepsilon$ and $\chi_{\varepsilon}(\sigma(\lambda)(x))=\chi_{\varepsilon}(x),\left|d \chi_{\varepsilon}\right|_{G_{\sigma, m}}=O\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)$. For the last condition we use (3.21) for $G_{a, m}$ (see also (3.14)) with the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariance of $\chi_{\varepsilon}$. Since the action $\sigma$ is globally free on $\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ ( $p=p_{1}=1$ by adjusting $\sigma$ to $\tilde{\sigma}\left(l e^{i \theta}\right)=\sigma\left(l e^{i \theta / p}\right)$ ) and $\operatorname{supp}\left(\chi_{\varepsilon}\right) \subset \Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}$, it follows that $D_{\varepsilon}:=\operatorname{supp}\left(\chi_{\varepsilon}\right) / \sigma(\subset$ $M:=\Sigma / \sigma)$ is a smooth manifold with the boundary $\partial D_{\varepsilon}$.

Back to (8.71) which equals

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}} d Q \wedge d \hat{v}_{m}=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}} \chi_{\varepsilon} d Q \wedge d \hat{v}_{m} \\
= & \lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}} d\left(\chi_{\varepsilon} Q\right) \wedge d \hat{v}_{m}-\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \int_{\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}}\left(d \chi_{\varepsilon}\right) Q \wedge d \hat{v}_{m}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we compute $\int_{\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}} d\left(\chi_{\varepsilon} Q\right) \wedge d \hat{v}_{m}$ on the RHS of (8.72), which equals

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{D_{\varepsilon}} d_{M}\left(\chi_{\varepsilon} Q\right) \int_{\mathbb{C}^{*} \text {-orbit }} d \hat{v}_{m}\left(\text { by } \mathbb{C}^{*} \text {-invariance of } \chi_{\varepsilon} Q\right) \\
& \stackrel{(3.27)}{=}\left(\int_{\partial D_{\varepsilon}} \chi_{\varepsilon} Q\right) \cdot 1=0\left(\chi_{\varepsilon} \mid{ }_{\partial D_{\varepsilon}}=0\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the last term in (8.72), using $N_{\varepsilon}=\left\{x \in \Sigma: \varepsilon \leq \rho\left(x, \Sigma_{\text {sing }}\right) \leq 2 \varepsilon\right\} / \sigma(\subset$ $M:=\Sigma / \sigma)$ as a $C^{\infty}$ manifold with boundary, we compute (recalling $\left|d \chi_{\varepsilon}\right|=O\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)$ ):

$$
\int_{\Sigma \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}}\left(d \chi_{\varepsilon}\right) Q \wedge d \hat{v}_{m}=\int_{N_{\varepsilon}}\left(d \chi_{\varepsilon}\right) Q \int_{\mathbb{C}^{*} \text {-orbit }} d \hat{v}_{m}=O\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right) v o l\left(N_{\varepsilon}\right) \cdot 1 \rightarrow 0
$$

as $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$ since $v o l\left(N_{\varepsilon}\right)=O\left(\varepsilon^{2}\right)$ in view that the real codimensin of $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}$ (resp. $\Sigma_{\text {sing }} / \sigma)$ in $\Sigma$ (resp. $\Sigma / \sigma=M$ ) is larger or equal to 2 . The assertion (8.71) follows from (8.72), (8.73) and (8.74). To get similar conclusion for those integrals on $\Sigma^{\bar{g}}$, we notice that $V^{\bar{g}}=V^{H_{k+1}}$ by (8.109) in Lemma $8.37 i$ ). It follows (cf. Lemma 8.37) that $S^{1} / H_{k+1} \times \mathbb{R}^{+}$acts on $\Sigma^{\bar{g}} \backslash \Sigma_{\text {sing }}^{\bar{g}}$ (globally) freely, where $\Sigma_{\text {sing }}^{\bar{g}}$ consists of lower dimensional strata. The remaining arguments are then similar to those from (8.72) to (8.74).

We remark that in [18] the statement and proof of the off-diagonal estimate (ODE for short) [18, Theorem 5.10, p.78] are correct but unfortunately ODE is not properly applied to the "supertrace" computation - i.e. to the proof of [18, Theorem 6.4, cf. (6.21) on p.98]. So the resulting index formula as stated there (cf. [18, Theorem 1.10, Corollary 1.13, Theorem 1.28]) is not entirely correct (see [19] for an erratum to [18]) unless certain conditions are imposed on the underlying CR manifolds. The misuse of ODE occurs in [18, (6.21)] where the supertrace computation involves "pullbacks", for which our application of ODE is not quite valid because the pullback operation may produce nontrivial endomorphisms of the bundles under consideration. Nevertheless we refer to [23] for special situations to which the original index formulas of [18] as just mentioned do apply.

# 8.4. Comparison with Duistermaat's formula for the Kähler case, Part 

I: from real to complex. In this subsection we are going to convert the real expression of $\mathcal{F}_{\bar{g}, m}$ in (8.48) into the complex version (8.57). The formula (8.57) allows us to compare our result with that of Duistermaat [32, p.184, (14.4)]. The

main result of this section is Proposition 8.33, which proves (8.57) claimed in the last subsection.

Our main references for this and the next subsections are [6] and [32]. The former is mainly on the real situation while the latter is on the (almost)-complex case. It is hoped that our presentation here may help to clarify some points; see for instance Remarks 8.32, 8.35, 8.40 and Footnote ${ }^{12}$ below.

We start with the general setup and fix the notation. Let $X$ be a complex manifold which plays the role as our $M=\Sigma / \sigma$. For simplicity we assume that $X$ is Kähler. Let $E$ be a holomorphic Hermitian vector bundle over $X$ with trivial Clifford action. Consider the Clifford module $\mathcal{E} \equiv \mathcal{E}_{X}:=\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X \otimes E$ with the Clifford connection obtained by twisting the Levi-Civita connection with the canonical (Chern) connection of $E$. The endomorphisms of a complex vector bundle are meant to be $\mathbb{C}$-linear.

Recall that the canonical $\hat{A}$-genus form $\hat{A}(X)$ and the Todd genus form $T d(X)$ of the complex manifold $X$ are defined as follows: ( $R^{+}$denotes the curvature of $\left.T^{1,0} X\right.$ as in $[6$, p.152])

$$
\begin{gathered}
\hat{A}(X):=\operatorname{det}\left(\frac{\left(\frac{i}{2 \pi} R^{+}\right) / 2}{\sinh \left[\left(\frac{i}{2 \pi} R^{+}\right) / 2\right]}\right)=\operatorname{det}\left(\frac{\left(\frac{1}{2 \pi i} R^{+}\right) / 2}{\sinh \left[\left(\frac{1}{2 \pi i} R^{+}\right) / 2\right]}\right) \\
T d(X):=\operatorname{det}\left(\frac{\frac{i}{2 \pi} R^{+}}{1-e^{-\frac{i}{2 \pi} R^{+}}}\right)=\operatorname{det}\left(\frac{\frac{1}{2 \pi i} R^{+}}{e^{\frac{i}{2 \pi i} R^{+}}-1}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

where the above convention involving $2 \pi$-factors is different from that in [6, p.152], cf. (8.84). Let $\gamma_{X}$ be a biholomorphic map and an isometry on $X$. Let $X^{\gamma_{X}}$ $\subset X$ denote the fixed point set of $\gamma_{X}$. Then $\gamma_{X}$ induces a complex (bundle) endomorphism $\gamma_{X}^{\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X}$ acting on $\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X$ over $X^{\gamma_{X}}$. For $E$ above, assume that $\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E}}$ is a holomorphic bundle map of $E$ covering the action of $\gamma_{X}$, preserving the Hermitian metric of $E$. Together we have a bundle map $\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E}}=\gamma_{X}^{\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X} \otimes \gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E}}$ on $\left.\mathcal{E}\right|_{X \gamma_{X}}$. Note that $\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E}}$ is compatible with the Clifford action and the Clifford connection. We have the following for use in Lemma 8.28.

Lemma 8.27. With the notation above, there is a canonical isomorphism $j$ : $\operatorname{End}(E) \rightarrow \operatorname{End}_{C(X)}\left(\mathcal{E}_{X}\right)$ over $X^{\gamma_{X}}$, where $C(X)$ denotes the real Clifford algebra of $X$.

Proof. We can embed $\operatorname{End}(E)$ into $\operatorname{End}_{C(X)}\left(\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X \otimes E\right)=\operatorname{End}_{C(X)}\left(\mathcal{E}_{X}\right)$ by extending the action on $\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X$ identically (note that the Clifford action on $E$ is trivial by default). We denote this canonical embedding by $j$. At each point $p$ of $X^{\gamma_{X}}, C(X) \otimes \mathbb{C} \cong \operatorname{End}\left(\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X\right)$ at $p$ by [6, Proposition 3.19] and the center of $\operatorname{End}\left(\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X\right)$ at $p$ is $\mathbb{C}$. It follows that $\operatorname{End}_{C(X)}\left(\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X\right)$ at $p$ is $\mathbb{C}$, so $\operatorname{End}_{C(X)}\left(\mathcal{E}_{X}\right) \cong \operatorname{End}_{C(X)}\left(\Lambda^{0, *} T^{*} X\right) \otimes \operatorname{End}(E)$ at $p$ is $\operatorname{End}(E)$ at $p$. Therefore $j$ is surjective, hence an isomorphism.

Let $K^{*}$ (resp. $K_{X^{\gamma_{X}}}^{*}$ ) denote the dual of the canonical line bundle of $X$ (resp. $\left.X^{\gamma_{X}}\right)$. Let $K_{N}^{*}$ denote the dual of the complex line bundle of the $\left(\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{S}} \mathcal{N}, 0\right)$ forms on (the complexification of) the real normal bundle $\mathcal{N}$ of $X^{\gamma_{X}}$ in $X$ (cf. [32, p.153]). Let $R^{K_{N}^{*}}$ (resp. $R^{K^{*}}, R^{K_{X^{\gamma_{X}}}^{*}}$ ) denote the curvature operator of $K_{N}^{*}$ (resp. $\left.K^{*}, K_{X^{\gamma_{X}}}^{*}\right)$. In view of Lemma 8.27 we define a twisting complex endomorphism $\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}} \in \operatorname{End}_{C(X)}\left(\mathcal{E}_{X}\right)$ by $\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}:=j\left(\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E}}\right)$. Let $F_{0}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}$ (resp. $F_{0}^{E}$ ) denote the restriction

of the curvature $F^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}$ (resp. $F^{E}$ ) to the fixed point submanifold $X^{\gamma_{X}}$ as in (8.36). We then define the $\gamma$-twisted Chern character forms in the sense of [6, pp. 194-195] (In strict conformity with [6, pp.194-195] we will define $c h_{B G V}$ later; see (8.99).):

$$
\begin{aligned}
c h\left(\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}, \mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}\right) & :=\operatorname{Str}_{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}\left(\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}} \exp \left(\frac{i}{2 \pi} F_{0}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}\right)\right) \\
c h\left(\gamma_{X}^{E}, E\right) & :=\operatorname{Str}_{E}\left(\gamma_{X}^{E} \exp \left(\frac{i}{2 \pi} F_{0}^{E}\right)\right), \text { both on } X^{\gamma_{X}}
\end{aligned}
$$

See [6, p.113] for the definition of the relative supertrace $\operatorname{Str}_{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}$ in (8.77).
Lemma 8.28. With the notation above, we have, on $X^{\gamma_{X}}$

$$
\hat{A}\left(X^{\gamma_{X}}\right) c h\left(\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}, \mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}\right)=T d\left(X^{\gamma_{X}}\right) c h\left(\gamma_{X}^{E}, E\right) \exp \left(\frac{\frac{i}{2 \pi} R_{X^{\gamma}}^{K_{X}}}{2}\right)
$$

Proof. From [6, p.152] using the Kähler assumption on $X$ it follows that

$$
F^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}=\frac{1}{2} T r_{T^{1,0} X}\left(R^{+}\right)+F^{E}
$$

where $R^{+}\left(=\left(R_{X}\right)^{+}=R_{X}^{+}\right)$denotes the curvature of the bundle $T^{1,0} X$ (here we have identified $\operatorname{End}(E)$ with $\left.\operatorname{End}_{C(X)}\left(\mathcal{E}_{X}\right)\right)$ through $j$ by Lemma 8.27). Observe that we have, over $X^{\gamma_{X}}$

$$
T r_{T^{1,0} X}\left(R^{+}\right)=R^{K^{*}}=R^{K_{X^{\gamma} X}^{*}}+R^{K_{X}^{*}}
$$

By (8.79) and (8.80) restricted to $X^{\gamma_{X}}$ we obtain

$$
\exp \left(\frac{i}{2 \pi} F_{0}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}\right)=\exp \left(\frac{\frac{i}{2 \pi} R_{X^{\gamma_{X}}}^{K_{X}^{\gamma_{X}}}}{2}\right) \exp \left(\frac{\frac{i}{2 \pi} R_{X^{\gamma}}^{K_{X}^{*}}}{2}\right) \exp \left(\frac{i}{2 \pi} F_{0}^{E}\right)
$$

On the other hand, from comparing (8.76) with (8.75) and applying to $X^{\gamma_{X}}$ it follows that

$$
\hat{A}\left(X^{\gamma_{X}}\right)=T d\left(X^{\gamma_{X}}\right) \exp \left[-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\frac{\frac{i}{2 \pi} R_{X^{\gamma_{X}}}^{+}}{2}\right)\right]
$$

Multiplying (Wedging) (8.82) by (8.81) gives

$$
\hat{A}\left(X^{\gamma_{X}}\right) \exp \left(\frac{i}{2 \pi} F_{0}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}\right)=T d\left(X^{\gamma_{X}}\right) \exp \left(\frac{\frac{i}{2 \pi} R_{X^{\gamma}}^{K_{X}^{*}}}{2}\right) \exp \left(\frac{i}{2 \pi} F_{0}^{E}\right)
$$

Here we have used $\operatorname{Tr} R_{X^{\gamma_{X}}}^{+}=R^{K_{X^{\gamma_{X}}}^{*}}$. Applying $\gamma_{X}^{E}$ (resp. $\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}:=j\left(\gamma_{X}^{E}\right)$ ) to the RHS (resp. LHS) of (8.83) and then taking the supertrace, we obtain (8.78) by [6, (3.10)] and the definition of the relative supertrace in [6, p.113].

The authors Berline, Getzler and Vergne in [6, p.152] define $\hat{A}$-genus form and Todd genus form without the factor $\frac{1}{2 \pi i}$ in (8.75) and (8.76): (we put the subscript "BGV" below)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{A}_{B G V}(X) & :=\operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(\frac{R / 2}{\sinh [R / 2]}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{det}\left(\frac{R^{+} / 2}{\sinh \left[R^{+} / 2\right]}\right) \\
T d_{B G V}(X) & :=\operatorname{det}\left(\frac{R^{+}}{e^{R^{+}}-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The following Corollary will be used in the proof of Proposition 8.33, for which we write the previous lemma with some signs opposite to the ones given in (8.77) and (8.78).
Corollary 8.29. With the notation above, we have, on $X^{\gamma_{X}}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \quad \tilde{A}_{B G V}\left(X^{\gamma_{X}}\right) S t r_{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}\left(\gamma_{X}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}} \exp \left(-F_{0}^{\mathcal{E} / \mathcal{S}}\right)\right) \\
= & T d_{B G V}\left(X^{\gamma_{X}}\right) S t r_{E}\left(\gamma_{X}^{E} \exp \left(-F_{0}^{E}\right)\right) \exp \left(\frac{-R^{K_{N}^{\gamma}}}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We are now ready to return to our situation. Recall that $M:=\Sigma / \sigma$ is equipped with the Hermitian metric $g_{M}$. Henceforth we assume that $g_{M}$ is Kähler. Consider the above $X$ as $V_{j}$ where $V_{j}$ is equipped with $\pi^{*} g_{M} \mid V_{j}$ which we warn is not $G_{a, m} \mid V_{j}$; see the line above (8.37) and Remark 8.22 for the warning. Identify the above $\gamma_{X}$ with $\gamma_{k}$ (see (8.47)) which is an isometry with respect to $\pi^{*} g_{M} \mid V_{j}$ by Corollary 8.5. Let the above $\mathcal{E}$ be $\mathcal{E}^{m}$ over $V_{j}$ with the metric given in Notation 7.12, on which we see that $\gamma_{k}$ acts as an isometry denoted by $\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ (see also (8.86) below. Set $\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{C}} V_{j}=n-1, \operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{R}} V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}=: l_{j, k}$. Let $n_{j, k}:=n-1-l_{j, k} / 2$, half the real dimension of the real normal bundle $\mathcal{N}_{j, k}$ to $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$ (resp. $\Sigma_{j, k}$ ) in $V_{j}$ (resp. $\Sigma$ ). Let $\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}$ denote the complex-linear transformation of $\mathcal{N}_{j, k}$ induced by $\gamma_{k}$; see Notation 8.30 below. Let $v o l_{\mathcal{N}_{j, k}}$ denote the standard section of $\Lambda^{2 n_{j, k}} \mathcal{N}_{j, k}^{*}$ of unit length over $\Sigma_{j, k}([32,(12.8)])$. For notational simplicity we frequently identify $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ with $V_{j}$. We have (cf. Notation 7.12, (8.47))

$$
\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}=\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right)\left\|_{V_{j}}} \otimes \gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{\star}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \mid V_{j}}
$$

where $\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ (resp. $\left.\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right) \mid V_{j}}, \gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{\star}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \mid V_{j}}\right)$ is the complex endomorphism induced by the action of $\gamma_{k}$ on $\mathcal{E}^{m}$ (resp. $\left.\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right) \mid V_{j}, \psi_{j}^{*}\left(E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{\star}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \mid V_{j}$ ). Note that $\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ is induced by $\left(\sigma_{\alpha_{k}}^{*}, \alpha_{k \circ x}\right.$ (7.60), which equals $\left(\sigma_{\alpha_{k}}^{*}, \alpha_{k}\right)_{x}$ if $x \in V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$.
Notation 8.30. The superscript (resp. subscript) " $c$ " is not used by [6], but here we use it to indicate a complex endomorphism. Suppose that $(V, J)$ is a real vector space of even dimension with an almost complex structure $J$. Let $\varphi \in \operatorname{End}(V)$ be a $J$-preserving endomorphism on $V$. Then we use $\varphi^{c}$ or $\varphi_{c}$ to denote the corresponding complex endomorphism on a complex space of complex dimension $\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{R}} V$.

The symbol of $\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}$ in (8.86) which will be used for (8.95) below is understood to be

$$
\sigma_{2 n_{j, k}}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\right)=\sigma_{2 n_{j, k}}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right) \mid V_{j}}\right) \gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{\star}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \mid V_{j}}
$$

cf. [6, top two lines on p.193]. Thus we need to compute the first term in the RHS of (8.87). See Lemma 8.31 below.

To proceed, note that $\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}$ on $\mathcal{N}_{j, k}$ can be diagonalized with eigenvalues $e^{i 2 \theta_{l}}$, where $\theta_{l}$ is the unique angle such that $0<\theta_{l}<\pi$ for $1 \leq l \leq n_{j, k}[32$, (12.5) on p.150] since no eigenvalue here can be 1 . We define the square root of the determinant of $\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}$ as follows [32, the middle of p.154]:

$$
\left(\operatorname{det}\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}\right)^{1 / 2}:=\prod_{l=1}^{n_{j, k}} e^{i \theta_{l}}
$$

Lemma 8.31. With the notation above, we compute the symbol seated in (8.87):

$$
\sigma_{2 n_{j, k}}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right) \mid V_{j}}\right)=2^{-n_{j, k}} \operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}\right)\left(\operatorname{det}\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}\right)^{1 / 2} v o l_{\mathcal{N}_{j, k}}
$$

over $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$. See the last paragraph of the proof for $v o l_{\mathcal{N}_{j, k}}$.
Remark 8.32. The authors of [6] consider general Clifford modules $\mathcal{E}$ rather than the specific $\mathcal{E}_{M}$. As such, they did not go further with the explicit computation as done here. Moreover our $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ is not a Clifford module from the point of view of $\Sigma$ (although $\mathcal{E}_{M}$ is so from that of $M=\Sigma / \sigma$ ); one may think of $\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}$ as a Clifford module of transversal type.

Proof. (of Lemma 8.31) Write $\mathcal{N}_{j, k}$ as $\mathcal{N}$ and decompose $\mathcal{N}^{*} \otimes \mathbb{C}=\mathcal{N}^{* 0,1} \oplus \mathcal{N}^{* 1,0}$. Note that $\left(\gamma_{k}^{-1}\right)^{*} \in U\left(\mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}\right)$ (meaning the action on $\mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}$ induced by $\gamma_{k}$ on $\mathcal{N}$ ), a unitary transformation on $\mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}$, extends naturally to an endomorphism $\gamma_{k}^{\Lambda \mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}}$ of the exterior algebra $\Lambda \mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}$. By [6, p.192, Lemma 6.10] (with our Lemma 8.27 without $E$ ), along $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$ we identify $\left.\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*} \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M} \mid v_{j}}\right|_{\mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}}\left(=\right.$ the preceding $\left.\left(\gamma_{k}^{-1}\right)^{*}\right)$ with a section of $C\left(\mathcal{N}^{*}\right) \otimes \mathbb{C}$ corresponding to $\gamma_{k}^{\Lambda \mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}} \in \operatorname{End}\left(\Lambda \mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}\right)$ via the isomorphism $c: C\left(\mathcal{N}^{*}\right) \otimes \mathbb{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{End}\left(\Lambda \mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}\right)$ ([6, Proposition 3.19] or [32, p.37]), i.e. $\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*} \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M} \mid v_{j}}=c^{-1}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\Lambda \mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}}\right)$ on $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$. Let $e_{l}, J e_{l}, l=1, \cdot, n_{j, k}$ be an orthonormal basis of $\mathcal{N}^{*}$. We claim

$$
\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*} \pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M} \mid v_{j}}=\exp _{\mathbb{C}} \sum_{l=1}^{n_{j, k}} \theta_{l}\left(e_{l} \cdot J e_{l}+i\right) \in C\left(\mathcal{N}^{*}\right) \otimes \mathbb{C}
$$

where $\exp _{\mathbb{C}}$ means the exponential [32, (4.3)]. By [32, p.37] we see that

$$
c\left(e_{l} \cdot J e_{l}+i\right)=2 i e_{e_{l}-i J e_{l}} \circ \iota_{e_{l}}
$$

on the RHS of which $e_{\bullet}$ (resp. $\iota_{\bullet}$ ) means the operators taking exterior (resp. interior) product with $\bullet$. Note that $e_{l}-i J e_{l} \in \mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}$. By acting on $e_{k}-i J e_{k}$ it follows from (8.91) that

$$
c\left(e_{l} \cdot J e_{l}+i\right)\left(e_{k}-i J e_{k}\right)=2 i \delta_{l k}\left(e_{k}-i J e_{k}\right) \text { and hence }
$$

$$
c\left(\exp _{\mathbb{C}} \sum_{a=1}^{n_{j, k}} \theta_{a}\left(e_{a} \cdot J e_{a}+i\right)\right)\left(e_{l}-i J e_{l}\right)=e^{2 \theta_{l} i}\left(e_{l}-i J e_{l}\right)
$$

On the other hand, we can easily show that $\left(\gamma_{k}^{-1}\right)^{*}$ on $\mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}$ is also diagonalized with eigenvalues $e^{i 2 \theta_{l}}$ (when $\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}$ on $\mathcal{N}$ is diagonalized with eigenvalues $e^{i 2 \theta_{l}}$ by our assumption lying above Lemma 8.31). So, by (8.93) the RHS of (8.90) is $\left(\gamma_{k}^{-1}\right)^{*}$. To show that it is $\gamma_{k}^{\Lambda \mathcal{N}^{* 0,1}}$ one computes as in (8.92), (8.93) the action on two-forms, three-forms, etc. This can be done similarly using the action (8.91). The final result gives (8.90); we omit the details (see [?]).

Now by using [32, (4.3) and Subsection 4.3] we obtain

$$
\text { The RHS of }(8.90)=\prod_{l=1}^{n_{j, k}}\left(\cos \theta_{l}+\sin \theta_{l} e_{l} \cdot J e_{l}\right) e^{i \theta_{l}}
$$

Combining (8.90) and (8.94) we can now compute the symbol of $\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right) \mid v_{j}}$ : (After converting $e_{l} \cdot J e_{l}$ in (8.94) into $e_{l} \wedge J e_{l}$ and keeping the top $2 n_{j, k}$-form,)

$$
\sigma_{2 n_{j, k}}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right) \mid v_{j}}\right)=\prod_{l=1}^{n_{j, k}} e^{i \theta_{l}} \sin \theta_{l}\left(\wedge_{l=1}^{n_{j, k}}\left(e_{l} \wedge J e_{l}\right)\right)
$$

From (8.88), [32, the third formula on p.154] ${ }^{11}$ and $\wedge_{l=1}^{n_{j, k}}\left(e_{l} \wedge J e_{l}\right)=: v o l_{\mathcal{N}_{j, k}}$ it is straightforward to see that

$$
\sigma_{2 n_{j, k}}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \mathcal{E}_{M}\right) \mid v_{j}}\right)=\left(\operatorname{det}\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}\right)^{1 / 2} 2^{-n_{j, k}} \operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}\right) v o l_{\mathcal{N}_{j, k}}
$$

We have proved (8.89).
Rewrite $\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}$ of (8.38) as $\mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j}=T_{V_{j}} F_{j, k}$ where in view of (8.47) for $\tilde{g}$,

$$
F_{j, k}:=c_{j, k} I(\tilde{g}) \operatorname{Str}_{\mathcal{E}=/ S}\left[\sigma_{2 n-\left(l_{j, k}+2\right)}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\right) \exp \left(-F_{0}^{\mathcal{E}^{m} / S}\right)\right]
$$

We are going to express $F_{j, k}$ in terms of the Todd and Chern character forms, where we recall (cf. (8.46))

$$
I(\tilde{g})=\frac{\dot{A}_{B G V}\left(T \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} / L_{\Sigma \tilde{g}}, g_{q u o t}\right)}{\operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\tilde{g}_{1}\right) \operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\tilde{g}_{1} \exp \left(-R^{1}\right)\right)}
$$

Using Lemma 8.31 we now come to the main result of this section and prove (8.57) above. Recall the notation $T_{V_{j}}$ in (8.38) but for the sake of clarity we will write $T_{V_{j}} \mid{ }_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}$ instead of $T_{V_{j}}$ to denote the Berezin integral of the bundle $\left.T V_{j}\right|_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}$ (see also the line after (8.106)) and to get a function on $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$. This notation $T_{V_{j}} \mid V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$ is not to be confused with $T_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}}$ below.

Proposition 8.33. With the notation above and $g_{M}$ being Kähler, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{F}_{k, m}^{j} \equiv T_{V_{j}} \mid V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}} F_{j, k}= \\
& T_{V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}} \frac{T d\left(T^{1,0} \Sigma^{\tilde{g}} / L_{\Sigma \tilde{g}}, g_{q u o t}\right) c h\left(\gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*} E \mid v_{j}}, \psi_{j}^{*} E \mid v_{j}\right) c h\left(\psi_{j}^{*}\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m} \mid v_{j}\right)}{\operatorname{det}\left(1-\left(\tilde{g}^{-1}\right)_{1}^{c} \exp \left(-\frac{i}{2 \pi} R_{c}^{1}\right)\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tilde{g}_{1}^{c}$ (resp. $R_{c}^{1}$ ) denotes the complex-linear transformation (resp. complex endomorphism valued curvature form) corresponding to the real transformation $\tilde{g}_{1}$ on $\mathcal{N} \mid V_{j}^{\tilde{g}}$ (resp. real endomorphism valued curvature form $R^{1}$ ). Compare the remark below.

Remark 8.34. For the above $R_{c}^{1}$ note that $R^{1}$ is complex linear ( $J$-linear) with respect to the complex structure $J$ by our Kähler assumption on $V_{j}$ in this subsection. Similarly $\tilde{g}_{1}^{c}$ can be viewed as an $n_{j, k} \times n_{j, k}$ complex matrix, $n_{j, k}=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{R}} \mathcal{N}$.
Proof. (of Proposition 8.33) By (8.87), (8.89) of Lemma 8.31 and noting that $\tilde{g}_{1}=$ $\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}$ along $V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}$ since $\sigma(\tilde{g})=\gamma_{k}$ on $V_{j} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ by (8.47) or (8.19), we obtain

$$
\frac{\sigma_{2 n-\left(l_{j, k}+2\right)}\left(\gamma_{k}^{\mathcal{E}^{m}}\right)}{\operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\tilde{g}_{1}\right)}=2^{-n_{j, k}}\left(\operatorname{det}\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}\right)^{1 / 2} v o l_{\mathcal{N}_{j, k}} \gamma_{k}^{\psi_{j}^{*}\left(E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right) \mid v_{j}}
$$

Substituting (8.98) into (8.95) with $I(\tilde{g})$ in (8.96) and making use of (8.85) with $X=V_{j}$, we get, by setting (compare (8.77) and (8.84) for the subscripts " $B G V$ " below; the difference between them involves multiplicative factors $\frac{i}{2 \pi}$ )

$$
\operatorname{Str}_{E^{\prime}}\left(\gamma_{k}^{E^{\prime}} \exp \left(-F_{0}^{E^{\prime}}\right)\right)=: c h_{B G V}\left(\gamma_{k}^{E^{\prime}}, E^{\prime}\right)
$$

[^0]:    ${ }^{11}$ To avoid possible confusion, we record this formula as follows (in the notation of [32]):

    $$
    \operatorname{det}\left(1-\gamma_{N}\right)^{-1 / 2}=\left(2^{l} \prod_{j=n-l+1}^{n} \sin \theta_{j}\right)^{-1}
    $$

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{j, k}= & c_{j, k} \frac{2^{-n_{j, k}}\left(\operatorname{det}\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}\right)^{1 / 2} v o l_{\mathcal{N}_{c, k}}}{\operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(1-\tilde{g}_{1} \exp \left(-R^{1}\right)\right)} \\
& \cdot T d_{B G V}\left(V_{j}^{\gamma_{k}}\right) c h_{B G V}\left(\gamma_{k}^{E^{\prime}}, E^{\prime}\right) \exp \left(\frac{-R^{K_{N}^{\prime}}}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $E^{\prime}=\left.\psi_{j}^{*}\left(E \otimes\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\right|_{V_{j}}$. Here $n_{j, k}=n-1-l_{j, k} / 2$ as before. The main computation of this proposition is the following:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{det}^{-1 / 2}\left(1-\tilde{g}_{1} \exp \left(-R^{1}\right)\right) i^{-n_{j, k}}\left(\operatorname{det}\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}\right)^{1 / 2} e^{-\frac{1}{2} R^{K_{N}^{\prime}}} \\
= & \left(\operatorname{det}\left(1-\left(\tilde{g}^{-1}\right)_{1}^{c} \exp \left(R_{c, l}^{1}\right)\right)\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Before we proceed, a warning is in order. With the square root $\left(\operatorname{det}\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}\right)^{1 / 2}$ chosen by (8.88), special care should be taken when using the usual rules for further computation or else an unwanted minus sign for (8.101) may occur in the end ${ }^{12}$. To show (8.101) we may assume that both $\left(\tilde{g}^{-1}\right)_{1}^{c}$ and $R_{c}^{1}$ are simultaniously diagonalized with respective eigenvalues $e^{-2 i \theta_{l}}$ (this being consistent with the lines above (8.88) as $\tilde{g}=g_{k}, \gamma_{k}$ here) and $R_{c, l}^{1}$ (which are two-forms) for $1 \leq l \leq n_{j, k}$ (cf. [32, second paragraph on p.167]). Note that $R^{K_{N}^{\prime}}=\operatorname{Tr} R_{c}^{1}=\sum_{l=1}^{n_{j, k}} R_{c, l}^{1}$. Observe that the $l$ th real $2 \times 2$ matrix block of $\exp \left(-R^{1}\right)$ corresponding to $\exp \left(-R_{c, l}^{1}\right)$ reads as (noting that $R_{c, l}^{1}$ is purely imaginary)

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\cos i R_{c, l}^{1} & \sin i R_{c, l}^{1} \\
-\sin i R_{c, l}^{1} & \cos i R_{c, l}^{1}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Using [32, p.154] or Footnote ${ }^{11}$ in the proof of Lemma 8.31, and (8.102) it is not difficult to show that

$$

$$

and that by $(8.88)$

$$
\left(\operatorname{det}\left(\gamma_{k}\right)_{1}^{c}\right)^{1 / 2} e^{-\frac{1}{2} R^{K_{N}^{\prime}}}=\prod_{l=1}^{n_{j, k}} e^{i\left(\theta_{l}+\frac{1}{2} i R_{c, l}^{1}\right)}

Thus by (8.103) and (8.104) to show (8.101) is reduced to verifying

$$
\frac{1}{2 \sin \left(\theta_{l}+\frac{1}{2} i R_{c, l}^{1}\right)} i^{-1} e^{i\left(\theta_{l}+\frac{1}{2} i R_{c, l}^{1}\right)}=\frac{1}{1-e^{-2 i\left(\theta_{l}+\frac{1}{2} i R_{c, l}^{1}\right)}}
$$

for each $l$. Now (8.105) holds true by a direct computation, proving (8.101).

Lemma 8.36. With the notation above (and $V_{j}$ possibly shrinked), there are unique subgroups $H_{l}$ of $H, l=0,1, \cdots, K$, with the properties $i$ ) $H_{0}:=\{1\} \subset H_{1} \subset \cdots$ $\subset H_{K-1} \subset H_{K}:=H$; ii) for $v \in V^{H_{l}} \backslash V^{H_{l+1}} H_{v}=H_{l}\left(V^{H_{K+1}}:=\emptyset\right)$.

$$

We claim that $\Psi$ maps $\left(0, \frac{2 \pi}{N_{j}+1}\right) \times \mathbb{R}^{+} \times\left(V_{j}^{\tilde{g}} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right)$ into $\left|\mathbb{C}^{*} \circ\left(V_{j}^{\tilde{g}} \times\{0\} \times\right.\right.$ $\{1\}) \mid \backslash\left(V_{j}^{\tilde{g}} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}\right)$ and is an embedding. So $e^{i\left(\phi_{1}-\phi_{2}\right)} x_{1}=x_{2}$ and hence $\pi\left(x_{1}\right)=\pi\left(x_{2}\right) \in M=\Sigma / \sigma$ where $\pi: \Sigma \rightarrow M$ is the natural projection. That $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ represent the same orbifold point implies that $h x_{1}=x_{2}$ for some $h \in H=G_{j}$ (via Theorem 2.3). It follows that $e^{i\left(\phi_{2}-\phi_{1}\right)} h x_{1}$ $=x_{1}$ so $e^{i\left(\phi_{2}-\phi_{1}\right)} h \in G_{j}$. Hence we write $e^{i\left(\phi_{2}-\phi_{1}\right)}=g_{0}^{l^{\prime}} \in G_{j}$. But this yields a contradiction since $0 \leq\left|\phi_{1}-\phi_{2}\right|<\frac{2 \pi}{N_{j}+1}=\arg g_{0}$, unless $\phi_{1}-\phi_{2}=0$ which gives $x_{1}=x_{2}$. This implies the embedding part of the claim. Using $\phi_{2}=0$ the similar argument yields the into part of the claim. Moreover $\Psi$ is indeed a diffeomorphism
