Remark 8.40. The definition of the Todd class given in [32, p.163] is basically $\operatorname{det}_{\mathbb{C}}\left(\frac{1}{2 \pi} \Omega /\left(1-e^{-(i / 2 \pi) \Omega}\right)\right)$ which is indeed consistent with the usual definition of the Todd class provided that $\Omega$ is put in the form of curvature (at least for the Kähler case). Unfortunately, Duistermaat points out that the matrix of $R$ (cf. [32, p.54]) is equal to minus the matrix of $\Omega$ [32, p.160], which seems to render his Todd class different from the usual one. Duistermaat's adoption of such an opposite sign convention above is explained by himself in [32, pp. 56-57] where his remarks end up with "This is one of the numerous sources of sign confusion in differential geometry . . .". In spite of his effort for clarification, his Proposition 13.1 [32, p.163], which is based on [32, (11.17)], seems to be confusing in view of the remark above and of the previous Remark 8.35. The similar can be said with his orbifold version of the index theorem [32, Theorem 14.1 on p.184], which is based on his Proposition 13.1 (via his Proposition 13.2). Given these confusions, if Duistermaat's characteristic classes were presumed to be the same as the usual ones (as ours here), then his written form of the orbifold index theorem [32, Theorem 14.1] would agree with that of ours as shown in our proof above.

Remark 8.41. For a slight simplification, recalling that by (8.116) it is going to be summing over $\tilde{F}^{\prime} s$ with each $\tilde{F}$ associated with $\tilde{g}=g_{0}^{k}, k=1, \cdots, N$, one can first group those $\tilde{g}^{\prime} s$ with the same $V^{H_{k+1}}$ (see Lemma 8.37) associated to $H_{0} \subset H_{1} \subset$ $\cdots \subset H_{k+1} \subset \cdots \subset H$ in the OTS (see the proof of Lemma 8.36) and then group this summation over "types $V^{H_{k+1}} / H$ " (with integrands still $\tilde{g}$-dependent).

Remark 8.42. ( $m>0$ case) In the previous and present subsections, the comparison between the formula of Duistermaat and that of ours is most naturally set up and made when $m=0$. If $m>0$ (without the extra bundle $E \rightarrow \Sigma$ as before), our formula (1.6) involves extra factors $\tilde{g}^{m}$ (for integrals over $\Sigma^{\tilde{g}}$ ). Using Remark 10.10 this $m$-index on $\Sigma$ can be converted to a natural index problem with the additional (orbifold) line bundle $\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ (let us call this 0 -index for short) on the orbifold $M$; compare Example 8.25. After reaching such a reduction, one can alternatively use Duistermaat's formula for this 0 -index computation. By similar computations as in this subsection (for $m=0$ above), it turns out that the relevant term $\lambda_{\tilde{L}} c h(\tilde{L})$ in [32, (14.4) on p.184] due to the extra bundle $\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ (i.e. $L$ of [32] is $\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ viewed as an orbifold line bundle on $M$ via descent from $\Sigma$ ) produces the contribution similar to that of the term $\tilde{g}^{m} c h\left(\psi_{j}^{*}\left(L_{\Sigma}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m} \mid V_{j}\right)$ in our formula (1.6) where we have (8.57) inserted; here the agreement between $\tilde{g}^{m}$ and $\lambda_{\tilde{L}}$ is from (3.2) and [32, the second paragraph of Section 14.5]. At this point the two formulas yield the same answer.

# 9. Nonextendability of open group action; meromorphic action 

Let $M$ be a complex manifold (not necessarily compact) with a holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma_{M}$. That is, the map $\sigma_{M}: \mathbb{C}^{*} \times M \rightarrow M$ denoted as $\sigma_{M}(\lambda, x)$ (also

as $\sigma_{M}(\lambda) \circ x$ or $\lambda \circ x$ ) is holomorphic and satisfies the group action condition: $\sigma_{M}\left(\lambda_{1} \lambda_{2}\right) \circ x=\sigma_{M}\left(\lambda_{1}\right) \circ\left(\sigma_{M}\left(\lambda_{2}\right) \circ x\right), \sigma_{M}(1) \circ x=x$. Note that no other condition such as freeness or local freeness is assumed on $\sigma_{M}$.

We say that $\sigma_{M}$ extends holomorphically to 0 (resp. $\infty$ ) provided that there exists a holomorphic map $\tilde{\sigma}_{M}: \mathbb{C} \times M \rightarrow M$ (resp. $\tilde{\sigma}_{M}:\left(\mathbb{C P}^{1} \backslash\{0\}\right) \times M \rightarrow M$ ) such that $\tilde{\sigma}_{M}$ equals $\sigma_{M}$ on $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times M$. Both conditions hold if and only if the holomorphic action $\sigma_{M}$ extends to a holomorphic action $\tilde{\sigma}_{M}$ on $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ :

$$
\tilde{\sigma}_{M}: \mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M \rightarrow M
$$

We say that $\sigma_{M}$ is trivial if $\sigma_{M}(\xi, x)=x$ for all $\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}, x \in M$.
We are going to show that the two-sided extension is impossible (even in the $C^{0}$ category; see Proposition 9.2) unless the original action is trivial. The above action and extension conditions can obviously be defined in the $C^{\infty}$ or $C^{0}$ category.

Proposition 9.1. Suppose that $M$ is a manifold with a smooth $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma_{M}$. Then it is impossible to extend $\sigma_{M}$ to a smooth map $\tilde{\sigma}_{M}$ of (9.1) unless the action $\sigma_{M}$ is trivial.

Let us examine the simplest case: the topological group $G:=\mathbb{R}^{+}$. Let $M$ be a topological space with a continuous $G$-action. Recall that a compactification of a topological Hausdorff space $X$ is a pair $(\bar{X}, h)$ consisting of a compact Hausdorff space $\bar{X}$ and a homeomorphism $h$ of $X$ onto a dense subset of $\bar{X}$ (see [31, p.242]). We often view $X$ as a subspace of $\bar{X}$ by identifying $X$ with $h(X) \subset \bar{X}$.

Proposition 9.2. Suppose that the topological group $G$ is $\mathbb{R}^{+}$and that $M$ is a topological space with a continuous $G$-action $\phi$. Let $\bar{G}$ be any compactification of $G$ in the sense above ( $\bar{G}$ need not be a topological group), such that $\bar{G} \backslash G$ is a countable set. Then $\phi$ as a map cannot be extended continuously to $\bar{G}$. That is to say, there does not exist a continuous map

$$
\tilde{\phi}: \bar{G} \times M \rightarrow M
$$

such that $\tilde{\phi}=\phi$ on $G \times M$ unless the action $\phi$ is trivial.
Remark 9.3. One can use $\sin \left(\frac{1}{x}\right)$-like graphs to easily construct examples $\overline{\mathbb{R}^{+}}$such that both cases where $\overline{\mathbb{R}^{+}} \backslash \mathbb{R}^{+}$is countable or is uncountable can occur.

Proof. (of Proposition 9.2) Take a sequence $\lambda_{n} \in G=\mathbb{R}^{+}$such that

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \lambda_{n}=a \in \bar{G} \backslash G \text { and } \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \lambda_{n}^{-1}=b \in \bar{G} \backslash G
$$

by compactness of $\bar{G}$. For any $\mu \in(1-\delta, 1)$ with small $\delta>0$, there exists a subsequence $\lambda_{n(\mu)}$ of $\lambda_{n}$ such that

$$
\lim _{n(\mu) \rightarrow \infty} \mu \lambda_{n(\mu)}=\alpha(\mu) \in \bar{G} \backslash G
$$

Since $\bar{G} \backslash G$ is countable by assumption, the map $\alpha:(1-\delta, 1) \rightarrow \bar{G} \backslash G$ in (9.3) cannot be injective. There exist $\mu_{1}, \mu_{2} \in(1-\delta, 1)$ such that $\alpha\left(\mu_{2}\right)=\alpha\left(\mu_{1}\right), \mu_{2}<$ $\mu_{1}$. For $x \in M$ we consider

$$
\mu_{1} \circ x=\left(\mu_{1} \lambda_{n\left(\mu_{1}\right)}\right) \circ\left(\lambda_{n\left(\mu_{1}\right)}^{-1} \circ x\right)
$$

where we denote $\phi(g, x)$ by $g \circ x$.
Assuming the extension $\tilde{\phi}$ (or $\tilde{\circ}$ for convenience) exists, we are going to prove that the action $\phi$ is trivial. Taking the limit $n\left(\mu_{1}\right) \rightarrow \infty$ in (9.4) we get, via (9.2)

and $(9.3), \mu_{1} \circ x=\alpha\left(\mu_{1}\right) \widehat{=}(b \widehat{=} x)$. Similarly we have $\mu_{2} \circ x=\alpha\left(\mu_{2}\right) \widehat{=}(b \widehat{=} x)$. We obtain $\mu_{1} \circ x=\mu_{2} \circ x$ since $\alpha\left(\mu_{2}\right)=\alpha\left(\mu_{1}\right)$ by assumption. It follows that

$$
\left(\mu_{1}^{-1} \mu_{2}\right) \circ x=x
$$

Since given any small $\varepsilon>0$ there exists a $\delta>0$ such that $\mu_{1}^{-1} \mu_{2} \in(1-\varepsilon, 1)$ if $\mu_{2}, \mu_{1} \in(1-\delta, 1)$ and $\mu_{2}<\mu_{1}\left(\alpha\left(\mu_{2}\right)=\alpha\left(\mu_{1}\right)\right)$, it follows from (9.5) that $\{1\}$ cannot be a connected component of the closed isotropy subgroup $G_{0}:=\{g \in G \mid$ $g \circ x=x\}$, which is a Lie subgroup of $G$ by [45, Ch.II, Theorem 2.3] (or Remark in the end of its proof). This implies that $\operatorname{dim} G_{0} \geq 1$ and hence $G_{0}=G$ since $\operatorname{dim} G$ $=1$. We have shown that the isotropy subgroup of any $x \in M$ is $G$; this amounts to the triviality of the action $\phi$.

Proof. (of Proposition 9.1) Clearly this proposition follows immediately from Proposition 9.2.

We say that the holomorphic action $\sigma_{M}$ extends pointwise holomorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$ if for any point $p \in M$, there is a holomorphic map $\varphi: \mathbb{C P}^{1} \times\{p\} \rightarrow M$ such that

$$
\varphi(\lambda, p)=\sigma_{M}(\lambda, p)
$$

for $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$.
By Proposition 9.2 there is even no continuous extension of a nontrivial holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M \rightarrow M$. However, the meromorphic extension does possibly exist. We say that $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M$ if $\sigma_{M}$ extends to a meromorphic map $\bar{\sigma}_{M}: \mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M-\cdot->M$ (in the sense of Remmert [39]). Note that the singular set of a meromorphic map is of complex codimension $\geq 2$ ([39]). See Remark 9.6 below for examples of meromorphic extension.

In the remaining of this section we mainly assume that the meromorphic extension exists. Let $\Omega_{M}^{\mathrm{p}}$ on $M$ denote the holomorphic vector bundle of holomorphic $p$-forms. $\sigma_{M}$ induces a holomorphic action on $\Omega^{p}$ by pulling back. Let $H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{\mathrm{p}}\right)$ denote the space of all global holomorphic $p$-forms.

Notation 9.4. Let $H_{k}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{\mathrm{p}}\right)$ or $H_{k, \sigma_{M}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{\mathrm{p}}\right)$ denote the space of all global holomorphic $p$-forms $\omega$ such that $\sigma_{M}(\lambda)^{*}(\omega)=\lambda^{k} \omega, \lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ where $\sigma_{M}(\lambda): M \rightarrow M$ is given by

$$
\sigma_{M}(\lambda)(p):=\sigma_{M}(\lambda, p)
$$

Here there is no need to talk about any regularity condition as in Definition 2.8.
Proposition 9.5. . With the notation as above, suppose that $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M$. Then we have

$$
H_{k}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{\mathrm{p}}\right)=\{0\} \text { for } k \neq 0 ; H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{\mathrm{p}}\right)=H_{0}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{\mathrm{p}}\right)\left(=H_{0, \sigma_{M}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{\mathrm{p}}\right)\right)
$$

Proof. Let $\omega \in H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{\mathrm{p}}\right)$. Since $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically, its pullback $\sigma_{M}^{*} \omega$ on $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times M$ (may contain the factor $d \lambda$ ) extends to a holomorphic $p$-form on $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times$ $M$ by Hartogs' theorem (e.g. [39, p.81]). In particular, the parameter $\lambda$ in the

holomorphic $p$-form $\sigma_{M}(\lambda)^{*} \omega$ on $M$ (see (9.6)) extends holomorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$. One is thus allowed to expand $\sigma_{M}\left(\lambda^{-1}\right)^{*} \omega$ near $\lambda=0$ to get

$$
\sigma_{M}\left(\lambda^{-1}\right)^{*} \omega=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \lambda^{k} \omega_{k}
$$

where $\omega_{k} \in H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$ does not depend on $\lambda$. Then, combining

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \lambda^{k} \zeta^{k} \omega_{k} & =\sigma_{M}\left((\lambda \zeta)^{-1}\right)^{*} \omega \stackrel{(9.8)}{=} \sigma_{M}\left(\zeta^{-1}\right)^{*}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \lambda^{k} \omega_{k}\right) \\
& =\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \lambda^{k}\left(\sigma_{M}\left(\zeta^{-1}\right)^{*} \omega_{k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with (9.8), we have

$$
\sigma_{M}\left(\zeta^{-1}\right)^{*} \omega_{k}=\zeta^{k} \omega_{k}
$$

i.e., $\omega_{k} \in H^{0}{ }_{+}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$. For $k>0$, the LHS of (9.9) is finite as $\zeta \rightarrow \infty$ and the RHS goes to infinity (unless $\omega_{k}=0$ ). We conclude that $\sigma_{M}\left(\lambda^{-1}\right)^{*} \omega=\omega_{0}$ in (9.8). This yields that $\omega$ is $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant. Now that $\omega \in H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$ is arbitrarily chosen, we are led to (9.7).

Remark 9.6. (Examples for the meromorphic extension) The assumption that $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M$ in Proposition 9.5 holds for any compact Kähler manifold $M$ with $\sigma_{M}$ having a fixed point (on $M$ ). For, by [76, Proposition II] $\mathbb{C}^{*}$ (through $\sigma_{M}$ ) acts projectively on $M$. By [76, Lemma II-B] for $Y=X=M$, $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically to $\hat{\sigma}_{M}: \mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M-\cdot->M$. Another natural class of examples consists of $M$ that is algebraic and $\sigma_{M}$ that is an algebraic action. Then $\sigma_{M}$ automatically extends to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M$ meromorphically. See, e.g., [9, p.777] and Remark 9.15 below.

Proposition 9.5 has an application to the study of $S^{1}$-action on a complex manifold $M$ via biholomorphisms. Denote such an action by $\sigma_{M}^{S^{1}}: S^{1} \times M \rightarrow M$. Assume that we can pass $\sigma_{M}^{S^{1}}$ to a holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma_{M}^{\mathbb{C}^{*}}: \mathbb{C}^{*} \times M \rightarrow M$. This $\mathbb{C}^{*}$ extension follows automatically if $M$ is compact (cf. [14, p. 50]). For an integer $k$, we define $H_{k, \sigma_{M}^{S^{1}}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$ to be the space of all holomorphic $p$-forms $\omega$ such that $\sigma_{M}^{S^{1}}\left(e^{i \vartheta}\right)^{*} \omega=e^{i k \vartheta} \omega$. By Remark 9.6, if $M$ is algebraic with an algebraic action $\sigma_{M}^{\mathbb{C}^{*}}$, then $\sigma_{M}^{\mathbb{C}^{*}}$ admits a meromorphic extension on $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M$.

The following result might be known to the experts, but we are unable to find a precise reference.

Corollary 9.7. With the notation above, suppose that $\sigma_{M}^{\mathbb{C}^{*}}$ extends meromorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M$. Then we have

$$
H_{k, \sigma_{M}^{S^{1}}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)=0 \text { for } k \neq 0 ; H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)=H_{0, \sigma_{M}^{S^{1}}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)
$$

Proof. Observe that $H_{k, \sigma_{M}^{S^{1}}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right) \subset H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)=H_{0, \sigma_{M}^{S^{1}}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right) \subset H_{0, \sigma_{M}^{S^{1}}}^{0}(M$, $\left.\Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$ by Proposition 9.5, and hence (9.10).

As another application of Proposition 9.5, we now want to relate Proposition 9.5 to [14, Corollary IV]. The main result is Proposition 9.10 below.

Some preparations are in order. Denote $\sigma_{M}(\lambda) \circ x$ by $\lambda \circ x$. Suppose that $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically to $\hat{\sigma}_{M}: \mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M-\ldots>M$. Then $\sigma_{M}$ extends pointwise holomorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1}$, i.e. (in particular) $\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \lambda \circ x$ exists for any fixed $x \in M$ (cf. [27, Lemma 2.4.1]). Moreover, the singular set of the meromorphic extension $\hat{\sigma}_{M}$ is contained in $\left(\{0\} \times S_{0}\right) \cup\left(\{\infty\} \times S_{\infty}\right)$ for some subvarieties $S_{0}, S_{\infty}$ of codimension $\geq 1$ in $M$. Observe that

$$
\sigma_{M, 0}:=\hat{\sigma}_{M}(0, \cdot): M \backslash S_{0} \rightarrow M
$$

is meromorphic on $M$ since $\{0\} \times M \nsubseteq\{0\} \times S_{0}$ (cf. [77, pp.35-36]). So $\sigma_{M, 0}$ is actually defined and holomorphic on $M \backslash T$ where $T \subset S_{0}$ is of codimension at least 2 in $M$. Denote this extension by $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}: M \backslash T \rightarrow M$. Note that $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}=\sigma_{M, 0}$ on $M \backslash S_{0}$, but $\sigma_{M, 0}$ is not defined on $S_{0} \backslash T$ where $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}$ is defined.

We define $F^{0}:=\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}(M \backslash T)$ and $G^{0}:=\sigma_{M, 0}\left(M \backslash S_{0}\right)$. Obviously $G^{0} \subset F^{0}$. Let $F^{\sigma_{M}}$ be the fixed point set of $\sigma_{M}$ on $M$, i.e. $\left\{x \in M \mid \sigma_{M}(\lambda) x=x, \forall \lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}\right\}$. $G^{0}$ equals $\left\{\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \lambda \circ x: x \in M \backslash S_{0}\right\}$ (while the same statement for $F^{0}$ via $M \backslash T$ may not hold, a priori) which is contained in $F^{\sigma_{M}}$. Observe that $F^{0}$ (resp. $G^{0}$ ) is connected since $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}$ (resp. $\sigma_{M, 0}$ ) is continuous on the connected space $M \backslash T$ (resp. $M \backslash S_{0}$ ).
Lemma 9.8. With the notation above, it holds that (a) $G^{0}$ is a complex submanifold in $M$; (b) $G^{0} \subset M \backslash S_{0}$; (c) $G^{0}=F^{0}$; (d) $G^{0}$ is closed in $M$.

The proof of Lemma 9.8 is postponed below.
Define

$$
\pi: M \backslash T \rightarrow F^{0} \text { by } \pi(x):=\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}(x)
$$

Note that for $x \in M \backslash S_{0}, \pi(x)=\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \lambda \circ x$. We can extend $\pi$ to $M$ by $\pi(x)$ $:=\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \lambda \circ x \in F^{\sigma_{M}} \subset M$ (cf. the pointwise holomorphic extension as mentioned earlier). Note that $\pi$ in (9.11) is holomorphic on $M \backslash T \subset M$ (since $\left.\pi\right|_{M \backslash T}$ $=\left.\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}\right|_{M \backslash T}$ ), yet $\pi$ on $M$ could be discontinuous across $T$. We call $\pi$ on $M$ a canonical extension of $\sigma_{M, 0}$ and $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}$.
Lemma 9.9. Let $\sigma_{M}$ be a holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on a complex manifold $M$ (not necessarily compact). Suppose $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M-\ldots>M$. Then there is a linear isomorphism:

$$
\pi^{*}: H^{0}\left(F^{0}, \Omega_{F^{0}}^{p}\right) \rightarrow H_{0}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)
$$

where $\pi^{*}$ is essentially defined via the "pullback" of the canonical map $\pi$ of (9.11).
Proof. For $\omega \in H^{0}\left(F^{0}, \Omega_{F^{0}}^{p}\right)$ (which makes sense by Lemma 9.8 (a), (c)), we can now define $\pi^{*} \omega$ of (9.12) to be $\pi^{*} \omega:=\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}^{*} \omega \in H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$ by Hartogs' extension theorem since $T$ is of codimension at least 2 in $M$. From $\pi=\pi \circ(\sigma(\lambda))$ on $M \backslash S_{0}$, it follows that $\pi^{*} \omega=\sigma(\lambda)^{*}\left(\pi^{*} \omega\right)$ on a dense open subset $U_{\lambda}$ (depending on $\lambda$ ) of $M$ (since $\pi$ could be discontinuous), giving that $\pi^{*} \omega$ is $\sigma(\lambda)$-invariant on $U_{\lambda}$ hence on $M\left(\pi^{*} \omega\right.$ being globally holomorphic as just defined) i.e. $\pi^{*} \omega \in H_{0}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$. The map $\pi^{*}$ of (9.12) is now well defined.

Suppose $\pi^{*} \omega=0$ on $M$. By $\iota_{G^{0}}: G^{0} \hookrightarrow M$ and $M \backslash S_{0} \xrightarrow{\pi} G^{0}$ and $\left.\pi\right|_{G^{0}}=I d$, one has $\left.\pi\right|_{M \backslash S_{0}} \circ \iota_{G^{0}}=I d$ on $G^{0}$ (note that $G^{0} \subset M \backslash S_{0}$ by Lemma 9.8 (b)). So (recalling that $\omega$ is on $\left.F^{0} \supset G^{0}\right) \omega\left.\right|_{G^{0}}=\iota_{G^{0}}^{*} \pi\left.\right|_{M \backslash S_{0}}^{*} \omega\left.\right|_{G^{0}}=\iota_{G^{0}}^{*}\left(\left.\pi^{*} \omega\right)\right|_{M \backslash S_{0}}=0$ if

$\pi^{*} \omega=0$, giving $\omega=0$ on $G^{0}$. Hence $\omega=0$ on $F^{0}\left(=G^{0}\right.$ by Lemma 9.8 (c)). That is, $\pi^{*}$ of (9.12) is injective.

For the surjectivity of $\pi^{*}$ let $\hat{\pi}: M \backslash S_{0} \rightarrow G^{0}$ be the restriction of $\pi$ to $M \backslash S_{0}$ $\subset M \backslash T$ (namely $\hat{\pi}=\sigma_{M, 0}$ ). At a regular point $(\lambda, x) \in \mathbb{C P}^{1} \times\left(M \backslash S_{0}\right)$, for $v$ $\in T_{x} M$ one has $\hat{\pi}_{*} v=\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \sigma(\lambda)_{*} v \in T_{\hat{\pi}(x)} G^{0}$ (which might not hold for $\hat{\pi}, S$ and $G^{0}$ replaced by $\pi, T$ and $F^{0}$ respectively). Now given $\eta \in H_{0}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$, that is $\sigma(\lambda)^{*} \eta=\eta\left(\forall \lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}\right)$, this invariance yields at $x \in M \backslash S_{0}$ with $v_{1}, . ., v_{p} \in T_{x}\left(M \backslash S_{0}\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\eta_{x}\left(v_{1}, . ., v_{p}\right) & =\eta_{\lambda \circ x}\left(\sigma(\lambda)_{*} v_{1}, \cdot \cdot, \sigma(\lambda)_{*} v_{p}\right) \\
& =\eta_{\hat{\pi}(x)}\left(\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \sigma(\lambda)_{*} v_{1}, \cdot \cdot, \lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \sigma(\lambda)_{*} v_{p}\right) \\
& =\eta_{\hat{\pi}(x)}\left(\hat{\pi}_{*} v_{1}, \cdot \cdot, \hat{\pi}_{*} v_{p}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The equality of (9.13) amounts to asserting that $\hat{\pi}^{*}\left(\iota_{G^{0}}^{*} \eta\right)=\eta$ on $M \backslash S_{0}$. In view that $M \backslash S_{0}$ is dense (and open) and $\hat{\pi}^{*}\left(\iota_{G^{0}}^{*} \eta\right)$ (and $\eta$ ) is actually holomorphic on the whole $M$ (by $\pi^{*}$ of (9.12)), it follows that $\hat{\pi}^{*}\left(\iota_{G^{0}}^{*} \eta\right)=\eta$ holds on $M$, giving in turn that $\pi^{*}\left(\iota_{F^{0}}^{*} \eta\right)=\eta$ on $M \backslash S_{0}$ thus on $M$ (or, using $G^{0}=F^{0}$ in Lemma 9.8 (c)). This amounts to yielding $\eta \in \operatorname{Im} \pi^{*}$. We have shown that $\pi^{*}$ of (9.12) is surjective hence in turn, an isomorphism.

By Proposition 9.5 and Lemma 9.9, we immediately obtain
Proposition 9.10. (cf. [14, Corollary IV] for $M$ compact Kähler) Let $\sigma_{M}$ be a holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on a complex manifold $M$ which can be noncompact. Suppose that $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M--->M$. Then we have a natural linear isomorphism:

$$
H^{0}\left(F^{0}, \Omega_{F^{0}}^{p}\right) \simeq H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)
$$

Let us compare Proposition 9.10 with [14, Proposition II] where $M$ is assumed to be a connected compact Kähler manifold and $\sigma_{M}$ has at least one fixed point. In our notation above, if $M$ is compact, the closure $\overline{F^{0}}$ in the usual complex topology is known to be a complex subvariety of $M$ by standard argument (or, one may see this via (c), (d) of Lemma 9.8). Note that $\overline{F^{0}}$, contained in $F^{\sigma_{M}}$ (fixed point set), is connected. In such a special situation $\overline{F^{0}}$ is equal/reduced to the source, denoted by $F_{1}$, as is introduced in [14, Proposition II, pp.55-56]; compare the proof of Lemma 9.8 (d) below.

Our result and proof above differ from those of [14, Corollary IV] in that in [14] the complex manifold $M$ is assumed to be compact and its proof relies on the so-called invariant decomposition of $M$ (associated with the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action), which was originally discovered by A. Bialynicki-Birula in the algebraic setting (cf. [7]). The comparison mentioned above is established by the following:
Lemma 9.11. Let $M, \sigma_{M}$ be as in Proposition 9.10 (so $M$ can be noncompact). Assume that $\overline{F^{0}}$ is an analytic subvariety of $M$. We have $H^{0}\left(F^{0}, \Omega_{F^{0}}^{p}\right)=H^{0}\left(\overline{F^{0}}, \Omega_{F^{0}}^{p}\right)$. Here, with $\overline{F^{0}}$ being possibly singular $\Omega_{\overline{F^{0}}}^{p}$ is defined in the sense of algebraic geometry (cf. [44, Chap.II, Section 8]). In particular, for $M$ compact we obtain, together with Proposition 9.10, $H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right) \cong H^{0}\left(F_{1}, \Omega_{F_{1}}^{p}\right)$ by $\overline{F^{0}}=F_{1}$, as originally stated in $[14]$.
Remark 9.12. In fact $F^{0}=\overline{F^{0}}$ as can be seen in the proof of Lemma 9.8 below (for (c) that $G^{0}=F^{0}$, whose argument applies here similarly).

Proof. (of Lemma 9.11) The natural map $H^{0}\left(\overline{F^{0}}, \Omega_{\overline{F^{0}}}^{p}\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(F^{0}, \Omega_{F^{0}}^{p}\right)$ (induced by $F^{0} \hookrightarrow \overline{F^{0}}$ ) is injective, so it suffices to show that every $\omega \in H^{0}\left(F^{0}, \Omega_{F^{0}}^{p}\right)$ on $F^{0}$ can be extended to $\overline{F^{0}}$ (hence the map is also surjective). This is in general not possible unless $\overline{F^{0}} \backslash F^{0}$ is of codimension $\geq 2$ in $\overline{F^{0}}$. We are not going to need such a codimension condition (cf. Remark 9.12). Instead, making use of Proposition 9.10 and its proof we have that $\omega$ must be of the form $\iota_{F^{0}}^{*} \eta\left(\iota_{F^{0}}: F^{0} \hookrightarrow M\right)$ for a unique $\eta \in H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$. It is now seen that $\iota_{\overline{F^{0}}}^{*} \eta\left(\iota_{\overline{F^{0}}}: \overline{F^{0}} \hookrightarrow M\right) \in H^{0}\left(\overline{F^{0}}, \Omega_{\overline{F^{0}}}^{p}\right)$ is the desired extension of $\omega$.

Proof. (of Lemma 9.8) Compared to the proofs above, the proof below is less conceptual as it mostly relies on use of local coordinates. Recall $G^{0} \subset$ the fixed point set $F^{\sigma_{M}}$ of $\sigma_{M}$. Near any fixed point $q$ there exists a chart $U$ of local holomorphic coordinates $\left(w_{1}, \cdots, w_{n}\right)$ such that if $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$, then ([14, p.56], however, see Remark 9.13 below)

$$
\sigma_{M}(\lambda)\left(w_{1}, \cdots, w_{n}\right)=\left(\lambda^{k_{1}} w_{1}, \cdots, \lambda^{k_{s}} w_{s}, w_{s+1}, \cdots, w_{t}, \lambda^{l_{t+1}} w_{t+1}, \cdots, \lambda^{l_{n}} w_{n}\right)
$$

for integers $k_{j}>0, l_{j}<0$ ( $s$ may be 0 and $t$ may be $n$ ) with $\left(w_{1}, \cdots, w_{n}\right)(q)=(0$, $\cdots, 0)$.

Given $q \in G^{0}$, there is a point $\tilde{q} \in M \backslash S_{0}$ such that $\sigma_{M, 0}(\tilde{q})=q$. By $\sigma_{M, 0}(\tilde{q})$ $=\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \lambda \tilde{q}$ we assume that for some $0 \neq \lambda_{0} \sim 0, \lambda_{0} \tilde{q}$ lies in a local chart where (9.14) is valid. Without loss of generality we may assume $\lambda_{0} \tilde{q} \notin S_{0}$ using $\tilde{q} \notin$ $S_{0}$ and analyticity. Moreover $\lambda_{0} \tilde{q}$ has coordinates $\left(w_{1}^{0}, \cdots, w_{t}^{0}, 0, \cdots, 0\right)$, proved by contradiction using the negative power $l_{j}<0$ (compare Remark 9.13 below), and similarly $w_{s+1}^{0}=\cdots=w_{t}^{0}=0$ by $\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \lambda\left(\lambda_{0} \tilde{q}\right)=q=(0,0, \cdots, 0)$ and (9.14). Take an open connected neighborhood $\tilde{V} \subset M \backslash S_{0}$ of $\tilde{q}$. Then $\sigma\left(\lambda_{0}\right) \tilde{V}\left(\sigma\left(\lambda_{0}\right)\right.$ is a biholomorphism of $M$ ) is an open connected neighborhood of $\lambda_{0} \tilde{q}$ in $M \backslash S_{0}$ (if $\tilde{V}$ small enough), hence contains $V \times\left\{0_{n-t}\right\}$ where $V$ is an open neighborhood of $\left(w_{1}^{0}\right.$, $\left.\cdots, w_{t}^{0}\right)$ in $\mathbb{C}^{t}$ and $0_{m}$ denotes the origin in $\mathbb{C}^{m}$. Then it follows from (9.14) using $\lambda \rightarrow 0$ that $\sigma_{M, 0}\left(\tilde{V} \cap\left\{w_{t+1}=w_{t+2}=\cdots=w_{n}=0\right\}\right) \subset \sigma_{M, 0}(\tilde{V}) \subset G^{0}$ covers an open neighborhood of $q$ in $\left\{0_{s}\right\} \times \mathbb{C}^{t-s} \times\left\{0_{n-t}\right\}$. Conversely only points in the local chart having coordinates $\left(0_{s}, w_{s+1}, \cdots, w_{t}, 0_{n-t}\right)$ can belong to $G^{0}$. Thus $\left(w_{1}\right.$, $\left.\cdots, w_{n}\right)$ in (9.14) provide a complex submanifold structure of $G^{0}$ in $M$ near $q$. We have proved (a) of the lemma.

Suppose $t<n$ in (9.14) for $q \in G^{0}$. For any $\tilde{q}_{1}$ sufficiently near $\tilde{q}$ with $\tilde{q}_{1}, \lambda_{0} \tilde{q}_{1} \notin$ $S_{0}, \lambda_{0} \tilde{q}_{1}$ has coordinates with vanishing $w_{t+1}, \cdots, w_{n}$ by the similar argument as above, giving that $\sigma\left(\lambda_{0}\right) \tilde{V}$ becomes degenerate, a contradiction to the biholomorphism of $\sigma\left(\lambda_{0}\right)$. Thus

$$
t=n \text { in (9.14) for } q \in G^{0}
$$

Let $\operatorname{Proj}: U \rightarrow G^{0}$ be the coordinate projection via (9.14) for $t=n$, i.e. $\left(w_{1}\right.$, $\left.\cdots, w_{n}\right) \rightarrow\left(0, \cdots, 0, w_{s+1}, \cdots, w_{n}\right)$. Clearly Proj holomorphically extends $\sigma_{M, 0}$ (originally defined on $U \backslash S_{0}$ ) to $U$. Thus $\sigma_{M, 0}$ is regular at $q=(0, \cdots, 0)$ since Proj is so, suggesting that $G^{0} \subset M \backslash S_{0}$. To prove this inclusion rigorously, by considering $\phi:\left(w_{1}, \cdots, w_{n}\right) \rightarrow\left(\lambda^{k_{1}} w_{1}, \cdots, \lambda^{k_{s}} w_{s}, w_{s+1}, \cdots, w_{n}\right)$ one shows in a similar way that $\sigma_{M}$ is regular at $(0, q) \in \mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M$, and hence the claim $G^{0} \subset M \backslash S_{0}$ in (b) of the lemma is proved.

From the definition of the extension $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}$ it is not difficult to see $F^{0} \subset \overline{G^{0}}$ (via $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}=\sigma_{M, 0}$ on $M \backslash S_{0}$ ). Obviously $\overline{G^{0}} \subset F^{\sigma_{M}}$. So given $\bar{q} \in F^{0}$ there is a neighborhood $U$ in $M$, which is contained in a local chart first having the property (9.14) with $\bar{q}$ set to be $q$ there then having $t=n$ in view of $G^{0} \subset F^{0} \subset \overline{G^{0}}$ and (9.15). We claim $G^{0} \cap U=F^{0} \cap U$. The coordinate projection Proj above defined on $U$ also holomorphically extends $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}$ (on $U \backslash T$ ) to $U$ meaning that $U$ is disjoint from the singular set $T$ of $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}$. So $T \cap U=\emptyset$ together with $S_{0} \cap U=\emptyset$ (as shown in the proof of (b) above), implies that $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 0}=\sigma_{M, 0}=$ Proj on $U$. Thus $G^{0} \cap U=$ $F^{0} \cap U\left(=\operatorname{Proj}(U)\right.$ ) hence $G^{0}=F^{0}$ proving (c) of the lemma.

The proof of (c) actually shows that $G^{0}=\overline{G^{0}}$ (compare the preceding sentence) hence (d) of the lemma. Recall the aforementioned $F_{1}$ after Proposition 9.10, which is defined in [14] for $M$ compact. Since $G^{0}$ is of the same complex dimension $t-s$ $(=n-s)$ as that of $F_{1}[14]$ which is connected, for $M$ compact we conclude $G^{0}(=$ $F^{0}=\overline{F^{0}}$ by (c), (d) above $)=F_{1}$ as asserted earlier. In this connection, $F^{0}\left(=\overline{F^{0}}\right)$ in our treatment here can be regarded as a replacement of $F_{1}$ when $M$ is not necessarily compact.

Remark 9.13. Since (9.14) for $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ is claimed without proof in [14], let us assume that $U$ is a small neighborhood of $q=(0,0, \cdots, 0)$, in which case (9.14) only holds for $\lambda \sim 1$. It might happen that a point $p \in U$ with some $w_{k}(p) \neq 0$ $(t+1 \leq k \leq n)$ lying outside $U$ after the action by some $|\lambda|<1$, travels back to $U$ after another action by $|\lambda|<<1$. This would not occur if (9.14) were true for $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ or if $U$ were large. For the remedy here we put $q_{1}=\lambda_{0} \tilde{q} \in U$. The fact $\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \lambda q_{1}=q$ gives that $\lambda q_{1} \in U$ for all $|\lambda| \leq \delta$ for some $\delta>0$. Then we have, by setting $q_{2}=\delta q_{1}, \lambda q_{2} \in U$ for all $|\lambda| \leq 1$. This yields $w_{t+1}\left(q_{2}\right)=\cdots=w_{n}\left(q_{2}\right)$ $=0$ otherwise it follows the contradiction that $\lambda q_{2} \notin U$ for some $|\lambda|<1$ (if $w_{k}\left(q_{2}\right)$ $\neq 0$ for some $t+1 \leq k \leq n$ and $\lambda q_{2} \in U$ for all $|\lambda|<1$ then $U$ cannot be small). Put differently the aforementioned scenario that a point frequently/always comes in and out through $U$ under the actions $|\lambda|<1$ is intuitively seen to get nowhere and therefore violates the foregoing existence of limit. Remark that the above enables us to simply replace $\lambda_{0}$ in the original argument by $\delta \lambda_{0}$. We are now done.

Another generalization of [14] from a quite different perspective is given in the next section.

For a general holomorphic action $\sigma_{M}^{G}$ given by a connected complex reductive Lie group $G$, we can show (below) that (9.7) of Proposition 9.5 still holds, without knowing the detailed $G$-invariant decomposition of $M$ as conjectured in [76, p.115].

To fix the notation for use shortly, let $\mathfrak{g}$ denote a complex simple Lie algebra, $\mathfrak{h}$ a fixed Cartan subalgebra of $\mathfrak{g}$ and $\Delta$ the set of all nonzero roots. In the root space decomposition $\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{h}+\sum_{\alpha \in \Delta} \mathfrak{g}^{\alpha}$ one can choose $\alpha_{j} \in \Delta, j=1, \ldots, l, X_{j} \in \mathfrak{g}^{\alpha_{j}}$ and $Y_{j} \in \mathfrak{g}^{-\alpha_{j}}$ such that

$$
\left[X_{j}, Y_{j}\right]=H_{j} \in \mathfrak{h},\left[H_{j}, X_{j}\right]=2 X_{j},\left[H_{j}, Y_{j}\right]=-2 Y_{j}
$$

and that $\mathfrak{g}$ is generated by $X_{j}, Y_{j}, H_{j}, 1 \leq j \leq l$ (cf. [45, p.482]). Also $X_{j}, Y_{j}, H_{j}$ form a canonical basis for the Lie algebra $s l(2, \mathbb{C})$. The following is basic:
Lemma 9.14. Let $T=\left\{\left(\begin{array}{cc}\lambda & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda^{-1}\end{array}\right) \mid \lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}\right\} \subset H=S L(2, \mathbb{C})$. Then the set $\bigcup_{h \in H} \operatorname{Ad}(h) T$ is dense in $S L(2, \mathbb{C})$.

We are now ready to prove Theorem 1.6 stated in the Introduction.

Proof. (of Theorem 1.6) Let us first assume that $G$ is semisimple. Associated to the Lie subalgebra $\mathfrak{g}_{j} \cong s l(2, \mathbb{C})$ spanned by $X_{j}, Y_{j}, H_{j}$ of (9.16), we have exactly one connected Lie subgroup $G_{j}$ of $G$ with its Lie algebra equal to $\mathfrak{g}_{j}$ (cf. [45, p.112]). Let $\pi_{j}: S L(2, \mathbb{C}) \rightarrow G_{j}(\subset G)$ be the covering map (since $S L(2, \mathbb{C})$ is simply connected). We have a Lie group homomorphism $\psi: \lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*} \rightarrow G$ defined by

$$
\psi: \lambda \longrightarrow\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\lambda & 0 \\
0 & \lambda^{-1}
\end{array}\right) \xrightarrow{\pi_{j}} G_{j} \xrightarrow{\text { incl }} G
$$

With the projective compactification $\bar{G}$ of $G$ (cf. Remark 9.15 below) and all the maps being natural, we conclude that $\phi: S L(2, \mathbb{C}) \rightarrow \bar{G}$ defined by the composition of $\pi_{j}$ and the inclusion map "incl" extends meromorphically to $\overline{S L(2, \mathbb{C})}$. Composed with the map $\lambda \rightarrow\left(\begin{array}{cc}\lambda & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda^{-1}\end{array}\right)$, we obtain that $\psi$ extends meromorphically (holomorphically in fact) to $\bar{\psi}: \mathbb{C P}^{1}=\overline{\mathbb{C}^{*}} \rightarrow \rightarrow \bar{G}$ (cf. [76, Lemma II-C]). It implies that the holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on $M$ via $\bar{\psi}$ extends to a meromorphic map as the following composite:

$$
\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M \xrightarrow{\bar{\psi} \times i d} \bar{G} \times M \xrightarrow{\bar{\sigma}_{M}^{G}} M
$$

Here we have used the facts that $\bar{\sigma}_{M}^{G}$ is meromorphic as assumed in the theorem and that the image of $\bar{\psi} \times i d$ is not contained in the singular set of $\bar{\sigma}_{M}^{G}$ (cf. [77, pp.35-36]). Similarly the holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$ action on $M$ through the map $\psi_{h}$ :

$$
\lambda \longrightarrow h\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\lambda & 0 \\
0 & \lambda^{-1}
\end{array}\right) h^{-1} \xrightarrow{\pi_{j}} G_{j} \xrightarrow{\text { incl }} G
$$

also extends meromorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M-\rightarrow M$.
By Proposition 9.5 and Lemma 9.14, we conclude that each holomorphic $p$-form $\omega$ on $M$ is $G_{j}$-invariant via the action $\sigma_{M}^{G}$. This implies that $\omega$ is also invariant under $\sigma_{M}^{G}(g)$ for $g$ in an open neighborhood $V$ of the identity of $G$ ([45, p.115]) since the Lie algebras of $G_{j}$ span the Lie algebra $\mathfrak{g}$ of $G$ as indicated earlier in (9.16). Now that $\cup_{k=1}^{\infty} V^{k}=G$ since $G$ is connected (cf. [64, p.181]), it follows that $\omega$ is $G$-invariant. This amounts to the inclusion $H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right) \subset H_{0, \sigma_{M}^{G}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$. The converse is obvious. Hence $H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)=H_{0, \sigma_{M}^{G}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$ for semisimple $G$. Since it is well known that a connected complex reductive group is the product of a connected semisimple group and $\left(\mathbb{C}^{*}\right)^{k}$ for some $k \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$ (e.g. [50, p.168], [63, p.21]), the similar reasoning as above (by using Proposition 9.5) concludes the proof.

Remark 9.15. According to [76, Remarks II-C], a good compactification $\bar{G}$ exists for $G$ that is reductive. Suppose $G$ acts projectively (see [76, p.107] for this definition) on a compact Kähler manifold $M$ through $\sigma_{M}^{G}$. Then $\sigma_{M}^{G}$ extends meromorphically to $\bar{G} \times M$ by [76, Proposition I]. For other examples of the meromorphic extension, see Remark 9.6.

# 10. Complex manifolds with two holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-actions 

The goal of this section is to prove Theorem 1.7 stated in the Introduction. This result combined with those of Section 8 proves Corollary 1.8. The main assertion $H^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)=H_{0, \sigma_{M}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$ in Proposition 9.5 (where $\sigma_{M}$ admits meromorphic extension) becomes a special case of $H^{0}\left(B, \Omega_{B}^{p}\right) \cong H_{0, \sigma_{M}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$ in Theorem 1.7, which is to be discussed below. See also the paragraph prior to Corollary 1.8 in the Introduction, that refers to moduli spaces with two fibrations; the results of this section might have applications to these spaces.

Our strategy is to consider the globally free case first, i.e. a principal $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-bundle $P$ over a complex manifold $M$ (not necessarily compact). We turn to the locally free case later.

Some setup first. Denote the standard holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on $P$ by $\sigma_{s}$ and $M$ $=P / \sigma_{s}$. Let $\sigma_{d}$ be another globally free holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on $P$, which maps fibre to fibre of the fibration $\pi: P \rightarrow M$ (perhaps different fibres). Let $\sigma_{M}$ be the $\sigma_{d}$-induced holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on $M$, i.e. the commutative relation $\pi \circ \sigma_{d}(\lambda)$ $=\sigma_{M}(\lambda) \circ \pi$ holds for any $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$. Assume that $B:=P / \sigma_{d}$ is a complex manifold and the natural projection $\pi_{2}: P \rightarrow B$ realizes $P$ as a principal $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-bundle on $B$ (via $\sigma_{d}$ ).

A typical situation that motivates us is the one in Section 9 ; here $P=\mathbb{C}^{*} \times M$ as a trivial principal $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-bundle on $M$, the "diagonal" action $\sigma_{d}(\lambda)(\xi, p):=(\lambda \xi$, $\left.\sigma_{M}(\lambda) p\right)$ for a given holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma_{M}$ on $M$, and $\left.B=P / \sigma_{d}(=\{[(\xi, x)] \mid\right.$ $(\xi, x) \in P\})$. Define $\psi: B \rightarrow M$ by $\psi([(\xi, x)])=\sigma_{M}\left(\xi^{-1}\right) x$, and $\psi^{-1}(y)=[(1, y)]$ $\in B$ for $y \in M$, i.e. $\psi$ is a biholomorphism.

Fix a local trivialization $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times U$ for $P \rightarrow M$. We may write 1 for the local holomorphic section $(1, y)$ on $U \subset M$ if no confusion occurs. Write $(\zeta, y):=\left(\zeta \circ_{s} 1, y\right)$ in $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times U$ where $\zeta \circ_{s} 1=\sigma_{s}(\zeta) 1$ for short; similar notations " $\circ_{d}$ ", " $\circ_{M}$ " also apply below. For $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}, \sigma_{s}$ acts by $\sigma_{s}(\lambda)\left(\zeta \circ_{s} 1, y\right)=\left((\lambda \zeta) \circ_{s} 1, y\right)$ or $\lambda \circ_{s}(\zeta, y)=(\lambda \zeta, y)$.

Throughout this section we assume that $\sigma_{d}$ commutes with $\sigma_{s}$, i.e. $\sigma_{d}(\lambda) \circ \sigma_{s}(\zeta)=\sigma_{s}(\zeta) \circ \sigma_{d}(\lambda)$ or $\lambda \circ_{d}\left(\zeta \circ_{s} q\right)=\zeta \circ_{s}\left(\lambda \circ_{d} q\right)$ for $q \in P, \lambda, \zeta \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$. We say that $\sigma_{d}$ is degenerate if $\sigma_{d}(\lambda)\left(\zeta, y\right)=\left(\zeta, \lambda \circ_{M} y\right)$ for $\lambda$ close to 1 in some local chart. Otherwise $\sigma_{d}$ is said to be nondegenerate. This definition is easily seen to be intrinsic. If $\sigma_{d}$ is nondegenerate, we claim the existence of $0 \neq l \in \mathbb{Z}$, such that

$$
\lambda \circ_{d}(\zeta, y)=\left(\lambda^{l} \zeta, \lambda \circ_{M} y\right)
$$

Here we assume that $\lambda$ is close to 1 to ensure that the image of $\sigma_{d}(\lambda)$ is contained in the same trivialization. Write $\lambda \circ_{d}(\zeta, y)=\left(\Phi_{\lambda}(\zeta), \lambda \circ_{M} y\right)$. Then it is not hard to see

$$
\Phi_{\lambda_{1} \lambda_{2}}(\zeta)=\Phi_{\lambda_{1}}\left(\Phi_{\lambda_{2}}(\zeta)\right)\left(=\Phi_{\lambda_{2}}\left(\Phi_{\lambda_{1}}(\zeta)\right)\right), \Phi_{\lambda}\left(\zeta_{1} \zeta_{2}\right)=\zeta_{1} \Phi_{\lambda}\left(\zeta_{2}\right)
$$

Note that the second equality of (10.2) follows from the commutativity of $\sigma_{d}$ and $\sigma_{s}:$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\Phi_{\lambda}(\zeta), \lambda \circ_{M} y\right) & =\lambda \circ_{d}(\zeta, y)=\lambda \circ_{d}\left(\zeta \circ_{s}(1, y)\right) \\
& =\zeta \circ_{s}\left(\lambda \circ_{d}(1, y)\right)=\zeta \circ_{s}\left(\left(\Phi_{\lambda}(1), \lambda \circ_{M} y\right)\right. \\
& =\left(\zeta \Phi_{\lambda}(1), \lambda \circ_{M} y\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Letting $\zeta=1$ in the first equality of (10.2) gives

$$
\Phi_{\lambda_{1} \lambda_{2}}(1)=\Phi_{\lambda_{1}}\left(\Phi_{\lambda_{2}}(1)\right)=\Phi_{\lambda_{2}}(1) \Phi_{\lambda_{1}}(1)
$$

so the map $\lambda \rightarrow \Phi_{\lambda}(1)$ is a holomorphic character. It follows (see Remark 10.1 below) that $\Phi_{\lambda}(1)=\lambda^{l}$ for $0 \neq l \in \mathbb{Z}$ if $\sigma_{d}$ is nondegenerate.
Remark 10.1. In the reasoning above, $\lambda$ is originally close to 1 . Under different local trivializations 1 and $1^{a}$, for the same point $\zeta \circ_{s} 1$ and $\zeta^{a} \circ_{s} 1^{a}$ lying over $y \in M$, we have the same point $\Phi_{\lambda}(\zeta) \circ_{s} 1$ and $\Phi_{\lambda}^{a}\left(\zeta^{a}\right) \circ_{s} 1^{a}$ lying over $\lambda \circ_{M} y \in M$. Writing $1^{a}=\mu 1$ thus $\zeta=\zeta^{a} \mu$ and using $\Phi_{\lambda}^{a}\left(\zeta \mu^{-1}\right)=\mu^{-1} \Phi_{\lambda}^{a}(\zeta)(10.2)$ one sees that

$$
\Phi_{\lambda}(\zeta)=\Phi_{\lambda}^{a}(\zeta)
$$

From $\Phi_{\lambda}=\Phi_{\lambda}^{a}$ in (10.3) it follows that $\Phi_{\lambda}$ can be extended to every $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ even if $\lambda \circ_{M} y$ may leave the original trivialization. In sum (10.2) remains valid for all $\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2} \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$.

We will sometimes drop the subscripts " $s$ ", " $d$ " and " $M$ " in " $\circ_{s}$ ", " $\circ_{d}$ " and " $\circ_{M}$ " respectively if there is no danger of confusion in the context.

Suppose that $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M--->M$. As usual, $H^{0}\left(B, \Omega_{B}^{p}\right)$ denotes the space of holomorphic $p$-forms on $B$. Take $\omega_{B} \in H^{0}\left(B, \Omega_{B}^{p}\right)$. Consider the global holomorphic $p$-form $\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}$ on $P$ (where $\pi_{2}: P \rightarrow B$ ).

To proceed further, some preparations are in order. From the proof of Proposition 9.5, we can localize the reasoning and restrict ourselves to a local trivialization $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times U$ of $P \rightarrow M$. The form $\left.\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{*} \times U}$ can now be expanded at $\zeta=0 \in \mathbb{C P}^{1}$ as before; this is dependent only on the local trivialization $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times U$ hence on $\zeta$ and independent of local coordinates at $x \in M$. With the previous notation we write

$$
\left(\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}\right)\left(\zeta \circ_{s} 1, x\right)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \zeta^{k} \tilde{\omega}_{k}(1, x, d x, d \zeta)
$$

where $\tilde{\omega}_{k}$ is a holomorphic $p$-form in $\zeta$ and $x$, whose coefficients are independent of $\zeta$.
Remark 10.2. An intrinsic description for the regularity (10.4) is the following. Regarding the principal $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-bundle $P \rightarrow M$ as seated inside the associated holomorphic line bundle $L \rightarrow M$ (cf. (10.29) below). The above regularity (10.4) is the same as to say that $\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}$ is regular at the zero section of $L$.

Define the projection $\operatorname{Proj}_{x}$ by dropping the terms involving $d \zeta$ :

$$
\omega_{k}(1, x, d x):=\operatorname{Proj}_{x} \tilde{\omega}_{k}(1, x, d x, d \zeta), k=0,1, \cdots
$$

Note that in $\omega_{k}(1, x, d x)$ there is no dependence on $\zeta$ and $d \zeta$. As $\operatorname{Proj}_{x}$ is presumably coordinate-dependent (on $\zeta$ as aforementioned), we are going to examine the patching property of $\omega_{k}(1, x, d x)$ below.
Lemma 10.3. As given in (10.5), the p-form $\omega_{0}(1, x, d x)$ is globally defined on $M$, and for every $k \geq 1\left(\tilde{\omega}_{k}-\omega_{k}\right) / d \zeta$ induces a global $L^{-(k+1)}$-valued $(p-1)$-form $\mathfrak{f}_{k}$ on $M$, where $L$ is some holomorphic line bundle on $M$ (in fact it is the same $L$ as the one in Remark 10.2).
Proof. For later use, the following proof discusses more than what is needed in the lemma. Let $1^{\prime}$ be another local holomorphic section such that $\left(\zeta \circ_{s} 1, x\right)=\left(\zeta^{\prime} \circ_{s} 1^{\prime}, x\right)$. Write $1^{\prime}=c(x)^{-1} \circ_{s} 1$ for some local (nowhere vanishing) holomorphic function $c(x)$, so $\zeta^{\prime}=c(x) \zeta$. Write $\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}\left(\zeta \circ_{s} 1, x\right)=\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}\left(\zeta^{\prime} \circ_{s} 1^{\prime}, x\right)$, and thus

$$
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \zeta^{k} \tilde{\omega}_{k}(1, x, d x, d \zeta)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\left(\zeta^{\prime}\right)^{k} \tilde{\omega}_{k}^{\prime}\left(1^{\prime}, x, d x, d \zeta^{\prime}\right)
$$

Via (10.5) one rewrites $\tilde{\omega}_{k}$ :

$$
\tilde{\omega}_{k}(1, x, d x, d \zeta)=\omega_{k}(1, x, d x)+\eta_{k}(1, x, d x, d \zeta)
$$

where $\eta_{k}$ is of the form (with $J$ denoting the multi-indices $I_{p-1}$ )

$$
\eta_{k}(1, x, d x, d \zeta)=\sum_{J} f_{k, J}(x) d x^{J} \wedge d \zeta
$$

Similar notation with a "prime" applies to $\tilde{\omega}_{k}^{\prime}, \eta_{k}^{\prime}$.
Substituting $d \zeta^{\prime}=\zeta c_{j}(x) d x^{j}+c(x) d \zeta$ (by differentiating $\zeta^{\prime}=c(x) \zeta$ ) into $\eta_{k}^{\prime}$ we obtain

$$
\eta_{k}^{\prime}\left(1^{\prime}, x, d x, d \zeta^{\prime}\right)=\zeta \sum_{J, j} f_{k, J}^{\prime} c_{j}(x) d x^{J} \wedge d x^{j}+c(x) \sum_{J} f_{k, J}^{\prime} d x^{J} \wedge d \zeta
$$

and hence by (10.6) for the terms involving $\zeta^{k} d \zeta$

$$
\sum_{J} f_{k, J}(x) d x^{J} \wedge d \zeta=c(x)^{k+1} \sum_{J} f_{k, J}^{\prime}(x) d x^{J} \wedge d \zeta
$$

It follows from (10.10) that

$$
f_{k, J}^{\prime}(x) d x^{J}=c(x)^{-(k+1)} f_{k, J}(x) d x^{J}
$$

Let $L^{-(k+1)}$ be the holomorphic line bundle on $M$ associated to the transition function $c(x)^{k+1}$. By (10.11) the collection

$$
\mathfrak{f}_{k}(p):=\left\{\sum_{J} f_{k, J}(x) d x^{J}\right\}
$$

for $p \in M$ with coordinates $x=\left(x^{j}\right)$ is a global $L^{-(k+1)}$-valued $(p-1)$-form on $M$.
Similar to (10.10), by (10.6) for the terms involving $\zeta^{k}$ (but excluding $\zeta^{k} d \zeta$ ) one has (see also (10.9))

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \omega_{0}(1, x, d x)=\omega_{0}^{\prime}\left(1^{\prime}, x, d x\right) \\
& \omega_{k}(1, x, d x)=c(x)^{k} \omega_{k}^{\prime}\left(1^{\prime}, x, d x\right)+c(x)^{k-1} \sum_{J, j} f_{(k-1), J}^{\prime} c_{j}(x) d x^{J} \wedge d x^{j}, k \geq 1
\end{aligned}
$$

The first equality of (10.13) shows that $\omega_{0}(1, x, d x)$ is a globally-defined holomorphic $p$-form on $M$. The statement about $\left(\tilde{\omega}_{k}-\omega_{k}\right) / d \zeta$ is from (10.7), (10.8) and (10.11).

Recall that $H_{0}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$ denote the space of $\sigma_{M}$-invariant holomorphic $p$-forms on $M$ (cf. Section 8). The crucial result of this section is the following:
Proposition 10.4. Let $P$ be a principal $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-bundle over a complex manifold $M$, not necessarily compact. Assume that there exists a finite open covering $\left\{U^{a}\right\}_{a}$ of $M$ such that $P$ is holomorphically trivial over a neighborhood $V^{a}$ of the closure $\overline{U^{a}}$. Let $\sigma_{d}$ be a nondegenerate, i.e. $l \neq 0$ in (10.1), globally free holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on $P$ which maps fibre to fibre of the fibration $P \rightarrow M$ (perhaps different fibres), and induces a holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma_{M}$ on $M$. Suppose that $\sigma_{d}$ commutes with $\sigma_{s}$ (the standard holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action on $P$ ) and $\sigma_{M}$ extends meromorphically to $\mathbb{C P}^{1} \times M \rightarrow \rightarrow M$ (see Remark 9.6). Let $B:=P / \sigma_{d}$, possibly noncompact. Then the following map from (10.4) and (10.5) in local coordinates:

$$
\psi: \omega_{B} \in H^{0}\left(B, \Omega_{B}^{p}\right) \rightarrow \omega_{0}(1, x, d x) \in H_{0}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right), p=0,1,2, \cdots
$$

is globally well defined and gives a linear isomorphism.

Remark 10.5. If $\sigma_{d}$ is degenerate, the assertion of the proposition may fail. For the trivial product $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times M=: P$ with $\sigma_{d}(\lambda)(\xi, x)=\left(\xi, \sigma_{M}(\lambda) x\right)$ we have $\omega_{B}:=d \xi$ for $p=1$ projecting to zero under $\psi$. The argument in the following proof breaks down when $l$ in (10.25) equals 0 (i.e. $\sigma_{d}$ is degenerate), and in this case no vanishing of $\eta_{k}(k \geq 0)$ is guaranteed (see Lemma 10.7); the foregoing $d \xi \neq 0$ corresponds $\left.\eta_{k=0}\right)$.
Proof. (of Proposition 10.4) By Lemma 10.3 that $\psi\left(\omega_{B}\right)$ in (10.14) is a globally defined $p$-form on $M$, it remains to show that it is $\sigma_{M}$-invariant. Writing $\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}=$ $\sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*} \pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}$ on the LHS of (10.4) via $\pi_{2} \circ \sigma_{d}(\lambda)=\pi_{2}$ and applying (10.4) again, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \zeta^{k} \tilde{\omega}_{k}(1, x, d x, d \zeta)=\left(\sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*} \pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}\right)(\zeta, x) \\
= & \sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*}\left(\left(\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}\right)\left(\lambda^{l} \zeta, \lambda \circ x\right)\right) \\
\stackrel{(10.4)}{=} & \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\left(\lambda^{l} \zeta\right)^{k} \sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*}\left(\tilde{\omega}_{k}(1, \lambda \circ x, d(\lambda \circ x), d\left(\lambda^{l} \zeta\right))\right) \\
= & \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\left(\lambda^{l} \zeta\right)^{k}\left(\sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*} \tilde{\omega}_{k}\right)(1, x, d x, d \zeta)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from (10.15) that

$$
\left(\sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*} \tilde{\omega}_{k}\right)(1, x, d x, d \zeta)=\lambda^{-l k} \tilde{\omega}_{k}(1, x, d x, d \zeta)
$$

By (10.16), (10.7), (10.8), (10.1) and (10.5), it is not difficult to convince oneself that, with $\omega_{k}:=\operatorname{Proj}_{x} \tilde{\omega}_{k}$,

$$
\left(\sigma_{M}(\lambda)^{*} \omega_{k}\right)(1, x, d x)=\lambda^{-l k} \omega_{k}(1, x, d x)
$$

It is tempting to let $\lambda \rightarrow 0$ (resp. $\infty$ ) for $l>0$ (resp. $l<0$ ) in (10.17) and conclude that

$$
\omega_{k}(1, x, d x) \equiv 0 \quad(k \geq 1)
$$

since the LHS of (10.17) is finite, which follows from the assumption on the meromorphic extension of $\sigma_{M}$ and Hartogs' extension theorem.

However, for $k \geq 1$ (10.17) is meaningful only for $\lambda$ close to 1 since a priori $\omega_{k}(1, x, d x)$ is local (see the second equality of (10.13)) and $\sigma_{M}(\lambda)$ may carry away the local chart if $\lambda \nsim 1$. For $k=0$ (10.17) together with the first equality of (10.13) did show that $\omega_{0}(1, x, d x)$ is a global $\sigma_{M}$-invariant holomorphic $p$-form on $M$. So the map $\psi$ in (10.14) of this proposition is now well defined.

The claim (10.18) enters into the proof that $\psi$ in (10.14) is an isomorphism. To prove (10.18) rigorously, the idea is to extend the action $\sigma_{M}(\lambda)$ in (10.17) to all $\lambda$ $\in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ (then taking $\lambda \rightarrow 0$ as reasoning above).
Lemma 10.6. For every $k \geq 1, \omega_{k}(1, x, d x)$ in (10.13) represents a global $L^{-k_{-}}$ valued holomorphic p-form on $M$, where the holomorphic line bundle $L^{-k} \rightarrow M$ is as similar to (10.12) and admits a natural $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\tilde{\sigma}_{M,-k}$ compatible with $\sigma_{M}$.

Lemma 10.6 will be obtained from the following vanishing result:
Lemma 10.7. (Vanishing result (I)) In (10.13) one has $\sum_{J} f_{k, J}(x) d x^{J} \equiv 0, k \geq 0$. Thus $\eta_{k}$ in (10.8) vanishes identically.

Proof. (of Lemma 10.7) For a fixed $k \geq 0$ write $\varpi_{k}:=\sum_{J} f_{k, J}(x) d x^{J}$ (recalling that this local $|J|$-form is independent of local coordinates at $x$, cf. remarks prior to (10.4)) and denote by $L \rightarrow M$ the line bundle associated with $P \rightarrow M$ (so that $e^{\prime}=c(x)^{-1} e$ with the transition function $c(x)$ already specified, cf.(10.11)); see also (10.29) below. We claim that the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\sigma_{d}$ on $P$ induces a $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action, still denoted by $\sigma_{d}$, on $L$. The action $\sigma_{d}$ has been explicated in (10.1), from which the claim follows. More generally, for every $q \in \mathbb{Z}, L^{q} \rightarrow M$ has a natural $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, q}(\lambda):$

$$
\tilde{\sigma}_{M, q}(\lambda) \text { sending } e_{p}^{q} \in L_{p}^{q}(p \in M) \text { to }\left(\sigma_{d}(\lambda) e_{p}\right)^{q} \in L_{\lambda_{0_{M} p}}^{q}
$$

induced by $\sigma_{d}(\lambda): L \rightarrow L$ equivariant with respect to $\sigma_{M}(\lambda)$ (thus $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, 1}=\sigma_{d}$ on $L)$. Since $\sigma_{M}(\lambda)$ acts on the bundle of holomorphic $p$-forms on $M$ via pull-back, a moment's thought yields that $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, q}(\lambda)$ acts, still denoted by $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, q}(\lambda)$, on the space of global sections under consideration, namely global $L^{q}$-valued $(p-1)$-forms on $M$. Here, a typical situation occurs with the global section $\mathfrak{f}_{k}$ in (10.12) ( $L^{-(k+1)-}$ valued) for $q=-(k+1)$. We have now that $\tilde{\sigma}_{M, q}(\lambda) \mathfrak{f}_{k}$ makes perfect sense for every $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$.

Let us first derive a scaling property for $\varpi_{k}$ (on some open subset $U \subset M$ ), regarded as local expressions of the global object $\mathfrak{f}_{k}$. From (10.16), (10.17) and (10.7) we get

$$
\sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*} \eta_{k}=\lambda^{-l k} \eta_{k}
$$

for $\lambda$ near 1 . Writing out (10.20) via (10.1) and (10.8), one is in a position to compare the terms involving $d \zeta$. Then it is not difficult to find, via $\Phi_{\lambda}^{s}(d \zeta)=\lambda^{l} d \zeta$, that

$$
\left(\sigma_{M}(\lambda)^{*} \varpi_{k}\right)(x)=\lambda^{-l(k+1)} \varpi_{k}(x), \lambda \sim 1
$$

Considering $\tilde{\sigma}_{M,-(k+1)}(\lambda) \mathfrak{f}_{k}$ for $\lambda \sim 1$, one infers from (10.21) (with $\lambda$ replaced by $\lambda^{-1}$ since $\sigma_{M}(\lambda)$ acts as $\sigma_{M}\left(\lambda^{-1}\right)^{*}$ on forms) and (10.1) (see also (10.19) and remarks below (10.22)) that $\tilde{\sigma}_{M,-(k+1)}(\lambda) \mathfrak{f}_{k}=\mathfrak{f}_{k}(\lambda \sim 1)$; slightly more precisely the contribution from the form-part of $\mathfrak{f}_{k}$ acted on by $\tilde{\sigma}_{M,-(k+1)}(\lambda)$ yields a factor $\left(\lambda^{-1}\right)^{-l(k+1)}$ while the contribution from the same action on the $L^{-(k+1)}$-part of $\mathfrak{f}_{k}$ gives another factor $\left(\lambda^{l}\right)^{-(k+1)}$ that cancels out the preceding one. As mentioned above $\tilde{\sigma}_{M,-(k+1)}(\lambda) \mathfrak{f}_{k}$ is well defined for every $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$. The crucial property due to the analyticity in $\lambda$ then leads to the important conclusion:

$$
\tilde{\sigma}_{M,-(k+1)}(\lambda) \mathfrak{f}_{k}=\mathfrak{f}_{k} \text { not only for } \lambda \sim 1 \text { but also for all } \lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}
$$

Denote by $\mathfrak{f}_{k}^{a}=\varpi_{k}^{a} s^{a}$ where $s^{a}:=\left(e^{a}\right)^{-(k+1)}$ and $\left.\varpi_{k}^{a}=\mathfrak{f}_{k}\right|_{V^{a}}$ for local expression on open charts $V^{a} \subset M$. Fix $p \in U^{0} \subset M$ and write $\mathfrak{f}_{k}^{0}=\varpi_{k}^{0} s^{0}$ where $s^{0}=\left(e^{0}\right)^{-(k+1)}$ around $p=p^{0}$ (if $U^{0}=U$ then $\varpi_{k}^{0}$ is the above $\varpi_{k}$ ); similar notation applies on $U^{a}, \overline{U^{a}} \subset V^{a}$. Two basic properties are introduced as follows. If $\lambda \circ_{M} p=p^{(a)}$ $\in U^{a}$, with $\tilde{\sigma}_{M}\left(\lambda^{-1}\right) s^{a}\left(p^{(a)}\right)=: \tau\left(\lambda^{-1}\right) s^{0}(p)$ (the subscript $-(k+1)$ in $\tilde{\sigma}_{M,-(k+1)}$ dropped throughout) we obtain the first property:

$$
\left(\tilde{\sigma}_{M}\left(\lambda^{-1}\right) \mathfrak{f}_{k}\right)(p)=\left(\sigma_{M}(\lambda)^{*}\left(\varpi_{k}^{a}\left(p^{(a)}\right)\right)\right) \tau\left(\lambda^{-1}\right) s^{0}(p)
$$

For the second property suppose $\nu \circ(\lambda \circ p)=\tilde{p}^{(a)} \in U^{a}$, i.e. $p=\lambda^{-1} \circ\left(\nu^{-1} \circ \tilde{p}^{(a)}\right)$ with $\lambda \circ p \in U^{a}$ as above. One sees that

$$
\tau\left(\lambda^{-1} \nu^{-1}\right)=\nu^{l(k+1)} \tau\left(\lambda^{-1}\right)
$$

since $\nu^{-1} \circ s^{a}=\nu^{l(k+1)} s^{a}$ by (10.1) and (10.19). Here we need not restrict ourselves to $\nu \sim 1$ although the set $\left\{\nu \in \mathbb{C}^{*} \mid \nu \circ(\lambda \circ p) \in U^{a}\right\}$ may be far from being a connected set. As the reasoning is similar to Remark 10.1, we leave it to the reader.

The following arguments constitute a refined treatment of those in (10.16)(10.18). Choose $c \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ with $|c| \neq 1$. Suppose $|c|<1$ and $l>0$ (the remaining three cases will be similar). For the sequence $\left\{c^{i} \circ_{M} p\right\}_{i=1,2, \cdots}$ there exists some fixed open chart $U^{a}$ and a subsequence $\left\{c^{n(i)} \circ_{M} p\right\}_{i=1,2, \cdots}$ such that $\left\{c^{n(i)} \circ_{M} p\right\}_{i}$ $\subset U^{a}$ by the finiteness assumption on $\left\{U^{a}\right\}_{a}$ as stated in the proposition. Denote $c^{n(1)}$ by $c_{1}, c^{n(2)-n(1)}$ by $c_{2}$, etc. and set $p_{i}=c_{i} \circ c_{i-1} \circ \cdots \circ c_{1} \circ p\left(=c^{n(i)} \circ p\right)=$ $c_{i} \circ p_{i-1} \in U^{a}$ with $p_{0}:=p$. For instance, by $c_{1}^{-1} \circ c_{2}^{-1} \circ p_{2}=p$ with $p_{2} \in U^{a}$ and from $(10.22),(10.23)$

$$
\varpi_{k}^{0}(p) s^{0}(p)=\mathfrak{f}_{k}^{0}(p)=\left(\tilde{\sigma}_{M}\left(c_{1}^{-1} c_{2}^{-1}\right) \mathfrak{f}_{k}\right)(p)=\sigma_{M}\left(c_{2} c_{1}\right)^{*}\left(\varpi_{k}^{a}\left(p_{2}\right)\right) \tau\left(c_{1}^{-1} c_{2}^{-1}\right) s^{0}(p)
$$

This yields $\sigma_{M}\left(c_{2} c_{1}\right)^{*}\left(\varpi_{k}^{a}\left(p_{2}\right)\right)=\tau\left(c_{1}^{-1} c_{2}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \varpi_{k}^{0}(p)$ and in turn, using (10.24) for $\tau\left(c_{1}^{-1} c_{2}^{-1}\right)^{-1}, \sigma_{M}\left(c_{2} c_{1}\right)^{*}\left(\varpi_{k}^{a}\left(p_{2}\right)\right)=c^{(n(1)-n(2)) l(k+1)} \tau\left(c_{1}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \varpi_{k}^{0}(p)$.

Similarly, for $i \geq 2$ one has

$$
\sigma_{M}\left(\left(c_{i} c_{i-1} \cdots c_{2}\right) c_{1}\right)^{*}\left(\varpi_{k}^{a}\left(p_{i}\right)\right)=c^{(n(1)-n(i)) l(k+1)} \tau\left(c_{1}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \varpi_{k}^{0}(p)
$$

It is trivial that $\sigma_{M}\left(\left(c_{i} c_{i-1} \cdots c_{2}\right) c_{1}\right)^{*}\left(\varpi_{k}^{a}\left(p_{i}\right)\right)=\left(\sigma_{M}\left(\left(c_{i} c_{i-1} \cdots c_{2}\right) c_{1}\right)^{*} \varpi_{k}^{a}\right)(p)$. Thus
$(10.25)\left(\sigma_{M}\left(c^{n(i)-n(1)} c_{1}\right)^{*} \varpi_{k}^{a}\right)(p)=c^{(n(1)-n(i)) l(k+1)} \tau\left(c_{1}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \varpi_{k}^{0}(p)(i=2,3, \cdots)$.
As an illustration, suppose $p, c \circ p \in U^{0}$ for the simplest case (corresponding to taking $n(1)=0$ and $n(2)=1$ ). Then

$$
\left(\sigma_{M}(c)^{*} \varpi_{k}^{0}\right)(p)=c^{-l(k+1)} \varpi_{k}^{0}(p)
$$

reproducing (10.21) above.
Now a contradiction follows from (10.25) by letting $i \rightarrow \infty$ and using the similar argument indicated in (10.18) since $|c|<1$ and $l>0$ by assumption. For other cases one may consider $\left\{c^{-n(i)} \circ p\right\}_{i=1,2, \cdots}$; we omit the details. Hence $\varpi_{k} \equiv 0$ as asserted by the lemma.

Proof. (of Lemma 10.6) By Lemma 10.7 and (10.13), one has

$$
\omega_{k}^{\prime}\left(1^{\prime}, x, d x\right)=c(x)^{-k} \omega_{k}(1, x, d x) \quad k \geq 1
$$

proving the first assertion of the lemma. The $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-action $\tilde{\sigma}_{M,-k}$ on $L^{-k}$ has been indicated in the proof of Lemma 10.7 (see (10.19)).

Using the similar method as in the previous lemma one proves the analogous statement:

Lemma 10.8. (Vanishing result (II)) In (10.13), $\omega_{k}=\omega_{k}(1, x, d x) \equiv 0, k \geq 1$.
Proof. Recall that $\omega_{k}$ is a global $L^{-k}$-valued holomorphic $p$-form on $M$ by Lemma 10.6 (see (10.27)). By comparing $\omega_{k}$ in (10.27) with $\varpi_{k}$ in (10.11) and $\omega_{k}$ in (10.17) with $\varpi_{k}$ in (10.26) or (10.21), it is perhaps a tedious matter but not a difficult one to convince oneself that one can formally run the arguments similar to the vanishing of $\varpi_{k}$ in Lemma 10.7 (which shall not be repeated here), giving the desired vanishing of this lemma.

Proof of Proposition 10.4 continued: In (10.7) for $\tilde{\omega}_{k}(1, x, d x, d \zeta)$, we obtain $\tilde{\omega}_{k} \equiv 0(k \geq 1)$ from the vanishing results Lemmas 10.7 and 10.8 above. For $k=0$, $\tilde{\omega}_{0}(1, x, d x, d \zeta)=\omega_{0}(1, x, d x)$ since $\eta_{0}$ in (10.7) vanishes by Lemma 10.7. By these vanishings, we thus reduce (10.4) to

$$
\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}(\zeta \circ 1, x)=\omega_{0}(1, x, d x)
$$

That the linear map $\psi$ of (10.14) is well-defined has been shown in the first half of the proof. The injectivity of $\psi$ follows from (10.28) since the pull-back $\pi_{2}^{*}$ of the surjective map $\pi_{2}$ is injective. It remains to prove the surjectivity of $\psi$.

Given an element $\omega_{0} \in H_{0}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)$, let $\tilde{\omega}_{B}:=\pi_{1}^{*} \omega_{0}$ on $P$ where $\pi_{1}: P \rightarrow M$ is the natural projection, so that locally $\tilde{\omega}_{B}(\zeta \circ 1, x)=\omega_{0}(1, x, d x)$ on $P$. We claim $\sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*} \tilde{\omega}_{B}=\tilde{\omega}_{B}$. For, $\omega_{0}$ is $\sigma_{M}$-invariant by assumption and this yields the claim:

$$
\sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*} \tilde{\omega}_{B}=\sigma_{d}(\lambda)^{*} \pi_{1}^{*} \omega_{0}=\pi_{1}^{*} \sigma_{M}^{*}(\lambda) \omega_{0}=\pi_{1}^{*} \omega_{0}=\tilde{\omega}_{B}
$$

using $\pi_{1} \circ \sigma_{d}(\lambda)=\sigma_{M}(\lambda) \circ \pi_{1}$ by (10.1). So $\tilde{\omega}_{B}$ descends on $P / \sigma_{d}=B$ to an element $\omega_{B} \in H^{0}\left(B, \Omega_{B}^{p}\right)$ in the sense that $\pi_{2}^{*} \omega_{B}=\tilde{\omega}_{B}$. This, together with $\tilde{\omega}_{B}=$ $\omega_{0}(1, x, d x)$ as just mentioned, implies that $\omega_{0}$ lies in the image of $\psi$ in (10.14) (cf. (10.4), (10.5) and (10.28)). We have proved the surjectivity of $\psi$, and hence the isomorphism of $\psi$.

The following remarks will be used in the proof of Theorem 1.7.
Remark 10.9. In the notation of Proposition 10.4, associated with $P$ is the holomorphic line bundle $L_{M}$ (resp. $L_{B}$ ) over $M$ (resp. $B$ ) by

$$
L_{M}:=P \times_{\sigma_{s}} \mathbb{C}=P \times \mathbb{C} / \sim_{s}\left(\text { resp. } L_{B}:=P \times_{\sigma_{d}} \mathbb{C}=P \times \mathbb{C} / \sim_{d}\right)
$$

where $(u, \zeta) \sim_{s}\left(\sigma_{s}(\lambda) u, \lambda^{-1} \zeta\right)\left(\right.$ resp. $\left.(u, \zeta) \sim_{d}\left(\sigma_{d}(\lambda) u, \lambda^{-1} \zeta\right)\right)$ for $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$. By the map $u \rightarrow[(u, 1)]$ via $\sigma_{s}$ (resp. $\sigma_{d}$ ) we have an embedding $P \cong L_{M} \backslash\{0$-section $\}$ (resp. $L_{B} \backslash\{0$-section $\}$ ) into $L_{M}$ (resp. $L_{B}$ ). We have the following linear isomorphisms:

$$
H_{m, \sigma_{s}}^{q}\left(P, \mathcal{O}_{P}\right) \simeq H^{q}\left(M,\left(L_{M}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right), H_{m, \sigma_{d}}^{q}\left(P, \mathcal{O}_{P}\right) \simeq H^{q}\left(B,\left(L_{B}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)
$$

This fact is nothing but a restatement of Proposition 2.9 adapted to the present context. Let us just be brief. Let $\Omega_{m, \sigma_{s}}^{0, q}(P)$ (resp. $\Omega_{m, \sigma_{d}}^{0, q}(P)$ ) denote $\Omega_{m}^{0, q}(P)$ (see Definition 2.8) with respect to $\sigma_{s}$ (resp. $\sigma_{d}$ ). The map from $\eta \otimes\left(e^{*}\right)^{\otimes m} \in$ $\Omega^{0, q}\left(M,\left(L_{M}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\left(\right.$ resp. $\left.\Omega^{0, q}\left(B,\left(L_{B}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\right)$ to $\omega \in \Omega_{m, \sigma_{s}}^{0, q}(P)$ (resp. $\Omega_{m, \sigma_{d}}^{0, q}(P)$ ), defined by

$$
\omega(z, \zeta e)=\eta \otimes\left(e^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}(z, \zeta e)=\eta(z)\left(e^{*}(\zeta e)\right)^{m}=\eta(z) \zeta^{m}
$$

induces a linear isomorphism between $H_{m, \sigma_{s}}^{q}\left(P, \mathcal{O}_{P}\right)$ and $H^{q}\left(M,\left(L_{M}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)$ (resp. $\left.H_{m, \sigma_{d}}^{q}\left(P, \mathcal{O}_{P}\right) \text { and } H^{q}\left(B,\left(L_{B}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}\right)\right)$.
Remark 10.10. (Generalization to locally free case, used in Example 8.25 too) Suppose $\sigma_{s}, \sigma_{d}$ on $P$ are only locally free in the sense that they satisfy conditions as stated in Theorem 1.1 except possibly the compactness of the quotient. Then the isomorphisms in (10.30) with $L_{M}^{*}, L_{B}^{*}$ considered as orbifold line bundles, remain valid. For, one can use Proposition 3.11 via the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-equivariant line bundle $L_{\Sigma}^{*}$ (with $\Sigma=P$ here) and translate the $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-invariant condition there ( $L_{\Sigma}^{*}$-valued) into an appropriate setting (cf. $L_{\Sigma}^{*} / \sigma, \sigma=\sigma_{s}, \sigma_{d}$ ) associated with orbifolds $(\Sigma / \sigma=$

$M, B)$ as $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-quotients of $\Sigma=P$ here. For the tensor product $\left(L_{M}^{*}\right)^{\otimes m}$ of orbifold line bundles, see for instance [1, p.14]. Compare the introductory paragraph in the proof of Theorem 1.7 after Lemma 10.11 below.

We turn now to the locally free case. The following lemma is perhaps well known (at least for the topological setting with compact group action), but we are unable to find it (i.e. the complex analytic setting with complex group action) in the literature.

Lemma 10.11. In the notation of Theorem 1.7, for the projection $\pi_{1}: P \rightarrow M$ and small open subsets $V$ of $M, \pi_{1}^{-1}(V) \subset P$ is biholomorphically of the form $\left(\mathbb{C}^{*} \times \tilde{U}\right) / \Gamma$, where $\Gamma\left(\subset S^{1} \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}\right)$ is some finite group and $\tilde{U}$ is some open domain in $\mathbb{C}^{\operatorname{dim}} P-1$.

Remark 10.12. The arguments in the proof below may be simplified if one uses Remark 2.5.

Proof. (of Lemma 10.11) We follow the last paragraph in the proof of Theorem 2.3 (with its $\Sigma$ set to be $P$ here). Given $x \in \tilde{U}$ and $h \in \Gamma$, where $\tilde{U} \times(-\delta, \delta) \times$ $\mathbb{R}^{+}$is a sufficiently small cone-like open neighborhood of a given point $p=(z, 0,1)$ $\in P$ with the isotropy group $\Gamma_{p}=: \Gamma \subset S^{1} \subset \mathbb{C}^{*}$, let $\tau(h)(x)=s h x$ for some $s$ (depending on $x$ ) near $1 \in S^{1}$, and let $h$ act freely on $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times \tilde{U}$ by $\phi(h):(\xi, x) \rightarrow$ $\left(\xi h^{-1} s^{-1}, \tau(h)(x)\right)$ with $\tau$ as in (2.12). It can be verified that $\phi\left(h_{1} h_{2}\right)=\phi\left(h_{1}\right) \phi\left(h_{2}\right)$ mainly because $\tau$ satisfies the similar group-law property.

Form the quotient $\left(\mathbb{C}^{*} \times \tilde{U}\right) / \Gamma$ via $\phi$ and define a holomorphic map $\mu:\left(\mathbb{C}^{*} \times \tilde{U}\right) / \Gamma$ $\rightarrow P$ by $[(\xi, x)] \rightarrow \xi \circ_{\sigma_{1}} x=: \xi x$. It comes down to proving that $\mu$ is injective. This reduces to the assertion that for $p_{1}=\left(z_{1}, 0,1\right), p_{2}=\left(z_{2}, 0,1\right)$ in $\tilde{U} \times\{0\} \times\{1\}$ and $\xi \in \mathbb{C}^{*}$ such that $\xi p_{1}=p_{2}, \xi$ must be of the form $\xi=h s$ for some $h \in \Gamma$ and $s$ near 1 , i.e. $\tau(h)\left(p_{1}\right)=p_{2}$. This assertion follows from the facts that in this case $\xi \in S^{1}$ by using Lemma $7.6 i$ ) with (2.6), and in turn that $\xi$ is near the isotropy group $\Gamma$ since $\xi p \sim p$ follows from the condition $\xi p_{1}=p_{2}$ where $p_{1} \sim p, p_{2} \sim p(\tilde{U}$ small around $z=z(p))$.

Proof. (of Theorem 1.7) In the locally free case, from Lemma 10.11 (and Theorem 2.3) it follows that $P \rightarrow M=P / \sigma_{1}$ via $\pi_{1}$ is regarded as the total space of an orbifold principal $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-bundle on the complex orbifold $M$. (We omit the detailed check on the transition functions; see Remark 10.10 for some relevant background material.) Assume that $M$ is compact, or in case it is noncompact assume that it can be covered by finitely many open subsets $V$ as specified in Proposition 10.4; that is, $\pi^{-1}(V) \cong\left(\mathbb{C}^{*} \times \tilde{U}\right) / \Gamma$ can be considered as local trivializations in the sense of orbifold bundle. As usual the local sections in the orbifold sense correspond to the $\Gamma$-invariant local sections of $\mathbb{C}^{*} \times \tilde{U} \rightarrow \tilde{U}$. With the preceding assumption on $M$, take now $B=P / \sigma_{2}$. Here it does not concern us whether $B$ is compact or not. Then, after examination of the preceding proof for the globally free case, this additional condition imposed by the $\Gamma$-invariance does not obstruct the main lines of the argument there. We leave the details to the reader.

An alternative approach is to restrict oneself to the regular part $M_{\text {reg }}$ of $M$ where the action $\sigma_{1}$ on $\pi_{1}^{-1}\left(M_{\text {reg }}\right)$ is globally free (here the action $\sigma_{M}$ on $M$ induced by $\sigma_{2}$ also maps $M_{\text {reg }}$ to $M_{\text {reg }}$ using the commutativity of $\sigma_{1}$ and $\sigma_{2}$ ). Now that $M_{\text {reg }}$ is necessarily noncompact (as long as $M \neq M_{\text {reg }}$ ), a straightforward use

of Proposition 10.4 on $M_{\text {reg }}$ would require a finite-covering condition on $M_{\text {reg }}$ as assumed in the statement there. Imposing the assumption of this finiteness (e.g. $M_{\text {reg }}$ being quasi-projective with algebraic principal $\mathbb{C}^{*}$-bundle $\pi_{1}^{-1}\left(M_{\text {reg }}\right) \rightarrow M_{\text {reg }}$ ) and using the Hartogs extension on normal analytic spaces (see Theorem 2.3) for the normality of $M$ ) the holomorphic $p$-forms on $M_{\text {reg }}$ can holomorphically extend to $M$ (see Footnote ${ }^{2}$ in the Introduction for $p$-forms on orbifolds), leading to the desired isomorphism map (see the next paragraph). We omit the details.

In sum, as in (10.14) of Proposition 10.4 the map $\omega_{B} \rightarrow \omega_{0}$ still gives us a linear isomorphism:

$$
H^{0}\left(B, \Omega_{B}^{p}\right) \simeq H_{0, \sigma_{M}}^{0}\left(M, \Omega_{M}^{p}\right)
$$

We have proved (1.10) of Theorem 1.7.
We turn now to (1.11) of Theorem 1.7. Here we assume that $B$ is smooth, compact and Kähler. We have

$$
\sum_{p=0}^{\operatorname{dim} B}(-1)^{p} \operatorname{dim} H^{0}\left(B, \Omega_{B}^{p}\right)=\sum_{p=0}^{\operatorname{dim} B}(-1)^{p} \operatorname{dim} H^{p}\left(B, \mathcal{O}_{B}\right)
$$

since $H^{0}\left(B, \Omega_{B}^{p}\right) \cong H^{p}\left(B, \mathcal{O}_{B}\right)$ in the Kähler case. By Remarks 10.9 and 10.10 (with $m=0$ ) identifying $H^{*}\left(B, \mathcal{O}_{B}\right)$ and $H_{0, \sigma_{2}}^{*}\left(P, \mathcal{O}_{P}\right)$ so that $H_{0, \sigma_{2}}^{\operatorname{dim} P}\left(P, \mathcal{O}_{P}\right)=$ $H^{\operatorname{dim} P}\left(B, \mathcal{O}_{B}\right)$ which is 0 since $\operatorname{dim} P=1+\operatorname{dim} B$, we have:

$$
\sum_{p=0}^{\operatorname{dim} B}(-1)^{p} \operatorname{dim} H^{p}\left(B, \mathcal{O}_{B}\right)=\sum_{p=0}^{\operatorname{dim} P}(-1)^{p} \operatorname{dim} H_{0, \sigma_{2}}^{p}\left(P, \mathcal{O}_{P}\right)
$$

Now (1.11) of Theorem 1.7 follows from (10.31), (10.32) and (10.33).

Proof. (of Corollary 1.8) Theorem 1.6 proved in the preceding section and Theorem 1.7 just proved clearly yield this corollary provided that Remark 9.6 is used to take care of the meromorphic extension condition needed in Theorem 1.7.

abstract:
For a complex manifold $\Sigma $ with $\mathbb{C}^{\ast }$-action, we define
the $m$-th $\mathbb{C}^{\ast }$ Fourier-Dolbeault cohomology group and consider
the $m$-index on $\Sigma $. By applying the method of transversal heat kernel
asymptotics, we obtain a local index formula for the $m$-index. We can
reinterpret Kawasaki's Hirzebruch-Riemann-Roch formula for a compact complex
orbifold with an orbifold holomorphic line bundle by our integral formulas over
a (smooth) complex manifold and finitely many complex submanifolds arising from
singular strata. We generalize $\mathbb{C}^{\ast }$-action to complex reductive
Lie group $G$-action on a compact or noncompact complex manifold. Among others,
we study the nonextendability of open group action and the space of all
$G$-invariant holomorphic $p$-forms. Finally, in the case of two compatible
holomorphic $\mathbb{C}^{\ast }$-actions, a mirror-type isomorphism is found
between two linear spaces of holomorphic forms, and the Euler characteristic
associated with these spaces can be computed by our $\mathbb{C}^{\ast }$ local
index formula on the total space. In the perspective of the equivariant
algebraic cobordism theory $\Omega _{\ast }^{\mathbb{C}^{\ast }}(\Sigma ),$ a
speculative connection is remarked. Possible relevance to the recent
development in physics and number theory is briefly mentioned.
